LEAD: SINCE he came to power in 1964, President Kenneth D. Kaunda has been a resilient opponent of South African apartheid.


THE SUBURBAN REVOLUTION
LEAD: THIS winter we are reading and hearing more about New York's homeless, but with spring we will turn to other pursuits.
The problems of the poor and the near poor will remain, however, until we recognize that it is in our own best interest to find some means of providing suitable housing for those who cannot provide it for themselves.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD: HOPSCOTCH, by Julio Cortazar.
Translated by Gregory Rabassa. (Pantheon, $8.95.) ''Hopscotch,'' the best-known novel of the Argentine writer Julio Cortazar (1914-84), is the story of a middle-aged Argentine living an expatriate's life in Paris with his mistress. ''The dialogue is brilliant,'' Donald Keene said in The Book Review in 1966, and ''the rapid-fire invention of the language makes every page sparkle, thanks to the translation.


IN SULPTURE, STEEL EPICS AND POP ICONS IN TWO SHOWS
LEAD: For some time now, the big subjects of European and American art have been very different.
Contemporary German and Italian art offer the United States a sustained meditation on history and the complexity of European culture, and a longing for healing and transformation.
The United States offers Europe an intense, deeply obsessive involvement with popular culture, commodification and the communications industry.


NONFICTION: IN SHORT
LEAD: THE ELK HUNT.
By Alan E. Nourse. (Macmillan, $19.95.) Six years ago Alan E. Nourse, a physician turned writer, took a crash course in cardiology - he had a heart attack.
Viewing medicine through a patient's eyes, Dr.
Nourse is impressed and distressed.
Though armed with many new drugs, doctors cannot quite find a recipe to tame his angina, the pain from his weakened heart.

AMPLIFIERS TEST THEIR LISTENERS
LEAD: In audio and elsewhere, it is easier to test equipment than to test a proposition.
In the first case, you merely deal with gadgetry, but in the latter instance you have to tackle larger and more slippery entities, like truth and falsehood.

Artifacts And Sacred Sites
LEAD: As a resident of the Southwest and as a sometime-dealer in antiques and artifacts, I read Derek V. Goodwin's article on the illegal trafficking of Indian ceremonial material with considerable interest (''Raiders of the Sacred Sites,'' Dec. 7).
There is surely material to be written about looting and desecrating ceremonial property, but the subject cannot be conveniently wrapped up by peppering a scenario with villains and vigilantes.

High on that list of thankless, postponed tasks is a bit of computer maintenance.
I am not talking about changing the ribbon on my printer, nor am I referring to such basic upkeep as standardizing the labeling system for my floppies.

LEAN, LOW-CHOLESTEROL VENISON MORE COMMON IN THE MARKET
LEAD: OBTAINING venison no longer requires a hunting expedition.
It has become more widely available commercially, and many butchers given a few days' notice can supply it.
The meat is extremely lean and relatively low in cholesterol.

LEAD: Skiing  Swiss Sweep Downhill: Peter Mueller, taking risks on the tricky Nationale course, upset Pirmin Zurbriggen, the defending champion, and led a Swiss sweep of the medals at the world Alpine championships at Crans-Montana yesterday.

JAZZ: ROVA SAXOPHONES
LEAD: THE Rova Saxophone Quartet's favorite sound is a tangled, writhing, pulsating lump of noise - one that might involve repeated phrases, improvised lines, trills, raucous honks or a tightly packed combination of all four.
The group writes and plays chamber music laced with improvisation, cross-referencing Stravinsky, Satie, Albert Ayler, Steve Reich and James Brown's horn section.

Q and A
LEAD: Cruises to Mexico  Question:Are there any cruises from New Orleans that enable you to see the Mayan and Aztec sites in Mexico? - A. B., Fair Lawn, N.J.
Answer:To visit the Mayan sites, passengers need to take a cruise that calls at ports in the Yucatan.
The cruise lines arrange guided excursions from the ports to the Mayan ruins by bus and sometimes by plane.

AN UNEASY FEELING ABOUT A REACTOR
LEAD: A TRENCH with a concrete roof stretches 3,000 feet into the scrubland around the N-Reactor on the Hanford nuclear reservation in Richland, Wash.
In a major accident, water from the Columbia River would be pumped through the core and into the trench.
Small amounts of radioactive water are dumped there routinely.

LEAD: Infant and child mortality rates in Angola and Mozambique are now the highest in the world, largely because of the fighting and war-related economic destabilization in southern Africa, according to Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.


AIDING YOUR NEIGHBORS' ENEMIES
LEAD: IN one of the world's worst-kept official secrets, Pakistan has for years harbored military bases of the guerrilla insurgency in neighboring Afghanistan.
To Washington, Pakistan's role is part of an elemental conflict between ''freedom fighters'' and a Communist regime propped up by Moscow.


Fire Escapes
LEAD: To the Editor:  I live next door to the Bentley, featured in ''Escape Route as Design Element'' on Jan. 18, and my apartment looks directly out on that exterior fire escape.
One feature of its design not mentioned in your article is that it has exposed fluorescent lights on every floor that glare through neighboring windows.

LEAD: THE vibrancy of color that results from the intersection of threads of different hues is one of the most seductive characteristics of textiles.

LEAD: THE Reagan Administration is sharply divided over proposals to provide health insurance to the elderly for catastrophic illness.

Topics: Bird Colonels / Animal Abuse; Laboratory Pets
LEAD: Most laboratory animals are bred specifically for research.
Since their health and genetic history are known, such ''purpose-bred'' animals yield superior data.
Still, each year, some 300,000 dogs and cats are bought from animal shelters for laboratory use.
Why?
They cost less.
Congressman Robert Mrazek, Democrat of New York, has introduced legislation to prohibit the National Institutes of Health from funding experiments that use shelter animals.


LEAN, LOW-CHOLESTEROL VENISON MORE COMMON IN THE MARKET
LEAD: OBTAINING venison no longer requires a hunting expedition.
It has become more widely available commercially, and many butchers given a few days' notice can supply it.
The meat is extremely lean and relatively low in cholesterol.

LEAD: Under the best conditions, logging is a hazardous way to make a living.
But these days many Maine logging concerns are taking additional risks by not carrying workers' compensation insurance, which pays for medical care and provides workers a portion of their wages while they recover from injuries received on the job.

Equality
LEAD: To the Editor:  Attributing increased layoffs of black managers to this administration's policies (''The Ax Falls on Equal Opportunity,'' Jan. 4) completely misses the point.
These unfortunate setbacks are not the result of the current Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, but rather a case of the racial engineering of the past undoing itself.

Mr.
Jacobson will become Hope's 10th president in 121 years.

LEAD: To the Editor:  Charles A. Lemaistre creates a badly distorted picture in ''Nobody is Safe if a Smoker is Around'' (Forum, Jan. 4).
His assertion that ''involuntary smoking is a cause of disease, including lung cancer,'' is based on conclusions that are highly questionable in light of the evidence.


HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS TELL CITY PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENTS OF HITLER'S OPPRESSION
LEAD: The classroom of talkative teen-age girls fell silent when the woman, old enough to be their grandmother, told about the persecution she had lived through when she was a girl.


DULL 'ANNE FRANK' AT BECTON THEATER
LEAD: FOR two years, six Jews have been hiding from the Nazis in the garret of a factory.
Now the dreaded, ominous pounding is heard on the door downstairs.


Karl May and Wagner
LEAD: To the Editor:


REMOVAL OF SCHOOL BOARD MEMBERS IN DISTRICT SEEN
LEAD: The president of the city's Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., says there is ''a real possibility'' that the central board will suspend the members of an upper Manhattan school board because of allegations of corruption, poor reading scores and overcrowding of classrooms.


Cable TV
LEAD: When the Academy Awards for achievement in film in the year 1985 were announced, eight of the coveted statuettes went to ''Out of Africa.'' Among the awards for the film - to be seen on cable for the first time this week (Sunday at 9 A.M. and 8 P.M. on HBO, on Tuesday at 10 A.M. and 8 P.M. on Cinemax, on Thursday at noon and 11 P.M.


GETTING A NEW PERSPECTIVE ON STRANDED MOTORISTS
LEAD: HOW many times have you slowed down your car to stretch your neck for a look at a stranded driver and then continued about your business, shaking your head and muttering to yourself, ''Poor guy''?


2 Die in Marseilles Car Blast
LEAD: Two people were killed today when their car exploded in front of a school in a suburb here, sources said.
The police were said to be investigating whether a bomb had been planted in the car.
An incendiary device was reported found in another car parked nearby.


Chrysler to Drop Its 'Amerika' Ads
LEAD: Even before ABC's mini-series ''Amerika'' had begun production, powerful foes were trying to keep it off the air.
In 1985, the Kremlin warned ABC's Moscow bureau of possible reprisals if the show ran.


Rio de Janeiro
LEAD: For a long time, Rio de Janeiro has been popping up as the exotic backdrop of movies, wicked novels and midwinter fantasy.
But it remained largely in the background rather than figuring prominently in the routes of frequent travelers to the sun.
There was good reason.
Five thousand miles - from New York to Rio de Janeiro - is a long way to go for fine weather.


Tightening State's Grip on Housing
LEAD: AT first blush, those familiar with the workings of the state-run rent-control system during and after World War II may think they recognize a familiar beast taking shape in the Cuomo's administration's proposed reform of the rent-regulation systems.


CAN'T THE ISLAND JUST BE ITSELF?
LEAD: A LIFELONG resident of Long Island once said, ''A true New Yorker is someone who doesn't know where Long Island is and hasn't the vaguest idea how to get out there.''


INSURERS ARE PRESSING FOR AIDS TESTING
LEAD: Despite vigorous opposition from civil rights groups and some state governments, insurance companies, fearing an avalanche of AIDS-related claims, are increasingly asserting that they have a right to require applicants for coverage to take the AIDS virus test.


PIANO: CYPRIEN KATSARIS
LEAD: CYPRIEN KATSARIS'S evening of piano music at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday was fiercely difficult, but less for its physical demands than for its testings of the mind and heart.
The Schubert B-flat Sonata and the 12 Grieg Lyric Pieces that followed are exercises in simplicity, though of different kinds.


DEFENSE AIDE REJECTS CONCEPT OF A WORLD FREE OF ATOMIC ARMS
LEAD: A senior Pentagon official today called suggestions that the world could some day be free of nuclear weapons an absurd folly.
President Reagan has often said a nuclear-free world is his goal.


NONFICTION: IN SHORT
LEAD: THE FINANCING OF TERROR.
By James Adams. (Simon &amp; Schuster, $18.95.) With an estimated $5 billion in assets and an annual income of $500 million, the Palestine Liberation Organization's gold, stocks, money-market certificates and Swiss bank accounts are the envy of many major multinational corporations.


QUESTIONS RAISED ON RESOURCE RECOVERY
LEAD: In ''Is Resource Recovery the Way to Go?'' (Jan. 11), Steven Pollock of the Ocean County Planning Board argued that solid-waste incinerators were a relatively safe technology.
He asserted that the small amount of contamination that issues from them is insignificant when compared to the dangers of landfilling wastes.


The Real Sambo
LEAD: To the Editor:


BALLET: WORKS BY ROBBINS AND BALANCHINE
LEAD: THE theme was variations Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, when the New York City Ballet offered Jerome Robbins's ''Goldberg Variations'' and George Balanchine's ''Four Temperaments.'' Both of these intricate works are musical and choreographic examples of the theme-and-variations form.


CALIBER OF CAREER
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


LEAN, LOW-CHOLESTEROL VENISON MORE COMMON IN THE MARKET
LEAD: OBTAINING venison no longer requires a hunting expedition.
It has become more widely available commercially, and many butchers given a few days' notice can supply it.
The meat is extremely lean and relatively low in cholesterol.

LEAD: The engagement of Christina Kan to Robert C. Sullivan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Sullivan of Chappaqua, N.Y., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs.
Joseph R. Kan of Fairbanks, Alaska, parents of the bride-to-be.
An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: A VALENTINE'S concert on Feb. 8, Sweet Saturday Night on a Thursday, ''Tonight at 8:30'' at 8 P.M., bluegrass tunes at the symphony - it will be a funny fortnight in Connecticut, but it will all add up to a remarkable and delightful diversity.


BAD DRIVING IS A WAY OF LIFE ON STATE'S ROADS
LEAD: BY the time we left Iroquois country in upstate New York on our holiday trip, a strange sensation had begun, a distant recollection of another time and place.
As the Appalachian plateau of Ohio flattened out into the cornfields of Indiana, it became more than a perception; it was real, proving itself again and again.


Reagan's Political Aide Quits
LEAD: President Reagan's chief political adviser has resigned and will return to Indianapolis to become executive vice president of the Hudson Institute, the White House announced today.

LEAD: A special advisory panel has given the Board of Regents the names of five candidates to be the next State Education Commissioner, but the board is unhappy with the size of the list and will seek to expand it, according to several Regents.


India and Pakistan Open Talks on Border Tension
LEAD: India and Pakistan began high-level talks here today aimed at easing mutual tensions, but neither side appeared willing to halt large troop movements along the border that have spread alarm in both countries in the last two weeks.

LEAD: HUMPHREY BOGART ONCE OBSERVED that he would never trust a man wearing a yachting cap, a reaction that finds parallels even now among yachting's better-known iconoclasts.
They include Dennis Conner, the skipper of Stars &amp; Stripes, the United States hope in the America's Cup challenge.


Study in Japan
LEAD: In search of a clearer vision of America, Edmund G. Brown Jr. is checking out the view from Japan.
The former California Governor, now 48 years old, said in an interview last week that he came to Japan in August to study Zen meditation and complete a book that he attempted to start writing in Los Angeles.

LEAD: In the strongest hint so far that he might run for President, Governor Cuomo last week named a panel of corporate chairmen, investment bankers, labor leaders and professors to advise him on the economy.

FALL IN BLOOD SUPPLY IS REPORTED TO SHOW NO SIGN OF REVERSAL
LEAD: The shortage of blood that regularly develops during the Christmas holidays has persisted this year and shows no sign of easing, officials of the New York Blood Center said last week.


Two Communisms, One Crossroad
LEAD: It is a spectacle of rare proportions.
The 20th century's two greatest experiments in government are consumed by inward struggle.
Soviet and Chinese leaders have decided that their nations cannot move forward without moving, in some ways, toward the capitalist economies rejected by their revolutions and without embracing some elements of freedom.

LEAD: The United Steelworkers union ratified a contract with the USX Corporation, the nation's biggest steelmaker, that will further erode their wages, union officials said today.

POSTINGS: Writing a Law; No Rent Increases
LEAD: It is rare for ordinary citizens to create their own legislation, but that is what the 15 members of the Senior Action Committee in Ridgewood, Queens, have done.
They want the state's Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption law, known as SCRIE, to be extended to all nonregulated apartments, provided the landlord agrees to participate.


Identity Crisis
LEAD: Howard Teicher, a member of the National Security Council staff, attended a dinner at the Brookings Institution the other night and the people around the table were asked to state names and hometowns, such as ''Joe Doakes, New York.''


FUTURISTIC VISIONS IN THE DESERT
LEAD: In the sun-parched griddle of the Arizona desert, Interstate 17 glistens with sleek black puddles.
They vaporize as the car approaches.
Mirages.
Dancing off the rocks, the searing heat plays other tricks.
Amid the tumbleweed and cactus, a futuristic space colony materializes on the desert floor, a cluster of vaulting arches and cubic modules and filaments of construction cranes poking into the thin blue sky.

LEAD: Sean Couch scored a career-high 33 points tonight to lead Columbia past Harvard, 88-81, in an Ivy League game.

LEAD: Glen Rice scored a career-high 33 points and Michigan took advantage of 26 Iowa turnovers today for a 100-92 upset victory that knocked the Hawkeyes out of a tie for first place in the Big Ten.

Salinger, who is famous for loathing fame, has won a decisive round in a court fight to keep some of his private letters private.

Germans May Destroy Nuclear-Tainted Milk
LEAD: West Germany's Minister for the Environment suggested today that the Bonn Government was considering disposing of 3,000 tons of radioactive powdered milk as contaminated waste and compensating its owners.

LEAD: IT TAKES A HEAP OF livin' not to feel envious when you read about television newspeople making $1.2 million per year.
Fortunately, a heap is the precise amount of livin' I have now undergone.
As a result, I felt nothing but pity recently upon reading about the bloated paychecks of certain telenews guys and gals.


Why Warrants Are Back in Style
LEAD: THE allure of stock warrants - basically rights that allow investors to buy common shares for an extended time at a fixed price - tends to rise and fall with speculative fervor.
The game offers both big rewards and high risks.
Indeed, many holders of warrants have done quite well in the recent Wall Street surge.

BEWARE OF AGING GRAY-MARKET FILM
LEAD: LAST week I hiked through the snow and slush to my local West Side camera store, in search of some tungsten-balanced Ektachrome film.
The store had the film, I gulped at the price, and I asked for two rolls.
No big deal.


THE LIFE BELOW THE GROUND
LEAD: SUBWAY (Aperture, $29.95) by the photographer Bruce Davidson offers a vivid diary of the people who enter this dimmed, often hostile arena.
There are pictures of proud young mothers and children, weary businessmen, despairing bag people, menacing young men, and passionate couples embracing.
In most cases the sitters are fully aware of being photographed and yet the confines of the train prevents them from donning the mask one ordinarily sees in posed pictures.

TINY CAFE HINTS OF NANTUCKET
LEAD: KUDOS to the new Nantucket Cafe in New Canaan for its imaginative use of interior space.
In a room that holds just nine tables and seats 22 people, the ambiance of Nantucket has been artfully evoked.

LEAD: Some coaches rely on strategy and percentages in the waning seconds when a game is in the balance.

LEAD: Several cities around the world are vulnerable to volcanic eruptions but have failed to do all they can to reduce the dangers, volcano specialists have warned at a conference in Hilo.

MAKING THE TRANSITION IN NEWARK
LEAD: TO OUTSIDERS, the change seemed negligible when Sharpe James replaced Kenneth A. Gibson last July to become Newark's 35th Mayor.


New Rules for Emergency Care
LEAD: The service that operates New York City's emergency ambulance system said last week that all 43 hospitals in the system would soon be required to maintain fully trained physicians on emergency-room duty around the clock.
The announcement followed a series of deaths in recent years that have been blamed on mistakes by poorly supervised interns and residents.


PLANNERS ACT
LEAD: THE Tarrytown Planning Board agreed by a narrow margin last week to ask its Village Board of Trustees to revoke the permits that had allowed a local builder to make major changes in his historic-district property.

LEAD: Shopping is gaining in popularity this year as an apres-ski activity in southern Vermont, and if you know where to do it, you can help cover the cost of a skiing weekend.

A Historic Wing Chair Sells for $2.75 Million
LEAD: A 200-year-old Philadelphia wing chair - its frame riddled with nail holes, its carved front feet looking like hairy paws - became the most expensive piece of furniture ever sold at auction yesterday in a sale at Sotheby's.


STUDENTS' RIGHT TO WORK DEFENDED
LEAD: I agree when Naomi Given writes  [ Jan. 18 ]  that ''the undergraduate college  [ is ]  a very troubled institution,'' but I cannot understand how a professor has such a poor and wrong knowledge of too many college - or even high school - students' situations.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An item in last Sunday's Westchester Guide about Black History Month gave an incorrect location for events in Greenburgh.
The story-and-song program at 3 P.M. today will be at the Greenburgh Town Hall; all other events sponsored by the Greenburgh Library will be held at the library, 300 Tarrytown Road in Elmsford.


BEAVER DAMAGE BRINGS COMPLAINTS
LEAD: NEAR Route 11 in Salem, beavers have built a dam, 40 feet long and 4 feet high, out of mud and branches.
Motorists often stop to admire the dam, which has made a thin, shallow brook into a wide, deep pond.


Deception Charged on Choosing Sex of Babies
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration has called a company's contentions that its Gender Choice kit can help couples choose the sex of babies a ''gross deception of the consumer.''

CBS News In Search of Itself
LEAD: In this era of changing telecast journalism, for CBS to look backward to find itself is hardly a testament to the vision of its president, Laurence A. Tisch, or, for that matter, Dan Rather and company (''CBS News in Search of Itself,'' by Peter J. Boyer, Dec. 28).


LEGISLATURES WEIGH MATCHING U.S. TAX CODE
LEAD: Efforts by the states to alter their income tax laws in response to changes in the Federal law enacted last year have led to some major political conflicts in state capitals and raised questions about the future of their taxing policies.


IDAHO PLATES: A POTATO BIAS?
LEAD: The ''Famous Potatoes'' slogan on Idaho automobile license plates seems to have been around as long as the Sawtooth Mountains or Sun Valley, but one Boisean, Andrew Freese, says it discriminates against other Idaho products, and he is suing the state to have it removed.


Relics of an Age of Crime Enjoy New Life As Art Objects
LEAD: THIS COLLECTION OF PHOTOgraphs, from crime magazines and newspapers of the late 1920's and early 30's, will be exhibited, beginning Tuesday, at Manhattan's Pace/MacGill Gallery.
The faces of crime were -and remain - grist for tabloid journalism, and they are shown here with the retouching marks and directions of the original editors, who often enhanced their pictures' visual impact.

LEAD: This Week:


Extraordinary, Holmes!
LEAD: To the Editor:


New Strength for Steel?
LEAD: After spending 1986 in the doghouse, steel stocks have recently given their holders some reason for cheer.
Measured by Standard &amp; Poor's industry index, these stalwarts of the industrial economy have risen by about 11 percent so far in 1987.


OLD GAS STATIONS: NUISANCES OR SITES OF HISTORIC IMPORT?
LEAD: DESPITE growing community opposition, the State Department of Transportation is continuing with its plans to demolish most of the 12 abandoned gas stations along two area parkways, a department official said last week.


A LA CARTE
LEAD: WHEN Summerfield's Cafe (442 Central Avenue, Cedarhurst) opened a few years ago, it was one of the first on Long Island to offer mesquite-grilled food.
The restaurant combined expertly grilled entrees, imaginative appetizers and home-baked desserts, resulting in a two-star rating in this column (May 5, 1985).


In Cars or TV's, Protection Never Works
LEAD: LAST week, Japan announced that it would extend the Voluntary Restraint Agreement limiting Japanese car exports to the United States to 2.3 million units.
However, with the backing of the Big Three car makers and the United Auto Workers, the Democratic-controlled Congress is under strong pressure to legislate even tighter curbs.


GIANTS FETE IS CALLED A SUCCESS
LEAD: WHILE thousands of football fans celebrated at Giants Stadium here last Tuesday, a group of NJ Transit and Bergen County police officials huddled in a mobile command post in Hasbrouck Heights, watching traffic movements as well as the homecoming ceremonies.


HEALTH CODE VIOLTIONS CITED
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 28 food establishments cited for violating the health code.


POSTINGS: In Bernardsville; Mansion for Sale
LEAD: For now, Harold Hamilton and Loretta Praher, husband-and-wife developers, are luxuriating in the 25-room country mansion in Bernardsville, N.J., that was formerly owned by R. Thornton Wilson.
Overseeing the house's restoration, the couple, principals of CHP Developers, can stoke one of 12 fireplaces - three of which are in the master bedroom suite - and watch the deer that grace the property.


Dance
LEAD: There is nothing quite like the annual benefits held for Performance Space 122, that home for the experimental arts on the Lower East Side.
To start, there are the benefits' zany titles.
This time it's ''Pipedreams,'' since funds raised from the three-day marathon of benefit performances will be used for such improvements as better backstage plumbing.

LEAD: To the Editor:  As the Buildings Department examiner on the crane-installation project at 650 Madison Avenue, I was pleasantly surprised to notice the familiar sight on the front page on Dec. 7 under the headline ''A Skyline Stage for New York Cranes.'' Your article on cranes was interesting, informative and largely correct.

SEAT BELTS BECOMING THE THING TO WEAR IN TEXAS
LEAD: When the Texas Legislature passed a law requiring drivers and front-seat passengers in automobiles to buckle up with seat belts, people hereabouts had a good laugh.
That, they said, would work about as well as the one setting the speed limit at 55 miles an hour.


11 NORTH KOREAN BOAT PEOPLE PUT JAPAN IN MIDDLE OF SQUABBLE
LEAD: Eleven North Koreans aboard a ship that developed engine trouble and drifted into Japanese waters more than a week ago have created an unusual diplomatic triangle that resists a swift solution.


FICTION: IN SHORT
LEAD: GHOSTLY POPULATIONS.
By Jack Matthews. (Johns Hopkins University, $14.95.) Children tell two kinds of tales: ghost stories and jokes.
As they get older the jokes get dirtier and the ghosts are forgotten.
But Jack Matthews gives the impression ''of a man listening to his childhood.'' Like the narrator of his title story, he is a collector of ghost stories, and his characters mutter old riddles as though they're mantras - ''What has four wheels, hemorrhoids, and a dream?


CONFINED BY ONE'S OWN TUNNEL VISION
LEAD: WE all change.
I don't run as fast any more, my midsection is sprouting a small spare tire and I am starting a family - all as things should be, I suppose.
But there are some changes I have become very conscious of recently.
As I am about to enter a brand new stage of life as a family provider I have found that my reading has become more and more focused toward financial materials, to the exclusion of most other types of literature.

LEAD: ITS facade bears credos vowing enlightenment through education.

FRESH START FOR HASKINS AND MINNESOTA
LEAD: AS college basketball coaches frequently do, Clem Haskins changed his place of employment last spring.
But it isn't as routine as it sounds.
Haskins moved from top 20-bound Western Kentucky, where he was a pioneer and a local hero, to scandal-ridden Minnesota and the unfamiliar chill of a program in crisis.

LEAD: One Flyer flipped an opposing player on his back.
Another Flyer sent a player sprawling with one punch.
This was only the between-periods highlight film at the Spectrum, and the strategy worked perfectly.
On tape, the Flyers towered over everyone.


DESCARTES, NIETZSCHE AND THE SEARCH FOR THE UNSAYABLE
LEAD: FEW lines have more effectively caught the chill of modernity than the conclusion of Wallace Stevens' poem ''The Snow Man:'' ''For the listener, who listens in the snow, / And, nothing himself, beholds / Nothing that is not there and the nothing that is.'' Plagued by the suspicion that we are nothing and haunted by the dread that nothing remains nothing, many regard our epoch as a post age.

LEAD: SITTING in his four-room New York City apartment, in the dining room that has long served as his office, Robert Ferguson does not look like a man with the power to create stock market gyrations like the 100-point swing in the Dow Jones industrial average one day late last month.
Yet some think he has such power.

But the cheese can not be rushed.

Mr.
Plunkett has been charged with five counts of damage to government property and one count of violation of Federal law, said Betty Goodson, a spokesman at Fort Rucker.

7-Year Warranty at Chrysler
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would extend its warranty on the power train of all its domestically made cars and trucks from five years and 50,000 miles to seven years and 70,000 miles.
The action by Chrysler, which had been expected, gives the company the longest warranty of any domestic manufacturer.

You cannot lower the trade deficit unless you address the automotive component.

The Dow hit a record of 2,163.39 before settling back to end the week at 2,158.04, a gain of 56.52.

A Daughter's Father
LEAD: I WAS APPLYING FOR A PASSPORT FOR MY 18-month-old daughter when I froze at the marital-status question.
Give the kid a chance, I thought, she's still in diapers.
But the question haunted me for days.
I recognized the feeling, which first appeared soon after Annie was born.
But it wasn't until that day at the Passport Office that I began to focus on just how radically my outlook has changed simply because my child is a female.

Walters Is Uneasy About U.S. Cutbacks at U.N.
LEAD: The chief United States delegate to the United Nations says he is uncomfortable that Washington is not paying its full financial contribution despite measures adopted by the General Assembly to improve budget procedures.


Shoes, Over and Under
LEAD: For two weeks now, a gray sky has hung low over New York City, spitting.
Mostly it spits snow, sometimes it spits rain and occasionally it spits something that it would be a kindness to call sleet.
The sun shows its face only long enough to prove it's still up there.
So slush is piled at the curbings, and trying to walk some streets is like trying to traverse the Wollman Rink without skates.


A CORRECTION
LEAD: An article in the Real Estate section Jan. 18 on the effect of the porters' union contract on commercial rents incorrectly stated the frequency of the rent increases and which aspects of the wage increases would have an effect on rents.
The increases are calculated annually, not monthly.
The base salary for a porter in Class A commercial buildings is $10.237 and the new contract calls for salary increases of 52.5 cents in the first year, 52.5 cents in the second year, and 50 cents in the third year.


Drug Tests for Suspected Felons
LEAD: A spokesman for the Civil Liberties Union called it ''a terrible idea'' and the director of the Legal Aid Society's criminal defense division didn't like it either.
But city officials are going ahead with a plan to ask suspects arrested on felony charges to undergo drug tests voluntarily.

NEW CLUES TO THE IMMUNE SYSTEM
LEAD: FOR TWO HOURS, THE MALIGNANT white blood cells are held in a plastic bag.
A tube channels the cells, which have been bathed in a drug, directly into an ultraviolet radiation field.
The rays of light penetrate the diseased blood, activating the drug, which attacks and maims the cells.

20TH-CENTURY GALLEY SLAVE
LEAD: IN the America's Cup, the men on the 12-Meters do essentially what men on sailboats have done for centuries.
At the wheel, the skipper peers through the salt spray on his bronzed face.
Nearby, his tactician and his navigator observe the wind.
Other members of the crew handle the sails.
And on the deck are the grinders, 20th-century galley slaves who toil together to turn the winches that move the heavy sails.

LEAD: For the most impertinent bid of this decade, or indeed any other, South's action on the diagramed deal must be a strong candidate.
Before considering the auction, however, study this question: is there any way to defeat five diamonds?


PERELMAN-WEST PLAY IN NEW TROVE AT BROWN
LEAD: As best friends, brothers-in-law and mutual admirers, S. J. Perelman and Nathanael West frequently talked about collaborating on a project.
So far as is known, only once did they share authorship over a sustained period.
The result was a play called ''Even Stephen,'' a satire on book publishing and mating habits in academia.


PRISONS OVERCROWDED, FLORIDA MAY HAVE TO BEGIN FREEING CONVICTS
LEAD: Florida will probably have to start letting convicts out of their cells unless something is done quickly to relieve overcrowding in the state prison system.


COLUMBIA U. FUND HONORS A VICTIM OF AIDS
LEAD: A drive to create a Columbia College scholarship in honor of Stuart Garcia, a leading member of the class of 1984 who died of AIDS last year, has won the endorsement of the Columbia University Senate.


Couple Are Murdered At Home in Brooklyn
LEAD: A husband and his wife were found shot to death with their hands taped behind their backs in their apartment in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn last night, the police said.


MET OPERA: TANNHAUSER'S NEW CAST
LEAD: THE principal roles in ''Tannhauser'' changed hands Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera.
William Johns took the title role and proved himself capable of getting through what may be Wagner's most arduous tenor part with plenty of voice left for the end.
Indeed if he had sung the whole role as well as he did the broken-spirited ''Rome Narrative'' in the last act, one would look forward to hearing him again.

LEAD: Tom Skiffington, who sent out Akabir to an upset victory in the Bougainvillea Handicap here Saturday, came back 24 hours later to saddle Anka Germania and Chaldea to a 1-2 finish in the First Division of the Columbiana Handicap today at Hialeah Park.


Gates-G.E. Battery Deal
LEAD: The Gates Corporation said Friday that it had completed the acquisition of the General Electric Company's battery business.
Terms were not disclosed.
Gates said the purchase includes G.E. plants in Gainesville, Fla.; Juarez, Mexico, and Newcastle, England.
The agreement calls for G.E. to continue marketing rechargeable batteries for the consumer market under its name.

LEAD: ''I THINK the Fed is coming under immense pressure from the banks, and for some reason it's caving in,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer.


Purchasers Say Growth in January Was Strong
LEAD: The economy's rate of growth increased sharply in January, according to a monthly report of the nation's purchasing managers.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Skiing Girardelli Takes Combined: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg overcame a shoulder injury yesterday to upset Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland and win the men's combined title at the Alpine world championships at Crans-Montana, Switzerland.
Earlier, Maria Walliser gave Switzerland its third gold medal by winning the women's downhill, beating a teammate, Michela Figini.


Wait for the Ravitch Commission
LEAD: Peter Vallone, the New York City Council majority leader, wants to strip the Board of Estimate of its budget-making authority.
That could be done by the State Legislature, but if it isn't, the Queens Democrat hints he will seek a citywide referendum in November.

LEAD: How should Americans view Howard Beach and Forsyth County, two recent reminders that racism remains alive in the land?
The Rev.
Jesse Jackson thinks these incidents must be seen in the larger context of class, not just racial conflict.

Taft Weighing Sale of Division
LEAD: The Taft Broadcasting Company said Friday that it was considering the sale of all or part of its entertainment group in a move that reflects its growing emphasis on television network affiliate, radio and cable broadcasting.


WORKERS CALLED BACK TO USX STEEL PLANTS AS STOPPAGE ENDS
LEAD: Union members will begin returning to work at USX Corporation steel mills, some as early as Monday, as the steelmaker begins the complicated process of resuming production after a six-month work stoppage.


Bomb in Kabul Kills 4 Near Indian Embassy
LEAD: A car bomb exploded today near the Indian Embassy in Afghanistan, killing four people, the Kabul radio said.
The embassy, which was damaged, is near Afghanistan's Interior Ministry and several other Government buildings.


STAGE: 'DEATH OF EAGLES'
LEAD: THE program for ''Death of Eagles,'' now at the Neighborhood Group Theater, 420 West 42d Street, contains the following caution from the director: ''In viewing this play, one must not try to apply the rules of logic.
The play is a dream . . . a black comedy that circles around and around, creating an absurd parody of America's proud military.


Saving Dragonflies In Belvedere Lake
LEAD: CENTRAL Park has many users.
When its curators drew plans to rebuild the Great Lawn and Belvedere Lake, they accounted for a symphony orchestra, an opera company and dozens of softball teams.
Now they have to deal with a diminutive, four-winged constituency that they had not imagined a week ago.
On Tuesday, an amateur entomologist, Charles Matson, disclosed that the lake was home to a variety of dragonflies and damselflies - insects of prehistoric appearance, rainbow irridescence and almost unearthly beauty.


Ballets of Pennsylvania And Milwaukee to Join
LEAD: The Pennsylvania Ballet and the Milwaukee Ballet have agreed to merge into one company that would perform in both places, with its first production scheduled for this fall, officials have announced.
The merger is subject to approval by the boards of director of both organizations.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD: PHOTO ALBUM The Whitney Museum of American Art at Equitable Center is made up of two handsomely grand galleries on the ground floor of the high-rise with the outsize lobby at 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street (554-1113).
The exhibitions at this Whitney, as at other Whitneys, central and branch, are meticulously and tastefully mounted and usually have a theme.

LEAD: Administrative charges of navigational mistakes that may have contributed to the sinking of a fishing tug on Lake Michigan last summer have been filed by the Coast Guard against the captain of a Yugoslav freighter and her American pilot.

SUCCEEDED HUSBAND IN CONGRESS
LEAD: Representative Sala Burton, a California Democrat who succeeded her late husband in Congress in 1983 and carried on his liberal policies, died today of complications arising from cancer.
She was 61.


Visitors Start Paying To See Miss Liberty
LEAD: Visitors to the Statue of Liberty will have to pay $1 beginning today to see the monument.
The fee, the first charged in the statue's 100-year history, was authorized by Congress as part of a test program.


Koch Returns From European Trip
LEAD: Mayor Koch at Kennedy International Airport after returning from a nine-day vacation in Poland and Hungary.
His trip included a visit with Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, and visits to two Nazi death camps.
Mr.
Koch called Poland an ''extraordinary'' country, populated by people of uncommon courage and said that he was persuaded that economic sanctions against Poland should be lifted.


C.I.A. Is Said to Oust Its Chief in Costa Rica
LEAD: The Central Intelligence Agency is forcing its station chief in Costa Rica to take early retirement, intelligence sources said today.


RUSSIAN BACK FROM BEDLAM STILL HEARS SHRIEKS AT NIGHT
LEAD: A week after his release from the Second Moscow Provincial Psychiatric Clinic, Serafim Yevsyukov's muscles still ache so badly he cannot put on his overcoat without help.
His fingers tremble slightly, he has lost 25 pounds and he walks with evident discomfort.


MEEK RISE TO BECOME CITY TERROR
LEAD: In certain parts of this, the nation's fifth largest city, the problem is not urban blight or urban angst.
It is urban deer.
Whole herds of white-tailed does, fawns and antlered bucks that seem to have bounded right out of ''Bambi.''

Giant Facts
LEAD: A victory in Pasadena, Calif., by a New York team based in New Jersey is doing wonders for a Boston publisher.
It is spurring sales of ''Giants Trivia,'' a book whose more than 600 questions about obvious events and obscure facts spanning more than six decades of team history can separate the casual fan from the true fanatic - even, it turns out, among the team's official historians.

As a result, Mendelssohn's A minor Quartet, Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's String Quartet 1974 and the Debussy G minor alternately thrived and stumbled under this unremitting heat.

LEAD: Teams of city building inspectors, police officers and even volunteer citizens patrolled the streets yesterday to insure that no demolition or construction occurred in single-room-occupancy hotels over the weekend when city protection of the hotels lapsed.


Japanese Investments
LEAD: Japanese investors bought a record amount of foreign shares last month while stepping up purchases of foreign bonds, the Finance Ministry said Friday.
Net foreign stock purchases rose to a record $1.55 billion in December from $686 million in November.
The previous record was $844 million last July.


Europe Backs U.S. Trade Pact
LEAD: The 12 member governments of the European Community gave final approval Friday to a four-year agreement assuring American grain exports to Spain, officials said.

Luiz Bonfa, Guitarist, Returns to New York
LEAD: The Brazilian guitarist Luiz Bonfa slipped into town for his first New York shows in nearly a decade, a four-night engagement through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's.
Mr.
Bonfa, who composed the score for ''Black Orpheus'' with Antonio Carlos Jobim, is a subtle, masterly guitarist.
His first set Thursday was a collection of exquisite miniatures as he carried lightly syncopated melody, harmony and rhythm on the six nylon strings of his classical guitar.

A-PLANT QUAKE SURVIVAL QUESTIONED
LEAD: The ability of many nuclear reactors now in operation to withstand earthquakes is unknown, because the builders analyzed the plants on the basis of their design instead of on how they were actually built, a design consulting company has complained to Federal regulators.


BUILDING OUTLAYS DROP
LEAD: Construction spending dipped five-tenths of 1 percent in December, the second consecutive monthly decline, as widespread weakness in private construction offset a sizable gain in governmental spending, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: Prime Minister Walter Lini of the South Pacific island nation of Vanuatu was admitted today to the George Washington University Hospital with what doctors suspected was a cerebral hemorrhage, American officials said, adding that he was reported to be in stable condition and was expected to remain in the hospital for at least several days.

LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, who has begun a trip to Saudi Arabia, will pledge that the United States will be ''strictly neutral'' in the Iran-Iraq war and will not try to exchange arms for hostages, according to officials traveling with him.


'SPEAKER FROM TEXAS,' ON JIM WRIGHT
LEAD: WHO is Jim Wright, the new Speaker of the House of Representatives?
He's an affable, highly ambitious Texan, that's who. ''The Speaker From Texas'' traces his career, although it is as much about politics and politicking as it is about the man.
The one-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, is still a reasonably candid look at one of the most important people in the country.

U.S. PROPOSING OIL LEASING IN DISPUTED OFFSHORE AREAS
LEAD: Contending that ''the global energy picture continues to worsen for the United States,'' Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel today announced a plan to offer oil leases for as many as 6.5 million acres off the California coast.


Ford to Expand Use of Air Bags
LEAD: By 1990, the Ford Motor Company plans to equip 500,000 to one million of its passenger cars with driver-side air bags and reduce the cost of the safety devices to about $300, company officials said.
Under the plan outlined by Ford's president, Donald E. Petersen, Ford will be the first domestic producer making air bags widely available.


Boston Trust 11 Begins A $990 Million Offering
LEAD: First Boston Mortgage Securities Trust 11 yesterday began offering $990 million of collateralized mortgage obligations equally divided between fixed- and floating-rate issues.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD: FANNING OUT


JAPAN WAGES UP 3.1%
LEAD: The average monthly wage of a Japanese worker rose 3.1 percent in 1986, the Labor Ministry reported today.
The increase, adjusted for inflation, was the highest in 13 years.

'HELGA' SHOW RENEWS DEBATE ON ANDREW WYETH
LEAD: The scheduled show of Andrew Wyeth's ''Helga'' drawings and paintings at the National Gallery of Art in Washington has stirred a more intense debate among art professionals than any other museum show in recent memory.


No Progress Seen In Airbus Talks
LEAD: Talks between American and European officials over subsidies for Airbus Industrie, the European airliner manufacturing consortium, made no progress today in what threatens to become a major trade dispute, the officials said.
At the same time, Airbus announced in Paris that it had its best January ever, receiving orders worth $5 billion.


Ginnie Mae Trading Shift
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today to oversee the MBS Clearing Corporation, which will be the sole book-entry depositary for the $250 million market of mortgage-backed securities guaranteed by the Government National Mortgage Association.


HIS DEPUTY NAMED TO TAKE HIS PLACE
LEAD: President Reagan today accepted the resignation of William J. Casey as Director of Central Intelligence and nominated the agency's deputy director, Robert M. Gates, a career officer, to succeed him.


People
LEAD: *
William Yamada is joining Wells, Rich, Greene's Image Group as its third executive vice president and creative director.

NIXON WILL FIGHT RELEASE OF PAPERS
LEAD: Former President Richard M. Nixon will challenge the legality of publishing many and possibly all of the 1.5 million Watergate documents the National Archives has prepared for release in May, his lawyer said today.

REAGAN WOULD TURN OVER 'EXCERPTS' FROM NOTES
LEAD: The White House announced today that it would turn over ''relevant excerpts'' from President Reagan's personal notes if they are requested by Congressional panels investigating the Administration's secret arms deals with Iran.


A Summit On the Budget
LEAD: A trillion, for those who lose track of zeros, is a thousand billion.
Use this amount to scale up the old quip - ''A billion here, a billion there, why pretty soon you're talking about real money'' - and you have a decent guide to today's economic plight.


Smooth Adolescence
LEAD: Although approximately 20 percent of adolescents are severely troubled, the vast majority of adolescents are not in rebellion against their families, and have a relatively smooth transition from childhood to adulthood, recent research shows.
The image of adolescence as an inevitably troubled time is inaccurate, according to research by Daniel Offer, head of the department of psychiatry at Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago.

Mission Liquidation Plea
LEAD: The California Insurance Commissioner asked the Superior Court today to order the liquidation of the Mission Insurance Company and its subsidiaries.


2 Pianists Are Named Winners of Auditions
LEAD: Two pianists have won the 1987 Young Concert Artists International audition, and will be presented in recital next season at the 92d Street Y. They are Hung-Kuan Chen, 28 years old, a Taiwan-born citizen of the United States; and the Israeli-born Rina Dokshinsky, 20.


CHINESE LIMIT CAMPAIGN TO PARTY
LEAD: Apparently alarmed that the drive to silence critics was being carried too far, the Chinese leadership moved today to confine the campaign against intellectual dissent to the ruling Communist Party.


On Gun Control
LEAD: A Washington lobby headed by Sarah Brady, wife of James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was seriously wounded in an assassination attempt on President Reagan, will push hard this year for a federally imposed waiting period for buyers of pistols.

Paul Simon Removed From U.N. Boycott List
LEAD: Paul Simon, who was criticized for recording a half-dozen songs for his album ''Graceland'' with black musicians in South Africa in 1985, was removed yesterday from the list of artists who have broken the United Nations cultural boycott against the country.


SPANISH FORT IS EXCAVATED IN FLORIDA
LEAD: Archaeologists at work at the Pensacola Naval Air Station are digging through what they believe may be the remains of a 17th century Spanish fort, part of the first European settlement in what is now the United States.

A CAUTIOUS PROFESSIONAL: ROBERT MICHAEL GATES
LEAD: Robert M. Gates, President Reagan's nominee to be the next Director of Central Intelligence, is frequently described as a smart, cautious intelligence analyst.


Compaq Net Rises by 62%
LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that its earnings rose 62 percent, to $16.2 million, or 57 cents a share, from $10 million, or 36 cents a share, a year ago.
Revenues increased 20 percent, to $186.9 million, from $156.3 million a year ago.


DANCE: OHIO BALLET IN TWO WORKS BY LAURA DEAN
LEAD: LAURA DEAN has often been a thought-provoking choreographer.
She was so again on Saturday night when the Ohio Ballet danced the premieres of two works by her at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College.
One was yet another of the rigorous studies in patterned movement for which she is famous.


Two Captives
LEAD: Iran and Lebanon have become swamps into which outsiders venture at their peril.
This was well understood by Terry Waite, the Anglican envoy last seen in Beirut on Jan. 20.
Indeed, he left instructions that no attempt be made to rescue him if he was taken captive.
And every Western correspondent knows the risks of accepting even an official invitation to Iran, with its hostile regime of feuding clerical rulers.

LEAD: Pleading the innocence of ignorance, Reagan Administration officials blame Israel for luring them into the bizarre bazaars of Teheran and the international arms market.

Who led whom into sin?

PIANO: DAVID BUECHNER
LEAD: DAVID BUECHNER, who played an Alice Tully Hall recital Sunday evening, is a thoughtful and technically accomplished pianist, though it came as a bit of a surprise to learn - by reading the pianist's discursive program note at intermission - that his thoughts about the music he played were more personal and particular than the performance would have made one think.


L.I. Rail Commuters: 'They Seem Normal'
LEAD: LONG ISLAND RAIL ROAD workers, back on the job after the two-week strike, kept a careful eye out for any angry signals from rush-hour commuters Monday morning. ''They seem normal,'' said the conductor, Emmett Smith. ''They seem a little bit better than normal.''

LEAD: Alistair MacLean, author of ''The Guns of Navarone'' and one of the biggest-selling adventure writers in the world, died of heart failure yesterday in Munich, West Germany.
He was 64 years old and lived near Geneva.

French Selling Phone Group
LEAD: The French Finance Ministry put the state-owned telephone equipment maker, Cie Generale de Constructions Telephoniques, on the block today, as part of the conservative Government's sweeping privatization program.


In Sleep, Less Is More
LEAD: Less time in bed may mean more sleep for some insomniacs, researchers at the Mount Sinai Medical Center believe.
They are testing this idea by prescribing sleep restriction therapy - less time in bed - to some long term insomnia patients who volunteer for the research.

Georgia Votes Down Mickey
LEAD: Voters in Georgia would no longer be allowed to vote for Mickey Mouse in state elections under a bill passed today by the State Senate.
The cartoon character is a popular write-in choice of voters who choose not to vote for a regular candidate.
The measure directs election officials to ignore any write-in vote cast for a person who has not filed a notice of a write-in candidacy.


Record Japan Dollar-Buying
LEAD: The Bank of Japan bought nearly $9 billion on foreign exchange markets in January in an attempt to stop the yen from rising against the dollar, Finance Ministry sources said today.

PRISONERS IN IRAN-IRAQ WAR:
LEAD: Iranian officers checking barbed wire used to confine Iraqi prisoners of war last week at a temporary prison camp near Ahwaz, Iran.

THE OTHER IRAN MIDDLEMAN: ALBERT HAKIM'S MANY DEALS
LEAD: Until last week Albert Hakim, an Iranian-American businessman, was the least known figure in the Iran-contra affair.
He has not talked to the press, and the Senate Intelligence Committee could not even find him during its investigation.


Blast Kills Swedish Woman
LEAD: An explosion abroad the British tanker O. T. Gerth in the Seine River estuary today killed a Swedish woman in the crew and injured eight other crew members.
A fire tug moved in and put out the fire.

LEAD: On the face of it, the notion of establishing a national policy on child-care leave for working parents would appear to be an idea whose time has come.


UMass Student Fined for Brawl
LEAD: A former University of Massachusetts student has been fined and given a suspended prison sentence for pushing another student during a racial brawl on campus after the final game of the World Series.

LEAD: Frank Stanton, who has been chairman of Simmons Market Research in the United States, has also been named chairman and chief executive of its parent company, the international Market Research Bureau Group, by the JWT Group, the holding company for all.

Muller Gains in Tennis
LEAD: Gary Muller, coming back from a four-and-a-half-month layoff with torn knee cartilage, defeated Marcel Freeman of Los Angeles today, 7-6, 1-6, 7-6, in the first round of the $465,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championship.


NEW YORK'S HOMELESS CHILDREN: IN THE SYSTEM'S CLUTCHES
LEAD: Teachers at Public School 64 are used to seeing children fall into a deep sleep, their heads on their desks, because the hotel rooms they live in are so noisy and crowded that they get little rest at night.


A.T.&amp;T. Sees 'Chaos and Gridlock'
LEAD: The nation's regional telephone holding companies yesterday lauded a proposal by the Department of Justice that would permit them to enter a variety of businesses from which they are now barred.

ONLY APPLAUSE IN AUSTRALIA
LEAD: In the slanting sun off the Indian Ocean, horns of other boats serenaded Stars &amp; Stripes's return to her dock with a 3-0 lead over Kookaburra III in the America's Cup final.


Murdoch Moves To End Obstacle
LEAD: Rupert Murdoch has moved to eliminate one of the last remaining barriers in his attempt to gain control of Australia's largest broadcasting and publishing properties, the Herald and Weekly Times group.


Cuomo Names Jorling To Environment Post
LEAD: Governor Cuomo today announced the nomination of Thomas C. Jorling, director of the Environmental Studies Center at Williams College, to head the State Department of Environmental Conservation.


Berbick Defends King
LEAD: Trevor Berbick, who lost his World Boxing Council heavyweight championship title to Mike Tyson, has come to the aid of Don King, the promoter who has come under scrutiny for his handling of much of the $2.1 million purse from that fight.
The Nevada State Athletic Commission, meeting Friday, expressed concern over advances of $500,000 given to Berbick and the manner in which $500,000 that went to Carl King, Don's son and Berbick's manager, was paid.

WRECKAGE OF WARSHIP FOUND
LEAD: The wreckage of the U.S.S.
Kearsarge, the last of the Navy's wooden warships and victor of a famed Civil War battle against the Confederate warship Alabama, has been found in Colombian waters by a movie crew that hopes to salvage major artifacts of the ship.


PRODUCTIVITY RATE OFF 1.7% IN QUARTER
LEAD: Business productivity, a key measure of the nation's competitiveness, rose less than 1 percent in 1986 as efficiency gains by manufacturers since the 1981-82 recession began to fade, the Labor Department said today.


JAZZ: WIND AND THUNDER
LEAD: WIND AND THUNDER, the sextet that performed Sunday night at Sweet Basil, pulls third-world instruments into jazz compositions.
Bill Cole, the group's leader, plays woodwinds from Africa and the Middle East, and his pieces recall efforts made in the 1960's to mix jazz and non-Western improvising traditions; the early set included a vamp tune, a modal blues and pieces steeped in hard-bop.


Indians and Pakistanis Meet on Border Strains
LEAD: Indian and Pakistani negotiators, stepping up their negotiations to defuse the tense situation on the border, held their third day of talks today amid signs they were seeking some kind of accord on troop deployments.


U.S. ACTS ON POLLUTION IN JERSEY
LEAD: Law-enforcement officials asked a Federal judge today to impose a $472,000 fine on Woodbridge Township, which, they said, had failed to stop polluting the Arthur Kill and Kinsey Creek, which feed into Raritan Bay.


DONALD LOWITZ, ARMS NEGOTIATOR
LEAD: Donald S. Lowitz, a Chicago lawyer who was the chief United States delegate to the United Nations Disarmament Conference here, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, American officials said today.
He was 57 years old.


Woman Calls to Say She Killed Man in '83
LEAD: A woman from Rye Brook confessed in a call early Sunday to the police that she killed her boyfriend in 1983 - a death initially ruled a heroin overdose, the authorities said yesterday.

What About Baby M's Umbilical Contract?
LEAD: To the Editor:


Westinghouse, NBC Hit Snag
LEAD: Talks between the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the National Broadcating Company about merging radio operations have again stalled, a NBC spokesman said.
Westinghouse, which owns 13 radio stations and NBC, which owns eight stations, had considered merging their operations to create a radio company with assets of more than $500 million.


BABY M'S LAWYER URGES GIVING FATHER CUSTODY
LEAD: The court-appointed legal guardian of Baby M urged today that the baby's father, William Stern, receive sole custody of the 10-month-old girl and that the surrogate mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, be denied visiting rights for the immediate future.

LEAD: Bill Parcells of the Giants was not the only Super Bowl coach who interested the Atlanta Falcons as a replacement for Dan Henning, who was dismissed after the final game.

LEAD: It was halftime of a basketball game at San Jose City College last year, and the cheerleaders had just finished their routine.

Seeing Iran Plain
LEAD: In searching through the obscurities of the Iran affair we are in danger of overlooking the obvious.
So it seems to one returning to this country after several weeks abroad, away from the Iran story.


Chubb Acquisition
LEAD: The Chubb Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Sovereign Corporation, a life insurance holding company.
Under terms of the agreement, the companies said Sovereign stockholders would receive in a tax-free exchange 0.1365 of a share of Chubb for each share of Sovereign.
Sovereign stock closed at $8.25, down 62.5 cents, in over-the counter trading yesterday.

NOW, THE CITY POSTMAN ALSO RINGS FROM A VAN
LEAD: At 11:20 each morning, Gabriel Serrano fights his way through lunch-time traffic on Park Avenue and angles his van toward the curb outside the National Distillers Building between 39th and 40th Streets.


Polish Trade Weakness
LEAD: Poland recorded a trade surplus with the West of only $1.08 billion last year, compared with a target of $1.6 billion, official figures showed today.
The Central Statistical Office also reported that the country's debt to Western countries and banks grew at the same time by $4.2 billion, to $33.5 billion.


Nothing Personal
LEAD: After her first game in the United States, Kaz Berry's coaches and teammates congratulated her on the triple double she had just achieved: 14 points, 11 rebounds and 12 steals.

LEAD: POLLYANA was right, new research shows.

EDMUND PENDLETON
LEAD: Edmund Pendleton, organist at the American Church in Paris for 40 years and a composer and choirmaster, died Friday at his Paris home, his family said today.

Yugoslav Sailor Asks Asylum
LEAD: A 26-year-old Yugoslav sailor changed his mind and returned to his ship after requesting political asylum, then left the ship again, a Federal official said today.
Ray Buskey, an agent of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said the sailor, identified as Nikola Dimitrijevic, was ''making an asylum claim.


New York Philharmonic To Tour South America
LEAD: The New York Philharmonic will go on tour to Venezuela, Brazil and Argentina from July 25 to Aug. 11, the orchestra announced yesterday.
All 11 concerts will be conducted by the orchestra's music director, Zubin Mehta.

G.M. Plan Seen on Plant
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation, which had once threatened to shut down its assembly plant here, will use the facility to build its new small van, top aides to Governor Cuomo said today.


Second Offer For Cyclops
LEAD: The Cyclops Corporation, a steel producer and retailer, said yesterday that it had received a second offer for the company.
Last Friday, Audio/ Video Affiliates Inc. offered $75 a share, or slightly more than $300 million.

President Retires At Coopervision
LEAD: Coopervision Inc. said yesterday that its president, John H. Williford, had taken early retirement at age 56.
The news sprouted rumors of a possible sale of the eye-care company.


Talking Business; Today's World Of Commerce: with Pehr Gyllenhammar of Volvo
LEAD: Pehr Gyllenhammar is chairman of Volvo A.B., Scandinavia's largest industrial company.
Known in the United States for automobiles, Volvo also makes industrial, marine and aerospace products and is active in energy, food and banking.
Last year Volvo earned $237.9 million before taxes on sales of $12.71 billion.

On Competitiveness
LEAD: President Reagan's focus on competitiveness has prompted major changes at the Council on International Educational Exchange, a body of 179 colleges and universities with academic programs overseas.
For the first time it will be advised by non-academics who will be looking at how the council should expand its international business programs overseas and attract more students and scholarships financed by corporations.


LACROIX, NEW COUTURE STAR, LEAVES HOUSE OF PATOU
LEAD: After a major success in Paris last week with his collection for Jean Patou, Christian Lacroix telephoned friends in New York yesterday to say he was forming his own couture house in July.
He said he would add a ready-to-wear collection next year.

LEAD: Bernice Latrobe Maguire Smith, wife of Gerard C. Smith, who led the United States delegation from 1969 to 1972 in the negotiations on limiting strategic arms, died of cancer at her home yesterday.
She was 74 years old.

LEAD: Marita Koch, the East German sprint star who set 16 world records, has announced her retirement.
The 29-year-old Koch won a gold medal in the women's 400 meters in the 1980 Olympics but missed the 1984 Los Angeles Games because of the Soviet-led boycott. ''For years I have been plagued by trouble with my Achilles' tendon.

LEAD: A new era of spending and experimentation in particle physics is on the horizon with the start of beam collisions at Fermilab's four-mile Tevatron accelerator near Chicago and the announcement last week of Presidential approval for a monumental 52-mile atom smasher costing $4 billion to $6 billion.

Top Marathons Show Increases
LEAD: The top 10 marathons in the United States showed collective increases of 12 percent in the number of entrants and 13 percent in the number of finishers from 1985 to 1986, according to figures compiled by Fred Lebow, race director of the New York City Marathon.

Pacific Isle Anti-Communists Chase Off Soviet Cruise Ship
LEAD: More than 1,500 anti-Communist demonstrators forced a ship carrying the Soviet Ambassador to Australia to leave the French Pacific territory of New Caledonia today without letting off its passengers.


2 AIRLINES FINED OVER COCAINE
LEAD: The United States Customs Service has imposed fines of $2.5 million against a Colombian airline and $640,000 against an Ecuadoran carrier after inspectors seized shipments of cocaine hidden aboard their jets, customs officials said today.


O'NEILL URGES INCREASES IN STATE AID FOR TOWNS
LEAD: Gov.
William A. O'Neill, carrying out a promise from his re-election campaign last fall, proposed today a sharp increase in state aid to cities and towns to help them hold down local property taxes.

'ORDINARY' IN BEL AIR HAS $3 MILLION ASKING PRICE
LEAD: The neighborhood is Old Bel Air, the most desirable part of the pricey Bel Air section of Los Angeles, where some local real estate brokers say an ''ordinary'' house on an acre of land goes for $3 million.
It is there that a group of President Reagan's friends have paid $2.5 million for a home for him and Nancy Reagan in retirement.


6 ARE ARRESTED AFTER TRYING TO EVICT A SUSPECTED DRUG RING
LEAD: A Brooklyn landlord and five other men were arrested after having tried to oust a suspected crack-dealing operation in the landlord's Bedford-Stuyvesant apartment building, their lawyers said yesterday.


GIFT TO THE NEEDIEST PROMPTED BY A 'TUG AT MY CONSCIENCE'
LEAD: ''A short walk through Penn Station reminded me that it was time to get my check in,'' Maria Romano of Manhattan wrote in a letter accompanying her donation of $20 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''To delay is to forget, and the neediest tug at my conscience too much to make me forget.


STEEL OUTPUT OFF 0.4%
LEAD: Steel production declined ot 1.337 million tons in the week ended last Satruday, a four-tenths of 1 percent decrease from the previous week's 1.343 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Insitiute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 58.4 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 58.7 percent in the previous week.


RIDERS RELIEVED AS L.I.R.R. RESUMES RUSH-HOUR SERVICE
LEAD: Facing its first rush hour after a crippling two-week strike, the Long Island Rail Road today ran trains that officials said were largely on time and that commuters said were much welcomed.


SLEUTHS TURN TO ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY TO TRACK DOWN ARSON
LEAD: When he first set foot inside the Dupont Plaza Hotel on New Year's Day, the day after it was ravaged by the most deadly American hotel fire in 40 years, Dan Garner saw only blackened rubble, charred debris and twisted metal, all covered with muddy soot and ashes.

Bally Hearing Delayed 2 Weeks
LEAD: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said a Federal District Court hearing involving its litigation with the real estate developer Donald J. Trump had been postponed until Feb. 17 at the request of lawyers for both parties.
Under an extension agreement, Bally agreed not to complete its proposed acquisition of the Golden Nugget casino in Atlantic City, and Trump has agreed not to buy shares of Bally.


SOME OF THE LESSONS FROM JAPAN AND RUSSIA
LEAD: THE United States Department of Education, in a recent report, called Japan ''a learning society of formidable dimensions.'' The comment brought to mind a similar assessment in 1959, when an American team of experts, headed by the United States Commissioner of Education, returned from the Soviet Union with the observation that the Soviet people had ''a grand passion for education.


Dennis Leonard Retires
LEAD: Dennis Leonard, who did what many thought was impossible when he pitched for the Kansas City Royals last season after a severe knee injury, retired from baseball yesterday.
The 35-year-old right-hander, who ended nearly three years of rehabilitation by pitching a three-hit shutout in his first start last April, said his retirement was a mutual decision with the Royals' general manager, John Schuerholz.


Back to the Bosses
LEAD: To the Editor:


MEMBER OF CONGRESS FROM SAN FRANCISCO
LEAD: Representative Sala Galant Burton, a California Democrat who succeeded her husband, Phillip Burton, in Congress in 1983 and carried on his liberal policies, died Sunday of complications of cancer.
She was 61 years old.


DOLLAR OFF IN CALM DAY; TRADE DATA REASSESSED
LEAD: The dollar declined yesterday as traders took profits following Friday's sharp run-up.
Compared with recent sessions, yesterday's trading pace was much more sedate, market participants said.


THEATER: 'SERGEANT OLA AND HIS FOLLOWERS'
LEAD: CERTAIN natives in Papua New Guinea, impressed by the shipment of consumer goods from capitalistic countries, are worshipers in what has been referred to as ''cargo cults.'' In the eyes of these people, the magical delivery of packages by sea and air can be brought about by imitating the rituals and habits of those representing so-called civilization.

Big Bet on Brazil
LEAD: Brazil got a big financial boost from the ''Paris Club'' of creditor governments late last month.

That spares a wobbly democratic Government further domestic humiliation.

BRITAIN'S HIGH-TECH BOOKIES
LEAD: Mention the Giants-Broncos Super Bowl game and Ronald Pollard shakes his head in disdain at the kind of betting that it inspired: about $40 million wagered legally in Nevada, dwarfed by illegal betting elsewhere in the United States estimated at more than $1 billion.

LEAD: At least 43 people were killed and 20 were missing in flash flooding in the foothills of the Peruvian Andes around Oxapampa, civil defense officials said today.

LEAD: Sealed by a 10-foot thickness of steel inside a bunker under a snow-swept Illinois prairie, a powerful new machine is giving scientists their first glimpses of microscopic, man-made explosions so violent that they mimic the state of the universe when it was only a fraction of a second old.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.Does the nightingale sing only at night?
A.
Contrary to popular belief, the nightingales sing at all hours -but mainly on clear moonlit nights several weeks after it flies north for the summer, according to bird watchers.
Of the two species found in Europe, Asia, and northwestern Africa, the thrush nightingale, Luscinia luscinia, is more accomplished in song than the nightingale, Luscinia megarhynchos, which can sometimes lapse into croaks and chuckles.

Wrong Voting Rights Burden
LEAD: Black Americans were robbed of their right to vote for a century, until the 1965 Voting Rights Act changed the burden of proof.
No longer could states with the worst histories of abuse keep changing their election laws as fast as civil rights lawyers could prove them discriminatory.
Congress decreed that new election laws could not take effect until the state or locality proved that they would not deprive minorities of voting power.

He was 96 years old and lived in Manhattan.

'Cinderella' to Return
LEAD: The Lyons Opera Ballet will return to City Center with its highly praised production of ''Cinderella,'' or ''Cendrillon,'' for two weeks starting May 18, with an option to renew for a third week.
The full-evening ballet, which sold out most of its performances at the theater last month, was choreographed by Maguy Marin, a French experimentalist.


Claims Court Head Named
LEAD: Governor Cuomo today named Judge Donald J. Corbett Jr. of Rochester as Presiding Judge of the state Court of Claims.
Judge Corbett, who was appointed to the court in 1983 by Mr.
Cuomo, will succeed Judge Harold E. Koreman.
He will be paid $87,500 a year.
Judge Corbett, who is 50 years old, is a graduate of the University of Notre Dame and Albany Law School.

METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD: A FRIGID Tuesday evening.
Mary Ann Jung is crossing East 87th Street.
Ahead of her a woman is walking a golden retriever, which, Ms.
Jung notices, has something dangling from its mouth.
Catching up, she sees that the something is a red suede glove; the woman wears a red suede glove on one hand while her other hand, clenched from the cold, is bare.

Big Operators Give Up
LEAD: No one knows exactly how many Americans have left farms in recent times, voluntarily or not.
The Agriculture Department found last June that the number of farms had dropped 65,000 in the previous 52 weeks, to 2.21 million, a loss of one farm about every eight minutes.
Experts estimate there are about three people on each farm, meaning nearly 200,000 rural

And his mind, which is as quick as the wrists that have inflicted so much damage to the equilibriums of so many goalies, has begun to tell him it cannot win this war against his body.

LEAD: Continuing a trend of unusually strong profits on Wall Street, First Boston Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net earnings jumped 73 percent, to $61.6 million, or $1.68 a share, from $35.6 million, or $1.10 a share, a year ago.
Revenues rose 68.6 percent, to $412 million, from $244.3 million.

LEAD: That gripping political drama in the Philippines continues to leave a world audience agape.

Roving Robot Move Into Industry
LEAD: THE mobile robot installed last month at the Orlando, Fla., semiconductor plant of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is unlikely to remind anyone of ballistic missiles or jet aircraft, its technological forebears.
Scooter, as A.T.&amp;T. calls the robot, rolls along at a top speed of less than one mile an hour, carries 30 pounds of semiconductor wafers between processing stations, and stops short when it bumps into a toe or other obstruction.

Shamrock Reports $42.2 Million Loss
LEAD: A day after announcing a restructuring intended to fend off a takeover bid, the Diamond Shamrock Corporation said today it lost $42.2 million in the fourth quarter.
The loss compared with a profit of $28.7 million in the 1985 quarter.


'Survival' Program Looks at Gorillas
LEAD: GORILLAS may not be the most enchanting of creatures, but on television they have their moments. ''Survival: Gorilla,'' a one-hour documentary on Home Box Office today at 5 P.M., presents a few.
The 1975 British production shows us gorillas as homebodies, chary of strangers, but kind to one another.


THEATERS CUT COSTS AND CROSS FINGERS
LEAD: A new plan to lower the cost of producing - and of seeing - shows in several underused Broadway houses will be put to the test for the first time tomorrow night when the musical revue ''Stardust'' begins performances at the Biltmore Theater.


'MANY SOURCES' AIDING U.S. REPORTER
LEAD: Governments friendly to both the United States and Iran are trying to gain the release of an American journalist detained in Iran, American officials and diplomatic sources said today.


FINANCIAL JOUSTING AT THE FED
LEAD: As eight stretch limousines waited outside the main entrance to the Federal Reserve Board's Eccles Building here today, some of the nation's most prominent bankers and Wall Street financiers jousted with board members over whether or not one of the nation's most basic banking laws should be breached.

LOS LOBOS ALBUM'S POPULIST VIEW
LEAD: ''ONE TIME, ONE NIGHT,'' the most powerful song on Los Lobos' new album, ''By the Light of the Moon'' (Slash/Warner Brothers), telescopes several harrowing personal dramas into a canvas of American life that is at once tragic and mystically hopeful.
Set to rolling, twangy country-rock in the mode of Creedence Clearwater Revival, its verses sketch a series of related vignettes, each presented in the clipped, unsentimental tone of a news item.

LEAD: In the Broadway column in Weekend last Friday, the director of ''Breaking the Code,'' a play starring Derek Jacobi that will be coming to New York this fall, was misidentified.

NEW ACCOUNT GIVEN IN ATTACK ON BLACKS IN QUEENS
LEAD: Prosecutors in the Howard Beach, Queens, case have obtained new evidence indicating that white youths were in close pursuit of Michael Griffith when he ran onto the parkway where he was killed by a car on the night of Dec. 19-20, according to law-enforcement sources.


DISCOVERIES
LEAD: 1.Whimsy in a Pitcher Marco Zanini has reinvented the pitcher.
The Italian designer has turned it into an object of whimsy, with a straight edge.
The pitcher is white ceramic, with a pale blue handle.
It is also available in black or brown for $50 in Chelsea Passage on the main floor at Barneys New York, Seventh Avenue and 17th Street.


TENNIS HOPEFUL, 16, STARTS ON ROAD UP
LEAD: The Blackmans sat in the loge seats overlooking the two Supreme Court surfaces on the floor of the Spectrum, where matches are often in progress simultaneously, giving the tennis pros a taste of what it is like to play on public courts.


FOOD NOTES
LEAD: Loving Calories Goodies for Valentine's Day, 10 days away, run from the sublime to heart-shaped hallah bread.
The bread is being made by Au P'tit Pain, 681 Lexington Avenue (56th Street), in sizes that run from small ( 1/4 pound, 80 cents) to medium ( 1/2 pound, $1.50) to large (1 pound, $2.50) to largest (2 pounds, $5), all inscribed with ''Happy Valentine'' in chocolate.


NELDA S. FREEMAN
LEAD: Nelda S. Freeman, a former managing editor and board member of W. W. Norton &amp; Company, the book publisher, died of cancer Saturday at the Northern Westchester Medical Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
She was 72 years old and lived in Brewster, N.Y.


WINE TALK
LEAD: CHATEAUNEUF-DU-PAPE, from the southern Rhone, was born to be drunk in winter.
It radiates warmth.
Typically it is velvety in texture and chewy, and has a peppery, spicy taste.
It is also as easy to find as mittens.

LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $1.5 billion of debentures equally divided between four-year and 10-year maturities, through various securities dealers.


Afghanistan to Let Red Cross Resume Seeing War Prisoners
LEAD: The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that Afghanistan had agreed to allow Red Cross delegates to resume visits to prisoners of war and to aid the wounded, after a four-year ban.
