GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD: SHAW UNBOUND


Louisville Dropout
LEAD: Kevin Walls, a sophomore who started nine games this season before being relegated to the bench, quit the Louisville basketball team yesterday, Coach Denny Crum said.
Walls's move follows his refusal to enter Monday night's game against South Carolina in the last minutes.
Walls had played less than one minute in the first half of Louisville's 90-62 victory.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Dec. 26, about steel service centers, incorrectly described the status of Frasse Bassett Inc., a Pennsylvania service center.
It is no longer in Chapter 11 proceedings, and it is still in operation.

Truck With Radioactive Material Jackknifes
LEAD: Part of a trailer containing carbon 14 being loaded onto another truck after a tractor-trailer jackknifed yesterday morning on Route 17 in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., closing the six-lane highway.
The trailer carried eight boxes of the isotope, which is a byproduct of nuclear power production and weapons testing and is used in industry and medicine.

Mmmm?
LEAD: Z is what they call him, but that's not his name.
M is, however.
Z is just his nickname, short for Zenon.
M is short already.
Except that he's 6 feet 7 inches tall.
Z is, that is, or rather M is.
Z M, if you will, except nobody calls him that.
His teammates on the Cal Poly-Pomona basketball squad just call him Z.

Greyhound Lines Deal
LEAD: Union leaders representing 6,000 employees of Greyhound Lines Inc. reached agreement on a three-year contract with a group that plans to buy the bus company.
The leaders voted, 20 to 3, to accept a plan that includes incentive pay and guaranteed job security for drivers and mechanics with at least five years' service.

The President's Notes
LEAD: The personal notes Presidents take in the White House for possible memoir-writing seem to have a way of getting around.
Under some pressure from Congress, President Reagan just agreed to make ''relevant excerpts'' from his notes available to investigators dealing with secret transfers of arms to Iran, despite any possible interference with his right of privacy.

LEAD: Fewer than a dozen California sea lions here are gobbling up a biologically treasured species of the steelhead, a prize game fish, and fish wardens seem powerless to stop them.

Dollar Rise Late in Day Erases Earlier Losses
LEAD: The dollar rallied late yesterday to end essentially unchanged in what currency dealers described as hectic trading.


Tucson Electric
LEAD: The Tucson Electric Power Company said it had bought a 9.5 percent stake in the Citadel Holding Company, the parent of Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association of Glendale, Calif.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Tucson said it was seeking a seat on Citadel's board and offered to acquire up to 400,000 unissued Citadel shares, or an additional 12 percent of the common stock, for $57 a share.

The Art of Artspeak: Be Sophisticated
LEAD: WHEN viewing art in galleries and museums, avoid terms like ''incredible,'' ''cool'' and ''totally awesome.'' Even ''interesting'' is preferable - especially when uttered with the head cocked and with a hand cupping the chin in a contemplative pose - although that old routine doesn't really fool many people anymore.


CBS NEWS DIVISION HIRING BLOCKED
LEAD: In a developing test of wills inside CBS, a top corporate executive has refused permission to CBS News to fill certain job vacancies characterized as essential by the news division.


Gulf States Utility
LEAD: The Texas Public Utility Commission has granted the Gulf States Utility Company of Beaumont, Tex., a $39.9 million emergency increase in electricity rates, about half of the $82 million increase that had been sought.
The commission said, however, the increase had been granted on the condition that the utility secure a $250 million line of credit.


4 in Family Killed in Long Island Fire
LEAD: Police officers outside charred house in which four family members died and two were critically injured in an early-morning blaze in Wantagh.


AMERICAN MEDICAL GETS OFFER
LEAD: A Chicago doctor, Leroy A. Pesch, offered yesterday to pay $1.7 billion in cash for American Medical International Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif., one of the nation's biggest hospital companies.


LIFE IN THE 30'S
LEAD: THE other night I had a dream about shopping in Saks.
I was looking for a dress for a formal dinner and I found exactly the right thing: black velvet, strapless, with a fitted bodice, the kind of dress you imagine but find only in your dreams.
Then while I was paying for the dress, I realized that I didn't have the right shoes, so I went to the shoe department and bought black peau de soie pumps with a medium heel.

LEAD: WHEN a group of developers announced more than a year ago that they would build on the site of a West 54th Street parking lot between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, their plan was for a mixed-use project that would combine rental apartments and a hotel in the same 46-story structure.

Not for Everyone
LEAD: To the Editor:


Falcons Pick Campbell
LEAD: After a six-week search for someone to replace the dismissed Dan Henning, the Atlanta Falcons found a new head coach within their own ranks yesterday, naming their defensive coordinator, Marion Campbell, to the post. ''We talked a great deal about hiring a name coach,'' the Falcons' owner, Rankin Smith, said.


THE ART OF AN INFORMAL TASTING AT HOME
LEAD: SO you need to buy a jar of mustard.
Seems like a mindless task - until you go into a specialty food store and confront more than 50 different brands.
Do you buy the one from France, because the French are known to make good mustard?
Or the expensive one, reasoning that it is bound to be good?
Most of us end up buying a tried and true brand, which might be acceptable, but not outstanding, when, sadly, a great mustard might sit on the shelf right next to it.


HOUSE ACTS TO GET RAISE AND EASE POLITICAL HARM
LEAD: Struggling for a way to preserve a scheduled pay increase for themselves and other Federal officials while minimizing the political damage, the leadership of the House of Representatives embarked on a strategy today that may do both.

LEAD: The day after Governor Kean told the Legislature that the economy of the state was booming and said ''these are our glory days,'' a group of urban mayors and 1,300 municipal workers who have received layoff notices rallied at the Capitol today to demand a share of the good times.

LEAD: CREATING a splendid new dish, spicing a familiar one to perfection or simply savoring another's cooking with the culinary equivalent of a jeweler's eye: These are hallmarks of a great palate.
Such gustatory distinction is within the reach of all who dare, according to leading chefs, taste researchers and eaters.

LEAD: THE PROPHETEERS.
By Max Apple. 306 pages.
Harper &amp; Row.
Cloth, $16.95; paper, $7.95.
MOST satirists are pretty angry fellows - writing, for them, is a way of expressing their rage at the inanities of society and the stupidities of their colleagues in the human race through caricature, pratfalls and simple outrageous humor.

ZAIRE, A PARADIGM OF MISMANAGERMENT
LEAD: A Zairian stood recently in front of the rusting and empty cages of Lubumbashi's zoo, once the finest in central Africa. ''With Mobutu's economic policies, people have eaten all the monkeys,'' he said without humor.


Orioles Pursue Guidry
LEAD: Ron Guidry's agent, Reggie Ringuet, said yesterday he would be in Baltimore next Monday to meet with Hank Peters, the Orioles' general manager.
The Orioles, who have been the most active of the clubs interested in Guidry, are believed to be ready to offer the free-agent pitcher a one-year contract for a salary between $600,000 and $700,000.


LEBANESE KIDNAPPINGS PROTESTED
LEAD: Moslem women demonstrating yesterday at the Beirut University College.
About 500 people took part in a march to demand the release of four professors kidnapped last month as a general strike, called by students, paralyzed West Beirut.
Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, the group which claims to hold the four kidnapping victims, said it has moved them from Beirut ''to different secure areas'' because of an expected United States attack on Lebanon to try to free the hostages.


Pride Spills Over At Home
LEAD: Suddenly, everyone here is a sailor.


BREZHNEV RELATIVE, EX-POLICE OFFICIAL, HELD IN BRIBE CASE
LEAD: The son-in-law of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the former Soviet leader, has been arrested and is under investigation for corruption and bribe-taking, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.


Chicago Utility
LEAD: The Commonwealth Edison Company, the nation's largest nuclear utility, has proposed raising electricity rates 9.6 percent this year, then freezing rates for five years.
Gov.
James R. Thompson and Illinois's Attorney General, Neil Hartigan, endorsed the plan, which would bring in about $660 million in additional revenue a year.


Xerox, VMS in Talks
LEAD: The Xerox Corporation said that it was negotiating with VMS Realty Partners Inc. to acquire part of the real estate syndicator but that no agreement had been signed.
An article in today's Wall Street Journal said that Xerox had agreed in principle to buy 25 percent of VMS as part of a $200 million transaction, but Xerox would not confirm or deny any such details.


Capote Is Rated Best of the 3-Year-Olds
LEAD: Capote, the Seattle Slew colt who is the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby on May 2, was ranked first among 102 colts and geldings who were weighted today in The Jockey Club's annual Experimental Free Handicap.

STAGE: STEVE TESICH'S 'DIVISION STREET'
LEAD: IN the opening gag of Steve Tesich's ''Division Street,'' a former 1960's radical named Chris drops a tablet of Alka-Seltzer in a glass of water and waits impatiently for it to go to work. ''Fizz!'' Chris orders the recalcitrant tablet. ''You're supposed to fizz!'' But the pill just sits there, inert, and so it goes with what follows.

Safe, Speedy Shucking
LEAD: ANYONE who has watched a master oyster shucker at an oyster bar must marvel at the speed and skill with which the deed is done.
Shucking oysters, however, is more than merely separating the shells: there is a right way and a wrong way.
The aim is to open the shell cleanly without severing the fragile meat or spilling the brine.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Skiing Walliser Wins Second Gold Medal: Maria Walliser mastered a tough supergiant slalom course with a daring and nearly flawless run yesterday at Crans-Montana, Switzerland, to win her second gold medal at the world Alpine championships.
Walliser clinched the gold medal by outracing her teammate, Michela Figini, whom she had beaten in the downhill.

60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: IT has been said, with only slight exaggeration, that you would need an encyclopedia to outline the many kinds of fish marketed under the name of sole or flounder.
In ''The Encyclopedia of Fish'' by A. J. McClane (Holt, Rinehart &amp; Winston, 1977), the section on sole has nearly a dozen entries, including Dover sole, English sole, Rex sole, sand sole and 15 varieties of the type of sole known as flounder, ranging from plaice to turbot.

LEAD: Sales of new homes jumped sharply in December as the housing industry completed its best year since 1978, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: Prince Takamatsu, a younger brother of Emperor Hirohito and a philanthropist, died of lung cancer today in a Tokyo hospital.

LEAD: Pat Quinn has not been banned from coaching in the National Hockey League until the 1990-91 season.
He has only been prohibited from coaching the Vancouver Canucks until that time.
The ban had been ordered by the N.H.L. president, John Ziegler, last Friday, and the league sent out a corrected version yesterday.

Tax Loophole In New Law
LEAD: The Treasury Department and some Senate tax writers agreed today that a loophole in the new tax law should be closed because it could cost as much as $20 billion in lost revenues over the next five years.

THRIFT UNIT OUTFLOW
LEAD: The flow of deposits out of federally insured savings and loan institutions narrowed to $3.96 billion last year, compared with $4.26 billion in 1985, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.
Deposits totaled $889.92 billion at the end of December, up from $885.44 billion in November.
Deposit outflows in December declined ot $2.07 billion, from $2.85 billion in November, the Board said.

LEAD: Two key aides to Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, will leave to take other posts and a third is exploring the possibility, White House and political sources said today.

Low Finance
LEAD: A coin collector we know finds nothing so stimulating as a midwinter thaw.
It's not the rising temperature or anticipation of the spring coin show, but the increase in curbside collecting.

'A Uniquely Jewish List'
LEAD: A five-pound volume listing the names of 11,000 Soviet Jews who have been denied permission to emigrate is being distributed to members of Congress, the State Department and other Government agencies as a reminder of their plight.
The book, ''A Uniquely Jewish List: The Refuseniks of Russia,'' includes only those who have been refused emigration more than once.

Play It Again, Yul
LEAD: To the Editor:


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: ALTHOUGH a home or apartment may seem to have plenty of closet space when you move in, all too often you later discover you need more.
Enlarging an existing closet is rarely possible, but often there is room to build another.
The easiest place to build an extra closet is in the corner of a room.
That way you only have to build two walls for the new closet; the other two are already in place.

The secret to managing catalogue temptations is to limit your selections to plants not readily found in local nurseries.

Homosexual Priest Dismissed by Vatican
LEAD: The Vatican has formally dismissed a homosexual Manhattan priest from his Jesuit order for publicly opposing the teachings of the church against homosexual activity.


U.S. CALLED LAX BY HOUSE PANEL IN FIGHTING SPIES
LEAD: The House Intelligence Committee said today that an investigation had uncovered ''dangerous laxity'' and serious ''security failures'' in the Government's system of catching spies.


IRISH JEWS TRY TO STOP A PLAY
LEAD: Prominent Irish Jews today condemned an effort to stage a play in Dublin that accuses Zionist leaders of collaborating with Nazis in the murder of Jews in World War II.
A production of the play was canceled last month in London after protests over its content.


COLOMBIA EXTRADITES A MAJOR DRUG FIGURE TO U.S.
LEAD: Soldiers captured a reputed billionaire cocaine trafficker at a rural mansion early today and extradited him to the United States for trial on drug charges.

PODDUBNY'S GOAL WINS EMOTIONAL GAME
LEAD: They stood in various poses down the long hallway that stretches between the dressing rooms.
Bobby Carpenter wore only a towel and an ice pack.
Mike Ridley leaned one shoulder against a wall.
Kelly Miller sipped a beer.
They were collected, it appeared, but Ridley said he felt ''weird,'' and Miller said that although he had reminded himself all day not to feel nervous, he still had ''the jitters.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration is close to a decision on whether to put into effect an interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty that would allow extensive testing of ''Star Wars'' systems, Government officials said today.


Pemex Head To Seek Office

The move by Mario Ramon


CABARET: O.C. SMITH, SINGER
LEAD: O.C.
SMITH has led at least three different lives as a pop-jazz performer.
In the early 1960's, the Louisiana-born singer replaced Joe Williams as the lead singer for the Count Basie band with whom he remained for three years.
Several years later he became a pop star growling out colorfully corny country-pop vignettes like ''Little Green Apples,'' which anticipated Kenny Rogers's rustic yarn-spinning.

LEAD: Residents of this old port city are temporarily sending away a cast-iron symbol of the past in order to bring it back preserved for the future.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article in Business Day last Thursday about Texaco Inc.'s earnings misstated the cause of a $60 million charge in the fourth quarter of 1986.
It resulted from the company's existing inventory accounting procedures.

FURNITURE WITH THE LOOK OF SCULPTURE
LEAD: TWO years ago, Angela Nolte began organizing exhibits for young furniture designers and avant-garde artists in Germany.
Last year, Mrs.
Nolte, top right, moved to New York, where she opened Nolte, which shows the furniture designed by the artists she represents.
Her husband, Randolph Nolte, oversees the production, which is mostly sculptural.

LEAD: The Egyptian Information Minister has denied a report in The New York Times that Cairo guaranteed money and offered planes in 1985 to private dealers trying to ship 39 American-made F-4 fighters to Iran.

LIBERACE, FLAMBOYANT PIANIST, IS DEAD
LEAD: Liberace, whose glitzy costumes, giant candelabra and extravagant showmanship made him almost as famous as his piano playing, died yesterday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif.
He was 67 years old.
His spokesman in New York, Denise Collier, said the cause of death was cardiac arrest due to congestive heart failure brought on by subacute encephalopathy.


NEAR-COLLISION IS REPORTED IN AREA OF FATAL CRASH
LEAD: In a near repetition of a midair collision last August, an Aeromexico jetliner came close to crashing into a smaller plane Saturday near Cerritos, Calif., Federal officials said Tuesday.

OFFICIALS IN DISCORD OVER U.S. PROPOSAL FOR AIDS VIRUS TEST
LEAD: A Federal proposal to give AIDS virus tests to anybody admitted to a hospital or applying for a marriage license raises difficult questions of confidentiality and proper priorities in fighting the disease, health officials and others said yesterday.
Experts disagreed on whether the plan would help in the battle against acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

NASA DELAY HINTED ON SPACE STATION
LEAD: The United States might not have a space station aloft by the 1994 target date and it might cost as much as $13 billion instead of the planned $8 billion, James C. Fletcher, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, testified Tuesday.


Texas Again Stops Admission To Its Overcrowded Prisons
LEAD: Texas prison officials closed the nation's second-largest corrections system to new admissions today for the second time in a month as the number of inmates topped a limit set by a law to curb crowding.


McEnroe to Rejoin Team
LEAD: The United States Tennis Association announced today that John McEnroe would rejoin the Davis Cup team this year, although he will miss the first round against Paraguay because of a scheduling conflict.

Shining Knight Leads Rutgers
LEAD: The coach sat on a bench in a hallway that led from the court to the dressing room, surrounded by a dozen or so reporters who dutifully took note of the postgame analysis.
The coach was attempting to explain the unique difficulties behind a 41-point victory, telling the assembled crowd that it was simply impossible for the players to ease up against a weaker opponent.


BETTE MIDLER AND DISNEY SIGN THREE-PICTURE DEAL
LEAD: Since the death of the long-term contract, Hollywood studios and stars make a deal, do one picture and then go their separate ways.
Now, in an arrangement that harkens back to the old studio system, Bette Midler has signed a contract with Walt Disney Pictures to star in three successive movies.


Two Milestones
LEAD: Last Nov. 1, in his first game at the Salt Palace after being traded from Portland to Utah, Kiki Vandeweghe played 21 minutes against the Trail Blazers and came away with no points.
That was the first time that Vandeweghe, a 23.4-point scorer as a pro, had been shut out in a 16-year career spanning more than 700 games and dating from junior high school.


A HIGHWAY-TRANSIT BILL IS APPROVED BY SENATE
LEAD: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a $65 billion highway and mass transit bill that could provoke the second veto confrontation between the Reagan White House and the new Democratic Congress this year.

Transamerica Gets Fairmont
LEAD: The Transamerica Corporation said today that its insurance group had agreed to acquire Fairmont Financial Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $150 million.
According to the agreement, which is expected to close during the second quarter, Fairmont stockholders will receive 0.555 share of Transamerica for each Fairmont common share, or a total of about 3 million


ECONOMIC DATE HELP DOLLAR ADVANCE A BIT
LEAD: The dollar rose modestly in relation to most major currencies in quiet trading yesterday.
It drew support from recent figures showing strength in the American economy.


Landlord Agrees To Building Repairs
LEAD: A Brooklyn landlord who was given a 45-day jail sentence last July for failing to correct housing-code violations has signed an agreement to put four apartment buildings into the hands of an administrator, the authorities said yesterday.

HELP IN KEEPING TRACK OF SKI ACHIEVEMENTS
LEAD: CERTAIN skiers like to brag that they logged billions of miles on their weekend ski trips and hit warp speed at least once during each run.
Why believe them?
Demand proof.
Ask to see what their Ski-Dometer said.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  SKIING  Zurbriggen Wins Giant Slalom: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland won the men's giant slalom today for his second gold medal at the world Alpine ski championships in Crans-Montana, Switzerland.
Zurbriggen got a big break when Joel Gaspoz, who appeared well ahead, fell after hitting the 48th gate of the 50-gate track.

AMERICAN HOME SEEKS ROBINS
LEAD: The American Home Products Corporation has offered to buy the A. H. Robins Company and take on the huge legal liabilities of Robins's Dalkon Shield birth-control device, the two health-care companies said yesterday.


4 White Movie Theaters Are Closed in South Africa
LEAD: A South African film distributor, pressed by American distributors to open its movie houses to all races, said today that it was closing four whites-only movie theaters in Pretoria until the city council voted to make them multiracial.

SERENADING THE LOST LAMBS OF THE COUNTERCULTURE
LEAD: Adam Hanuszkiewicz, who was dismissed five years ago as director of Poland's national theater because of his activities in the Solidarity period, has just been invited to the Ministry of Culture for talks about a new job.
Films blocked by censors since 1981 are being released, and some artists and writers who shunned Government contact after martial law was declared are being asked to take tea with Gen.


PAN AM WILL GET CITICORP AID
LEAD: The Pan Am Corporation, the parent of Pan American World Airways, said yesterday that it had hired the Citicorp Investment Bank to advise it on any merger talks and that Citicorp would arrange up to $150 million in financing for the airline.

Mostly sunny skies are expected today, with temperatures in the 30's. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: President Reagan, recuperating from surgery a month ago, has not been able to resume his daily exercise regimen yet but will begin to ease into his routine soon, a spokesman said today.


Washington Times Editor Ill
LEAD: Arnaud de Borchgrave, the editor-in-chief of The Washington Times, became ill at his office today and was admitted to a hospital in intensive care, the newspaper said. ''Tests are being conducted at this time to rule out the possibility of a heart attack and the hospital lists his condition as serious,'' the newspaper said in a statement.

Ard Stays in Jury Pool
LEAD: Billy Ard, offensive guard for the Giants, tried to be excused from serving in a jury pool for a murder trial in New Jersey, but the presiding judge was not swayed.
Ard said the jury duty would interfere with his weight training and could cost him money.
Since the Giants defeated the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXI, Ard said he has had several paid appearances and speaking engagements scheduled.

NEW YORK PLATE LOOK
LEAD: To the Editor:


FLOWER SHOWS: HARBINGERS OF SPRING
LEAD: NOTHING satisfies that yearning for spring better than a flower show.
Several have been scheduled for the East Coast.
Here they are:  New Jersey Flower and Garden Show, Feb. 28 through March 8.


EX-GUARD CHIEF CARRIES HISTORY OF CONTROVERSY

Bartender Pleads Not Guilty In Hotel Fire in Puerto Rico
LEAD: Bartender Jose Francisco Rivera Lopez pleaded not guilty Tuesday in Federal District Court here to a charge of instigating arson in the Dupont Plaza Hotel fire that killed 96 people on New Year's Eve.
Judge Justo Arenas denied bail.
United States Attorney Daniel Lopez Romo said he has 13 witnesses who allege that Mr.


KASPAROV, PUBLICIZING CHESS IN BRITAIN, PLAYS TV MATCH
LEAD: Gary Kasparov, the Soviet chess world champion, began a two-day televised challenge match today with the British grand master Nigel Short that was billed as an attempt to project the game for a mass television audience.


Canada's Reserves Soar
LEAD: Canada's official foreign currency reserves, used to protect the Canadian dollar, soared to the highest level in nearly 13 years in January, the Finance Department said today.
The figure rose by nearly $2 billion (American), to $6.07 billion.


CHILEAN, IN REMORSE, ADMITS ROLE IN LETELIER SLAYING IN '76
LEAD: A former official in the Chilean secret police, saying he was consumed by guilt, confessed in a Washington courtroom today to involvement in the 1976 murder here of a former Chilean Ambassador to the United States.


British Bank Seeks Inquiry
LEAD: The Bank of England said today that it would investigate, at the request of the Standard Chartered Bank, how the bank fought off a takeover bid from Lloyds Bank last July.


O'NEILL PROPOSES 13.9% RISE IN BUDGET
LEAD: Citing Connecticut's ''unheralded prosperity,'' Gov.
William A. O'Neill proposed today a $5.6 billion state budget that would increase spending by 13.93 percent without raising taxes.


COLLEGE SEEKS A COMFORTABLE, AND CHEAP, CAMPUS
LEAD: Museums, theaters, gracious old buildings, convenience and the excitement of city living are all here.
But eventually every urban dweller looks at the cramped accommodations and wonders if, for the same money, he could not get something bigger and more comfortable, maybe built to order, in a nice quiet suburb.

10-Year U.S. Notes Bring 7.25%
LEAD: The Treasury auctioned $9.75 billion of 7 1/4 percent 10-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 7.25 percent, the same interest rate obtained at the previous refunding sale last November.
Dealers said the result was expected after it became known that Japanese and other foreign investors were strongly interested in this maturity.

Race No. 4 And Heidi No. 2
LEAD: Damon Runyon's famous comment notwithstanding, the 1987 America's Cup competition struck a lot of television viewers as more exciting than watching grass grow.
Despite the late hour of ESPN's live telecasts from Australia, many East Coast viewers stayed up beyond 3 A.M. to watch the races to the very end.

MUSIC: IVO POGORELICH PIANO RECITAL
LEAD: IN a world overpopulated with steely-fingered athletes of the keyboard, what can a young artist do to set himself apart from the throng?
Ivo Pogorelich, the Yugoslav pianist who gave a recital last evening at Carnegie Hall, has solved the problem so successfully that although still in his 20's, he already has a thriving recording career and has acquired a sizable following for his live appearances.

BRIEFS
LEAD: *
American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said that until March 31 it would offer buyers of 1986 Renault Alliance and Encore models and 1987 Alliance and GTA models a choice of free air-conditioning or automatic transmission.
It also said it would give a $500 rebate to buyers of cars without those options.


CETUS INVESTMENT
LEAD: The Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said the MIP Equity Fund, based in The Hague, would invest $5 million in the developemnt of Cetus's Western European subsidiary.
The unit, EuroCetus B.V., will be based in Amsterdam.
MIP Equity, which had played an important role in Cetus's decision to locate the unit in the Netherlands, is making a five-year loan at 6 percent interest in return for warrants to purchase 165,800 shares of Cetus stock at $03 each; the warrants may be exercised after one year.

Conversations With Inouye
LEAD: As public officials go, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the chairman of the special Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra scandal, is surely one of the toughest to interview.

Topics: When Persistence Pays Off; Up Under
LEAD: Does the America's Cup belong to the United States?
No, no more than the Davis Cup belongs to Australia.
Cups belong to winners.
Hats off to Dennis Conner, his splendid crew and everyone else who collaborated in Stars &amp; Stripes' resounding victory in four straight races in the Indian Ocean.
With dazzling dedication to excellence, they earned it.


Dow Spurts 22.78 in Heavy Trading
LEAD: With oil stocks providing much of the punch, Wall Street yesterday scored another sizable gain, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to record levels just shy of the 2,200 mark.

LEAD: The Ohio Water Development Authority is tentatively offering $139.2 million of refunding bonds, with a maximum yield of 6.79 percent for those due in 2007, through underwriters led by the Donaldson, Lufkin &amp; Jenrette Securities Corporation.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.The siding on my house is rough sawn cedar.
I have been told not to caulk the joints where the boards overlap as the siding must breathe.
Is this true, and will caulking cause sweating and condensation?
A.It probably will not cause condensation, but it is unlikely to do much good: this siding is not meant to be very airtight.

White at Citadel Says Hazing Was Harmless
LEAD: A racial hazing incident at The Citadel, the military academy here, inflicted ''no harm or damage whatsover'' on the black cadet involved, one of the five white cadets in the case contends in court papers.


GERHARD KLOPFER, GENERAL IN TH SS
LEAD: Gerhard Klopfer, a former SS general who was the last surviving member of the 1942 Berlin conference that plotted the ''Final Solution'' to systematically kill European Jews, died Jan. 28.
He was 81 years old.


COUNTRYMAN UPSETS WILANDER
LEAD: An early-season tennis tournament is a lot like the first few days at school after the summer recess.
Minds tend to wander and work habits are sometimes poor.
It is when some of the better students of the game are more vulnerable than they are at any other time of year.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A table in Business Day on Jan. 28, showing short interest in Nasdaq stocks for the month ended Jan. 15, carried an incorrect total supplied by Imreg Inc. to the National Association of Securities Dealers for that company's class A stock.
As a result, the total Nasdaq short interest and the decline for the month were also given incorrectly.


Who Axed Military Raises?
LEAD: Amid all the discussion about big pay increases for members of Congress, judges and top civilians in Government, nobody seems willing to say just who rejected any real effort to get similar raises for top military officers.


Coleco Disclosure
LEAD: A legal dispute between MCA Inc. and Coleco Industries over rights to the ''King Kong'' name set off the talks that led to MCA's acquisition of a 9 percent stake in Coleco, according to Arnold C. Greenberg, Coleco's chairman and chief executive.
The dispute was settled as part of the agreement announced Tuesday.


MUSIC: LIBOVE AND LUGOVOY
LEAD: ALTHOUGH the violinist Charles Libove and the pianist Nina Lugovoy democratically billed their Monday-night program at Merkin Concert Hall as a joint recital, it was Mr.
Libove's lean, full tone and dapper technical expertise that made the evening a memorable one.


TIMES SQUARE: TRYING TO KEEP THE PANACHE
LEAD: That night in November 1965, when the electricity failed, Times Square disappeared.
While the rest of the city merely went dark, the square that with appropriate immodesty calls itself the crossroads of the world vanished in a blackness made more stygian because it so contrasted with the usual nocturnal blaze of glory that is its trademark.

LEAD: Random House has decided to file a request this week for a reconsideration of the recent Federal Appeals Court decision barring it from publishing an unauthorized biography of J. D. Salinger.
If the request is not granted, a spokesman for the publisher, Annik La Farge, said yesterday, Random House will ask the Supreme

Sampson Injures Knee
LEAD: This season has not gone smoothly for the Houston Rockets, who are 23-22 after reaching the championship round of the National Basketball Association playoffs last spring before losing to the Boston Celtics.
Now things are much worse.
Ralph Sampson, Houston's 7-foot-4-inch power forward and center, will probably miss the rest of the season after injuring his left knee in a game Tuesday night against the Denver Nuggets.

BROOKLYN YOUTH ACQUITTED IN SLAYING OF CATHOLIC PRIEST
LEAD: A Brooklyn youth who had told the police that he shot and killed a Roman Catholic priest during a sexual encounter last May was acquitted yesterday of murder charges in the slaying.


FOSTER CHILDREN TO BE ASSIGNED REGARDLESS OF RACE
LEAD: Children in need of foster care will not have to wait in hospitals or agencies for foster parents of the same race, top Koch administration officials said yesterday.
If guardians of other races or ethnic groups are available, they said, the children will be permitted to stay with them.


DOCTOR WITH AIDS BACK AT HOSPITAL
LEAD: A doctor with AIDS was suspended from clinical duties at Cook County Hosital Monday but was reinstated today over the objections of the hospital's medical director.


SIX YOUNG FASHION DESIGNERS: CREATIVITY ON THE HOME FRONT
LEAD: MIRIAM BENDAHAN, a designer of elegant evening dresses, greeted a guest in the doorway of her three-room East Village tenement walk-up.
Or more precisely, in its kitchen, between her bathtub, which holds a dish rack, and a plank supporting a jagged piece of mirror - her vanity.
Two shoes, painted silver to match her kitchen walls, were hanging above the door.


HOW TECHNOLOGY CAN BREED BOREDOM
LEAD: THE purpose of better technology, as anyone knows, is to foster laziness and sloth among the populace.
That's what's going on with the up-and-coming formats for prerecorded music, the cassette (which now commands considerably more than half the market) and the compact disk.
While they've been coming into their own, popular music has encouraged basking rather than rocking out - a tendency that fits right in with the new technology.

USX TO SHUT 3 PLANTS, CUT 3,700 JOBS
LEAD: The USX Corporation said today that it would ''indefinitely idle'' three steelmaking operations and part of a fourth.
The action reduces USX's steelmaking capacity by more than a fourth and trims its work force by about 3,700 employees.


IRAN SAID TO ORDER U.S. REPORTER'S OUSTER
LEAD: Iran said today that it had ordered the expulsion of an American journalist detained four days ago and subsequently charged with espionage.

Bond Granted in Bomb Case
LEAD: A Federal magistrate granted a $95,000 property bond today for a former member of the radical Weather Underground who faces a charge of conspiring to bomb a building at the University of Washington in 1970.
Magistrate John Weinberg granted the bond for Silas Trim Bissell, who was arrested Jan. 20 after being a fugitive since 1970.

LEO CASTELLI TAKES STOCK OF 30 YEARS OF SELLING ART
LEAD: Leo Castelli, whose celebrated gallery has played a key role in shaping American art over the last three decades, admits to a certain bafflement about the current scene.
The man who has tirelessly promoted such movements as Pop, Minimal, Conceptual and Neo-Expressionist art, and such talents as Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg, Frank Stella, Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein and Julian Schnabel, confesses that - as he approaches his 80th birthday - he really doesn't ''know where things are going.


CONCERT: ORFORD QUARTET
LEAD: THE Orford String Quartet, a Canadian ensemble now in its 21st year, appeared Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y for a most interesting concert.
The interest lay not in the boldness of the repertory, which was entirely conventional, nor in the seemingly ordinary fact that these musicians applied an intense, dramatic style to the music at hand.


Test on Redesigned Rocket For Shuttle Called Inadequte
LEAD: Robert L. Gibson, an astronaut, said he doubted that one of a series of tests planned for the redesigned solid-fuel booster rocket on the space shuttle will be adequate to prove its safety.

LEAD: Six North Carolina basketball players are either sick or injured and it was not known how many would be able to play in tonight's game against North Carolina State.
Among the starters, only J. R. Reid is healthy.
The injury list: Kenny Smith (surgical knee), Joe Wolf (flu), Jeff Lebo (flu), Dave Popson (bruised leg), Rodney Hyatt (stress fracture in leg), Scott Williams (bruised thigh).

It is undergoing changes that have been brought on, in no small part, by its own success.

Piedmont Aviation Gains

Revenues rose 22.1 percent, to $509.8 million.

BEREFT OF REFS
LEAD: The team from Jersey City State was there, the Kean College team was there, and so were cheerleaders and a couple of hundred fans.

There were no referees, and when it became apparent that they weren't going to show up, everybody else did the logical thing.


AUCTIONS
LEAD: WRISTWATCHES - one of the most popular collectibles of the 1980's - will be auctioned tomorrow at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street.
Outstanding among the more than 400 examples is a 1909 minute repeater by Audemars Piguet, an ultra-thin platinum dress watch that is a rarity, according to Daryn Schnipper, one of Sotheby's watch specialists.

Corrections
LEAD: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday misidentified a Utah Jazz player who failed to score in a basketball game Nov. 1.
He is Kelly Tripucka, who was traded to Utah by Detroit last summer, and not Kiki Vandeweghe, who plays for Portland.

SCIENTISTS VERIFY FOSSILS OF GIANT APE
LEAD: Two American anthropologists say they have verified the existence of a potentially rich trove of fossil relics in the mountains of northern Vietnam, some of which may shed light on the origins of man and his close relatives.


2 MILLION CHILDREN STAY HOME ALONE
LEAD: More than two million American youngsters spend at least some time unsupervised after school, with the largest share in white upper-income households, the Census Bureau reported today.

LEAD: Arms control advocates in Congress and among the Western allies expressed concern today about reports that the Reagan Administration may interpret the ABM treaty of 1972 to allow extensive testing of some ''Star Wars'' systems and accelerate their deployment.

Tenneco Notes
LEAD: The Tenneco Credit Company is offering $250 million of 8 3/8 percent notes due 1997 at 99 7/8 to yield 8.393 percent, or 1.2 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
Noncallable for seven years, the notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.&amp;P.


Exchange With Italy
LEAD: More than 25 artists and groups from New York - representing theater, opera, dance and music - will perform this month in Italy at the Carnival of Venice.
Italian artists will take part in the International Festival of the Arts to be held in New York next year.
Martin E. Segal, the chairman of the New York festival, and Italy's Consul General, Francesco Corrias, announced the exchange at a press conference yesterday.

The Highway Bill: Too Dear, Too Slow; Demonstrate Sense, Not Pork
LEAD: Last year the Democratic House and the Republican Senate failed to agree on highway aid, so there was none.
Now each has passed its bill again, and despite the change in control of the Senate, the same two issues divide them just as passionately.
The Senate still supports relaxing the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit and resists a whole list of pork barrel projects that the House would hand out along with regular highway funds.

LEAD: The venture capital industry, which has nurtured the growth of hundreds of high-technology companies such as Apple Computer, Genentech and Lotus Development, is shifting its focus to more mundane investments that have little to do with technological innovation or creating new jobs.

The Tyranny of One-Handed Doctors
LEAD: Webster's dictionary defines ''athlete'' as ''a person trained in exercises, games or contests requiring physical strength, skill, stamina, or speed.'' As both an athlete and a surgeon, I have long felt that surgeons, at least the great ones, possess all of the attributes of athletes.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 379 money market mutual funds increased $1.76 billion, to $236.02 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $492.3 million, to $65.77 billion.
Assets of the 196 general purpose funds were up $475.5 million, to $62.83 billion.

LEAD: The nation's largest general retailers reported mixed sales results for January, but analysts did not attach much significance to the figures announced yesterday because the first month of the year is a slow time for stores.

Flower Power
LEAD: Uncle Sam may soon sabotage St.
Valentine's Day.
The International Trade Commission is considering invoking sweeping penalties and duties on imported flowers, which could possibly double the cost of flowers sold on the streets of American cities.
This is a nice example of the inane application of our trade regulations and of the idiotic system that could subjugate the interests of millions of consumers to the benefit of a few hundred farmers.

LEAD: The diplomatic climate between the United States and Poland, frozen by President Reagan a half-dozen years ago over the suppression of the Solidarity labor movement, is continuing to warm as spring approaches.

Brazil Eases Price Controls
LEAD: Brazil today dismantled most price controls, a key feature of a nearly year-old battle against rampant inflation, because of widespread shortages and mounting opposition from business executives.

LEAD: The takeover of the Harris Graphics Corporation last year and a $5.3 million invoice to Ivan F. France to Sell 1/2 of Network
LEAD: France's Government put up for sale a controlling interest in one of the state's most glamorous holdings, TF1, the country's oldest and most prestigious television network.
The announcement, the latest in a series involving the sale of Government properties, said the price would be three billion francs, or about $500 million.


METS, GOODEN EAGER TO AGREE
LEAD: The Mets appeared to be avoiding another off-the-field headache yesterday when Dwight Gooden's agent said that it was ''overwhelmingly desirable'' for both sides to agree on a contract without going to arbitration.


REAL ESTATE AGENCY, IN HONOR OF TENANTS, HELPS NEEDIEST
LEAD: A gift of $2,412 from Mountbatten Equities, a real estate concern, was among those that have been made to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The donation was made ''in honor of the tenants of the Printing House,'' an apartment building at 421 Hudson Street in lower Manhattan.

LEAD: In the beginning, it was merely a game between teams enduring seasons of trouble.
But it became a small ray of hope for the Knicks and just another distressing defeat for the Nets, who have tumbled so far that the annual break for this weekend's All-Star Game has become a welcome relief.

LEAD: Last summer, a New York City man who doesn't know much about art but knows what he likes fell head over heels in love with Helga, Andrew Wyeth's fascinating model.
Now he's crestfallen.
In May, 140 of Mr.
Wyeth's Helga paintings will go on exhibit at the National Gallery in Washington and then travel to five other cities.

LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor discussed his Middle East trip yesterday with seven American Moslem leaders and said afterward that the meeting was held to balance one held two weeks ago with Jewish leaders.


NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1987
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-9  Concern about ''Star Wars'' systems is rising among some members of Congress and Western allies.
The Reagan Administration may interpret the 1972 ABM treaty to allow testing of the systems and speed their deployment.
Page A1  More than 400 people were arrested as they tried to enter a nuclear weapons testing site in Nevada after nearly 2,000 people, including six members of Congress, held a rally protesting the arms testing.


BASEBALL FEVER ON THE RISE IN AUSTRALIA
LEAD: Now that the America's Cup is over, and the touring British cricketers have returned home, many Australian sports fans are turning their attention to the final championship games of a growing phenomenon here: baseball.


HUGE PROJECT ON COLUMBUS CIRCLE IS APPROVED BY BOARD OF ESTIMATE
LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate voted early this morning in favor of a huge redevelopment plan for Columbus Circle, with only one vote cast against it.


Ex-C.I.A. Director Is Mugged
LEAD: William E. Colby, the former Director of Central Intelligence, was beaten and robbed while walking near his Georgetown home last Friday, the District of Columbia Police said today.
Mr.
Colby was approached by four people who demanded money and then knocked him to the ground when he said he had none, said Officer Walter Ferguson.


LOWER EAST SIDE A MAINSTAY FOR MUSIC
LEAD: The real-estate boom, the rise in the legal drinking age and increased downtown tourism have taken a toll on the Lower East Side's music scene - particularly on weekends, when clubs fill up with or without live performers.
But a few stalwart places continue to present music, and visitors to the Lower East


Randy Lanier Sought
LEAD: Randy Lanier, last year's Indianapolis 500 Rookie of the Year, was being sought in several states yesterday after failing to show up in Federal court in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Wednesday on charges of racketeering for participating in a marijuana smuggling ring.
Lanier has also been named to a six-count Federal grand jury indictment in Southern Illinois contending he engaged ''in an enterprise to distribute'' more than 1,000 pounds of marijuana over a six-year period.

BOULDER, AN ECLECTIC CITY, TACKLES MATTERS OF TASTE
LEAD: Depending on the point of view, this city's new urban design plan is either a visionary document that will protect historical architecture or a quagmire of unnecessary guidelines remniscent of the anti-business attitudes here in the 1960's.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Maureen McGovern, Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street (888-1633).
Listening to Maureen McGovern's hit versions of theme songs for 70's disaster movies (''The Morning After'' from ''The Poseidon Adventure'' and ''We May Never Love Like This Again,'' from ''The Towering Inferno''), one could never have guessed that a decade later the singer would be hailed as the most technically accomplished pop-jazz singer on New York's cabaret circuit.


WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  BALINESE DANCE  Midwinter Manhattan may seem a long way from the island of Bali, but this weekend the magic of this tropical paradise will be more than in the air.
With opulent masks and exotic sounds, Islene Pinder's Balinese American Dance Theater will re-create a journey of demons and deities when the company performs ''Eden'' and ''Night Shadow'' at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace.

GREATER ACCESS TO TERRORISM DATA IS SOUGHT FOR IMMIGRATION AGENCY
LEAD: The Reagan Administration is preparing plans to identify and deport aliens with links to international terrorism who could support or plan violence inside the United States, according to Administration officials and documents.


FILM: 'DEAD OF WINTER,' A GOTHIC HORROR TALE
LEAD: THE star plays three women, one of them mostly dead.
The setting is a huge, isolated mansion filled with unnerving decorating touches, like the polar bear in the parlor.
The town is the kind of place where they give you free goldfish when you buy gas, and nobody thinks that's peculiar.
And the villain likes to tell eerie little stories about President McKinley, which are lies.

FILM: 'COME AND SEE,' FROM SOVIET
LEAD: THE terrible central event of ''Come and See,'' which takes up about a quarter of the 2-hour, 22-minute Soviet movie now at the Bleecker Street Cinema, is the burning of a Byelorussian village by German invaders in 1943.
A line on the screen tells us that hundreds of villages in the Soviet republic east of Poland were destroyed, their people annihilated.


BOMB NEAR OFFICIAL'S HOMES IN CAPE TOWN INJURES WOMAN
LEAD: A bomb blasted the roof off a bus shelter today about 330 yards from President P. W. Botha's house in the Groote Schuur Estate, the police said.
A young white woman was wounded.
The bus stop is on a main road about 15 feet from the gate to the estate, where several Cabinet ministers live.


APPLIANCES, RULES AND POLITICS HAVE SENATORS IN AN UPROAR
LEAD: A testy Senate floor fight erupted today involving a bill on household appliances, parliamentary rules, a hasty car ride from the White House by the Vice President and - most important - a political struggle that placed Democrats on the offensive against Republicans.


STATE TO SEEK REVERSAL ON WEDTECH PLEA DEAL
LEAD: State prosecutors will try again today to get a judge in Manhattan to accept a complicated plea arrangement in the Wedtech bribery investigation.


Amtrak Inquiry Takes a Turn
LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that it had asked the authorities in Baltimore County, Md., to search a section of the Gunpowder River for a television set that might be related to the January collision between an Amtrak passenger train and a unit of Conrail engines.
A spokesman said the safety board received a tip that a television set had been tossed into the river shortly after the accident.


RETALIATION FEARS STIR ALERT
LEAD: A former Colombian state senator identified by Federal officials as one of the world's biggest and most violent drug traffickers was placed under heavy guard today in Florida after his late-night extradition from Colombia.

LEAD: HARD as it is to believe, the brilliant director of ''The Return of Martin Guerre'' has now made an idiotic comedy about a paleontologist, some women and some bones.
The bones, being silent, have a definite advantage over the other players.

LEAD: More than 400 people were arrested today when they tried to enter the nation's nuclear proving grounds here after nearly 2,000 demonstrators, including six members of Congress, held a rally to protest nuclear weapons testing.

A VALENTINE SHOW THAT SHOOTS ARROWS TIPPED WITH SATIRE
LEAD: WHEN the Ballroom, a staid restaurant-cabaret in Chelsea, recently decided to present comedy as well as music on a regular basis, a brilliant, virtually unknown 18-member troupe of satirists calling themselves Artificial Intelligence stole the show at the club's opening-night marathon.
Impersonating a film crew from the fictitious Beacon network and swarming through the club with video equipment, the troupe turned the Ballroom into a make-believe television studio, where it ''filmed'' (though no film was actually rolling) a 1967 variety show entitled ''Vicki's Valentine Thing.


Holocaust Council Chief
LEAD: President Reagan is expected to name Harvey M. Meyerhoff, a Baltimore real estate developer and philanthropist, to succeed Elie Wiesel as chairman of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council.
When he resigned the chairmanship in December, Mr.
Wiesel said the project needed a leader who knows ''a lot more about management and architecture than I do.


BROADWAY
LEAD: THERE are all kinds of wonderful theater things going on at the moment - in London, it's true, but don't sniff and say ''So what?'' They're all headed here - a few of them fairly soon - and two of the big ones were born in America.


JWT Group to Report Fourth-Quarter Loss
LEAD: The JWT Group, whose chief executive a week ago put down a palace revolt brought on at least partly by the company's financial performance, reported yesterday that the picture might be darker than expected.


15 of Philadelphia's Judges Suspended Pending Inquiry
LEAD: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has ordered 15 judges of Philadelphia courts to leave the bench pending an investigation of allegations involving cash gifts from a union local seeking favorable treatment for its members.


Back To the Constitution
LEAD: President Reagan's loss of authority since disclosure of his Iran policy has brought renewed talk that our constitutional system is not working.
There must be something basically wrong, it is said, when three Presidents in 20 years win overwhelming election victories only, in time, to lose effective power.


Iceland Acting on Bank
LEAD: Iceland will go ahead with privatizing Utvegsbanki, the country's second-largest bank, officials said today.
The bank lost most of its capital on bad loans last year.


Sooner Sledder
LEAD: When Mike Aljoe, a defensive end and special-teams player at Oklahoma, saw a television commercial in which a bobsled plowed through a huge wall of shaving cream, he was intrigued enough to call the United States Bobsled Federation and ask a few questions.
Within five days of Oklahoma's victory in the Orange Bowl last month, Aljoe was encamped at Lake Placid, learning how to be the brakeman on a two-man sled with Randy Will, the American team's rookie of the year for 1985-86, and a pusher, in the third position, on a four-man sled with Will, Brian Wolf and Craig

Ex-Senator Pisani Released
LEAD: Former State Senator Joseph R. Pisani was released yesterday from a Federal prison in Kentucky where he was serving a sentence for tax evasion.
Mr.
Pisani, 56 years old, is scheduled to arrive at a halfway house in Manhattan to serve the remaining five months of his jail term.
The former state senator, who represented the 36th District in Westchester for 19 years, was sentenced to one year and a day in a minimum-security prison after pleading guilty last summer to failing to report $27,000 he received as income in 1979.


ABC Said to Plan 'Amerika' Disclaimer
LEAD: ABC, which has been criticized by the United Nations for its mini-series ''Amerika,'' has agreed to run a disclaimer at the beginning of the show stating that institutions portrayed in it are fictional, a source involved in negotiations with the network said today.


G.M. Profit Fell 26.1% Last Year
LEAD: Two of the Big Three auto makers today reported earnings declines for 1986, as the industry began to close the books on its fourth prosperous year in a row.

Antitrust Suit On Ethyl Deal
LEAD: The Justice Department said it intends to file an antitrust suit challenging the Ethyl Corporation's proposed $55 million acquisition of the Dow Chemical Company's Bromine and Brominated Chemicals division.


FILM: 'THE ASSAULT,' A TALE OF WAR
LEAD: IT is an ordinary day in the Netherlands during January 1945, or a day as ordinary as an occupied nation can know.
The Steenwijk family, having pulled down its blackout shades and had its paltry dinner, is at the end of a reasonably peaceful evening.
Then shots are heard.
A well-known and hated collaborator has been assassinated in front of the house next door, and his body has been moved to the Steenwijk's, who will now be held responsible for the crime.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: The Providence College basketball coach, Rick Pitino, apologized yesterday for berating the officiating crew following the Friars' 67-66 loss Tuesday night to Boston College. ''Officiating college baskeball is probably the most difficult job in the world,'' Pitino said in a statement. ''Although our game was a bitter pill to swallow, my remarks directed toward the men with the whistle were out of line and uncharacteristic of my respect for them.


BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1987
LEAD: Markets  The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 2,200 in a surge of trading that also lifted broader-based market indicators to new highs.
In a day marked by sharp price swings, the Dow added 10.26 points to close at 2,201.49.
Volume was 256.7 million shares, the second-busiest session on record.

Mariner Wins Case
LEAD: Phil Bradley, the Seattle Mariners' perennial .300 hitter, won his salary arbitration case for the second consecutive year yesterday, becoming the first two-time winner since Mario Soto of Cincinnati won in 1982-83.
Neil Gundermann, the arbitrator, awarded Bradley a $750,000 salary over the $550,000 the Mariners sought.

LEAD: IN Newark, the young know when a couple of guys come up and say, ''pass off,'' they mean give up your fur-collared bomber jacket, or you can get shot.

LEAD: Iran said yesterday that Gerald F. Seib, an American reporter detained on espionage charges, would be expelled within 24 hours, and there were unconfirmed reports last night that he had already left Teheran.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo said today that he had met over the last seven days with key national political strategists and that he would decide within two weeks whether to take preliminary steps toward running for President.


A Number on Kemp
LEAD: The Jack Kemp for President Exploratory Committee is backing a 1988 Presidential hopeful who is regarded by many Democrats and even some of his fellow Republicans as so conservative as to exemplify an earlier era in American political life.
So when the committee announced the opening of its Arlington, Va., headquarters and the press phone number (247-1936) there, John Buckley, the Kemp press secretary, felt it necessary to add: ''There should be no historical inferences drawn from the final four digits of the press office's phone number.

'21' PATRONS: LOST SHEEP, FOR A TIME
LEAD: Felix G. Rohatyn is lunching at his desk more often.
Eileen Ford is surviving on Chinese carryout food and deli sandwiches.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An Associated Press dispatch from Miami in some copies on Wednesday about the murder of Don Aronow misidentified the kind of boat used on the ''Miami Vice'' television show.
It is a model made by Wellcraft, not a Cigarette model made by Mr.
Aronow.


Xerox Unit Buys Stake
LEAD: A newly formed subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation said today that it had acquired a 25 percent equity interest in VMS Realty Partners Inc., a Chicago-based real estate syndicate, for $80 million.
Xerox, which is based in Stamford, Conn., had said earlier this week that it was considering such a deal in an effort to expand its financial services business.

Reports Bolster Dollar; Gold Rallies After Fall
LEAD: The dollar rose yesterday, bolstered by growing expectations that the major industrial countries will mobilize and take measures to stem the currency's protracted decline.


Ford Widening 6-Year Warranty
LEAD: Officials of the Ford Motor Company said the company's six-year and 60,000-mile powertrain warranty would be extended to light trucks and vans as well as cars.
The warranty is retroactive to the beginning of the 1987 model year. ''The warranty war is over,'' said Louis E. Lataif, Ford's vice president for sales.


Attacking Arms Control, and Arms
LEAD: The Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972 is in peril.
Almost alone among arms control agreements, it has helped prevent nuclear war, sharply curtailing the development of a dangerous mix of defensive and offensive forces.
Now President Reagan appears ready to launch a double-barreled attack against the treaty.


L.I. 'SUMMIT' PRODUCES JOINT APPROACH TO ISSUES
LEAD: Long Island's top government officials, holding what they called the first-ever ''summit meeting'' between the leaders of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, agreed today to work jointly to solve several regional problems.


U.S. MAY SEEK END TO LOCAL VETOING OF NUCLEAR PLANTS
LEAD: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has drafted a proposal that would permit the agency to license nuclear plants like those in Shoreham, L.I., and Seabrook, N.H., for full operation over the objections of state or local authorities, the agency said today.


CARL R. ROGERS, 85, LEADER IN PSYCHOTHERAPY, DIES
LEAD: Carl R. Rogers, a popular author and preeminent American psychotherapist whose influence has spanned decades, died Wednesday night of a heart attack after surgery for a broken hip at the Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, Calif.
He was 85 years old.
Dr.
Rogers, a psychologist, was known for developing the client-centered approach to psychotherapy, in which the therapist maintains an accepting and empathic stance toward the patient and lets the patient take the lead in the focus, pace and direction of therapy.

FILM: 'BLACK WIDOW,' FROM BOB RAFELSON
LEAD: BOB RAFELSON'S ''Black Widow,'' with its good, flashy star-performances by Debra Winger and Theresa Russell, comes on with the seductiveness of an expensive perfume that inevitably evaporates before the night is over.

Diner's Journal
LEAD: ARQUA is a rustic village in northeastern Italy and the home of the 14th-century poet and philosopher Petrarch.
It also is the name of an engaging new restaurant housed in a towering former commercial retail space in TriBeCa.
Opened five weeks ago, it is quickly gaining a downtown following for its original and lovingly prepared pastas, herb-scented grilled entrees and homemade desserts.


Church's Reports Talks With Sonic
LEAD: Church's Fried Chicken Inc., the nation's second-largest fast-food chicken operation, said today that it had been asked to consider the possibility of a takeover bid from Sonic Industries Inc.


Judge Orders Atlanta Suburb To Let Klan March Tomorrow
LEAD: A Federal District judge ruled today that city officials in an Atlanta suburb must allow the Ku Klux Klan to stage a march Saturday.
The judge, William C. O'Kelley, ruled that College Park, the suburb, must grant the parade permit to the white supremacist group.
The town had sought to deny it unless the organization agreed to pay $3,085 for police overtime.


THE TRAINING OF NEW POLICE OFFICERS
LEAD: Recruits standing in formation during a drill on ''Zero Day,'' last day of a week of orientation lessons before regular training at the Police Academy on East 20th Street.
Page B1. (NYT/Neal Boenzi)


U.S. PLEDGES AID TO SOUTH AFRICA'S NEIGHBORS
LEAD: The senior American aid official today pledged $93 million in new aid to support joint efforts by southern African countries to reduce their economic dependence on South Africa.


DANCE: BALLET RAMBERT IN THREE ALSTON WORKS
LEAD: BALLET RAMBERT looked casual on Wednesday night.
Too casual, perhaps.
The program - the second in a weeklong engagement at the City Center Theater, 131 West 55th Street - included three works by the British company's artistic director, Richard Alston.
Everyone was amiable in Mr.
Alston's ''Java.'' Indeed, to employ a slang term, the dancers even seemed laid back in this choreographic suite to old recordings by the Ink Spots.


RESTAURANTS
LEAD: AN enigmatic portrait of a 1930's starlet by Man Ray, the Surrealist photographer, keeps you slightly on edge as you sit at the bar and sip an aperitif at Chelsea's hottest new bistro.
Art Deco light fixtures and spindly wooden bar stools from vintage Paris Metro cars contribute to the period setting, where the focus is on ingenuous


GIRL WAS SEXUALLY ASSAULTED AT TWO CHILD CENTERS
LEAD: A teen-age girl, brought into the New York City child-care system after she accused two members of her adoptive family of raping her, suffered sexual assaults at two children's centers and then was sent back to the home she had fled, law-enforcement sources say.


Mother and Baby Are Stabbed to Death
LEAD: A mother and her 2-year-old daughter were found stabbed to death in their Bronx apartment when the woman's husband returned home from work yesterday, the police said.


JESSE MOORE, A TOP NASA AIDE, QUITS
LEAD: Jesse W. Moore, who gave the final approval to the fatal launching of the space shuttle Challenger, has resigned from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the agency announced today.

BUILDER SAYS THE ACTION IS NOW IN JERSEY SUBURBS
LEAD: For years conventional wisdom had it that the hub of the action was Manhattan if you wanted to be successful in metropolitan area real estate.
Commercial properties in center city for sure, and residential as close as possible.

LEAD: The Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio, featuring the pianist Joseph Kalichstein, the violinist Jaime Laredo and the cellist Sharon Robinson, will play music by Mendelssohn, Schubert and Haydn at Montclair (N.J.) High School Community Auditorium Sunday afternoon at 3:30, at the corner of Chestnut and Park Streets in Montclair, under the auspices of Unity Concerts.

Lemieux Gets Clearance
LEAD: Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh Penguins center who outpolled Wayne Gretzky in the fan balloting for the National Hockey League All-Star team that meets the Soviet National Team in the two-game Rendez-Vous '87 series next week, has been given medical clearance to play. ''I have three more games to play before Rendez-Vous,'' Lemieux said.


Young Man in a Hurry
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky scored his 50th goal of 1986-87 Wednesday night, in the 55th game of Edmonton's season.
After only eight years in the N.H.L., Gretzky now claims four of the 10 earliest arrivals at the 50-goal plateau in league history.

BONDS UP IN STRONG DEMAND
LEAD: Greater-than-expected demand from speculators and solid buying by foreign investors at the Treasury's 30-year bond auction yesterday caused prices of outstanding issues to rise sharply.


Woman, 25, Dies in Plunge
LEAD: A 25-year-old woman from Manhattan, Katherine Alexander, daughter of Shana Alexander, the journalist and author, plunged to her death last night, apparently in a suicide.
The body was found in a yard behind the apartment building on Park Avenue at 59th Street where she lived with her mother.
According to a police spokesman, Officer Peter O'Donnell, Miss Alexander, who had been under psychiatric care, apparently jumped from an upper floor or the roof of the building.


SENATORS CHALLENGE OFFICIALS ON CONTRAS
LEAD: Two senior Administration officials encountered heated, skeptical cross-examination today from Democratic senators about the military effectiveness of the Nicaraguan rebels and the Administration's commitment to a negotiated settlement in Central America.


ALLIES REJECT A U.S. PLAN TO MEET ON HOSTAGES
LEAD: The Reagan Administration has been rebuffed in its plan to convene a conference with six major allies to discuss coordinated responses to the continued hostage-taking in Lebanon, White House and State Department officials said today.

2 Latin-Jazz Groups
LEAD: The percussionist Mongo Santamaria and the pianist Michel Camilo will each lead Latin-jazz groups in a double bill tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592).
Shows begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M., with a 1:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, a $7.50 music charge at the bar.

Now that ''The Seasons'' can be seen through March 7 at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway, at Spring

LEAD: Corporations have given almost everything imaginable to nonprofit groups at one time or another.
Now an internationally famous research center can be added to the list.

The two pieces on Twyla Tharp's second program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Wednesday night have both been seen in previous incarnations.

AT THE MOVIES
LEAD: MORE than anything else, the various episodes of Woody Allen's ''Radio Days'' are held together by the music of the late 1930's to mid-1940's - the highly structured songs with sweetly genteel lyrics that not only provide background for the film but also establish its emotional center.

A SEQUEL IS AUTHORIZED FOR 'GONE WITH THE WIND'
LEAD: ''Gone With the Wind,'' one of the most popular novels and motion pictures of all time, is about to get a sequel.
The estate of the author, Margaret Mitchell, has authorized it, the William Morris Agency has found someone to write the book, and when the motion picture or television mini-series based on the new book is written, the agency will handle the arrangements.


TRADING SURGE PUSHES THE DOW BEYOND 2,200
LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average broke another ''century'' mark yesterday, closing above 2,200 for the first time.


Prosecutor to Review Action by Legislator
LEAD: The Albany County District Attorney said today that he might investigate possible state crimes committed by an Assemblywoman who testified last month in Federal court that she had added two ''no-show'' jobs to her office payroll.


State Board Plans Raise for Jockeys
LEAD: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has proposed an amendment to its rules that would increase the minimum fees paid to jockeys who ride the second and third finishers in races with purses of $25,000 or more.
Riders of second- and third-place horses in these races ar now paid $150 and $100, respectively.


RACISM BLAMED FOR BRAWL AT U. OF MASSACHUSETTS
LEAD: A melee among students on the Amherst campus of the University of Massachusetts after the last World Series game was ''predictable, preventable and primarily racially motivated,'' according to a report by a member of the Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination.

Market Place; Schoellkopf's Apparel Stake
LEAD: AN investment firm that is part of the financial empire of Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf - by some accounts the nation's wealthiest woman - has increased its stake in the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, the Manhattan-based apparel company.


George W. Woodruff, Atlanta Philanthropist
LEAD: George W. Woodruff, a director of the Coca-Cola Company for 49 years and a major contributor to education and medicine in Georgia, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Emory University Hospital.
He was 91 years old.

Toll Increase to Begin For Crossings in City
LEAD: Automobile tolls on the major crossings operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority will rise to $2 from $1.75 after midnight tonight.
Tolls for trucks and other vehicles will also rise proportionately.


Salomon's Coup: 45% Of Japanese Offering
LEAD: Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. scored a coup in the Japanese Government bond market earlier this week when it bought about 45 percent of a recent 100-billion-yen issue of two-year notes, according to sources at the Ministry of Finance.


Babbitt Sets a Date
LEAD: Former Gov.
Bruce Babbitt of Arizona may not be the first Democrat to formally enter the party's 1988 Presidential competition, but he is the first to announce when he will announce.
The word out of Phoenix is that Mr.
Babbitt will officially become a candidate on March 11, with an appearance at his national headquarters in the Arizona capital and a cross-country flight featuring speeches in Iowa, where the first Presidential caucuses will be held in mid-February next year, and in New Hampshire, where the first primary takes place a week later.


ART: 'OUT OF THE STUDIO,' COMMUNITY SETTINGS
LEAD: ''OUT OF THE STUDIO: Art With Community'' is surely the most ambitious attempt to explore the possibilities of art made within a community environment.
The artists invited by P.S. 1 have been making work for or in collaboration with a particular community for some time.
For each one, the idea of the artist working alone in a studio, making art that can be approached solely within a gallery context, has little or no appeal.


London Printers to End Fight With Murdoch
LEAD: Britain's largest printing union voted tonight to stop its yearlong protest against the publisher Rupert Murdoch, effectively ending the country's most serious industrial dispute since the coal miners' strike of 1984- 85.


Queens High Schools Handled Tensions Well
LEAD: To the Editor:


Bridge: Card Table Provides Outlet For Clash of Public Agencies
LEAD: Medieval arguments were sometimes settled by nominating two heroes who would then joust against each other.
One can daydream pleasantly about the possibility of settling modern disputes at the bridge table or some other recreational arena.


ART PEOPLE
LEAD: IN December 1981, Andrzej Czeczot was imprisoned by the martial-law Government in Poland.


Connecticut Demurs
LEAD: To the Editor:


Examination for Flatley
LEAD: Patrick Flatley of the Islanders, who injured his left knee Wednesday night during the team's 4-1 loss in Vancouver, returned to New York yesterday with suspected ligament damage.
Flatley, who suffered the injury after being checked by a Canucks player, was examined by Vancouver's team doctors after the game and sent home on their recommendation.


A SEX BARRIER FOR CANTORS IS BROKEN
LEAD: The Jewish Theological Seminary of America announced yesterday that it would for the first time certify women as cantors to lead services in Conservative congregations around the world.


Rosco Gordon to Play
LEAD: The rhythm-and-blues pianist-singer Rosco Gordon will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (473-8908).
Shows are around 9:30 P.M. and midnight, with the Holmes Brothers opening tonight and the blues singer John Campbell opening tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.


A CHANCE TO JAM FOR 'OFFICE TYPES'
LEAD: DR.
Robert Litwack, a senior cardiothoracic surgeon at Mount Sinai Hospital, performs surgery at all hours most weekdays - except Fridays at noon, when he plays the drums.

15 INDICTED IN PRIMARY-PETITION FORGERIES
LEAD: Fifteen people have been indicted on charges of forging signatures on primary petitions for two candidates in 1985, the Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday.


Atom Technician Ends His Fast in Israeli Jail

GROMYKO SAYS A-TESTS SOUR TIES
LEAD: President Andrei A. Gromyko told former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today that the latest nuclear test in Nevada was part of an American effort to sour relations with the Soviet Union, the Tass press agency said.

Reagan's 76th
LEAD: From available reports, the White House is resisting the opportunity to make ''Seventy-six Trombones'' the theme of President Reagan's birthday of the same number today.
Instead of marching bands, there will be a low-key in-house observance, consonant with the President's continuing recovering from prostate surgery last month.


U.S. RULES OUT WEAPONS ON PLANNED SPACE STATION
LEAD: The Reagan Administration will rule out deploying major weapons systems on a proposed space station but will allow some Pentagon research to go forward, Government officials said today.

FILM: 'LIGHT OF DAY,' A ROCK SAGA
LEAD: THERE'S a make-or-break moment in Paul Schrader's ''Light of Day'' in which Joan Jett, the hard-rock singer-guitarist who plays a similar type of musician in the film, announces, ''I've been tryin' to live my life by an idea!'' Part of the audience is sure to find this ridiculous - and not without reason, since the character she plays is an unmarried, unfit mother who spends most of her time in high-decibel dives.

Goldin-Boesky Calls Under Investigation
LEAD: The New York City Department of Investigation said yesterday that it had started a ''formal inquiry'' into telephone calls by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin to raise money for an investment concern headed by Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator.


DIGITAL IS EXPECTED TO INTRODUCE MODEL
LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation is expected to introduce next week a desktop-size computer work station able to do the chores that Digital machines as big as a room did a decade ago.


CONNORS SHOWS ENDURANCE IN VICTORY
LEAD: His first clenched fist came after the 11th game of the third set, when he broke Scott Davis and was only one game from victory.
The fire that Jimmy Connors has stoked for 16 years on the professional tour is slowly being reduced to embers, and even Connors understands it is best to conserve his energy now, saving it for the points that are getting increasingly more difficult to win.

CONCERT: NEW WORKS BY TEITLEBAUM
LEAD: WE still think of electronic music as a brand-new art form, but by now there are composers who have made a life out of it.
Richard Teitelbaum, who presented a most appealing concert Wednesday night at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street, has been involved with electronics as a composer and performer for 20 years and counting.

LEAD: New York will honor Dennis Conner and his victorious Stars &amp; Stripes crew with a parade up Fifth Avenue on Tuesday, and Donald J. Trump will foot the bill, he and Mayor Koch said yesterday.

LEAD: Arizona, one of two states cited by the Federal Government last year for inadequately enforcing the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit, recently got its lumps: a fine of 1 percent of its Federal highway funds, or $510,000.
This slap on the wrist adds to the speed law's history of hypocrisy.

LEAD: Yoav Talmi will lead the New York Chamber Symphony in a program of works by Mendelssohn, Mozart, Beethoven and Barber at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 3.
David Bar-Illan will be the soloist in a performance of Mendelssohn's Piano Concerto No. 1 in G minor.

The performance will feature works by noted dancers who were students or faculty members at the school, among them Paul Taylor, Jose Limon and Anthony Tudor.

The Marshes of Mesopotamia
LEAD: The fog of battle still swirls over the marshes around Basra.
Iraq, loaded with weapons and usually loath to commit infantry, seems unable to dislodge the Iranians completely from the outskirts of Basra, its second largest city.
If Iraq's counterattacks fail, Iran may yet gain an advantage that threatens America's objective in the war, peace through stalemate.

QUEENSBORO BRIDGE PLAN TO ADD TO TRAFFIC WOES
LEAD: Congestion on the Queensboro Bridge - already expected to increase as drivers seek to avoid today's toll increase at other East River crossings -will be even more seriously compounded after Feb. 18.
On that Wednesday, the city and the state are to begin a reconstruction of half of the bridge's upper roadway that is expected to last at least two years, a city transportation official said yesterday.


DUVALIER'S LIFE OF LEISURE
LEAD: A year after his flight into exile, Jean-Claude Duvalier is living at ease on the French Riviera with no indication that he plans to leave anytime soon.

COLLECTION AGENCIES AND RIGHTS
LEAD: RACHELLE CAGNER opened her mail last Sept. 26 and found a letter from the Corporate Accounting Office of the Disbursement Center.
In exchange for ''confirmation'' of her Social Security number, date of birth, telephone number and address, the letter said the office would forward ''a check'' for ''funds on deposit'' in her name.

LEAD: A record number of people were employed in New York State in January and the unemployment rate in New Jersey was the lowest since 1970, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
