RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: GOLF  Langer, Couples Even at Halfway Point: In Honolulu, Bernhard Langer left his driver in the bag on the way to an eight-under-par 64 that lifted him into a tie with Fred Couples for the lead yesterday after the second round of the Hawaiian Open. ''I carried it around just to show off,'' said the West German star, who completed two rounds over the Waialae Country Club course in 134, 10 under par.

BANKAMERICA
LEAD: The Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation has raised the BankAmerica Corporation's preferred stock rating to B+, from B. The S.&amp;P. said its action reflected a modest narrowing of operating losses in the second half of 1986 and continuance of preferred dividends in a difficult operating environment.
The rating agency also assigned a preliminary B+ rating to the preferred stock portion of BankAmerica's recent Rule 415 $1 billion shelf registration and a preliminary BBB- to the shelf's subordinated debt securities.

TRYOUT FOR CARLTON
LEAD: Steve Carlton, who built his career totals to 323 victories and 229 losses while pitching for the Philadelphia Phillies, the San Francisco Giants and the Chicago White Sox last season, is still interested in at least one more major league season.
Carlton, a 42-year-old left-hander, has been in touch, through his agent, Peter Funsten, with the Cincinnati Reds, who said they were willing to give him a tryout, but don't seem to share Carlton's optimism about his pitching prowess.

Canada Jobless Rate Up
LEAD: Canada's unemployment rate rose to 9.7 percent in January after holding steady at 9.4 percent for the previous three months, Statistics Canada said today.
But the Government agency said the rise, adjusted for seasonal variations, was largely the result of a strong increase in the labor force rather than a loss of jobs.


AS TRUCE ENDS, REBEL LEADER TRIES A TASTE OF NORMAL LIFE
LEAD: In the final days of a two-month cease-fire, Victoria Justiniani, a rebel leader, borrowed perfume, earrings and high heels the other night and went out to dinner for the first time at the glittering Manila Hotel.

A Plan to Foil CD Taping
LEAD: President Reagan will propose legislation intended to foil future home recording of compact disks and other digitally recorded audio material, Administration officials said today.


IRAQ SAID TO GAIN UPPER HAND AT BASRA
LEAD: Iraq has successfully counterattacked against Iranian forces on the outskirts of an Iraqi city and appears to have gained the upper hand in the six-week-old battle, according to American military specialists.

DEMPSEY JOINS INDIANS
LEAD: Rick Dempsey, who established himself behind the plate in 10 years with the Baltimore Orioles, signed a one-year contract with the Cleveland Indians yesterday and will now have to compete for the No. 1 catching job with Chris Bando and Andy Allanson.
The 37-year-old Dempsey earned $442,000 last year with Baltimore, but the Orioles refused to pick up his 1987 option for $600,000.

Baryshnikov Joins Series on Gershwins
LEAD: Mikhail Baryshnikov has joined the roster of noted singers, dancers and actors participating in the opening performance on March 11 at 7 P.M. of a monthlong series at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, devoted to the music of George and Ira Gershwin.
Mr.
Baryshnikov will dance in three new works choreographed by Dan Siretta to the Gershwin songs ''Nocturne for Lily Pons,'' ''Short Story'' and ''Promenade.

LEAD: There was a quiet sense of history in the air on Thursday when the Don Redlich Dance Company presented a program of new works by Mr.
Redlich at the Washington Square Methodist Church.
Former teachers of Mr.
Redlich were in the audience, including such noted dance figures as Hanya Holm, Bessie Schonberg and Martha Hill.

NEW ALLIES: CREDIT CARDS AND CAUSES
LEAD: Imagine charging $500 in airline tickets on your Visa card, knowing that $2.50 will automatically go to fight environmental pollution, support feminist causes or aid the homeless - at no additional cost to you.
Such a credit card would bear the logo of your favorite charitable or politically active organization, and beneath the inscription might be a four-color image of mountains and streams or an impressionistic likeness of a woman's face.


Five Are Arrested in Denver In a Series of Brutal Attacks
LEAD: Five people suspected of being gang members have been arrested and charged in a wave of attacks on the streets that left one woman dead and terrorized an east Denver neighborhood, the police said Thursday.

A SURPRISE(?) PARTY FOR THE PRESIDENT
LEAD: President Reagan blows out the candles on his birthday cake with a little help from his wife, Nancy.
Mr.
Rea- gan's staff threw the party, and if it was not exactly a surprise, he at least acted as if it was.
The Reagans had planned to celebrate his 76th birthday privately. (NYT/Paul Hosefros)

Col.
Oliver L. North to rally support for military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

Beirut Magazine Predicts a Release of Waite
LEAD: The magazine that first reported that the United States had secretly sold arms to Iran said today that the Anglican emissary Terry Waite was in captivity but would be freed next week.

LEAD: The authorities in several states today sought to identify six children who the police said were apparently taken from their parents by two Washington, D.C., men and enlisted in what some have described as a bizarre cult of devil worshipers.

LEAD: Dozens of Lebanese Shiite guerrillas began a major attack in southern Lebanon today and fought pitched battles with Israeli soldiers and their Lebanese Christian allies.

SUIT ALLEGES AMNESTY LAW PUTS MANY ALIENS IN LIMBO
LEAD: Adalberto Garza has lived in the United States illegally since 1975, working for most of the time as a machinist in the Houston area.
He is one of an estimated 3.9 million illegal aliens who could be eligible to apply for legal status under the amnesty provisions of the nation's new immigration law.

15 Are Hurt in Protest By Youths in Madrid
LEAD: Fifteen people were hurt and 15 arrested in clashes with the police here today as nearly 2,000 youths protesting university admissions policies sought to march on the office and housing compound of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez.


MATCHUP TEST FOR NAVY
LEAD: David Robinson, Navy's spectacular 7-foot-1-inch center, faces what may be his stiffest test of the season when the Middies play Miami in Baltimore Arena today.
For the first time, Robinson will be facing someone his own size in Tito Horford, a 7-1 native of the Dominican Republic who is still learning the game.


LAW FIRM PARTNERS AND STAFF SEND GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES
LEAD: A gift of $500 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has been received from the partners of the Manhattan law firm of Reid &amp; Priest.
Employees of the firm also made a gift totaling $150.

Treasury Coupon Prices Drop
LEAD: Prices of Treasury coupon issues declined yesterday, but discount rates on bills rose as the demand for Federal funds remained strong.
The rise in bill rates was linked to traders' nervousness about the continued high rates for these funds that banks lend each other overnight.


FREED BY IRAN, REPORTER GETS TO ZURICH
LEAD: An American reporter arrived here today after his release from Iran, where he was seized last weekend and later accused of espionage.

Foli Out as Manager
LEAD: Tim Foli, the manager of the Puerto Rican team in the Caribbean Baseball Series, was dismissed yesterday after a clash with Felix Millan, the general manager, over the way the club has been playing. ''He was disrespectful to me and it is not the first time this has happened,'' Millan said.
Foli was not available for comment after Millan announced the dismissal.

British Air's Big Stock Sale
LEAD: Investors made a last-minute dash today to snap up shares in British Airways, the state-owned airline being sold off to the public.


China Sentences Editor As a Critic of Socialism
LEAD: The editor of a literary magazine has been sentenced to seven years in prison for defaming China's socialist system, the daily China Legal News reported today.
It was the first reported criminal case in China's campaign against Western liberalism.

US AGENT IS SHOT DURING DRUG RAID IN RIVERDALE
LEAD: A Federal agent was shot and wounded in an apartment in the Riverdale section of the Bronx yesterday morning during a raid that the authorities said grew out of a yearlong investigation of a multimillion-dollar cocaine distribution ring.

LEAD: American auto dealers who missed out on the sales success of Hyundai and Yugo cars last year are now eagerly awaiting the new offerings of foreign manufacturers.
As a result, American consumers may soon be test-driving offerings from Malaysia, India, Portugal and Spain.

EX-WEDTECH AIDES SAY THEY KEPT FILES ON SIMON BRIBES
LEAD: Former executives of the Wedtech Corporation kept detailed records for thousands of dollars in bribes paid to Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.


MURDOCH ADVANCES BID IN AUSTRALIA
LEAD: Rupert Murdoch was set to clinch the takeover of Australia's largest media group, the Herald and Weekly Times Ltd., for $1.54 billion (American) after a rival bidder, John Fairfax Ltd. agreed to step aside.
Fairfax, a leading newspaper publisher based in Sydney, will not go ahead with a proposed $2.5 billion, or $1.67 billion (American), bid for the group, the Herald and Weekly Times chairman, John Dahlsen, announced after a long board meeting.

PIZZA INN GETS TAKEOVER OFFER
LEAD: Pizza Inn Inc. said that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer from Concept Development Inc. for a combination of stock and cash valued at $13.85 a share, or a total of about $45 million.
Under the proposal, Concept Development, a St.
Louis-based operator of 125 Panterra's pizza restaurants, would offer Pizza Inn shareholders $3 a share and 1.4 shares in Concept Development stock for each Pizza Inn share.

2 Die in Upstate Train Crash
LEAD: Wreckage of two trains after a head-on collision yesterday in Concord, N.Y., about 25 miles south of Buffalo.
Two crewmen were killed and at least two others were seriously injured.
Investigators said the crash may have been caused by one train's failure to turn off the single track onto a siding.

Prices for Cattle Drop While Pork Improves
LEAD: Prices of live-cattle futures declined yesterday, weakened by a large supply of animals and expectations of shrinking demand.

LEAD: When Philippe de Villiers, Secretary of State for Culture in France's conservative Government, opened a new collection in the Invalides war museum in Paris this year, there was only one thing wrong.


S.E.C. Subpoenas Drexel Customer
LEAD: A subpoena to one of the largest ''junk bond'' customers of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is a highlight of the Securities and Exchange Commission's broadening inquiry into takeover abuses by issuers and buyers of these high-yield, high-risk instruments, lawyers close to the investigation said today.


IRANIAN PROTEST IN WASHINGTON
LEAD: Part of a crowd of about 3,000 demonstrators marching yesterday in Lafayette Park against the fundamentalist Islamic rule of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
The marchers declared their support for a resistance movement seeking to overthrow the Government and to condemn the sale of American arms to Iran.

2 SOVIET FAILURES IN SPACE REPORTED
LEAD: The successful launching of astronauts to the Soviet Union's Mir space station Thursday was preceded by two serious rocket and satellite failures in the previous week that went unacknowledged by Soviet officials, American space experts reported yesterday.


Consumers Rein In Debt
LEAD: Americans borrowed $105 million more than they paid off in December, the smallest increase in consumer credit in five years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The slowdown was attributed to changing borrowing patterns brought on by the new tax law.

NEW PLAN ON NUCLEAR PLANTS IS LAID TO FRUSTRATION
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission staff's proposal to relax the requirements for emergency evacuation planning at nuclear plants was driven by frustration that plants were being stopped by intransigent state and local officials after billions had been spent on their construction, officials said today.


University Graduates an Owl
LEAD: Southern Connecticut State University's owl rehabilitation program has had its first graduate.
The school reported this week that it paid about $200 to nurse a female great horned owl back to both health and freedom after it was found injured alongside a road about a year ago.
The bird was cared for at a raptor rehabilitation center, and released on Dec.

American Ballet Theater
LEAD: American Ballet Theater has announced the promotions of Cheryl Yeager, Amanda McKerrow and Johan Renvall to the rank of principal dancer.
Miss Yeager, from Washington, joined the company in 1976.
Miss McKerrow, born in Albuquerque, N.M., is a former member of the Washington Ballet and the winner of the gold medal at the Moscow International Ballet Competition in 1981.

LEAD: Hanging from the rafters of the towering Cathedral of Saint John the Divine these days, there is - of all things - a giant plastic fish.

Staten Island's War Over Wetlands
LEAD: Staten Islanders can be divided into two groups.
Call one group the pioneers, people who cherish the rural character of New York City's last frontier.
Call the others the settlers, who build housing and push suburbanization.
By misusing a wetlands law, the state Department of Environmental Conservation is pleasing pioneers at settlers' expense.

CLUE IN AMTRAK ACCIDENT SOUGHT
LEAD: Divers searching a river yesterday in Chase, Md.
An anonymous caller said someone was seen throwing a television set into the water shortly after an Amtrak passenger train slammed into three Conrail locomotives near-by.
It has been suggested that the Conrail crew may have been watching the National Football League playoff game between the Giants and the 49ers.

A Surplus of Economic White Lies
LEAD: There won't be a special meeting of finance ministers this weekend to do something about the dollar because of ''scheduling problems.'' That news comes from an anonymous ''monetary source.'' When finance ministers agree that they need to meet, they meet.
When they disagree, they find ''scheduling problems.

LEAD: As some in Washington see it, the newly designated chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Dennis R. Patrick, might be a sort of re-run of his predecessor, Mark S. Fowler.
Like Mr.
Fowler, Mr.
Patrick, whose appointment President Reagan announced last week, is a firm suppporter of deregulation of the broadcast industry.

LEAD: An employer's offer of half-pay until retirement age not to come to work would sound fantastic to some, even without forced layoff.
I suspect that many employees might voluntarily elect that option, were it presented to them.


THE IMPACT AND INFLUENCE OF JOHN CAGE
LEAD: Approaching his 75th birthday - the date is Sept. 5 -John Cage looms among us, twinkling, patriarchal, inspiring and annoying in all the right ways.
It seems almost certain that Mr.
Cage's place in musical history will be a significant one.
It was he who fathered a whole generation (or two or three) of experimental composers in this country and the world, and who did more than anyone else to introduce the contemplative aura of Oriental religion and philosophy into the highly individuated, careerist sensibility of the


IN CONTEST FOR INDUSTRY, INDIANA SCORES
LEAD: FOR decades, as a conservative foothold in the industrial Midwest, Indiana relied on low tax rates and a laissez-faire tradition to lure and keep businesses.
But in the recession of the early 1980's, unemployment rose, productivity declined and a series of plants closed, stunning a state that had seemed immune to such troubles.

Chilean Admits Role in '76 Murder
LEAD: United States courts long ago established an official Chilean role in the 1976 murder in Washington of Orlando Letelier, an exiled opponent of President Augusto Pinochet.
But the case has never been resolved because Chile has refused to extradite the suspects.

Bush said today.

LEAD: MASSAGE has had a tenuous link with medicine for years.
Nurses traditionally administered back massages to soothe the aches of bed-ridden patients, and even today many nurses and physical therapists study massage techniques.

LEAD: Additional titles of interest:


Social Security
LEAD: To the Editor:  If Social Security payroll taxes discourage employers from hiring and employees from working (''Put a Permanent Lid on Payroll Taxes,'' Forum Jan. 25), they fairly suffocate something else: Initiative.


WHITE HOUSE FACING CRISIS OF CONFIDENCE
LEAD: As Ronald Reagan enters the final two years of his Presidency, his White House has started to lose the distinctive aura of confidence and control that contributed heavily to the many achievements of his first six years in office, according to White House insiders and Reagan supporters outside the Government.


FROM FRANCE, A TASTE OF EUROPE'S AVANT GARDE
LEAD: Innovation and creativity are taken for granted in American dance - in large part because modern dance in this country has been rooted in such principles.
Not so in most of Europe.
The opera-house network in many countries there frequently goes hand in hand with an establishment taste, with resident ballet companies in those theaters catering to an establishment audience.

LEAD: It was shortly after noon Thursday that the Board of Estimate began its hearing on an ambitious plan to replace the old Coliseum at Columbus Circle with a huge two-tower complex, complete wth indoor atrium and eight movie theaters.

LEAD: VIRTUALLY every economist we have heard from and most of the publications and sources we consult in monitoring and anticipating the progress of the Long Island economy have told us that 1987, like 1986, will be another good year for our region.

LEAD: To the Editor:  ''Remaking the American C.E.O.'' (Jan. 25) is an unwarranted, unfair and simplistic attack on an entire class of mostly patriotic and hard-working American men and women.

LEAD: Francis Wells Davison, a physician who specialized in disorders of the ear, nose and throat, died Thursday at the Geisinger Medical Center in Danville, Pa.
He was 84 years old.

Q and A
LEAD: Caribbean Resorts  Question: Can you suggest a family resort in the Caribbean with a reasonable price in winter that includes two meals and water sports and on an island with direct flights from New York? - L. K., Larchmont, N.Y.
Answer: Many resorts meet these requirements, but the search can be narrrowed somewhat by referring not to direct but to nonstop flights.

RECEIVERS DRAW ATTENTION
LEAD: The venerable saying that there is more than one way to skin a cat has not lost its validity.
In audio, for example, different approaches often lead to the same end, as in the case of two currently popular receivers - one by Nakamichi, the other by Yamaha.
They have been attracting attention because they confront audiophiles with contrasting design precepts.

Cessna Strays Near Jetliner
LEAD: The Pilot of a Western Airlines jet with 59 people aboard veered to the left while approaching the international airport here Friday to avoid a small plane that strayed near the airliner, a Federal official said.
Lee Fryer, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said a single-engine Cessna 172 and a Western Boeing 737 flying from Las Vegas, Nev., had been given final clearance to land on parallel runways.

In video, this attitude culminated in the Handycam - a bantam camera-recorder combination that may be regarded as the video version of the Walkman.

THE QUESTION OF CONDOM ADS
LEAD: Should television carry advertisements for condoms?
The question is part of a growing debate.
In a recent speech in Washington, Dr.
Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said that a worldwide AIDS epidemic in the next 10 years would be more devastating than the Black Plague.
Meanwhile, there are heated discussions over sex education.

NEW YORKERS, ETC.
LEAD: WHOEVER said ''take care of the small things and the big things will take care of themselves'' was seriously naive.
That doesn't mean, however, that small things shouldn't be taken care of.
They definitely should, and the first of the small things to go should be the irritating habits of others.

LEAD: A plea for clemency in an 11-year-old murder case has led to a political dispute that is threatening the prestige and future of President Christos Sartzetakis.


DO YOU LIKE THE COLLEGE 3-POINT BASKET?
LEAD: Over recent years basketball has evolved into 7-foot behemoths pushing and shoving for territory under the basket for easy dunks, tip-ins or layups.
Placing a premium (3 points) on 19-foot or greater shots returns a modicum of skill to the sport.
Rebounds and tip-ins should be equivalent to a foul shot (which incidentally many of the ''big men'' cannot seem to conquer).

LEAD: More than 300 demonstrators chanting ''79th Precinct, Undercover Crack-house,'' marched yesterday from a junior high school in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn to the 79th Precinct station house to protest what they said was police collusion with drug dealers.

DO YOU LIKE THE COLLEGE 3-POINT BASKET?
LEAD: It is too short!
Players are averaging more points than they should be.
Larry Bird and Chris Mullin would have averaged over 40 points a game in college with this line's ridiculous distance from the net.
Players do not show that they are capable of playing in the N.B.A. by scoring from this distance.

ENDING ALTMAN'S LAZY DAYS
LEAD: LAST year, when the two C.P.A.'s planning to buy B. Altman &amp; Company's retail stores took their first close look at the 121-year-old department store chain, they went into a state of shock.
The merchandise mix, the huge numbers of non-sales employees, even the amount of office equipment in use, all seemed more attuned to a company seeking a tax loss than one looking for a profit.

SOME PRUNES CAN BE SHOW STOPPERS
LEAD: WHY is it we hate prunes so much when we are children?
Perhaps it is because they show up in such unflattering circumstances: stewed and served on top of cereal, or with custard for dessert.
But prunes are transformed when they become adult food.
They go wonderfully with rich winter meats such as pork, venison, duck or goose, and even with chicken or veal.

Mr.
Blotnick, whose previous books are ''The Corporate Steeplechase'' and ''Otherwise Engaged: The Private Lives of Successful Career Women,'' here analyzes successful men.

5 OF 27 CARIBOUS IMPORTED TO MAINE DIE
LEAD: Five of 27 caribous brought to Maine recently in an effort to reintroduce the animal to the state have died, two on the trip from their native Canada late last year and three within two weeks after their arrival at a compound at the University of Maine in Orono, the project's director said.

Last Check Before Moving In
LEAD: JUST before a buyer takes title to a brand-new home, either a condominium or a single-family house, the builder normally arranges for a final inspection of the property to verify that everything is in order.
Many buyers are perplexed by this ritual and do not understand what they should be examining and why.


RESIDENTS OPPOSE CONDOMINIUM PLAN
LEAD: THE town of Greenburgh made an unusual proposal last summer - to switch two-thirds of its commercial zoning on 450 acres at 15 sites to residential use.
It would do this in the hope of gaining some moderate-priced housing instead of more offices and hotels.


Bad Blood
LEAD: Carlos Lehder Rivas, reputedly one of the world's most dangerous billionaires, was captured by authorities in Colombia last week and extradited to the United States to face a long list of drug-related charges in two Federal courts in Florida.
Mr.
Lehder, who was said by prosecutors to be part of a ring responsible for 80 percent of the cocaine smuggled into the United States, was indicted three months ago in Miami on charges of conspiring to ship 58 pounds of cocaine into Florida.

OPEC May Stumble, But It Won't Fall
LEAD: EUPHORIA has overtaken the oil markets in recent weeks, as the OPEC agreement on production limits has demonstrated a surprising staying power.
Even the Soviet Union, never a particularly trustworthy partner in these matters, has promised to join the effort to scale back production.
And just this week, the four American oil companies that make up Aramco agreed to pay a fixed price of $18 a barrel.

LEAD: Prisoners who have been kept in solitary confinement for days and sometimes years have sued the state for violating their civil rights.


LOOKING FOR LINCOLN IN THE 1980'S
LEAD: AT the Gettysburg cemetery, the Abraham Lincoln of Gore Vidal's novel barely gets through his first sentence - about the events in America ''four score and seven years ago'' - when the young Presidential secretary, John Hay, cynically observes that such rhetoric ''will please the radicals.'' Though the national commitment to the noble notion that ''all men are created equal,'' particularly in its Civil War, black-white context, is thereby dismissed, the Gettysburg Ad-dress itself is not.

ROSTROPOVICH LEADS NATIONAL SYMPHONY AT CARNEGIE
LEAD: WHEN Mstislav Rostropovich and the National Symphony Orchestra are good, they are very, very good, and they are often at their best in the music of Shostakovich.
On Friday night, the orchestra played one of Shostakovich's least known works -the Symphony No. 4 in C minor (Op. 43), written in 1935-36 at the height of the ''great terror'' and immediately after Stalin had denounced the young composer for his ''formalism'' and for writing ''muddle instead of music.


CORRECTION
LEAD: In last week's column, a computer malfunction caused question marks to appear in several places in the game score.
All but one appeared where a dash should have been; one, however, made White's 12th move unitelligible; the move should have been B-N3.

The Rewards of Buying Frequent-Flier Awards
LEAD: If you telephone American Airlines and buy a round-trip ticket from New York to Honolulu, it will cost at least $598.
At that rock-bottom rate, you would have to make your reservations and pay for your ticket at least 21 days before departure, you could travel only on a Tuesday or Wednesday and you could not make any stopovers on the way.

A 'SHARK WATCHER' ON WALL STREET
LEAD: ''I WAS the first shark watcher,'' said Arnold Minsky of Brookville.
But don't look for the 48-year-old Mr.
Minsky in the waters off Montauk, chumming for great whites.
Look for him - figuratively speaking - on Wall Street, trolling for the sort of sharks inclined to feed on stock as they raid tempting targets in corporate takeovers.

WINTER'S GLOOM? NO, WINTER'S GIFTS
LEAD: A WINTER'S day, the stillness, the quiet all down the length of Jericho Turnpike, a feeling of bleakness as the seasons turn - to some, these bring complaints of winter's gloom; to me, they bring winter's gifts.
Among these gifts is a sense of a return to another time when vast stretches of Long Island's turnpikes were empty roads leading to land that was still free of concrete, still being turned by the farmer's hand.

LEAD: Despite a Government effort to block them, thousands of demonstrators gathered here Saturday to mourn the death by torture of a 21-year-old student three weeks ago.

LEAD: Take yesterday's disco rhythms, add a slightly flat British singer, and the result can be a pop hit.
That's the formula that has made the Human League a regular entry on the pop Top 40, most recently with ''Human,'' a Philadelphia-soul-style ballad about infidelity written by the band's producers, Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis.

EDINBURGH OFF SEASON
LEAD: Waking early on a winter morning in Edinburgh, you may see stone pavements glistening under street lamps as cars and red double-deckers rumble along Princes Street, Princes Street's gardens a watery green despite overcoat weather.
If it's clear, the moon may hang full in an inky sky, paper white in contrast to the yellow headlights playing on the fronts of buildings.


AUDUBON POSITION
LEAD: With regard to the Jan. 4 article ''Controls on Swans Proposed,'' this is to inform you that on Jan. 6 the Connecticut Audubon Society's Environmental Issues Committee endorsed the addling of eggs but not the outright killing of swans at this time.
JOEY CORCORAN

Smoking
LEAD: To the Editor:  Frederick Thayer  [ Letters, Jan. 18 ]  says that when the Environmental Protection Agency and the Surgeon General join hands to argue that environmental tobacco smoke is a danger to non-smokers, the public should suspect a conspiracy.
A more normal reaction would be to have increased confidence in the assertion that passive smoking is a major health hazard.

Ms.
Wheeler possesses a mezzo-soprano voice of moderate size, dark hue and naturally affecting timbre.
Unfortunately, on Wednesday night her upper register was not secure, her pitch sense lacked authority, and her interpretations were careful rather than inspired.

BEYOND THE PALE WITH EDGAR ALLAN POE
LEAD: ANYONE aware of the difficulties of Edgar Allan Poe's life must wish to see his reputation prosper.
Yet he alone among the Immortals calls up the sort of smirk otherwise reserved for writers who are not only living but also local.
Anyone who confesses an admiration for Poe learns quickly that he is not respectable, because he set out to create powerful responses in his readers by methods already conventional when he used them.


HOT AND BOTHERED IN PARIS AND LONDON
LEAD: PALAIS-ROYAL By Richard Sennett. 274 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.


YOUTH PUTS HIS ENERGY IN GYMNASTICS
LEAD: IT didn't take long for Garie Jean Mulcahey of Stamford to realize that she had to find a way to channel her young son's energy, which was being manifested in a number of unusual ways.


FIGHTING CITY HALL WITH PSYCHOLOGY
LEAD: WHEN the building inspector and Zoning Board of Appeals in Groton, Mass., refused to let Thomas Hefele build a house on his property in 1985, he struck back at what he viewed as ''arbitrary authority.''


The Editorial Notebook; Blacks and Blue Power
LEAD: In Chicago, it used to be routine police practice to sweep up large numbers of young black and Hispanic men on disorderly conduct charges, hold them overnight and release them the next day without prosecution.
In 1982, the American Civil Liberties Union challenged the practice in Federal court.
In 1983, when Harold Washington took over as Chicago's first black mayor, the city entered into a consent decree to end the sweeps.


Science On the Track of God
LEAD: In his article ''Science on the Track of God'' (Jan. 4), James Gleick searches for ''the evidence of design that cannot be explained away,'' and seems frustrated because ''science does eventually manage to explain.'' There is some confusion here, and it revolves around the word ''explanation.'' Science is made up of theories.


JAPANESE SET SAIL FOR THE CUP
LEAD: SLEEK and shiny, the futuristic yacht with the Japanese flag appeared to have arrived from a James Bond movie.
Maybe you noticed it on television just before the start of the second America's Cup race when Stars &amp; Stripes and Kookaburra III sailed around it.
Another few feet and it would have created an international incident.


PLIGHT OF A SURROGATE COMPLAINER
LEAD: NAN, a neighbor, and I love freezing in April on a beach in Maine (getting a so-called tan), shopping for Christmas on Labor Day, and having icicle duels with our respective husbands in deep winter.
We marvel that human beings can be so similar.
Except for one thing: Nan can't complain about anything, so I do all the complaining for her.

ALIENS IN U.S. GAIN REFUGE IN CANADA
LEAD: Illegal aliens who are not eligible for legal status under the new immigration law are migrating from the United States to Canada in substantial numbers.


M.C.I. Increases
LEAD: To the Editor:  Your article called the ''Vanishing Supply of Rentals'' on Dec. 28 quotes an executive of a realty management firm complaining about the 6 percent cap on M.C.I. rent increases as a disincentive to landlords contemplating major capital improvements to a building.
He felt that way since a 6 percent increase of an average $500 rental would be only $1,800 over the course of the 5-year amortization period that is used (6 percent times $500 times 60 months).


POSTINGS: Showcase for 96th; Restoring a Gem
LEAD: Everything about the mansion built in 1915 for Lucy D. Dahlgren at 15 East 96th Street is decorative - from the Beaux Arts-style facade, replete with carved swags and an intricate wrought-iron balcony, to the grand marble staircase and octagonal dining room with two marble fountains.


MAYORAL PANEL CITES YOUTH PREGNANCIES IN POOR COMMUNITIES
LEAD: Teen-agers living in poor neighborhoods give birth in significantly higher numbers than those in the rest of New York City, in some cases accounting for more than one-quarter of all births in a neighborhood, a mayoral panel has found.


PAYOFFS TO UNION TIED TO WEDTECH
LEAD: Former Wedtech executives have told Federal prosecutors that, in addition to bribing government officials, they paid more than $100,000 to union officers to gain labor peace for the company, according to prosecutors and other lawyers familiar with the case.


MUSHROOM FARM REVIVED
LEAD: WHEN the Ralston Purina Corporation sold its mushroom farm in Franklin four years ago, it said it was getting out of the business because the Northeast market was oversupplied.

LEAD: This village remained afloat in a sea of red ink this weekend as about 70 municipal employees, many of them still owed wages from January, accepted token payments of $100 each and stayed on the job.

O'Rourke, in one of the strongest messages of his administration, coupled a plea for the municipal construction of affordable housing last week with a threat that the county would condemn property to build emergency housing in seeking to help Westchester's growing homeless population.

LEAD: IN THIS seat of Bergen County, where high-rise apartment houses and Victorian homes are the more-usual landscape, battle lines have been drawn in an unlikely spot: A 14.2-acre tract of virgin woodlands that is a nuisance to some and a garden spot to others.

LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN'S proposed $10.18 billion budget for the coming fiscal year contains increased financing for education, prisons, welfare and health services, but pressures for still higher spending continue to grow faster than the state's ability to pay for new programs.


The Istanbul Synagogue Massacre
LEAD: I am one of the few persons in the United States who has engaged in lengthy discussion with Abu Nidal (''The Istanbul Synagogue Massacre: An Investigation,'' by Judith Miller, Jan. 4).
During my visit last December to the Middle East, seeking the release of the hostages held in Lebanon, I met with members of Abu Nidal's Fatah Revolutionary Council.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''I guess something is changing in the Soviet Union.
It may be that enough has changed so that I can live here.''  - Sergei Grigoryants, newly released from a Soviet prison.  [ 10:1. ]


SOME PRUNES CAN BE SHOW STOPPERS
LEAD: WHY is it we hate prunes so much when we are children?
Perhaps it is because they show up in such unflattering circumstances: stewed and served on top of cereal, or with custard for dessert.
But prunes are transformed when they become adult food.
They go wonderfully with rich winter meats such as pork, venison, duck or goose, and even with chicken or veal.


GERMAN RUNS 35-YEAR SHOW OF TALK ON TV
LEAD: If Werner Hofer had had his way, he would never have become the most famous television personality in West Germany.


PERFORMING-ARTS CENTER IS PLANNED FOR BOSTON
LEAD: Boston's depressed theater district, where pornographic movie houses outnumber cultural outlets and show tickets are sold from a dilapidated trailer, will be transformed into a busy center of dance, music and theater within the next five years, city officials say.

LEAD: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, freely admits that he knows ''a lot more about the problems of dairy farmers than wheat, corn and soybean growers or farmers who raise livestock.'' Since Mr.
Leahy has just become chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, his selective ignorance has suddenly assumed greater importance.

LEAD: Sammy Chevalier is the birdman of Kennedy International Airport.


SURPLUS FOOD DISTRIBUTED TO THE NEEDY
LEAD: Workers preparing bags of food to be distributed to those who were standing in line outside Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center.
About 10,000 people were to receive cheese, rice, honey, butter, flour and milk.
The hospital has distributed more than two million pounds of Government food in the past four years.

The Venetian Maskmakers' Art Revived
LEAD: Venice will always be a city of mystery and intrigue, just as she was in those last desperate days of the Most Serene Republic at the close of the 18th century.
One has only to walk her splendid fondamenti (canal walkways) or cross her magic bridges counting the shadows after nightfall to know that much.

LEAD: Republican candidates for the United States Senate raised $28 million more than their Democratic opponents in the 1986 election, but those funds were not a determining factor in most races, an analysis of campaign finance reports shows.

LEAD: THE DUCK AT THE DOOR FROM the outside, Susan Rosenberg's home in Merrick looks like many suburban split-levels.
But when you knock on the glass storm door and a quacking black duck waddles toward you in greeting, it's obvious that all is not exactly as it seems.


ACTION IS CALLED FOR ON ELECTRIC RATES
LEAD: I read, with great interest, your article ''Power Cost Is Down but Still an Issue''  [ Jan. 18 ] .
Although I agree that with electric rates down in 1986, the push for cheaper power has lost some momentum, I feel that the fight for reduced Con Ed bills must go on.
We pay the highest rates in the nation.

Art
LEAD: Just a week remains in which to see the exhibition of oils, watercolors and drawings by Oskar Kokoschka (1886-1980) at the Guggenheim Museum.
Just before World War I, Kokoschka was one of the most conspicuous young artists in the Vienna that has lately become so fashionable.
In Dresden, between 1917 and 1923, he painted landscapes and figure subjects that are among the glories of German art.

New York, the Supreme Court's 1905 decision invalidating a restriction on bakery working hours, remains a symbol of its age.
The dissenters in Lochner, and similar cases that followed, eventually prevailed.

Now, we have another N.B.A.; National Boredom Association, that is.

DO YOU LIKE THE COLLEGE 3-POINT BASKET?
LEAD: The college game, unlike professional basketball, has never suffered the sort of slump warranting significant rule changes.
Moreover, even if such rule changes were necessary in college basketball, the current 3-point rule would still be inappropriate.

LEAD: Yes, but - only if you complete the adjustment by establishing a 1-point zone round the basket.

CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD: DINO DAYS The Yale Peabody Museum has given new meaning to ''The Three B's.'' Bach, Beethoven and Brahms will be displaced, at least from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M.
Thursday through next Tuesday, by baroque, bagels and brontosaurus.


MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC IN WORK BY MATTHUS
LEAD: THE novelty on the New York Philharmonic's current program, which this listener heard Friday afternoon, was a concerto for orchestra by the East German composer Siegfried Matthus.
Entitled ''Die Windsbraut'' (The Bride of the Wind), this 15-minute piece in four movements played without pause belongs to a genre of symphonic work that might be described, not without honor, as ''weather music.

REDUCING NUMBER OF HOSPITAL BEDS IS 'POLITICS' AND OVERLOOKS PUBLIC NEED
LEAD: HEALTH-CARE costs are of vital concern to us all.
As physicians, we recognize the public's desire that waste be eliminated and duplication minimized in the provision of hospital services.
Yet we are fearful that the hastily drawn plans to consolidate hospital services in this region have not carefully assessed the facts, allowed sufficient public input or sought the views, guidance and assistance of practicing physicians in accomplishing those goals while maintaining the public interest.

Forecasting Prices in Manhattan
LEAD: CAN an econometric model predict how resale prices in Manhattan residential real estate will rise or fall?
The next few years will tell, because such an model has been established for the first time with data from M. J. Raynes, a large sales organization, and the help of Susan M. Wachter, an economist and associate professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

Gentrification
LEAD: To the Editor:  Your article titled ''Rebuilding From the Grass Roots Up'' on Dec. 21 mentions that homes on a redeveloped Charlotte Street in the South Bronx will be sold for $100,000.
It then states that these are ''low- and moderate-income projects.'' Since when are $100,000 houses classified as low- and moderate-income?


BUSINESS GETS LONG-DISTANCE BREAK
LEAD: OVERALL, the average cost of placing a long-distance call has declined about 30 percent since the breakup of the American Telephone &amp; Telegraph Company in 1984, according to the Federal Communications Commission.
But businesses have benefited more from the decline than individual consumers have, though consumers are also paying less for long-distance calls.


U.S. JOINS INQUIRY ON OYSTER BAY
LEAD: THE United States Attorney for the Eastern District has joined the Nassau County District Attorney in investigating possible corruption in the Oyster Bay town government, according to law enforcement officials.


BILL WOULD LET JOBLESS 'BOOTSTRAP'
LEAD: CONGRESS is looking for entrepreneurs among the unemployed.
Under a new ''bootstrapping'' bill backed by Representative James A. Courter, Republican of the 12th District (Hunterdon County and parts of Mercer, Middlesex, Morris, Somerset, Sussex and Warren Counties), jobless workers could draw unemployment checks while starting a small business.


Court Finds for Farm Workers
LEAD: Saying that Labor Secretary Bill Brock's decision to require the states to issue field sanitation standards for farm workers was an abdication of authority based on a faulty view of federalism, a three-judge panel in Washington last week ordered the Labor Department to issue Federal guidelines that farm worker advocates have been petitioning or suing for since 1972.

NATURE'S CONTROLS ON SWAN POPULATION
LEAD: I am responding to Shirley Becker's letter to the editor  [ ''Let Nature Take Care of Swans,'' Jan. 18 ]  regarding the Jan. 4 article ''Controls on Swans Proposed.'' I share her love of swans, but her conclusion to ''let nature take care of overpopulation'' may be a bit naive.
Will nature be able to take care of the overpopulation?

LEAD: AS the prominence of conservative legal thinkers has grown during the Reagan Administration, so has a split about the fundamental issues of constitutional jurisprudence.
The division centers on whether judges should take the activist role of striking down a wide range of economic regulations.


CRIME
LEAD: It was about a dozen years ago that the Australian writer William Marshall started writing his Yellowthread Street mysteries.
Those were procedurals set in Hong Kong, and were distinguished by a wacky kind of writing in which seriousness was mingled with farce.
There have been 11 in that series.

SOME PRUNES CAN BE SHOW STOPPERS
LEAD: WHY is it we hate prunes so much when we are children?
Perhaps it is because they show up in such unflattering circumstances: stewed and served on top of cereal, or with custard for dessert.
But prunes are transformed when they become adult food.
They go wonderfully with rich winter meats such as pork, venison, duck or goose, and even with chicken or veal.

LEAD: One of the three or four most satisfying piano recitals to come this critic's way in the last few seasons was Peter Serkin's at the 92d St.
Y, and now the best parts of it are represented on a new recording for New World Records (NW 344).
Those are the knotty, intense Passacaglia (1936) of Stefan Wolpe, a work of steadily accumulating power; two clean-lined and inevitable sounding Stravinsky performances, and an engaging new three-part work by Peter Lieberson called ''Bagatelles.

TWO MAJOR PIANISTS JOIN IN SOME ELEGANT MUSIC-MAKING
LEAD: Playing piano four hands -that is, four hands at one piano - is part of the growing up of many musicians.
In earlier days, before radio, records and television, it was also an integral part of the education of every music-lover.
All symphonic and chamber music was published in four-hand versions so that amateur and professional alike could become familiar with the content of the scores, Most four-hand music, aimed at the amateur as it was, did not need a virtuoso technique.

DIDION &amp; DUNNE: THE REWARDS OF A LITERARY MARRIAGE
LEAD: SHE'S SO THIN THAT IF YOU touch her back you can feel the ribs, like ridges on a roll-top desk.
He has a paunch.
She likes to sit on a stool, her back ramrod straight; he drapes his body across a couch, assuming a languid, informal pose.
She moves slowly, gently; talks softly.
He moves quickly, his eyes alert to danger or intrigue, his voice booming with good humor, spiked by the energy of a hair-trigger temper.

SOME PRUNES CAN BE SHOW STOPPERS
LEAD: WHY is it we hate prunes so much when we are children?
Perhaps it is because they show up in such unflattering circumstances: stewed and served on top of cereal, or with custard for dessert.
But prunes are transformed when they become adult food.
They go wonderfully with rich winter meats such as pork, venison, duck or goose, and even with chicken or veal.

LEAD: The Royal Philharmonic, like all the major British orchestras, is supported by private sponsors and government grants.

Recently, however, the Royal Philharmonic decided it wanted to be able to call the tune, so to speak, on recordings, and formed its own record company, called, of course, RPO Records.

LEAD: IN the space of seven weeks two winters ago, the Toronto Blue Jays solved their glaring bullpen problem.

It has a sparse score, also disposable, by Marvin Hamlisch (music) and Carole Bayer Sager (lyrics).
And the story, which is said to be based upon the once-upon-a-time romantic relationship between the composer and the lyricist, is by Neil Simon.

John Cadwalader, a colonial patron of the arts and Revolutionary War hero - was advanced at a New York auction when a 200-year-old wing chair with furry looking feet and a frame riddled with nail holes was sold for the highest price ever paid at auction for a piece of furniture - $2.75 million.

Taiwan Trade Surplus
LEAD: Taiwan's trade surplus surged in January, officials said Friday, and economists said they were optimistic about prospects for further growth in the first quarter.
The surplus rose to $1.41 billion last month, from $1.39 billion in December and $1.26 billion in January 1986.
Trade volume totalled $5.25 billion, compared with $5.95 billion in December and $4.94 billion in January 1986.

Reagan's SALT II Folly
LEAD: President Reagan's reaffirmation, in his State of the Union Message, of the importance of protecting our country was deeply ironic, coming on the heels of his decision to violate the SALT II treaty.
This decision marked the first time either superpower has violated the treaty sublimit on missiles and bombers, thereby risking an accelerated nuclear arms race.

Canada Jobless Rate Up
LEAD: Canada's unemployment rate rose to 9.7 percent in January after holding steady at 9.4 percent for the previous three months, Statistics Canada said Friday.
But the Government agency said the rise, adjusted for seasonal variations, was largely the result of a strong increase in the labor force rather than a loss of jobs.

LEAD: Andrei D. Sakharov stood in his hallway today and weighed the question: Is there evidence yet of a real shift in the Soviet handling of human rights, or have there been only gestures designed to deceive the West?

LEAD: Despite two years of rapidly rising premiums, the property and casualty insurance industry is jittery again.

They were identified as Kenneth Barton, the pilot, who was chief of the volunteer fire department in Garrison, and Dr.


RITTER AND SELLECCA IN 'THE LAST FLING'
LEAD: IT'S all a matter of style. ''The Last Fling,'' tonight's television movie on ABC at 9, tries hard, and often rather amiably, to be what used to be known as a romantic romp.
Billy Wilder, in his ''Some Like It Hot'' period, would probably have pulled it off with great dollops of panache.
Television, insistently clumsy, gives us silliness that keeps toppling into stupidity.


CORAL GABLES PREPARES FOR FUTURE BY DRAWING ON ITS GRAND PAST
LEAD: This suburb of Miami is preparing for the future by dusting off its past, encouraging a civic facelift by promoting the old instead of the new.


Condoms Handed Out During Church Service
LEAD: A Unitarian Universalist minister distributed condoms to his congregation during a worship service Sunday, saying the spread of AIDS must stop and condoms would help.

LEAD: Late last month, the White House submitted to Congress a report entitled ''National Security Strategy of the United States'' over the signature of President Reagan, in an effort to keep the lawmakers up to date on the underlying principles of the nation's foreign policy and their use abroad.

LEAD: The municipal bond market faces two large financings this week, both intended to take advantage of the steep drop in tax-exempt bond yields.

CITY BALLET: SILENT 'MOVES'
LEAD: THERE seem to be a remarkable number of dancegoers with bronchitis at each performance of ''Moves,'' a ballet by Jerome Robbins that was presented by the New York City Ballet last Wednesday at the New York State Theater.
And the ballet's performers always seem to seethe coolly with emotion.
The reason seems to lie in the fact that the ballet is performed in silence.


SOUTH KOREA WELCOMES FAMILY FLEEING NORTH
LEAD: Eleven North Koreans who escaped by boat to Japan arrived in Seoul today to a hero's welcome, marking a rare defection by North Korean civilians to the South.


Man Dies in a Blast In Queens Apartment
LEAD: The body of an unidentified man was found lying on the floor of the bathroom in a Hollis, Queens, apartment last night, apparently the victim of a small explosion, the police said.


SCHEER PICKED TO RUN NETS
LEAD: After months of procrastination, the Nets will name Carl Scheer as their general manager next week.
He replaces Lewis Schaffel, who resigned before the start of the season to head a group of investors that is trying to bring a National Basketball Association franchise to Miami.


Herk van Tongeren, Sculptor
LEAD: Herk van Tongeren, a sculptor, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in Seattle.
He was 43 years old and lived in Hopewell, N.J.

LEAD: A 2 1/2-month-old Canadian girl who underwent surgery to replace her malformed heart was in critical but stable condition today, and doctors were optimistic about her progress.
The girl, identified only as Jessica of Calgary, Alberta, received the transplanted heart Saturday at Loma Linda University Medical Center, said a hospital spokesman.

THE STAGE: ARTHUR MILLER'S 'DANGER: MEMORY!'
LEAD: THE OPENING one-act play in ''Danger: Memory!,'' Arthur Miller's new double bill at Lincoln Center, is titled ''I Can't Remember Anything,'' but it's Arthur Miller's nature that he can never forget.
The horrors that haunt his characters today - the 20th century's police inquisitions, pogroms and wars - are the same specters that hung over ''After the Fall'' and ''Incident at Vichy,'' plays he wrote for the first Lincoln Center theater company, more than two decades ago.

LEAD: A clandestine group that last month kidnapped three American professors and an Indian academic here today repeated its threat to kill them unless 400 Arabs held in Israeli jails are freed.

LEAD: Should nuclear power be regulated by the Federal Government or the states?

The shift assumes additional importance because of two current vacancies on the Federal Reserve Board.


MUSIC: CONTINUUM IN TRIBUTE TO IVES
LEAD: THE composer Charles Ives has been abundantly celebrated in recent years; as such, this listener found Continuum's program Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, ''Ives the Visionary,'' somewhat less engaging than the group's usual performances.
At this point, Ives does not need Continuum's advocacy as much as do most of the composers the group takes on (recent concerts have been devoted to new music from Israel, the avant-garde in the Soviet Union, the music of Arvo Part, Alfred Schnittke and the man who elevated the player piano into the world of high Modernism, Conlon Nancarrow.)

Savings Bond Sales Increase
LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds totaled $710 million in January, as the total amount of savings bonds held by the public reached a record $93.11 billion, the Government reported.


Karrinyup Kangaroos
LEAD: NEAR the third tee at the Lake Karrinyup Country Club, black swans, pelicans, cranes and ducks could be seen splashing.
Off in a eucalyptus tree, a kookaburra laughed, understandably.
Three wandering Yanks, turning a lay day into a play day, were about to swing their drivers.
With a loopy lunge, one who shall be known as Kindred Spirit pushed his tee shot toward trees and palm bushes.


Trooper Killed in Missouri
LEAD: A Missouri highway patrolman was shot and killed here today as he sat in his patrol car, the authorities said.
Russell W. Harper, 45 years old, of Springfield, an 18-year veteran, was killed by one of several bullets that pierced his car, said Sgt.
Sam Kaunley, a highway patrol spokesman.
Sergeant Kaunley said a witness told the police that a white man wearing camouflage trousers, a dark sweatshirt and a blue and white cap got out of a red pickup truck and fired shots at the patrol car.

BUSINESS DEIGES: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1987
LEAD: The Economy The liability insurance crisis appears to be over after two years of coverage cancellations and sharp increases in premiums.
Companies that could not buy coverage at any price are now finding it, and premiums have leveled off.
But coverage is more expensive, and less extensive, than before.

LEAD: Nancy Lopez shot a 2-over-par 74 and weathered a challenge from Kathy Baker to win the $200,000 Sarasota Classic by three strokes today, a victory that qualifies her for induction into the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame.

But fewer than 100,000 new subscribers have signed on, according to preliminary figures obtained recently from the four H.M.O.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: The Relationships column on the Style page on Feb. 2, about the prospect of losing a job, misstated the employment status of Dr.
Leonard Moss, a psychiatrist.
He is a consultant to the Mobil Oil Corporation.
His hours were reduced during a reorganization, but he was never a full-time employee and was not laid off.

G.M. Talks Collapse
LEAD: The negotiations between the Hungarian truck maker Raba Eto and the General Motors Corporation for a barter deal have collapsed, Budapest radio said.
Under the plan, Hungary would have imported Opel cars from G.M.
A Budapest newspaper quoted a Raba executive as saying that G.M. asked too much for the Opels and offered too little for Raba goods.

Some Bonds Ruled Out For Second Refinancing

Hasbro's Net Off 11.8%
LEAD: Hasbro Inc., one of the nation's largest toy makers, said yesterday that it earned $17.2 million, or 29 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, down 11.8 percent from $19.5 million, or 34 cents a share, a year ago.
Revenue rose 10.6 percent, to $358.8 million, from $324.5 million.
For the year, the company's earnings were little changed at $99.2 million, or $1.71 a share.


JOHN M. HIGHTOWER, REPORTER
LEAD: John M. Hightower, who won a Pulitzer Prize and other honors as a diplomatic correspondent for The Associated Press, died today of cancer.
He was 77 years old.


NOTES ON FASHION
LEAD: BUBBLES and bows.
That's the word on what's selling in the stores as the new spring styles hit the racks.
At Bergdorf Goodman, bubble-shaped skirts by Bruce Oldfield, Vicky Tiel and Fabrice are floating out of the store.
Bloomingdale's reports that crinolines and petticoats of all kinds are selling, mainly in above-the-knee lengths, though Donna Karan's calf-length poplin skirt boosted by petticoats is also a success.


Ex-Guard Is Shot at Hotel
LEAD: A former security guard at the Holland Hotel on 42d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, where many welfare families are housed, was shot and critically wounded last night.
The guard, Malik Muhammad of 350 West 56th Street, was found on the seventh-floor hallway floor with gunshot wounds in the head and the left arm.

REAGAN EXPECTED TO BACK PROPOSAL ON MAJOR ILLNESS
LEAD: President Reagan is expected to support a health insurance program for catastrophic illness that would expand Medicare coverage of elderly people, Administration officials said today.
The decision would end more than two months of debate that produced an impasse within the Administration.


Meat Output Seen Easing
LEAD: World beef and veal output is expected to fall slightly this year, bringing relief from years of overproduction and improving prospects for a firmer market, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has predicted.

Kings Dismiss Coach
LEAD: The Sacramento Kings yesterday dismissed Coach Phil Johnson and replaced him with one of his assistants, Jerry Reynolds.
The Kings also dismissed another assistant coach, Frank Hamblen.
They replaced him with Don Buse, a former N.B.A. player.
It was the second time the Kings had dismissed Johnson as head coach.

Surgery for Nehemiah
LEAD: Renaldo Nehemiah, the world-record holder in the 110-meter hurdles, was scheduled to undergo surgery today for removal of a bone spur on his left heel.
Dr.
Tony Daly, a sports medicine specialist who will perform the surgery at Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital in Marina Del Ray, Calif., said Nehemiah could be sidelined for two and a half months.


Paramount Home Video Chooses Thompson
LEAD: Paramount Home Video in Los Angeles has assigned its advertising to the local office of the J. Walter Thompson Company.
Hollace Brown, vice president of advertising for the client, would only say that the ad budget was in seven figures.
And she made it sound like the healthy seven figures.


Murdoch Sells Several Units
LEAD: The News Corporation, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said today that it had sold its television operations and several other media properties to the Westfield Capital Corporation of Sydney for about $555 million.

SUPPLY OF GROWTH HORMONE BRINGS HOPE FOR NEW USES
LEAD: HUMAN growth hormone, long available in minuscule amounts to help abnormally short children reach normal adult height, is finally being produced in mass quantities by genetic engineering techniques, opening the door to a wealth of potential new medical uses.
But experts fear that plentiful supplies may also encourage abuse - that practitioners of ''cosmetic endocrinology'' will use the hormone to increase athletic prowess or to increase the height of children in the belief it will improve their social and economic prospects.

Dow Falls by 10.13; Dollar Drop Cited
LEAD: Trading volume was light yesterday on Wall Street and stock prices drifted lower after a sharp drop in the dollar's value brought on new fears that the Federal Reserve's ability to cut interest rates might be hampered.


Lord of the Birds
LEAD: For the kindly people who set out feeders of bird seed in winter, February's snows have brought a sense of reward.
Resident birds have been crowding around the handouts and have been joined by northern birds not always seen hereabouts.
There are pine siskins by the flock; there are evening grosbeaks and redpolls, and nearby there are mouse-eating snowy owls, wintering on Long

LEAD: A 1,000-foot high fountain in Lake Michigan, a ''Great Wall of Milwaukee'' and a solar-heated geodesic dome that would house the world's largest indoor playground have been suggested as Milwaukee searches for a symbol that would draw worldwide attention.

American Medical Rejects Pesch Bid
LEAD: American Medical International Inc., the big West Coast hospital chain, said yesterday that it had ''no interest in pursuing'' a $1.74 billion takeover bid from LeRoy A. Pesch, a Chicago physician.


POLICE SAY UNIDENTIFIED CHILDREN IN FLORIDA ARE NOT VICTIMS OF CULT
LEAD: Local police officials announced here today that six children found last week in Florida had apparently not been kidnapped and that there was no evidence to show that the secretive group that has been raising them is a cult involved in child abuse.

Drug Suspect Ordered Held
LEAD: A man described by prosecutors as among the world's leading and most dangerous cocaine traffickers was ordered held without bond today on drug charges.
Security at the hearing was so tight that the nails in people's shoes set off a metal-detector alarm.
The defendant, Carlos Lehder Rivas, 37 years old, was being held on 11 drug-smuggling counts.


For Confidentiality In AIDS Testing
LEAD: Renewed attention is being focused on questions about AIDS testing.
Who should be tested?
Should it be voluntary or mandatory?
Should test results be kept confidential or made public?


Defectors in American Debut
LEAD: Luba Pisarenkova and Yuri Krasnov gave their first circus performances at the Memorial Coliseum here this weekend since they defected from the Soviet Union last Sept. 22.
The married couple walked away from the Leningrad Music Hall performing troupe and into the United States Embassy while the group was on tour in the Seychelles.


Sjoberg Joins Meet
LEAD: Patrik Sjoberg of Sweden, holder of the world indoor high jump record at 7 feet 10 3/4 inches, is planning to compete in Saturday night's United States Olympic Invitational track meet at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, according to the meet director, Ray Lumpp.
Competing against Sjoberg will be Jimmy Howard, the American-record holder, and Dennis Lewis, the defending champion.


STATE JUSTICE DECLARES OFFICE OF SUFFOLK EXECUTIVE VACANT
LEAD: The official status of the Suffolk County Executive, Michael A. LoGrande, was placed in doubt yesterday when a state judge ruled that the job of Suffolk County Executive was vacant and that the Governor could appoint a successor, or mandate a special election to fill the post.

SANDSTROM EXCELS IN A QUIET MANNER
LEAD: In the peacefulness of the Ranger locker room the other night, after a half-dozen TV crews and some 40 reporters had left, the equipment staff and the laundry crew moved without talking, sorting out the uniforms, running a vacuum across the blue carpet.
The players had separated for their all-star week hiatus, and now it was time for their locker stalls to be straightened and their mail to be stacked.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.  How do bullet-proof vests work?
A.
Most lightweight bullet-resistant garments are made of Kevlar, a material developed by the Du Pont Company.
Kevlar, once described as ''the step beyond nylon,'' is formed of fibers of aromatic polyamide, ultra-strong chains of carbon atoms.
The material resists penetration by low-velocity projectiles like shrapnel and pistol bullets.


2 PHONE CONCERNS POST PROFITS
LEAD: The GTE Corporation and United Telecommunications Inc., which formed the long-distance carrier U S Sprint last year, yesterday both reported increases in earnings for the fourth quarter and the year.


'MANCHILD REVISITED' OFFERS VIEWS ON CRIME
LEAD: ''MANCHILD REVISITED,'' subtitled ''A Commentary by Claude Brown,'' isn't quite what you expect.
In the 1965 book ''Manchild in the Promised Land,'' Mr.
Brown wrote about growing up in Harlem in the 1940's and 50's.
In ''Manchild Revisited,'' on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, he talks about violent crime.

LEFT SOVIET FOR CANCER TREATMENT
LEAD: Inna Kitrosskaya Meiman, the wife of a Soviet dissident, died yesterday at the Lombardi Cancer Research Center of Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, three weeks after she was allowed to go abroad for treatment of an inoperable tumor on her neck.
She was 53 years old and had been waiting years for permission to travel.


THOSE STODGY SAILORS
LEAD: The America's Cup race emerged as one of the great studio sports of all time.
Some studio - the entire Indian Ocean - but how else explain this recent phenomenon?


That Vanuatu Party
LEAD: When a delegation from the tiny Pacific nation of Vanuatu came to Washington recently for talks with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and a meeting with scholars from the Smithsonian Institution's Wilson Center, it did what any other diplomatic group would do: It threw a party on Embassy Row.


U.S. JUDGE RETRACTS CRITICISM OF A JUROR
LEAD: A Federal judge who appeared to criticize a juror two weeks ago for holding out for acquittal in the trial of an organized-crime figure told the juror in a personal letter yesterday that there was ''no possible basis for criticism of your conduct.''

Kaiser Aluminum
LEAD: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, based in Oakland, Calif., said the previously announced sale of its subsidiary Kaiser Aluminium Europe Inc. to Hoogovens Groep B.V. provides for the Dutch steel and aluminum concern to pay $175 million in cash at closing.
The sale has a total value of about $280 million, a Kaiser spokesman said.

LEAD: It is the rare executive who can concede that his own job is redundant.

Precious Blood
LEAD: The snowstorms buffeting New York have slowed blood donations to a mere trickle as schools, businesses and churches cancel blood drives.
That means depletion of supplies already at a dangerously low level.
The result is a blood emergency.
The five-day blood inventory normal for this time of year is down to only one day.

LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, the former White House national security adviser and a prominent figure in investigations of the secret sale of arms to Iran, was admitted to Bethesda Naval Hospital today after taking an overdose of Valium, according to his lawyers.


Soviet Docking in Space
LEAD: Two Soviet astronauts aboard a Soyuz craft have linked up with the orbiting station Mir, and Soviet space officials expressed satisfaction with the performance of the crew and a new docking technique.

LEAD: LOW petroleum prices in recent years have all but halted American development of alternative energy sources, but in Norway and several other countries, the extraction of electrical energy from ocean waves has become a reality.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A table in Business Day on Jan. 22, showing short interest in New York Stock Exchange shares for the month ended Jan. 15, carried an incorrect total supplied by the First Pennsylvania Corporation for its stock.
As a result, the total Big Board short interest and the decline for the month were also incorrect.


OFFICIALS ON CASE ASSERT WEDTECH FALSIFIED REPORTS FOR A LONG TIME
LEAD: For at least four years before filing for bankruptcy last December, executives of the Wedtech Corporation prepared falsified financial statements that likely misled bank lenders, stockholders and bond investors, according to law-enforcement officials working on the case.

Steel Output Down 1%
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.323 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 1 percent from the previous week's 1.337 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 57.8 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 58.4 percent in the previous week.


PICKENS GROUP GIVES UP DIAMOND SHAMROCK BID
LEAD: T. Boone Pickens today abandoned his third attempt to acquire the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, leaving analysts uncertain about whether he intends to attempt yet another bid or will turn his sights on a different energy company.

LEAD: Two plastic surgeons testifying as expert witnesses said yesterday that a 66-year-old Bronx woman could have continued to slash at police officers who were trying to subdue her, even after a shotgun blast had torn away part of her hand that held a knife.

Details Given on Sale Of Spielvogel Office
LEAD: Gary Bayer, president of the Chicago office of Backer &amp; Spielvogel, yesterday disclosed the names of the three other admen who will join him in buying the office from Britain's Saatchi &amp; Saatchi.
Papers should be signed in two weeks, after which the former office of the New York agency that was originally the house agency of Quaker Oats will be known as Bayer, Bess, Vanderwarker &amp; Flynn.


Major Quake Strikes Villages On Papua New Guinea Coast
LEAD: A major earthquake struck near the coast of Papua New Guinea in the southwestern Pacific today, leveling villages and leaving at least 1,000 people homeless, officials said.
A second tremor struck the area some hours later.


Allotments Cut In Paribas Sale
LEAD: Private investors, promised at least 10 shares each in the Government's sale of the state-owned bank group Paribas, will have to settle for four shares because of heavier than expected demand.


Pilot Is Killed as Helicopter Explodes off Waikiki Beach
LEAD: A tour helicopter exploded and crashed just after takeoff from a helipad on Waikiki Beach Sunday, killing its pilot.
Four passengers were rescued by surfers, canoists and beachgoers, the authorities said.


MUSIC: 3 PIANISTS
LEAD: AFFILIATE ARTISTS and its supporters at the Xerox Corporation have had the happy idea of wedding new performers to new music.
Another of these affairs - featuring three emerging pianists and two world premieres - happened at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday.

FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


PIANO: LAZAR BERMAN
LEAD: THERE was a great deal of extramusical excitement surrounding last night's piano recital at Carnegie Hall by Lazar Berman, and, of course, some musical interest as well.
An appearance by the Soviet virtuoso, his first here in seven years, was certain to generate curiosity.
However, before the music could begin, the entire audience was kept standing outside in the bitter cold for as much as 25 minutes while an electronic security check was run, airport-style, by guards stationed immediately inside the hall's doors.


Acting Lessons For the Political World
LEAD: Dave Modai, a 32-year-old lawyer and lobbyist, stands in front of a dozen people.
He is speaking gibberish, gesticulating wildly, faking accents, throwing out snatches of foreign languages, improvising phrases like ''bla bla bla.'' He is selling toy dolls.
Selling toy dolls?


MENCKEN SHOW REBUTS RACISM CHARGE
LEAD: The ghost of H. L. Mencken, the iconoclastic journalist and acerbic social critic who appointed himself - and, in his opinionated fashion, became - the nation's angry conscience in the decades between the World Wars, is being rehabilitated here in a way that even his curmudgeonly specter might approve.

LEAD: Henry D. Clarke Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Clabir Corporation, has built a company with successful acquisitions, but he has also had his share of deals that fell through.

LEAD: Dennis Conner, drapery maker.


SIMMS RECEIVES REWARDS AS M.V.P.
LEAD: Phil Simms, the Giants' quarterback, was presented yesterday with the rewards for being named the most valuable player of Super Bowl XXI last month, a new car valued at $17,000 and $10,000 to donate to the charities of his choice.


LYNDA CARTER STARS IN 'STILLWATCH'
LEAD: ''STILLWATCH,'' on CBS at 9 tonight, was adapted by Laird Koenig and David Peckinpah from a novel by Mary Higgins Clark.
The executive producers are Zev Braun and Lynda Carter, once television's ''Wonder Woman.'' Ms.
Carter is also one of the stars, playing Patricia Traymore, a television news reporter who arrives in Washington to produce an in-depth profile on Senator Abigail Winslow, who is on the verge of becoming the next Vice President of the United States.

3 ISRAELIS MAY LOSE IMMUNITY IN POLLARD SPY CASE
LEAD: The Justice Department has notified three Israelis that it will seek to revoke their immunity from prosecution in the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case and has told a prominent Israeli Air Force officer that he may soon be indicted, Reagan Administration officials said today.


A SAD JOYCE CAROL OATES FORSWEARS PSEUDONYMS
LEAD: Pronouncing herself surprised and very disappointed that her literary cover had been blown, Joyce Carol Oates said she would never again try to write a book under a pseudonym.
She tried it this once, she said yesterday, because ''I wanted to escape from my own identity.''


Careers; Improving Employee Morale
LEAD: FOR the past two years consulting firms have been helping companies dismiss thousands of hourly workers as well as many middle managers.
Now, consulting firms are being hired to advise on ways to keep the remaining skeleton forces motivated and loyal at a time when middle management cynicism and pessimism have never been higher.


BEYOND FIREWORKS: NEW YORK'S CEREBRAL SALUTE TO 1787
LEAD: On Feb. 21, it will be exactly 200 years since the Confederation Congress, sitting in New York, called for a national convention in Philadelphia to revise the Articles of Confederation.


AIDS POSES A CLASSIC DILEMMA
LEAD: AS Government officials struggle to control the lethal spread of AIDS, they are confronting a classic dilemma in public health: how to balance the individual's right to privacy with the public's right to take stiff measures to thwart an epidemic.
Similar clashes have arisen in the past.
But acquired immune deficiency syndrome has added new dimensions because of enormous public attention and the stigma and discrimination faced by people known simply to be carriers of the AI


Note and Bond Rates Gain
LEAD: Interest rates rose modestly for short- and long-term Treasury securities yesterday as prices for some issues fell below levels set at last week's auctions.


THE TROUBLE WITH QUOTAS
LEAD: AMERICAN colleges face growing charges that they are using secret quotas in admissions.
The prime target, according to critics, are students of Asian descent.
Women may be next, these critics say.


RECITAL: SOEDERSTROEM SINGS
LEAD: ELISABETH SOEDERSTROEM'S song recital at Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon, in tandem with the pianist Vladimir Ashkenazy, was one of the most beautiful concerts of the season.


Boesky Investors Agree To Distribution Payout
LEAD: The investors in Ivan F. Boesky's investment firm have agreed to terms for distributing the firm's remaining capital, sources familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.


ISRAELI TROOPS SHOOT AT ARAB PROTESTERS, LEAVING 9 WOUNDED
LEAD: Nine Palestinians were wounded by Israeli soldiers today in two West Bank confrontations described as the worst outbreak of violence this year in the tense occupation zone, Israeli officials said.


Horse Cents
LEAD: For generations, horseshoes has been a serene country recreation, a backyard and barnyard sport in which stakes are of little consequence except to be thrown at.
Now it appears headed for far greener pastures.


FROM PARIS, SHORT BRIGHT NIGHTS
LEAD: Spurred by the success of the bubbles and poufs in their fall and winter collections, Paris couture designers opened up an important category of fashion for spring and summer: the short evening dress.
Sometimes very short indeed - Yves Saint Laurent showed a number of puckered clingy black dresses that barely cleared the top of the thighs -these styles added to the youthful look that is bringing new relevance to the couture.

LEAD: An experimental geothermal well being drilled in Honduras by scientists from the Los Alamos National Laboratory has produced a gusher that promises the production of cheap electricity for the poor Central American country.

LEAD: BRITISH experimenters have discoverered that the arch of the human foot compresses and recoils like a spring, providing a significant amount of the energy used in running.

RIVERSIDE DANCE TO CLOSE
LEAD: The Riverside Dance Festival, now in its 12th year at the Theater of the Riverside Church, will close in June.
Joan Bacchus, director of communications at Riverside Church, cited a $900,000 deficit at the church as a reason for the termination of the festival, part of a program of cutbacks at Riverside.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo and Bernard Charles, next to him, chairman of the Governor's black advisory council, arriving yesterday for a meeting with the Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus.

LEAD: A former shipyard worker has filed what is believed to be the first product liability lawsuit stemming from exposure to glycol ethers in paints.

LEAD: For more than a century, farmers here have taken the cool brown water of the Arkansas River, channeled it into their fields in shallow ditches, and watched the land explode with color and crops.

Dogs' Deaths Halt Tests On Hearts

Chip Makers Assail Japan
LEAD: The Semiconductor Industry Association called today for President Reagan to impose trade measures immediately against Japan.

MUSICC: IN-DEPTH BEETHOVEN EXPERIENCE
LEAD: By now, original-instrument performances of Baroque and Classical music are commonplace.
And there is no logical reason why such an approach cannot be extended right through the 19th century.
Familiar masterpieces by Beethoven, Schubert, Mendelssohn, Brahms and Wagner would sound very different if played with the instruments and in the performing style common when they were composed.

LEAD: THE recent discovery of a wildly speculative manuscript by Freud, which had long been thought lost, promises to touch off a new round of debate about the influences that spawned psychoanalytic thought.

'A CAROL BURNETT SPECIAL' ON ABC
LEAD: ONCE upon a time, variety shows were a television staple.
Hardly a night passed without some performer or personality being host of an hour or so of comedy and music. ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' led the way on Sunday evenings for years.
And then, suddenly, there were none.
Perhaps the public had heard all the jokes and seen all the production numbers.
