VATICAN CHOOSES PANEL OF 3 TO EVALUATE SEATTLE DIOCESE
LEAD: The Vatican announced yesterday that it had appointed a commission of three bishops to evaluate the governing arrangement in the Seattle Archdiocese, where Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen was superseded by an auxiliary bishop in a disciplinary move.


IN BEIRUT, ONLY THE CALAMITIES CHANGE
LEAD: A Lebanese man returning to Beirut after a six-week vacation abroad found many changes in the city.


CHICAGO-LONDON FUTURES LINK IS SET
LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade and the London International Financial Futures Exchange agreed yesterday to link each other's futures contracts.


The Contras Minus Arturo Cruz
LEAD: When Congress reversed itself a year ago and voted $100 million in military aid for the contras, what tilted the balance was the joint appeal of three rebel leaders: Adolfo Calero, Arturo Cruz and Alfonso Robelo.
Mr.
Cruz, a left-of-center democrat, carried the most weight.
Yet now, he seems ready to break with other Nicaraguan rebel leaders.


Boston U. Wins Beanpot
LEAD: Mike Kelfer's goal 5 minutes 28 seconds into overtime tonight lifted Boston University to a 4-3 victory over Northeastern in the championship game of the 35th annual Beanpot hockey tournament.

LEAD: Marvin L. Warner, the former owner of the Home State Savings Bank, testified today that he was not responsible for some questionable deals with a Florida securities company whose closing led to the 1985 collapse of the thrift institution.

IS THIS AMERICA?
LEAD: She is 22 years old, a student in San Diego, Calif.
She was born in Ramallah, in the West Bank, came to this country at the age of 3 and is an American citizen.
On the telephone, she sounds like California.
I shall call her Evelyn Bitar: not her real name.

MOSCOW CONVENING A FORUM ON PEACE
LEAD: Several hundred prominent professors, artists, scientists and statesmen from the West have been invited to Moscow next weekend for a three-day forum on nuclear disarmament.


Owens Boar To Meet on Bid
LEAD: The board of Owens-Illinois Inc. is scheduled to meet Thursday to decide whether the company ought to be acquired by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company in a bid valued at $3.6 billion.
But there were rumors on Wall Street yesterday that the meeting had been moved up.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A Washington dispatch last Wednesday, about a vote by the House of Representatives to override President Reagan's veto of a water bill, misidentified the home state of Representative Arlan Stangeland.
He is a Minnesota Republican.


When Great Isn't Good Enough
LEAD: Suppose a country weak in basketball - England, perhaps - decided to launch a national program to upgrade the sport.
Suppose Julius Erving took up residence in London and offered his help as a coach. ''Hold on, Julius,'' the English say. ''You can't coach here if you don't have one of our coaching licenses.


INSIDE
LEAD: Vatican Inquiry on Seattle  The Vatican named three bishops to study the Archdiocese of Seattle, where Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen was disciplined.
Page A16.
Dollar Plunges  The dollar had its biggest drop in months when Treasury Secretary Baker said no meeting was planned to stabilize the currency.


TEMPLE IS WINNER IN OVERTIME, 73-70
LEAD: Mike Vreeswyk made two free throws with 13 seconds left in overtime tonight to help Temple defeat Penn State, 73-70, in an Atlantic 10 game.


Captors Drop Deadline; Beirut Bomb Kills 17
LEAD: Kidnappers holding four Western hostages reiterated that they would kill their captives at midnight tonight unless 400 Arab prisoners were freed by Israel, then, as the deadline passed, announced that it had been extended ''until further notice.''

LEAD: Two men delayed the start of a piano recital by the Russian pianist Lazar Berman at Carnegie Hall last night, shouting ''Free Soviet Jews, Communist Nazis.''


Western Union
LEAD: The Western Union Corporation said that it expected to report a substantial charge against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect the write-down of certain communications facilities.
The financially troubled company said that, before the write-down, it earned about $17 million, which includes a gain of about $40 million from the sale of its interests in Airfone Inc.

THE STAGE: 'MOMS'
LEAD: FOR 50 years, Jackie (Moms) Mabley was a top headliner on the black vaudeville circuit.
In her squashed hat, baggy housedress and drooping socks, looking not too far removed from a shopping-bag lady, she won laughs with her attitude of total disrespect.
Late in life (she died in 1975), she began to break through to a wider public.

THIOKOL LOSES CONTRACT FOR MILITARY BOOSTERS
LEAD: MORTON Thiokol Inc., the maker of the space shuttle's booster rockets, has lost a key contract to make boosters for a fleet of unmanned military rockets, industry officials said yesterday.
The rockets are to launch military satellites grounded by the shuttle disaster a year ago.

Digital Equipment
LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation, as expected, introduced two new models of its popular VAX line of computers, one of which will sell for half the cost of previous low-end models.
The new models are aimed at the engineering, educational, scientific, government and commercial markets.
The VAX Station 2000 is a free-standing desktop computer that has high-performance graphics capabilities, the company said.

LEAD: Honeywell Inc. lost $492.8 million in the fourth quarter of 1986 because of huge, one-time charges for restructuring, write-downs and asset sales, the company said today.

LEAD: New York City's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, who has said he made telephone calls on behalf of an investment partnership formed by Ivan F. Boesky, also held financial interests in two other companies controlled by Mr.
Boesky, according to information provided yesterday by Mr.
Goldin's office.

LEAD: Differences between Nicaragua and its neighbors are sharpening, making a negotiated settlement of regional disputes more distant than ever, according to delegates at a meeting here called to discuss Central American issues.

LEAD: North Korean sports officials gathered today to discuss with International Olympic Committee leaders Pyongyang's insistence on sharing the 1988 Summer Olympics with South Korea.
The meeting is set for Wednesday.


Death Sentence in 3 Killings
LEAD: A jury today ordered the death penalty for a man who said he hacked three women to death with a hatchet after he tired of hearing them argue.
The man, David Martin Long, 33 years old, previously told the state district court panel he wanted the death penalty and was afraid he would kill again.
He was convicted Saturday of capital murder in the Sept.


Lieberman Traded
LEAD: Nancy Lieberman, who became the first woman in professional sports to compete in an all-male league when she averaged 1.7 points and 1.3 assists with the Springfield Fame in the United States Basketball League last season, has returned closer to home.
In exchange for second- and third-round draft choices, the 5-foot-10-inch point guard from Far Rockaway, Queens, and Old Dominion College was obtained yesterday by the Long Island Knights of the U.S.B.L.


Taylor's Credo
LEAD: At a luncheon yesterday at Gallagher's restaurant, where Lawrence Taylor received the Seagram Sports Award as pro football's defensive player of the year, the Giants linebacker answered many questions.
But he has never discussed last winter's rehabilitation from chemical dependency, and he bristled when asked what advice he would give to youngsters about dealing with drugs.


Cult's Farm Searched For Human Remains
LEAD: A plot on a farm that was used by a cult was excavated today after the authorities received information that human remains might be buried there, but nothing was found, the police said.

THE STAGE: 'CIRCUS'
LEAD: HUCK SNYDER'S ''Circus'' is a contender for the title of the smallest show on earth.
Next to it, the one-ring Big Apple Circus is spectacular.
It is the tiniest top - one-tenth the size of ''Le Cirque Imaginaire,'' the Victoria Chaplin show seen earlier this season - and festooned with fanciful delights.


A Video Camera for Children
LEAD: Budding film makers take note: At the New York Toy Fair this week, the Fisher-Price toy company demonstrated a $150 camera that can record 11 minutes of black and white video images on a regular 90-minute audio tape cassette.
To play back the recording, the user simply plugs the camera directly into a television set; a video cassette player is not required.


MEXICO: WORLD'S BACK DOOR TO U.S.
LEAD: Citizens of countries as far away as India, China, Yugoslavia and Lebanon are increasingly using Mexico as a transit and staging point to enter the United States illegally, according to American and Mexican government officials.

LEAD: Charles Stewart Desmond, who was Chief Judge of New York from 1960 through 1966, died Monday at Mercy Hospital in Buffalo.

BALLET UNITES U.S. AND SOVIET YOUTHS
LEAD: It was the first time the Soviet and American teen-agers had ever met, but they skipped the usual banter about rock stars and got right to a topic close to their hearts: ballet toe shoes.

Worker Hurt in Brooklyn Building Collapse
LEAD: Firefighters removing an injured man from site of a collapsed building yesterday in the Fort Greene section.
The man, identified as Kenny Rencher, was trapped for a while under 15 feet of debris in the rubble of the 100-year-old structure.
He suffered minor injuries.
The building was undergoing renovation.

Devils Recall Two
LEAD: With injuries to Greg Adams (bruised ribs), Mel Bridgman (irritation of left foot), Timo Blomqvist (fractured nose and left eye orbit) and Jan Ludvig (left hip flexor), the Devils have recalled Perry Anderson, a wing, and Uli Hiemer, a defenseman from West Germany, from the minor leagues.
The two played the first half of the season with the Devils and were demoted Jan.


MAN AND WOMAN STABBED TO DEATH IN APARTMENT
LEAD: A man and a woman were found stabbed to death in an apartment in Greenwich Village yesterday morning, and the police said they did not know whether the slayings were a double murder or a murder and a suicide.


'Well, I'm a Gentleman'
LEAD: When Michael Burke worked as a sports executive in this town, he always seemed a throwback to the age when gallantry was expected, when brave gestures were not just a page out of Hemingway.

STATE DEPT. GIVES MOSCOW A RARE PAT ON THE BACK
LEAD: The Reagan Administration gave Moscow a rare pat on the back today, welcoming the Kremlin's decision to free 140 political prisoners as ''an important step'' and urging further releases as a way toward improving Soviet-American relations.


EMANUEL HELLER
LEAD: Emanuel Heller, professor of marketing and dean of students at Pace Unversity's Manhattan campus, died Monday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.


YOUTH COOPERATES IN BREAKING CASE
LEAD: Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor who investigated the Howard Beach racial attack, said yesterday that the break in the case occurred on the holiday honoring the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr., when one of the young men involved in the attack came forward.


Hockey Bans Urged
LEAD: According to General Secretary Jan-Ake Edvinsson, a five-man disciplinary committee of the International Ice Hockey Federation has recommended disqualification from international tournaments for periods of up to three years of all 19 players (excluding goaltenders) in a Soviet-Canada brawl at the world junior hockey championships Jan.


4 Members of Family Die in House Fire
LEAD: Four members of a family, including two children, were killed early yesterday in a fire in an apartment building that investigators said was being repaired to correct housing code violations.

Knight and Orioles May Reach a Deal
LEAD: Ray Knight, the unemployed hero of the World Series, has a chance to end his free fall from the Mets today by accepting a one-year contract to play third base for the Baltimore Orioles.


CONCERT: AN DIE MUSIK AT MERKIN
LEAD: AN DIE MUSIK, the chamber-music group, finished its 11th season at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday afternoon with every evidence that its roots grow stronger and deeper in New York's concert life.
This program, inventively planned, played to an audience that filled Merkin's auditorium and spilled up onto the stage; the balance and substance of the music was largely matched by the performances.


How to Be Constructive in Africa
LEAD: Already the next wave of human suffering breaks over Africa, this time the southern third of the continent.
Here, in Angola and Mozambique, are the highest infant mortality rates in the world.
Here, in the nine black-ruled states near South Africa, war, ethnic rivalry and drought threaten starvation and wrenching migrations.


INSIDE
LEAD: Democrats Choose Atlanta  The Democratic Party announced that it had decided to hold its 1988 Presidential nominating convention in Atlanta.
Page B14.  2 Projects Advance  A builder was picked for a residential complex on the Hudson River, and the Guggenheim Museum scaled down plans for a tower.


Low-Budget Movies Get A High Gloss
LEAD: The American public's appetite for feature films is growing rapidly, in large part because of the phenomenal popularity of video cassettes.
The cost of making those feature films, though, is rising even more rapidly.
In 1985, the last year for which figures are available, the average production cost of a feature film was $16.8 million, according to the Motion Picture Association of America.


RJR Nabisco Net Falls 6%
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 6 percent, but the full year showed a record.


'Starlight Express' Delayed
LEAD: Mechanical problems with the staging have delayed the opening of the new musical ''Starlight Express,'' by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Richard Stilgoe.
It is now to begin previews Feb. 19 and open March 5 at the Gershwin Theater, said Bill Evans, spokesman for the show.
The musical, directed by Trevor Nunn, was to have begun previews next Tuesday and to have opened on Feb.


BAKER SEES YEN RATE AS SATISFACTORY
LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, in an apparent reward to Japan for its efforts to cooperate with the United States, suggested today that the dollar had now declined enough against the Japanese yen.

Stanley Kunitz Wins Bollingen Poetry Prize
LEAD: Stanley Kunitz has won the Bollingen Prize in Poetry of the Yale University Library.
The $5,000 prize, announced yesterday, is given every two years to one or more living American poets for the best collection published in that period, or for a body of poetry written over several years.
Mr.
Kunitz, who is 81 years old, and whose ''Selected Poems'' (1958) won the Pulitzer Prize, was cited for the ''growth and vigor'' of his own work, his support as a ''nurturing spirit for scores of younger poets,'' and his influence on such poets as Theodore Roethke and Robert


Dust Balls, Vacuums And Library Stacks
LEAD: ''POMPIDOU'' by Rouanet was absolutely disgusting.

MEXICAN PRICES SURGE
LEAD: Comsumer prices rose 8.1 percent in January, according to Mexico's central bank, thus starting another year of what could be triple-digit inflation.
In 1986, Mexican inflation soared to a record 105.7 percent.
Although the Government hopes to reduce that by 20 or 30 percentage points this year, some private analysts warn that it could reach 120 percent.

Could We Have Less Progress in Central Park?
LEAD: To the Editor:


A DEATH STIRS FEAR OF AIDS ACROSS JAPAN
LEAD: A wave of anxiety over AIDS has spread across Japan, sending Japanese to clinics for blood tests and prodding the Government to start special programs to keep the disease in check.


Soviet Ballet Students Begin Tour in the City
LEAD: Visiting Soviet teen-age dancers performing yesterday at the Juilliard School in Manhattan.
Students of the Perm State Ballet School compared notes on ballet shoes and other trade secrets with their counterparts at the School of American Ballet as the troupe began a two-week tour of the United States.

DANCE: BALINESE AND AMERICAN STYLES
LEAD: IN choreographing for her Balinese American Dance Theater, Islene Pinder combines Western modern dance with Balinese dance.
Her cultural borrowings resulted in two types of works -sketches and dance-dramas - when the troupe appeared Sunday afternoon at the Nikolais-Louis Studio.
The sketches were particularly effective.


Europe to Cut Butter Stocks
LEAD: The European Community's agriculture ministers agreed today to spend $3.7 billion to dispose of nearly all of the trading bloc's surplus butter, which totals more than 1.3 million tons and costs more than $1 billion a year to store.


DEMOCRATS, LOOKING SOUTH, PICK ATLANTA FOR '88 CONVENTION
LEAD: The Democratic Party decided today to hold its national convention in Atlanta July 18-21, 1988, underscoring the political importance of the Deep South in next year's Presidential election.

Neil Simon Leaves Hospital
LEAD: The playwright Neil Simon, recovered from adrenal-gland surgery, was discharged from Cedars Sinai Medical Center Sunday, the hospital announced.
Mr.
Simon, 59 years old, underwent the surgery Feb. 2 as a follow-up to an operation performed last year.


Contel-Comsat Merger Approved
LEAD: A telecommunications merger valued at about $2.5 billion was approved by stockholders of both the Contel Corporation and Comsat, but Federal regulators must approve the deal and it also may be examined by Congress.

LEAD: After a fruitless monthlong search for another buyer, Owens-Illinois Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company, the investment firm, for more than $3.6 billion in cash.

KOOP URGES TV CONDOM ADS TO FIGHT AIDS
LEAD: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, saying that condoms offered the best protection from the deadly AIDS virus for those who ''will not practice abstinence or monogamy,'' today called for condom advertisements on television.

M'FARLANE INQUIRY CLOSED, POLICE SAY
LEAD: Police officials said today that the drug overdose taken by Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser to President Reagan, was apparently a suicide attempt but that they had ended their investigation because there were no grounds for criminal charges.


LAWYER FAULTS THE DAILY NEWS FOR RACIAL BIAS
LEAD: A lawyer for four black journalists said in Federal court in Manhattan yesterday that The Daily News had a long-established pattern of racial bias that had ruined the careers of his clients.

Offering Increased By Texas Utility
LEAD: The Texas Utilities Electric Company is offering $250 million of 9 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds, due in 2017, at a price of 99.60 to yield 9.289 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.
It previously planned to offer $200 million of bonds.

PERSONAL HEALTH
LEAD: MILLIONS of Americans have taken seriously recent studies suggesting that diet may help to prevent certain devastating diseases.
Among the nutrients that have most captured consumer attention are calcium to prevent osteoporosis, fish oils to prevent heart disease and vitamin A to prevent cancer.


Economic Scene; The Dollar Tug-of-War
LEAD: THE foreign exchange markets have been nervous and confused about where the dollar is going.
One day it rallies, the next it plunges, sending shock waves through the bond, stock and futures markets, and then it rallies again, as investors struggle to interpret the Delphic remarks of Treasury Secretary James A.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A report on Jan. 3 in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page mis stated the period in which the brothers Robert and Edward Kennedy served together in the Senate.
It was 1965 to 1968.


3 MANHATTAN BUILDINGS ARE NAMED LANDMARKS
LEAD: The monumental former home office of the New York Life Insurance Company, the oldest surviving structure built as a synagogue in New York and a once-luxurious Upper West Side hotel all became official landmarks yesterday.

KHOMEINI, IN FIRST SPEECH IN 3 MONTHS, PLEDGES WAR UNTIL VICTORY
LEAD: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, in his first public speech in nearly three months, declared today that Iran's long conflict with Iraq was a holy crusade and that his fundamentalist Government would make ''war until victory.''


CHARGE IS MURDER FOR 3 OF YOUTHS IN QUEENS ATTACK
LEAD: Three white teen-agers from Queens were charged yesterday with murder and nine others were charged with lesser crimes in the second attempt by authorities to identify and prosecute participants in the Howard Beach racial attack.

Cattle Prices Advance While Pork Declines
LEAD: Cattle futures prices advanced yesterday despite lower wholesale beef prices.
Pork declined, with some pork belly deliveries suffering limit losses.


Politics of Smoking: Don't Hold Your Breath
LEAD: Legislation designed to curb smoking is more than a health issue in the House and the Senate.
It involves economics, the budget, individual rights, the Constitution, social issues and the old-fashioned trading of votes.


Chairman of GCA Revises Equity Plan
LEAD: Richard P. Rifenburgh, chairman and chief executive of the GCA Corporation, says he sees himself as a turnaround person. ''I do like a particularly difficult situation, and GCA was it,'' he said yesterday.


MORE ARE STUDIED
LEAD: The Soviet Union has pardoned 140 prisoners convicted of subversive activities, and a comparable number of cases are being reviewed, the Government said today.


VATICAN, ITS DEFICIT GROWING, ORDERS 1987 SPENDING FREEZE
LEAD: The Vatican, pressed by a swelling budget deficit, has ordered a spending freeze for 1987, church officials said today.


12 DEFENDANTS IN ATTACK CASE: A DIVERSE GROUP
LEAD: The 12 Queens teen-agers indicted yesterday in the Howard Beach racial attack are a varied lot of close friends and casual acquaintances.
One studies management; another wants to be an artist.
Some attend high school; others have entered college.

Bridge: A Fatal Blow Was Delivered By 'Suicidal' Defensive Play
LEAD: Perhaps the weirdest move in card play is the Grosvenor Gambit.
It is a suicidal defensive play that gives the declarer a chance to score a trick he is not entitled to.
The defender is confident that the declarer will not take advantage of the gambit because he will assume sanity rather than generosity.

LEAD: Within five years of returning to civilian life, Army combat veterans who served in Vietnam had an overall death rate 45 percent higher than a comparison group of veterans who served elsewhere in the same period, according to a Government study about to be published.


WINE TALK
LEAD: LONG before graduating to wine, most of us begin with milk, which, of course, brings us to our first vintage-dating: The carton says ''Sell by Feb. 11.'' But wine is wine and milk is milk, and never the twain shall sensibly meet in a glass.
Yet the twain come close to meeting when a half ounce of Cognac (brandy distilled from wine), a half ounce of heavy cream and a half ounce of creme de cacao are shaken together with cracked ice and strained into a cocktail glass.

Hutton Life Insurance Company and the World-Wide Reassurance Company of Britain, has assets of more than $2.9 billion and posted revenues of more than $700 million in 1986.

Trimming a Fillet of Beef
LEAD: A WHOLE fillet of beef can be an elegant and relatively simple entree if you are cooking for 10 to 12 guests.
It can be roasted whole and carved just before serving with the sauce of your choice, or sliced into individual fillets for pan-frying or broiling.
The fillet of beef, also called the tenderloin, often comes untrimmed from the butcher.

LEAD: After months of delay, Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, announced today that construction was about to begin on a Brooklyn shelter for homeless families - a model for other family shelters he hopes to build throughout New York City and the state.

LEAD: A gift of $100 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has been received from Dan Wedge of Sussex, N.J., honoring ''the honest soul'' at the American Male clothing store at 80th Street and Broadway in Manhattan who found and returned a lost purse containing valuables and refused a reward.

LEAD: This is the kind of southern French town, in the dry hills near the Mediterranean coast, that is often regarded by those who do not live here as old fashioned and steeped in archaic habits, virtually a symbol of the things that do not change in France.

LEAD: Rudolf Nureyev was quoted today as saying he would like to dance again in the Soviet Union after living more than 25 years in the West.

Remarrying Congress and the C.I.A.
LEAD: Next Tuesday, Robert M. Gates will appear for his confirmation hearing as Director of Central Intelligence.
He will surely be confirmed, as surely he ought.
But his appearance could accomplish more than that.
It could reconstitute a relationship between the intelligence community and Congress that was building beautifully until it came apart this winter.


Later Release Of Trade Data
LEAD: Trade balance reports will come out later each month to give fuller data and avoid revisions, the Government said today.
Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said monthly reports on the gross national product would also be delayed, partly to include the more complete trade data.

LEAD: ''I can say to you that there are comrades who think, the harsher the better.
But at the moment we are heading into a softening, so that we may have fewer people behind bars and behind barbed wire.''  - Gennadi I. Gerasimov,  the Soviet Foreign  Ministry spokesman.  [ A12:4. ]

LEAD: AS a professional chef, I find it easy to comprehend today's blending of Oriental flavors with those of the West.
I find myself using a good deal of so-called Asian flavors, including fresh ginger, fresh coriander, bean and chili paste and, of course, soy sauce.

Blimp's Invitation Revoked
LEAD: Officials have revoked an invitation for the Goodyear blimp to join the city's centennial celebration so as not to offend Uniroyal-Goodrich, the city's largest employer and Goodyear's competitor.
Having the blimp ''would be like having the big, bright Texaco star fly over Bartlesville,'' home of Phillips Petroleum, City Manager Craig Weinaug said Monday.


Fight Drugs With Work Camps
LEAD: The national hysteria over drug abuse appears to have faded.
Even the White House, having recently promised ''a sustained, relentless effort to rid America of this scourge,'' now talks of chopping drug enforcement funds.
And in truth, the drug legislation hustled through Congress last year leaned more heavily toward spending than imagination.

LEAD: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett handed out mixed grades today in his annual report on schools nationwide and called the results ''a hangover after the binge'' of recent improvements.

America's Cup Book Set
LEAD: St.
Martin's Press has paid a six-figure advance for Dennis Conner's story of his triumph in the America's Cup, and expects to have the book in stores in May, the publishing house announced Monday.
Titled ''Comeback: My Race for the America's Cup,'' the book, told to Bruce Stannard, an Australian journalist, is to contain more than 50 full-color photos, the publisher said.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A San Francisco dispatch on Feb. 2, about AIDS among Roman Catholic clergymen, misidentified a priest and his affilation.
He is the Rev.
Bernard Lynch, an order priest who counsels AIDS patients in New York.
He has no association with the Archdiocese of New York.


First Clash With Rebels Is Reported by Manila
LEAD: Troops battled Communist rebels today in the first clash since a cease-fire ended two days ago, and a military report said 18 people were killed, including 12 civilians caught in the crossfire.


CITICORP BUYING 50 SEARS UNITS
LEAD: Citicorp agreed yesterday to buy 50 savings and loan branches in Southern California from Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company.


KEAN AND GROUP OF MAYORS AGREE ON PACKAGE TO RAISE URBAN AID
LEAD: After hours of negotiations with legislative leaders and several mayors of big cities, Governor Kean said this evening that substantial agreement had been reached on an urban-aid package that would avoid layoffs and provide property-tax relief.


Market Place; Opinion Mixed On Tobaccos
LEAD: TOBACCO stocks, the market's best-performing group last year, ran into a slight selling squall yesterday. ''Some people were cashing in their chips after big gains enjoyed by the tobaccos,'' said Emanuel Goldman of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco.


OLIVE GROVE BRINGS ARABS AND JEWS TOGETHER
LEAD: A simple grove of olive trees brought Arabs and Jews together today to protest the Israeli Government's plan to uproot trees long tended by the Arabs.


Texas Accepts New Inmates
LEAD: The Texas prison system began accepting new inmates today after its population fell below a ceiling mandated by the state, but officials warned that this week's influx could force another cutoff.
About 390 new inmates were accepted by midafternoon and about 125 were released at the same time, according to a spokesman for the Texas Department of Corrections.

FILM: 'THE GOOD FATHER'
LEAD: THOUGH he makes a good living as a marketing executive with a London publishing house, Bill Hooper (Anthony Hopkins) lives in self-imposed squalor in a dingy bed-sitter near some railroad tracks.
Bill, divorced and the father of a small son, is furious with the world and everybody in it, especially with the self-sufficient Emmy, his former wife, who now lives with another man, and even with the child, whom he blames for coming between the parents.

I was a little surprised,'' Edberg said after his match with Reneberg, a junior at Southern Methodist.

STAGE: 'FELL OFF A TRUCK,' FOR CHILDREN
LEAD: IN the anthropomorphic world of the Paper Bag Players, the New York-based children's theater company that has just begun its 29th season, inanimate objects lead secret lives of which most of us remain oblivious.
Rebellious chairs reposition themselves when their owners aren't looking.
Innocuous-looking boxes turn into vaudevillian performers.

A.M.C. Warranties
LEAD: The American Motors Corporation said it had extended its engine and transmission warranties on 1987 Renault cars to six years or 60,000 miles, from five years or 50,000 miles.
A.M.C. also extended rust protection to six years or 100,000 miles.
The powertrain warranty is identical to those announced by the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.


MIXED MUSIC THE FARE AT THE KITCHEN
LEAD: ''WHEN I think of the role of the Kitchen,'' said Arto Lindsay, who is now the music curator at New York's avant-garde institution, ''it's been in finding what's happening next and trying to help that happen.'' Mr.
Lindsay has been active in New York's new music since the late 1970's, playing compacted noise in the band DNA, quasi-jazz in the Lounge Lizards and fractured Brazilian music with the Ambitious Lovers.


Outclassed
LEAD: John Angelus, basketball coach at the academically elite University of Chicago, on the blowouts that can result when the Maroons stray from Division III: ''It's tough playing against kids who don't have science lab twice a week.''


Cray Develops 4 Computers
LEAD: Cray Research Inc. said yesterday that it had developed four new models of its supercomputers.
The Minneapolis-based company said one entry-level model, at $2.5 million, would be the lowest-priced supercomputer ever.


A Division Assignment For Omnicom's Watson
LEAD: Thomas Watson, 52, who had an important role in the three-way merger of BBDO International, Doyle Dane Bernbach and Needham Harper Worldwide that created Omnicom Group, has been assigned from group headquarters to the Diversified Agency Services division as its president and chief operating officer.


MORGAN LIBRARY TROVE SHEDS LIGHT ON LINCOLN
LEAD: Between now and the next Inauguration, most of the 1988 Presidential candidates will invoke the name of the 16th President and, accurately or inaccurately, quote his words.
All political candidates - Democratic or Republican - can find passages in the Lincoln record to match their own ideas.

LEAD: Concern for homeless people is a theme repeated by contributors to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Juror's Trial
LEAD: Jury service, an important civic duty, can also be onerous, but in the Federal courtroom of Judge John Bartels recently it became an outrage.
After a mistrial caused by one juror's holdout vote for acquittal, the judge denounced the lone juror as ''more guilty'' than the defendants.

In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York investment firm said that it had bought the 1.3 million shares ''in connection with arbitrage and other activities.

To License or Not
LEAD: TO THE HOME SECTION:


CYANIDE IS FOUND IN JERSEY STORE AFTER CALLER TELLS OF TAMPERING
LEAD: A tea bag containing a lethal dose of cyanide was found in a Princeton Township supermarket on Tuesday after an anonymous caller told a store employee that he had also poisoned some store cheese and left the tea bag as proof of his visit, the authorities said today.


Macmillan Offer
LEAD: Macmillan Inc., the publishing company, is offering $125 million of 5 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2012 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.
The issue is rated Ba-1 by Moody's and BBB+ by Standard &amp; Poor's.
Noncallable for two years, the debentures are convertible into Macmillan's common stock at a price of $69 a share.


U.S. AIDE ASSESSES CHANGES IN SOVIET
LEAD: A State Department official said today that the Soviet Union was exhibiting a trend toward artistic and literary liberalism and that American officials had a ''basically positive'' view of Soviet human rights moves.


Skiers To Blaze a Trail
LEAD: Eventually, the Catamount Trail will be a self-guided cross-country experience for anyone who wants to ski Vermont from end to end.
In the meantime, 100 or more skiers will cover the route in a series of daily relays beginning Feb. 27 -just to prove it can be done.

LEAD: Two weeks after the latest air-fare wars erupted, many of the cheapest tickets from New York to the most popular vacation destinations are sold out through early April, according to travel agents and airline executives.

KNICKS COLLAPSE IN THIRD QUARTER
LEAD: The feeling of helplessness did not escape Bob Hill.
He stood on the sideline last night, watching the Milwaukee Bucks put together a staggering run of 17 straight points.
Patrick Ewing sat on the bench with four fouls, and the Knicks were almost continually being slowed by a vigorous press.


Teleglobe Canada
LEAD: The Canadian Government, in its latest move to reduce its holdings of state-run enterprises, said that it would sell Teleglobe Canada Inc., which handles the country's overseas telecommunications.
Memotec Data Inc., a small Montreal-based company, is making the purchase for $608.3 million, or $456 million (United States).

LEAD: Just who provoked the scuffle remains unclear.
Armed with a sawed-off rifle and a pistol, a Christian man and his son took on a group of Moslems last week.

He is an expert on that subject.


Second Nuclear Test of '87
LEAD: A nuclear device was detonated in a weapon test beneath the Nevada desert today, the second of six such tests scheduled for a two-month period.
The device was listed as having an explosive force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT.
Six protesters gathered on a road leading to the test site gate, and one demonstrator was arrested for trespassing.

The space agency will spend $9.5 billion for next year's space show.

RECITAL: STEPNER AND CARLIN
LEAD: THE violinist Daniel Stepner and the fortepianist Seth Carlin played an admirable joint recital at Merkin Concert Hall Monday night on modern replicas of antique instruments.
Mr.
Stepner's violin was a copy of a Stradivarius, and Mr.
Carlin played a 1984 instrument copied from a Graf piano, circa 1827, the year Beethoven died.

The 39th Witness
LEAD: In the early morning of March 13, 1964, a woman named Catherine Genovese walked to her home on Austin Street in the borough of Queens and was stabbed to death.
Her killer attacked her once, ran when she screamed, returned again, attacked again and then once more.
And while she screamed her young life out on Austin Street, 38 people, by police count, heard her.

Lincoln's Birthday
LEAD: Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning.
Governmental offices - Open.
Post offices - Regular schedules.
Banks - In New York City, open; In New Jersey and Connecticut, optional closing.
Financial markets - Open.
Transportation - Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular schedules and N.J.


Ohio Bus Service Resumes
LEAD: Bus service for 90,000 daily riders resumed Tuesday after a court order provided at least a three-day break from the two-month-old strike by drivers and mechanics over wages and the use of part-time workers.
But both sides in the dispute said resumption of service did not mean a resolution of differences.

LEAD: Paratroopers of the 82d Airborne Division prepared today to embark on a mock airborne invasion of Honduras on Thursday.

Honest, Abe Had Athletic Ability
LEAD: Once upon a time Bill Stern, an exceedingly creative sports radio personality, related a tale in the 1940's about the time a man was playing baseball when a committee called to inform him that he had just been nominated for President of the United States.
And ''in shirtsleeves,'' recalled Stern, the man ''made the dignitaries wait on the sidelines until he had had his lick at bat.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A chart yesterday listing the hostages in Lebanon and their captors included one name erroneously.
Aurel Cornea, a French television soundman, was freed on Dec. 24.
In addition, the chart misstated the date on which Do Chae Sung, a South Korean Embassy official, was kidnapped.
It was Jan. 31, 1986.


Troubled Times for Big Banks
LEAD: In the fourth quarter, the nation's biggest commercial banking companies were plagued by continued weakness in lending, a decline in investment-banking income and a disturbingly high level of special items.
As a result, the year turned out to be one of the harshest for the banks since deregulation began in the late 1970's.


Edna Manley, an Artist And Patron in Jamaica
LEAD: Edna Manley, a Caribbean artist and art patron and the widow of Jamaica's first Prime Minister and the mother of another, died Monday at her home, according to a family spokesman.
She was 86 years old.

LEAD: Vice President Bush, starting a two-state swing, focused on the Reagan Administration's accomplishments in a speech here tonight, saying, ''These are good times to be a Republican.''

LEAD: Walter E. Ousterman Jr., chairman, president and chief executive of the Kaiser Cement Company, plans to retire next month after Kaiser is acquired by the Hanson Group.

LEAD: Bond issues denominated in foreign currencies continue to proliferate in the American market, as investors look for higher interest rates and currency diversificiation.

LETTERS: ABOUT HUMILIATION
LEAD: TO THE HOME SECTION:


FOR HORTICULTURISTS, WRITING FLOURISHES
LEAD: THE evidence is plain in my mailbox every week: letter writing is a dying art.
Some old friends write a note from time to time.
At Christmas, others send a printout omnibus letter about their lives since last Christmas.
Sometimes these computerized letters have a small personal touch at the end, but even with that, they remain letters to no one in particular.

AIDS Victims Upheld In California Bias Case
LEAD: A state commission has ruled that an employer cannot discriminate against people who have AIDS, saying that the disease is a physical handicap under state law and cannot be transmitted by casual contact.

TOWER PANEL DATA SAID TO LINK N.S.C., PRIVATE REBEL AID
LEAD: A White House commission has uncovered information linking the National Security Council to private efforts to aid the Nicaraguan rebels while such activity by the Federal Government was banned, according to sources familiar with the commission's work.


U.S. ACCUSES CITY CONTRACTOR OF $6 MILLION FRAUD
LEAD: Two brothers who operate an electrical contracting company were charged yesterday with defrauding New York City of $6 million for work on several major projects and buildings, including Police Headquarters and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.


BARYSHNIKOV BARS MOSCOW VISIT NOW
LEAD: Mikhail Baryshnikov said yesterday that he will not take part in a three-day conference on science and the arts that begins Saturday in Moscow.


CONDOMS, AIDS AND MORALS: NEW CONCERN ALTERS DEBATE
LEAD: The increasing public discussion of the condom, a birth-control device that was once an unmentionable in many homes, has stirred debate among educators, religious leaders and parents.


CUOMO IS SEEKING SHIFT IN FUNDS TO REFLECT STATE FISCAL SITUATION
LEAD: The state's equine drug testing program would receive $400,000 more and the new Challenger Scholarship program $1 million if the Legislature approves the extra appropriations requested today by Governor Cuomo.


WALSH IS WIDENING INQUIRY OF CONTRAS
LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran arms case, Lawrence E. Walsh, has widened his investigation by assuming control of at least three Justice Department inquiries into the private American supply network for Nicaraguan rebel groups, according to Federal law-enforcement officials.


Note and Bond Prices Mixed
LEAD: The Treasury sector followed the lead of the currency and overnight loan markets yesterday, with prices falling early in the day as the dollar weakened and overnight rates rose.
But as the dollar strengthened and overnight loan rates fell, prices rebounded for Treasury issues.


GUARD ARRESTED
LEAD: A uniformed security guard in a dormitory at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center was arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 29-year-old medical student in the basement, the police said.


Use of Condoms As an AIDS Bar
LEAD: The AIDS virus has been documented to spread only through direct exchanges of blood and through anal and vaginal intercourse with those who carry the virus, according to many research studies.
Some scientists suspect that the AIDS virus can spread in oral sex.

LEAD: TNT Ltd., an Australia-based freight company, said that the Airborne Freight Corporation had expressed an interest in a possible joint venture.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, TNT, which holds a 17.6 percent stake in Airborne, said that talks on a joint venture began after Airborne rejected a TNT takeover bid of $172 million, or $29 a share.

Sea-Land Deal By CSX Approved
LEAD: The Interstate Commerce Commission voted unanimously to approve the CSX Corporation's planned $803 million acquisition of the Sea-Land Corporation, the first merger between a railroad and an ocean shipper.
The merger means that Richmond-based CSX would operate 27,000 miles of railroad tracks, along with barges, pipelines, trucking and global shipping.

LEAD: William Shawn's 35-year reign as editor of The New Yorker, a reign as distinguished and as total as any in the annals of modern journalism, is expected to end without fanfare tomorrow when the legendary 79-year-old editor passes the torch to Robert Gottlieb, who is 24 years his junior.

LEAD: The Air Force has selected 10 bases in eight states, stretching from Louisiana to Washington, for consideration as sites for 50 additional MX intercontinental missiles, the Defense Department said today.

Chip Orders Remain Flat
LEAD: Orders for semiconductors remained flat during January, an industry trade group said yesterday.
But the book-to-bill ratio increased for the fourth month in a row, providing a further sign that the American chip industry is recovering.

LEAD: A lawyer for one of the 12 youths indicted in the Howard Beach assault asserted yesterday that the prosecution had twice failed to respond to the lawyer's efforts to discuss the case.

The other day a longtime Washington hand who had not visited the office in some time noticed that the rather stern-visaged countenance was missing from its place on the wall.


DOLLAR MOVES HIGHER AMID SHORT COVERING
LEAD: The dollar moved higher yesterday, largely because traders who had sold the currency short earlier began buying out of their positions late in the day.
Dealers said the late demand came after a day of lackluster trading in which prices overseas and in New York had moved in extremely narrow ranges.

WHICH PROJECTS PAY OFF
LEAD: WHAT remodeling projects will pay off the most?
If you're planning to sell your house within a year after the project, an interior face lift -such as repainting or wallpapering - will give you the most return on your investment, according to the National Association of the Remodeling Industry in Arlington, Va.


GARBAGE LANDFILLS IN HALF OF THE STATES APPROACHING CAPACITY
LEAD: In Massachusetts, three-fourths of the 199 landfills now receiving garbage will be used up in three years.
In New York, less than 10 years remain for all existing landfills.
More than half of Alabama's sites will close in five years.

LEAD: BRITISH advertising is consistently better than the work being done in the United States, according to Len Sugarman, who has been a creative director on both sides of the ocean.

LEAD: For a long time, he wondered if he would be here.

Red Sox Beat Hurst
LEAD: Bruce Hurst beat the Mets twice for the Boston Red Sox in last season's World Series, but he couldn't beat the Red Sox this week.
Bernard Meltzer, an arbitrator, yesterday selected the Red Sox figure of $700,000 as Hurst's 1987 salary.
The pitcher, who last season earned $495,000, had sought $845,000 in the salary arbitration hearing that was held Monday.

LEAD: Jeff Lebo scored 22 points as North Carolina defeated Wake Forest, 94-85, in an Atlantic Coast game tonight to give Dean Smith his 600th career coaching victory.

Cooper Technicon
LEAD: The Cooper Development Company said that its affiliate, Cooper Technicon Inc., would sell its worldwide industrial systems business, which produces spectroscopy equipment, to Alfa-Laval A.B. of Sweden for about $51 million.
The industrial unit, based in Tarrytown, N.Y., has annual sales of about $50 million and employs about 200 people.

MUSIC: CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA AT CARNEGIE
LEAD: MATCHING symphony orchestras to music directors is more art than science.
Sheer luck also may have something to do with it.
Certain highly gifted conductors never seem quite at home in front of their orchestras, no matter how long their acquaintance.
Lorin Maazel and the Cleveland Orchestra, for instance, always struck one as a classic mismatch, despite his long and generally successful tenure as music director of the ensemble he inherited from the late George


U.S. Assails Import Plan
LEAD: A proposal by the European Community to ban imports of meat from hormone-treated animals could increase trade tensions between Europe and the United States, American trade officials said today.
The ban, if enacted, would mean the loss of about $80 million for American meat producers.
Reagan Administration officials warned that the community's proposed ban constituted a violation of trade rules and could spark retaliation by the United States.


Truly an Ironman
LEAD: He doesn't expect to win, but Pat Griskus figures to have an easier time of it in today's 86-floor, 1,575-step Empire State Run Up than he does at the Ironman Triathlon in Hawaii.
That's because he won't have to change legs on the way up.


CALIFORNIA IN DEBATE ON PRIVACY AND AIDS
LEAD: California, faced with a forecast of 50,000 cases of AIDS and 34,000 related deaths in the state by 1991, is debating how to halt the disease but still maintain the confidentiality of medical information and do tests only with the patient's informed consent.

LEAD: A defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial was shot several times in the back yesterday while walking with his wife on a busy avenue in Greenwich Village, the police said.

LEAD: Joe Paterno, whose undefeated Penn State team won the national championship of major college football by beating Miami in the Fiesta Bowl, was selected winner of the 19th annual Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award as major college coach of the year in the East.
This is the seventh time and second year in a row that Paterno has won the award from the New York Football Writers Association.

LEAD: TUESDAY  BASEBALL
CINCINNATI (NL) - Invited Terry Francona, first baseman-outfielder, to spring training.
CLEVELAND (AL) - Invited Turner Gill, infielder; Don Schulze, Reggie Ritter, Kurt Kepshire, Kent Murphy, Gibson Alba and Bryan Oelkers, pitchers; Dain Syverson, Kevin Buckley and Ron Tingley, catchers, and Rod Allen, outfielder, to spring training.

LEAD: Sir Peter Hall, who said last month that he would leave his post as artistic director of Britain's National Theater when his contract expired at the end of 1988, yesterday announced the formation of a partnership to produce plays for the commercial theater in London and New York and for international touring.

LEAD: The prospect for long and tough negotiations was evident yesterday after the National Basketball Association and its players union held their first bargaining session for a new contract at the St.
Regis hotel in Manhattan.
The present four-year pact expires 24 hours after the league champion is crowned in June.

Vermeer Quartet to Play In Place of the Berg
LEAD: The Alban Berg Quartet, because its cellist has developed tendinitis, has canceled a two-month tour of North America.
The Berg ensemble was to have appeared at Carnegie Hall Monday evening at 8, with Shlomo Mintz as guest soloist, but instead the Vermeer String Quartet will appear, playing works by Haydn, Janacek and Mendelssohn.

SCREEN: 'OVER THE TOP'
LEAD: IT took colossal crust - more specifically, it took Sylvester Stallone - to make a film that is largely about arm-wrestling.
It isn't that exciting to watch, and it's not the sport of kings, either.
But Mr.
Stallone saw the potential for something Rockylike in this subject, as indeed he sees it everywhere.


Bridge: Bidder Makes Unusual Leap From One No-Trump to Six
LEAD: A player who makes any natural no-trump bid is in principle barred from taking strong action subsequently.
That makes South's action on the diagramed deal - one no-trump followed by six no-trump -quite extraordinary.


Reuters Net Climbs 47%
LEAD: Holdings P.L.C. said today that its net income rose 47 percent in 1986 on a surge of new orders, favorable currency rates and a lower tax rate.
The news agency's after-tax profit totaled $:80.7 million, or $119.4 million, up from 1985's $:54.9 million.
Revenues rose 43 percent, to $:620.9 million, or $918.9 million, from $:434.1 million.


Church's Chief Resigns To Join Bid for Company
LEAD: The president and chief executive of Church's Fried Chicken Inc., Richard F. Sherman, resigned yesterday to ''participate in an offer to acquire'' the fast-food restaurant chain, the company announced.

NEW AND OLD IDEAS FROM FRANCE
LEAD: IN 1979, the French Government decided to revitalize its furniture design industry and to try to bring it to the forefront of international design.
The French Ministry for Industry established the Committee to Promote Innovation in Furniture Design (V.I.A., for Valorisation de l'Innovation dans l'Ameublement) and chose the furniture designer Jean-Claude Maugirard, left, as its director.

Breland's Trainer Is Back for a 3d Time

A WEEK OF 'DONAHUE' TAPED IN SOVIET UNION
LEAD: HOW do the United States and Soviet Union lessen world tension and avert a terrible war?
By allowing people of both countries to meet one another, a school of thought holds; everyone will find they have lots in common.
Phil Donahue, who may be television's most prominent advocate of that school, taped five episodes of ''Donahue,'' his syndicated talk show, in the Soviet Union last month.


Night Trading Hours
LEAD: Members of the Chicago Board of Trade voted today to become the first big United States exchange to have evening trading hours.
Under the program, the trading floor would be open from 5 P.M. to 9 P.M., central standard time, Monday through Thursday.
Board of Trade officials said they hoped to begin the program in April, pending approval from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.


EAST GERMANY RESISTS CHANGE
LEAD: East Germany's Communist leadership has strongly signaled that it is unenthusiastic about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's calls for ''openness'' and ''democratization'' and that it does not intend to imitate the Soviet Union's outlined reforms.


G.M. CHIEF SEES PROFIT GAIN SOON
LEAD: Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicted today that his company's cost-cutting efforts would start to improve earnings this year, but many analysts doubt that big short-term gains are likely.


GORBACHEV DRAWS A MIXED REACTION
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's espousal of greater openness in Soviet society has met a mixed response from his Eastern European allies, from applause in Poland to apparent unease in Czechoslovakia.

TUSSIE-MUSSIES FOR FRAGRANT VALENTINES
LEAD: DEAR Valentine, how do I love thee?
With a tussie-mussie, a tuzzie-muzzie, a nosegay or a posy?
An Anglo-Latin dictionary of 1440 gives the three terms as interchangeable for a small fragrant bunch of flowers.
Today a posy is defined as a nosegay or bouquet, nice to smell, and a tussie-mussie as a fragrant hand-held cluster or knot of flowers.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Kemp at the Net
LEAD: Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, onetime quarterback of the Buffalo Bills, is known for his prowess on the football field, but he is also a mean hand on the tennis court.
So is John W. Warner, the senior Senator from Virginia, who, by the way, turns 60 next Wednesday.


Implant for DiMaggio
LEAD: Joe DiMaggio has undergone a heart pacemaker implant at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach, Fla., and is scheduled to be released today, the hospital reported.
DiMaggio, 72 years old, checked into the hospital Feb. 3 after being diagnosed as having an abnormally slow heartbeat and Dr.
Philip Samet, chief of cardiology at Mount Sinai, peformed the implant last week.


IMPRESARIO PROMOTES LAUGHS
LEAD: Stand-up comedy plays in New York and Hollywood, but what interests Richard Fields is how well it plays in the likes of Peoria and Poughkeepsie.


FOR DWINDLING DEBUTS, THE ORIGINAL PURPOSE
LEAD: ONLY the closest observers of New York's concert life -perhaps only those in or near the music business itself - will have noticed the sharp drop-off in formal debut recitals this season.
These are the only people who pay much attention to such concerts anyway, and that is one reason for the drop.


INTRUDER ATTTACKS 2 OFFICERS OUTSIDE LONDON PALACE
LEAD: A man attacked two officers with a knife and hammer in the Kensington Palace garden early today but did not get inside, where the Prince and Princess of Wales and other members of the royal family slept, the police said.

DeBartolo, which is based in Youngstown, Ohio, bought the interest in the eight-year-old project held by Kenneth Treister, the Miami architect who designed the center, and Joseph A.

Clabir to Pursue Bid for Atlantic
LEAD: The Clabir Corporation, a military contractor, said that it intended to pursue its efforts to acquire the Atlantic Research Corporation.
Atlantic Research, which is based in Alexandria, Va., makes rocket motors and high-technology products.
It has rejected Clabir's acquisition proposal.

Corrections
LEAD: A report last Sunday on the wedding of Dr.
Michelle E. Ehrlich to Dr.
Samuel Evans Gandy 3d misstated the location of the ceremony.
It took place at the Craig Park Community Center in Chesterfield, S.C., not at a church.


MUSEUMS AND COLLECTORS AGAIN PURSUE THE MEDIEVAL STYLE
LEAD: THE Gothic style, revived many times and in many countries since it first appeared in the late Middle Ages, is once again being exhibited by museums and pursued seriously by collectors and dealers.
The versions most enthusiasts seek today are those from the mid-19th century that echo the architecture of medieval cathedrals, awash with pointed arches, quatrefoils, finials, crockets, rosettes, crenelated moldings and clustered columns.


PRO TENNIS STARS MIGHT PLAY IN SEOUL
LEAD: The broadening of Olympic eligibility continued today when the executive board of the International Olympic Committee unanimously approved a code of tennis eligibility that would permit the sport's millionaire stars to play in the 1988 Games.


'ROOM WITH A VIEW' AND 'PLATOON' LEAD OSCAR LIST
LEAD: ''A Room With a View,'' a comedy of manners set in Edwardian England, and ''Platoon,'' an infantryman's view of the agony of the Vietnam War, led the list of films nominated today for the 59th annual Academy Awards.


Chiat/Day, New York, Resigning Beer Account
LEAD: Chiat/Day, New York, announced yesterday that it was resigning from its two-year-old Miller Brewing Company assignment for Plank Road Original Draught Beer, which is still in test market.


Yields Are Mixed
LEAD: Falling interest rates paid at banks and thrift institutions appear to have stalled for the moment, as the overnight rate for banks loans in the Federal funds market, a closely watched benchmark for other short-term interest rates, continues to hover above 6 percent.


PLEAS OF NOT GUILTY MADE FOR MEN SEIZED ON CHILD NEGLECT CHARGES
LEAD: Pleas of not guilty were entered today for two men associated with a commune in rural Virginia who were charged with child neglect after they were found with six unkempt children in a city playground.

LEAD: FOR a couple of years, British acquaintances have been singling out something called ''The Black Stuff'' and its five-part sequel ''Boys From the Black Stuff'' as examples of television in their country at its biting best.

F.D.R. for the Aeons
LEAD: To the Editor:


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article yesterday about the designation of three Manhattan buildings as landmarks misidentified the current owner of the former Tiffany &amp; Company building at Fifth Avenue and 37th Street.
It is News World Communications.
In addition a picture with the article was published in error; it showed showed the synagogue of Congregation Beth Hamedrash Hagodol at 60 Norfolk Street, not Anshe Chesed Synagogue at 172-76 Norfolk Street, which was declared a landmark on Tuesday.

LEAD: Thirty-two states have passed legislation dealing with asbestos hazards, three-fourths of them in the past two years, a survey has reported.

LEAD: The American Opera Center of the Julliard School is to observe the 40th anniversary of the premiere of Benjamin Britten's opera ''Albert Herring'' by giving two performances of the work at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, next Wednesday at 8 P.M. and Sunday, Feb. 22, at 3.

Rubik (of the Cube) Robbed
LEAD: Burglars have broken into the villa of Erno Rubik, inventor of the Rubik cube, the Government daily Magyar Hirlap said today.
The police believe the intruders were seeking designs for new puzzles as all Rubik's papers were disturbed.
Despite the presence of valuable equipment in the home, only a video recorder was stolen.


Miami Herald Names Editor From Colorado
LEAD: Janet Chusmir, president and publisher of The Daily Camera in Boulder, Colo., will become executive editor of The Miami Herald in May, Richard G. Capen, the publisher of The Herald, said today.

LEAD: The state of mind of Robert C. McFarlane was said to have improved today as Washington officials, from both the past and the present, closed ranks behind him.

Khao I Dang: Refugee Job Not Finished
LEAD: In announcing the closing of the Khao I Dang refugee camp Thailand pleads with the West: Resettle these 15,000 Cambodians as you have pledged or back they go to the border with Cambodia.
The West needs to heed the message if it is to protect the carefully assembled international structure for handling refugees.

Hoyt Leaves Prison
LEAD: LaMarr Hoyt was released yesterday from a Federal prison camp at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida where he served 38 days of a 45-day sentence on a misdemeanor drug conviction.
While Hoyt was serving his sentence, the San Diego Padres waived the 32-year-old right-hander, contending that he voided his contract by violating a good citizenship clause in his pact.

THE REVOLUTION WROUGHT BY TOLL-FREE CALLS
LEAD: IT seemed like a gimmick when it was introduced 20 years ago, but that first toll-free, long-distance telephone call unleashed a revolution in telecommunications, marketing, information services and personal dialing habits beyond even the wildest dreams of most telephone-industry executives.
The 800 number - that 10-digit tie line to a mind-boggling array of products and information - has mushroomed into a multibillion-dollar business and is entrenched in


THE HUMBLED SAUDI ECONOMY
LEAD: Early in the 1980's, when Saudi Arabia was riding the oil boom, stories circulated about Saudis who traded in their cars when the ashtray filled up.
Today, however, many cars on the roads of Riyadh look three, four and five years old.

EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Burnham Service Corp., Columbus, Ga., an electronics and household mover, named Calvin J. Martin president and chief operating officer, succeeding Raymond E. Crowley, who remains chairman and chief executive.
Mr.
Martin was also named a director.


Reagan to Visit Canada
LEAD: President Reagan will make an official visit to Ottawa April 5 and 6, the White House announced today.
The trip will be Mr.
Reagan's fourth meeting with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada.


OBSCENE CALL LAW IS OVERTURNED
LEAD: The Oregon Supreme Court has again overturned a state law against making obscene telephone calls.


Lonrho Mining
LEAD: The British holding company Lonrho P.L.C. said it had increased its stake in Western Platinum, a South African mining company, to more than 99 percent, at a cost of $75 million.
Lonrho, which already had 50.4 percent of the company's shares, said it had bought another 49 percent from Falconbridge Ltd., one of Canada's largest mining companies, under an agreement signed 17 years ago.

Long Distance Lobbyist
LEAD: Peter Vallone, majority leader of the New York City Council, hired a lobbyist to represent the Council's interests in Albany.
It turns out that the $30,000-a-year lobbyist, Alan Warshauer, considers it a seldom-show job, doing more to embarrass than represent his Council clients.


MUSIC: LINDA TILLERY
LEAD: LINDA TILLERY, a pop-soul singer who has worked in the San Francisco Bay Area since the late 1960's, has performed twice in New York City during the past year.
In her most recent appearance, on Tuesday at the Bottom Line, she shared the bill with Teresa Trull, a fellow performer on the West Coast women's music label, Redwood Records.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: MOST people will agree that an open fireplace can be a cheery and warming sight on a cold winter night.
But if it is constantly smoking, allowing smoke and soot to drift into the room and letting fires smolder or die, the fireplace is more of a nuisance than an attractive asset.


MOUNT SINAI ADMITS FAULT IN TRANSPLANT
LEAD: The Mount Sinai Medical Center has admitted responsibility for an unauthorized heart transplant performed there last August and has been fined $8,000 by New York State.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Food Notes column in The Living Section yesterday misstated the ownership of the ''21'' Club.
The restaurant's sole owner is Marshall S. Cogan; Stephen Swid is no longer his partner.


HAITIAN CHIEF FAULTED FOR NOT BREAKING WITH PAST
LEAD: To mark the first anniversary of the fall of the Duvalier dictatorship, Lieut.
Gen.
Henri Namphy, the head of Haiti's provisional Government, rode in a dark blue Maserati sedan to a national historical museum near the presidential palace to dedicate a memorial plaque.


KNIGHT, AN ORIOLE, TAKES A CUT
LEAD: Ray Knight, the World Series hero who spurned an offer of $800,000 to return to the Mets, finally found a home yesterday - with the Baltimore Orioles for $300,000 less.


2 Charged in Mugging A Philadelphia Judge
LEAD: Two men have been charged in the mugging of a prominent judge and snatching of her purse while 100 bystanders looked on, the police said today.


Sutter Has Surgery
LEAD: Bruce Sutter, the Atlanta Braves' reliever, has undergone surgery in Denver to repair nerve damage to his right shoulder in the hopes of returning to baseball in 1988.
Sutter underwent a three-hour operation Tuesday at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center.
Dr.
Steven Ringel said it would be several months before doctors know whether they were able to regenerate damaged tissue in Sutter's pitching arm.


The Place of Violence in South Africa, as Once in the 13 Colonies
LEAD: To the Editor:


Hoyas Destroy 1,000th
LEAD: Reggie Williams scored 34 points tonight as Georgetown rolled to its 1,000th basketball victory, a 78-50 Big East decision over Connecticut.


Q &amp; A
LEAD:  Q. We recently moved into a brownstone and in one room there appears to be a lot of the original wainscoting on the walls.
Unfortunately, there are many layers of paint over this and they have almost completely hidden the surface texture.
Is there any way I can remove this paint without damaging the wainscoting, and preserving its orginal texture?


RESULT PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  McEnroe Advances: John McEnroe posted a 6-3, 6-4 victory yesterday in his opening performance of the United States Indoor Tennis Championships in Memphis, but said he was still not playing at top form. ''The mental and physical combination is not there yet, but I believe deep down that it can get better,'' McEnroe said after he defeated Paul Annacone.


BEIRUT ISLAMIC GROUP AGAIN WARNS OF U.S. ATTACK
LEAD: A Moslem group holding two Americans hostage here announced today that it had ordered its members on full alert in anticipation of an American troop landing, and an Armenian underground faction threatened to end a four-month-old truce with France.

Page A1  Prospects for new Congressional aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents are so bleak that the Reagan Administration may postpone its formal request until September, Administration officials said.

G.E. TV Order Shifted to U.S.
LEAD: The General Electric Company said today that it would begin to make midsize color television sets at a plant in Bloomington, Ind.
The sets were previously made overseas.


Pentagon to Test MX Today
LEAD: The Air Force has scheduled the 16th flight test of the MX missile on Friday at the Vandenberg Air Force Base in California, the Pentagon announced today.
The missile, which is capable of carrying 10 nuclear warheads, will be launched from an underground silo and be aimed at the Kwajalein Island missile test range in the Pacific Ocean.


REAGAN ASSAILED ON JUDICIAL RECORD
LEAD: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, chairman of a Senate judicial screening panel, charged today that the Reagan Administration had a ''shameful'' record on appointing women and members of minorities to the Federal bench and warned that the courts might become ''an enclave of white male exclusivity.''

LEAD: A pedestrian approaching the snow-dusted corner of Fifth Avenue and 24th Street yesterday.
Evident was the fact that others, somewhat earlier, had traversed the same small piece of the city.

LEAD: A young woman from Manhattan who is visiting Florida this week has been barred from attending the races at Hialeah.

Ruland Out for Season
LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers have resigned themselves to the fact that Jeff Ruland, their injured 6-foot-10-inch center, will be out for the season.
Ruland, who was acquired in a deal last April that sent Moses Malone to the Washington Bullets, has been ordered to rest his left knee completely.
Cartilage in the knee has eroded.


IN A LAND OF PALACES, SAUDI KING'S IS SPECIAL
LEAD: Even though the oil slump has forced an unfamiliar economic restraint on this country, the building of palaces continues, and one in particular is worth note.
It will be the new main home and offices of King Fahd, the seat of a dynasty that started in tents.


REAGAN ALLY SHUNS JOB IN WHITE HOUSE
LEAD: Stuart K. Spencer, a longtime political associate of President Reagan, turned down an offer of a White House job today, saying he had ''too many personal commitments to keep'' in California.


AT THE MOVIES
LEAD: ''THE GOOD FATHER'' stars Anthony Hopkins as a middle-aged man fighting for what he might call ''male liberation.'' It depicts the fury of a liberal British publishing executive whose wife has left him for another man and who is forced to see his 6-year-old child only on weekends.

FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Barris Industries has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $50 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2012, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.


Government Executive
LEAD: The National Journal, since last year a property of the Times Mirror Company, yesterday announced the acquisition of the 17-year-old monthly magazine Government Executive from its owner, C. W. Borklund.
Government Executive has a circualtion of 70,000 on the Federal, state and local levels.


DINING OUT: SUNDAY
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
AMBASSADOR GRILL, 1 United Nations Plaza, First Avenue at 44th Street (355-3400) -  * (Oct. 3, 1986) Smoky glass panels and starry lighting contribute to the modern urbane setting at this East Side hotel restaurant that is open for dinner on Sunday evenings.


TITAN ROCKET, AFTER TWO FAILURES, LAUNCHES SATELLITE FROM AIR BASE
LEAD: The Air Force successfully launched a Titan 3B rocket late Wednesday after two consecutive failures in the last 18 months, Pentagon officials said today.
The Defense Department declined to disclose the nature of the rocket payload, saying it was classified.


AIDS DOUBTS CITED IN LIBERACE DEATH
LEAD: There was enough doubt about whether Liberace had AIDS to justify his doctor's decision to protect the showman's privacy by reporting heart failure as the cause of death, the physician's attorney said today.


INSIDE
LEAD: U.S.
Courting Arabs  Washington has proposed new arms sales to Arab countries and begun some subtle diplomatic maneuvering in the Middle East.
Page A14.


Chamber Symphony
LEAD: The New York Chamber Symphony will play music by Boyce, Vivaldi, Bach, Telemann and Lully tomorrow night at 8 o'clock at the 92d Street Y. Anthony Newman will conduct from the harpsichord; soloists will include the violist Jean Dane and the oboist Randall Ellis.
Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50.
Information: 996-1100.


JULES BERGMAN, 57, SCIENCE EDITOR OF ABC NEWS FOR 25 YEARS, DIES
LEAD: Jules Bergman, science editor of ABC News for more than 25 years, was found dead yesterday in his apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
He was 57 years old.
The police said Mr.
Bergman's body was found by a maid, Argelia Torres, in a bathtub with scalding water running.
A spokeswoman for the police, Sgt.


U.S., HURT BY IRAN AFFAIR, IS COURTING ARABS ANEW
LEAD: In an effort to repair damage done to its reputation in the Arab world by the Iran affair, the Reagan Administration has proposed new arms sales and begun some subtle diplomatic maneuvering in the region.


LARRY CORYELL, GUITAR
LEAD: The guitarist Larry Coryell is leading a quartet - with the pianist Stanley Cowell, the bassist Buster Williams and the drummer Beaver Harris - tomight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street.
Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10cover and a $6 minimum.

ON THE HUNT FOR THE UBIQUITOUS MAN-MADE EAGLE IN MANHATTAN
LEAD: THE bald eagle, an endangered species, is at roost all around Manhattan - in stone, in bronze, in paint, in stitchery, on sidewalks and rooftops, canvas and quilts, on monuments and office buildings, in parks and museums.

Patriots Under a Dome?
LEAD: The possibility of a domed stadium for the New England Patriots arose yesterday when a spokesman for Edward G. (Buddy) LeRoux confirmed that the part owner of the Boston Red Sox and the Suffolk Downs thoroughbred race track was considering the purchase of the Patriots along with Sullivan Stadium and the adjacent harness racing track in Foxboro, Mass.


Embassy in Soviet Reassigns Marines for Currency Crimes
LEAD: Several Marine guards were reassigned from their postings at the American Embassy here after an internal investigation indicated they had been involved in illegal currency transactions, Ambassador Arthur A. Hartman said today.

Purdue Beats Iowa In Big Ten, 80-73
LEAD: Everette Stephens had a career-high 23 points, including hitting five of five 3-point field goals, as Purdue beat Iowa, 80-73, tonight in a Big Ten game.


PENN ENDS REQUIRED STUDIES FOR THE PREMEDICAL STUDENT
LEAD: In another effort to broaden the undergraduate education of the country's premedical students, the University of Pennsylvania has eliminated all course requirements for admission to its School of Medicine and will no longer even recommend undergraduate courses.

Man Exposed to AIDS Put Under Quarantine
LEAD: State officials issued a quarantine order Wednesday against a male prostitute who tests showed had been exposed to the AIDS virus.


Disney 'Valentine' Tonight on Channel 4
LEAD: For curmudgeons who complain that popular music has gone to the dogs, that the singers of today are guilty of caterwauling, proof at last is at hand.
Look no farther than Channel 4 tonight between 8 and 9 o'clock.
There's an hour of popular music, and the screen is filled with dogs and cats.


Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 379 money market mutual funds decreased $15.8 million, to $236.01 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $452.6 million, to $65.32 billion.
Assets of the 196 general purpose funds were up $156.1 million, to $62.99 billion.


Paribas Shares Up 18% in Price
LEAD: Institutional investors trying to buy shares in Cie Financiere de Paribas bid the price of the banking group's shares up by 18 percent on the first official day of trading.
Paribas is one of 24 major concerns that Prime Minister Jacques Chirac aims to return to private ownership over the next five years.


U.S. DECISION IS NEAR ON ENDING POLISH SANCTIONS
LEAD: President Reagan will decide in the next two weeks whether to restore trade benefits to Poland that were suspended in 1982 in response to the outlawing of the Solidarity movement, according to high-ranking Administration officials.


PIANO SINGER WHO STILLS THE ROOM
LEAD: THE basic task of the typical cabaret singer-pianist is modest: to fill silence by unobtrusively establishing a mood of nostalgic conviviality.
But Ann Hampton Callaway is one of a handful of young singing pianists who, with little fanfare, can bring a crowded room to a hush.
The Chicago-born singer, who is ensconced in the main dining room at the Backstage Restaurant and Cabaret (318 East 45th Street) Thursday through Saturday evenings, has appeared in 40 to 50 restaurants and clubs around the city over the last seven years.


THE SAN FRANSISCO
LEAD: The San Francisco Symphony, under the direction of Herbert Blomstedt, will play the New York premiere of Charles Wuorinen's ''Golden Dnce,'' tonight at 8 o'clock at Carnegie Hall.
The program includes Brahm's Symphony No. 1 and the ''Firebird'' Suite by Igor Stravinsky.
Tickets are $12.50 to $16; information: 247-7800.

2 From Vermont Bench Deny They Violated Ethics Canons
LEAD: A Vermont Supreme Court justice and a former assistant judge accused of misconduct have denied that they broke any canons of judicial ethics.

Richard B. Wigton
LEAD: When Federal marshals finished arresting three prominent arbitragers in its latest round of insider-trading charges, word spread quickly yesterday from trading desk to trading desk on Wall Street.
But that was not so much because the scandal had grown, but rather that the individuals named seemed to be among the least likely to be charged.

DINER'S JOURNAL
LEAD: WHENEVER I peek into a new restaurant to see if it might be worth investigating I focus on two things: the food and the expressions on customers' faces.
Both were encouraging at Pasta Presto, a bright and cheerful new pasta house on Second Avenue between 33d and 34th Streets, where a satisfying three-course dinner with wine can be had for $15 or less.

Marcus Aurelius Rides Again
LEAD: The second-century bronze statue of Marcus Aurelius and his horse will be restored and returned to its place on Capitoline Hill.
City officials said Wednesday that they would spend $460,000 to complete restoration of the Emperor's statue, which was removed from the square in front of City Hall in 1981 because of air pollution and other damage.


'AMERICATHON' SCHEDULE
LEAD: Monday's admission-free Americathon 1987 concert at the New School Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street, will consist of a series of interviews with composers, interspersed with a brief concert of each subject's music.
The number for information is 669-7748, but the office will be closed tomorrow and Sunday.


CABARET: ARLENE SMITH OF CHANTELS
LEAD: AMONG the brash, fearless adolescent voices that animated rock-and-roll music in the late 1950's, none were more fervent than Arlene Smith, the lead singer of one of the earliest ''girl groups,'' the Chantels.
Along with Frankie Lymon, Ms.
Smith helped to inaugurate a pubescent rock-and-roll belting style that has since been adapted by dozens of singers, including the young Michael Jackson and


ZIGGY MARLEY, REGGAE
LEAD: Ziggy Marley, Bob Marley's son, will lead his reggae band, the Melody Makers, Sunday at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street.
Shinehead will open at 9 P.M., with the Melody Makers on at about 10:30; tickets are $13.50 in advance, $15 Sunday.
Information: 254-2800.


Pan Am Estimates $400 Million Loss
LEAD: C. Edward Acker, chairman and chief executive of the Pan Am Corporation, estimated that the airline company's losses for 1986 would total more than $400 million.
With the carrier having lost $265 million in the first nine months, he said, Pan Am would probably lose more than $135 million in the fourth quarter, or slightly more than some analysts had predicted.
