JERSEY POLICE DIRECTOR IS INDICTED IN A CITY LAND-PURCHASE SCHEME
LEAD: The Police Director of New Brunswick and the former head of the city's Law Department have been indicted and accused of helping to persuade city officials to buy land in which the two men held a hidden interest, United States Attorney Thomas W. Greelish announced today.


Loss for Norsk Hydro
LEAD: Norsk Hydro A.S., the state-controlled energy concern that is Norway's biggest company, said today that it lost money last year for the first time since 1944.
The company, a producer of North Sea oil and gas, fertilizers and aluminum, said it lost 324 million crowns, or $46.9 million, in 1986, in contrast to a profit of 2.08 billion crowns - $301 million - in 1985.


200 HOMELESS IN JERSEY RIVERFRONT BLAZE
LEAD: Hundreds of people fled into the cold early this morning when a fire engulfed a three-story garden apartment complex here, destroying 102 apartments.


Game Called Due to Traffic
LEAD: The Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference basketball game scheduled for tonight between St.
Peter's and Army was postponed because the bus carrying the Peacocks was stuck in traffic on the Gov.
Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.
The team from St.
Peter's, which is in Jersey City, was unable to reach the United States Military Academy because of the huge volume of traffic caused by an accident.

Interest Rates Stage a Retreat
LEAD: Interest rates declined for short- and long-term issues yesterday on the strength of buying by some speculators and investors who had been active sellers earlier in the week and signs that the Federal Reserve is not pushing short-term rates higher as some analysts feared.

Aiwa to Sell Digital Recorders
LEAD: The Aiwa Company of Japan became the first concern formally to announce a marketing date for a consumer digital tape recorder - a controversial high-fidelity product that could swing customers away from compact disks.
Aiwa will begin selling its digital recorder in Japan March 2, but has no plans now for marketing overseas, a spokesman, Kazuhiro Hoshi, said.

CALIFORNIANS WHO ASSESS CUOMO FIND HIM LIKABLE BUT ENIGMATIC
LEAD: Governor Cuomo of New York flew home today after a quick visit to California, leaving an impression among many voters that he was an interesting but still mysterious alien who had yet to define himself in the eyes of Californians.


San Francisco Mayor Shuns Race for House
LEAD: Nancy Pelosi, who has raised millions of dollars for the Democratic Party, announced her candidacy for the House of Representatives today, a few hours after Mayor Dianne Feinstein said she would not enter the race.


Police Report Few Clues in Shooting in the Village
LEAD: Investigators said yesterday that they had not established a motive in the Greenwich Village shooting of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial, and that they could not question the victim because he was in critical condition.


SOME CHINESE BACK OLD SOVIET PLANS
LEAD: Many of the senior Chinese officials who appear to have profited from the forced resignation last month of Hu Yaobang as Communist Party leader are supporters of traditional Soviet-style economic planning and ideological control.


ARBITRAGERS WORRIED BY ARRESTS
LEAD: Although Wall Street had been bracing for months for a new round of charges in the insider-trading scandal, the news yesterday of the arrest of three arbitragers from two of its most prestigious investment-banking firms set off a wave of shock and fear.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A listing yesterday of holiday closings for Lincoln's Birthday misstated the schedule for public schools in New York City.
They were open yesterday but are closed today.

Sensible Welfare Reform
LEAD: For 20 years, the problems of the Federal-state welfare system have become increasingly apparent.
Among them are its incentives for single motherhood and broken families, high and increasing costs, paternalistic and unresponsive bureaucracies, staggering economic obstacles in the way of departing the system for remunerative work, constant intergovernmental friction, a bewildering array of inconsistent regulations and the strong suspicion that the system is perpetuating a dependent welfare class that threatens to persist over generations.


Bank Board to Tap Japanese Market
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board will tap the Japanese capital markets for the first time ever next week, when it offers $200 million of bonds due in 1997, an officer with Daiwa Securities America Inc. said.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  McEnroe Ousted: Johan Kriek followed a blistering serve to a 7-5, 6-4 victory last night over John McEnroe in the third round of the United States Indoor Tennis Championships in Memphis. ''Things just don't seem to be going my way recently,'' said McEnroe, who was seeded fifth.
Kriek, seeded 11th, ended the match with three aces in a row.

Evader Wins One From IRS
LEAD: A convicted tax evader has been awarded $13,000 from the Internal Revenue Service after a Federal judge ruled that one of its agents harassed the man.
The plaintiff, Daniel Neal Heller, of Miami, had been convicted on charges of evading income taxes on $250,000 in fees from clients.
A 1983 conviction was thrown out after a juror reportedly made racist remarks, but Mr.

Shows are at approximately 9:30 P.M. and midnight, with Little Mike and his Blue Band opening; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.
Information: 473-8908.

COMPROMISE ON OLYMPIC SITES
LEAD: Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that North Korea had agreed in principle to a compromise proposal for sharing the 1988 Summer Games with South Korea.


First U.S. Biathlon Medal
LEAD: Josh Thompson of Gunnison, Colo., became the first American ever to win a medal at the biathlon world championships when he captured the silver medal today in the men's 20-kilometer event behind Frank-Peter Roetsch of East Germany.


Few Treaty Violations Found
LEAD: A Stanford University group issued a report here today that found little evidence to support Reagan Administration charges of Soviet cheating on arms control agreements.

Rubik Theft: Puzzle Solved?
LEAD: Two burglars who broke into the villa of Erno Rubik, inventor of Rubik's Cube, have been arrested, the Hungarian press agency MTI reported today.
The men were said to have taken a video recorder from Mr.
Rubik's house in January while he was in Japan.
They were identified as Tibor Csorba, 27 years old, and Istvan Csaba, 30, both of Budapest.


TEXACO LOSES PLEA IN TEXAS
LEAD: A Texas appellate court today upheld a historic judgment by a lower state court, agreeing that Texaco Inc. illegally persuaded the Getty Oil Company to back out of a merger three years ago with the Pennzoil Company.

LEAD: Carlos Enrique Lehder Rivas rose from peddling marijuana on New York street corners to become one of the titans of the cocaine industry, commanding, officials say, legions of gunmen, racing boats, airplanes, a ranch with a racetrack and even his own small neo-facist party.

Jewish Center Names 74 as Suspected Nazis
LEAD: A Jewish center said today that it had turned over to the Justice Department the names of 74 people suspected of being Nazi war criminals who came to the United States after serving in German military units that murdered tens of thousands of Jews in Eastern Europe in World War II.


West German Economy Flat
LEAD: The West German economy stagnated at the end of last year, as the dollar's fall against the mark reduced the nation's exports, the nation's central bank said today.


Miranda Ruling: Complain, Complain, Complain
LEAD: Eighteen months ago Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d denounced as ''infamous'' and ''wrong'' the Supreme Court's ruling in Miranda v.
Arizona that the police must tell arrested suspects of their rights to remain silent and to have legal counsel.


TURMOIL ON WALL ST.
LEAD: The insider-trading charges disclosed yesterday against three Wall Street executives were the latest episode in a year of scandal in the investment community.
The biggest case of the year involved the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky, who agreed to plead guilty to insider trading and to pay $100 million in penalties.


LEHMAN RESIGNING AS NAVY SECRETARY
LEAD: John F. Lehman Jr., the combative Secretary of the Navy, is leaving the Reagan Administration, the Pentagon announced today.


RETAIL SALES IN JANUARY PLUNGED A RECORD 5.8%
LEAD: The nation's total retail sales dropped a record 5.8 percent last month as auto sales plunged an unprecedented 22.4 percent, the Government reported today.

U.S. and Allies to Reopen Talks on Space Station
LEAD: The United States and its potential partners in a planned orbiting space station concluded a critical two-day meeting in Washington yesterday with an agreement to resume negotiations aimed at developing a facility that would be used for ''peaceful purposes'' and establishing the basis for long-term cooperative ventures in space.

NAVY PLANE CRASHES IN CALIFORNIA
LEAD: The wreckage of a Blue Angel F-18 jet fighter on railroad tracks south of Brawley yesterday.
The pilot was able to parachute to safety before crash.
It was the fourth military air crash in the Imperial Valley since October.


NORTH FROM THE BATTERY, SEEKING WASHINGTONIANA
LEAD: NEW YORK was once George Washington's town.
He drank at Fraunces Tavern, commanded the Continental Army from the Morris-Jumel Mansion, took his Presidential oath at Federal Hall and prayed at St.
Paul's Chapel.
Two centuries later these places still stand, with furnishings and relics that reveal varied facets and some little-known facts of the official and personal life of the first


SYRIAN ARMY RAIDS PALESTINIAN GROUP
LEAD: Troops in Damascus stormed the office of a Marxist Palestinian group today and arrested one of its leaders in another sign of the growing split between Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization, Beirut radio stations reported.

It was McKim, Mead &amp; White.

LEAD: Merger mania continues - and along with it, allegations of widespread insider trading on Wall Street.
Arrests yesterday of three more securities traders in the Boesky case should add to the pressure for a legislated fix.
But poorly targeted legislation could prove worse than no legislation at all.

BROADWAY

Mr.
Robards will, naturally, play the devilish widower, a considerable change of pace from his last starring role on the Great White Way - his 1985 portrayal of Hickey in ''The Iceman Cometh.

Ishmael and Isaac
LEAD: To the Editor:


Holiday Monday
LEAD: George Washington's birthday will be observed Monday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Following are holiday schedules.
Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning.
Governmental offices - Closed.
Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only.

LEAD: At a briefing on the progress of the observation of the Constitution's 200th birthday, Warren E. Burger, the chairman of the bicentennial commission, remarked on the right of Americans to criticize their government.
He compared that right favorably with the limited freedom enjoyed in the Soviet Union, even with the recent moves by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S.


ROBERT M. FREEMAN
LEAD: When Federal marshals finished arresting three prominent arbitragers in its latest round of insider-trading charges, word spread quickly yesterday from trading desk to trading desk on Wall Street.
But that was not so much because the scandal had grown, but rather that the individuals named seemed to be among the least likely to be charged.


FILM: 'DUET FOR ONE'
LEAD: IT took half a dozen extra characters and a very large tree to open up Tom Kempinski's two-character play ''Duet for One'' and bring it to the screen.
But the focus is still Stephanie Anderson, a brilliant violinist (modeled, to some extent, on the cellist Jacqueline Du Pre) who is married to a celebrated conductor and has multiple sclerosis.

LEAD: Hamiett Bluiett and Ed Blackwell, Jazztrack, Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street (645-2387).
Hamiett Bluiett is, without question, the leading baritone saxophonist of the 1980's, with a big, blustery tone, astonishing fluency, a command of upper octaves only he knows how to reach and a style steeped in the blues.

MOYERS PULLS REPORT SERIES FROM PBS
LEAD: ''News Minutes,'' a planned nightly series of reports on the Constitution and one of Bill Moyers's first projects since leaving CBS for public television, has been scrapped after a dispute between the Public Broadcating Service and some PBS stations over the program.


G.M. to Eliminate 3,500 More Jobs
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation, America's biggest car maker, said it would lay off 3,500 more workers, effective Feb. 16, as part of its overall cost-cutting and restructuring strategy.
The announcement came a day after G.M.'s chairman, Roger B. Smith, reassured shareholders he planned to trim the company's operating costs by $10 billion a year by 1990 and increase earnings.

NETS KEEP SLIDING, 121-99
LEAD: Nothing changed.
The Nets, a team trapped in a losing streak with no apparent end, faded again tonight.
Now, even the excuses have become familiar.


Is a Currency Deal Possible?
LEAD: THE United States is still going round and round in a clumsy waltz with its partners in Japan, West Germany, France and Britain over when to hold the next Group of Five meeting.
At the start of the week, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said that no special G-5 meeting had been scheduled, alarming the foreign exchange markets.

LEAD: The Leaders, an all-star jazz group that includes the saxophonists Chico Freeman and Arthur Blythe, the trumpeter Lester Bowie, the pianist Kirk Lightsey, the bassist Cecil McBee and the drummer Don Moye, will appear tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street.


Partners Sought In Bid for Lucky
LEAD: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman said that he had asked third parties to join him in a renewed attempt to seek control of Lucky Stores Inc.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr.
Edelman, the chairman of the Datapoint Corporation, did not disclose the names of the parties with which he held the ''preliminary discussions,'' and he said no agreements had been reached.

SOUTH AFRICA ACKNOWLEDGES DETENTION OF BLACKS UNDER 12
LEAD: The Government acknowledged today that it had jailed black children 11 years old or younger, and it was challenged to say precisely how many people it had detained in an eight-month-old crackdown on black protest.


NEW DONOR TO THE NEEDIEST FULFILLS A PROMISE
LEAD: Each year, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund receives letters from first-time contributors, some of whom have for years intended to help the drive.


Reorganization At DDB Needham
LEAD: DDB Needham Worldwide, the result of the merger of the Doyle Dane Bernbach Group and Needham Harper Worldwide under the Omnicom Group, has done a bit of restructuring and title-bestowing under the direction of Keith Reinhard, the chairman and chief executive, and John Bernbach, the president and chief operating officer.


BUSH, IN MIDWEST, PUSHES IRAN ISSUE OFF A BIT MORE
LEAD: Vice President Bush, apparently seeking to deflect the political liabilities of the Iran arms affair, said today that he had voiced ''certain reservations'' about it as it was developing.


U.N. Report Estimates Iran Executed 7,000
LEAD: A United Nations report issued here today estimates that 7,000 people, most of them opponents of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Government, were executed in Iran after the ouster of the Shah in 1979.
It charged that torture and summary executions remained widespread.


MUSIC: 'STILL LIVES'
LEAD: PHILIP GLASS, Laurie Anderson and do-it-yourself electronic minimalists were among the subjects that the experimental composer William Hellermann amusingly twitted in his performance art music piece ''Still Lives'' at the Alternative Museum on Wednesday evening.


SCOUTING
LEAD: Give Dean Smith his due, by all means, for 600 victories.
Fact is, though, he takes a distant backseat to Dick Baldwin.


Coghlan Aims to Top His Best
LEAD: Last Monday, Eamonn Coghlan tried to talk his way out of tomorrow night's Meadowlands Mile.
Now he says his workouts this week have been so good that he will run the mile and thinks he can better his world indoor best.


CHINA, XEROX IN VENTURE
LEAD: The Xerox Corporation and a Chinese computer research institute opened a center today that will use laser printers and a multilingual computer system to produce documents in almost any language, including Chinese.

RESEARCHERS DISCOVER AN AIDS-LIKE VIRUS IN CATS
LEAD: Researchers have discovered a virus that causes diseases in domestic cats and is similar to the one that causes AIDS in humans, a development that they say could make the cat a useful animal model for research on acquired immune deficiency syndrome.


JAPAN TRADE SURPLUS WIDENS
LEAD: Japan's seasonally adjusted trade surplus jumped 19 percent in January from a month earlier, indicating that the turnaround in world trade imbalances is taking longer than expected.

Condom Stock Gain Continues
LEAD: PRIMARILY reflecting the health threat of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, the stock prices of publicly owned manufacturers of condoms continue to soar to record levels.


Colgate's Net Increased 3.8% in Fourth Quarter
LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said today that its net income rose 3.8 percent in the fourth quarter of 1986, aided by the introduction of new products, cost reduction programs and improving profit margins.

LEAD: It is a basic constitutional right in this country to read and express political ideas, however unpopular.
We can subscribe to Pravda.
We can distribute literature calling for replacement of Israel by a Palestinian state, or calling for a Greater Israel with its Arabs expelled.

Poland Bank Note Plan
LEAD: After five consecutive years of double-digit inflation, the National Bank of Poland has announced plans to start printing 10,000-zloty bank notes, double the denomination of the largest bank note now circulated, the official Polish press agency, P.A.P., said today.
Earlier this month, the Government said prices rose by 18 percent last year, compared with a 15 percent inflation rate in 1985.


The 1099 Drought of 1987
LEAD: There's more tax frustration this year because of the Internal Revenue Service's Form 1099 - or rather the lack of it.
The nine different versions of 1099 are the slips on which employers, banks, dividend-paying corporations and other payers tell recipients every February how much money they received in the previous year.


Merc's Price Limit Plan Dismays Many Traders
LEAD: In a move that surprised and dismayed many futures traders, board members of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange voted late Wednesday to install daily price ranges on its widely used Standard &amp; Poor's 500-stock index futures contract.


New York Merc Head To Relinquish Position
LEAD: Michel D. Marks, who is credited with saving the New York Mercantile Exchange after disasters in potato contracts almost put it out of business, said yesterday that he planned to give up the post of chairman of the exchange.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., promoted Michael I. Roth to executive vice president.

Guinness in 'Monsignor Quixote'
LEAD: WHILE ABC prepares Sunday night's premiere of the $40 million, 14 1/2-hour production of ''Amerika,'' which presents the specter of a Russian-occupied United States, public television tonight offers a modest, two-hour drama about a Roman Catholic priest and a Marxist politician who come to understand and even love each other.


CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
LEAD: The Cleveland Orchestra, under the direction of Christoph von Dohamanyl, will play Berg's Chamber Concerto for Piano, Violin and Thirteen Wind Instruments and Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 tonight at 8 o'clock at Avery Fisher Hall.
The soloists in the Berg work will be the pianist Joela Jones and the violinist Daniel Majeske.

LEAD: Random House asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday to reconsider its Dec. 29 decision barring publication of a biography, ''J.
D.
Salinger: A Writing Life,'' by Ian Hamilton.
The court held that the author made unfair use of some 70 unpublished letters written by Mr.


THE GETTY REPORTS A SCANDAL
LEAD: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., acknowledged on Wednesday that Jiri Frel, head of the department of antiquities at the museum, was relieved of his ''curatorial responsibilities'' in April 1984 after an extensive investigation disclosed ''serious violations of the museum's policies and rules regarding donations to the antiquities collection.


4 Killed and 13 Wounded in Philippine Fighting
LEAD: Four civilians were killed and 13 wounded today when Communist rebels raided a village and bombed a police station, the military said.
The deaths raised to 42 the death toll in rebel-related violence reported since a 60-day cease-fire ended Sunday.

THAT ELUSIVE CURRENCY PACT
LEAD: The United States and its four principal economic allies may be edging toward agreement on stabilizing their currencies but they are still a considerable distance from an accord, American and foreign officials said here today.


BROOKLYN BISHOP LIMITS CHURCH USE BY HOMOSEXUALS
LEAD: The Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has told his 850 priests that groups that condone homosexual activity will no longer be allowed to use churches, hospitals or colleges for meetings or religious services.
The ban applies to the two boroughs in the diocese, Brooklyn and Queens.

Philips, Sony Set Audio-Video Plan
LEAD: Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and the Sony Corporation of Japan, two of the world's largest electronics concerns, have agreed on specifications for the marketing of a combined audio-video compact disk player, Philips said.
Philips said the two companies had set a world standard specification for the new combination player, just as they did two years ago for compact disks and players.

Hill Holliday Connors Gets 3 Gillette Products
LEAD: Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos in Boston has been named agency for three brands from Gillette's Personal Products division: Good News Toiletries, which had been at Young &amp; Rubicam; Aapri, a facial scrub formerly at N. W. Ayer, and Deep Magic Cleansing Lotions, which Gillette hopes to revive.


S.I. COLLEGE BARS TEAM'S PLAYING IN TOURNAMENTS
LEAD: The president of the College of Staten Island of the City University has barred its championship basketball team from postseason tournament play because some of its white members participated in a brawl with black fans that he said had racial overtones.


THE MANY FACETS OF PAUL KLEE, AT THE MODERN
LEAD: PAUL KLEE'S inventiveness, imagination and wit have made him a popular, if not beloved, figure.
Of all the 20th-century artists, perhaps only Picasso and Matisse have clearly been more influential.
Klee's ability to work figuratively and abstractly, to make a few lines read like a dramatic script and to make the same color freeze, throb and glow inspired Joan Miro, Andre Masson, Saul Steinberg, Mark Rothko, Adolph Gottlieb, Robert


FUNERALS FOR AIDS VICTIMS: SEARCHING FOR SENSITIVITY
LEAD: Driving a station wagon with tinted windows, Timothy O'Brien recently carried the corpse of a man who had died of AIDS from a funeral home in East Harlem to another in Queens where a wake would be held.


RED PAPER, CRAYONS AND WORDS OF LOVE
LEAD: How do I love thee?
With three tiny hearts decorated with smiley faces, with four noodles pasted nearby, and a big red cutout heart next to the words ''I like you and I love all of you.'' ''It's special if you make it yourself,'' said Jeremy Wang-Iverson, who is 6 years old, as he critically surveyed the valentine collage he was constructing at his desk.


CLEARINGHOUSE CREATED
LEAD: Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company is offering $750 million of collateralized mortgage obligations, in a financing that typifies the willingness of dealers and investors to devise varieties of mortgage-backed securities.


AN ALL-AMERICAN FEAST OF MUSIC ON WNYC
LEAD: When do classical-music radio stations broadcast a lot more than just mainstream classical music?
When they're WNYC, the venturesome public-radio station at 93.9 on your FM dial, and especially when they're WNYC in the midst of an annual American Music Festival week.


SCXOUTING
LEAD: For one recruit it snared, Penn State can thank God, literally.
Dave Daniels, a wide receiver from Sarasota, Fla., says he struggled for a while to choose among pursuing schools. ''So I asked God to help me,'' he told The Centre Daily Times of State College, Pa. ''That night I had a dream.
I dreamed I walked out on a football field for warm-ups, and when I looked up at the head coach it was Joe Paterno.


Chairman Chosen At A.C. Nielsen
LEAD: John C. Holt yesterday was named chairman and chief executive of the A. C. Nielsen Company, a subsidiary of the Dun &amp; Bradstreet Corporation that is best known to the public as a monitor of television viewing tastes.


A REVIVAL OF PROBLEMS IS EXPECTED FOR TEXACO
LEAD: The decision yesterday by a Texas appeals court could create serious problems for Texaco Inc., according to industry analysts and specialists who have followed the struggle.


ART: TOWARD DEFINING 'CONTEMPORARY CUTOUTS'
LEAD: THE cutout, an advertising device, became high art after its appropriation by the Pop movement, but without the scholarly attention that usually accompanies such promotions.
This has now been rectified by ''Contemporary Cutouts,'' a show organized for the Whitney Museum's Philip Morris branch by its director, Susan


FILM: 'FACES,' TWO IVORY COAST TALES
LEAD: DESIRE ECARE'S ''Faces of Women,'' opening today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema, is a technically rough, cheerfully rude, folkloric comedy about the status of women in the Ivory Coast, where Mr.
Ecare was born and raised.
It is, in fact, two separate fables with a common frame, that of a street festival where the singing and dancing is nonstop.


N.H.L. STARS STICK TO SIMPLE GAME PLAN
LEAD: Normally at this point of the National Hockey League season, when selfishness is sometimes rewarded and those with imposing statistics wear stars on their uniforms for a night, the consolation prize for unrecognized effort is a day or two at a distant beach.

Bass Wins Arbitration
LEAD: Kevin Bass, Houston's right fielder, won his salary arbitration, but Gary Pettis, California's center fielder, lost for the second successive year.
Bass, who earned $310,000 last year, gained a 1987 salary of $630,000; the Astros' offer was $560,000.
It was the Astros' second loss in three cases.
Pettis had a $300,000 salary last year after losing in arbitration and went up to $400,000 with his loss this time.


AUCTIONS
LEAD: ''WHEN the doors were swung back, one was struck by the remarkable smell of 18th-century French morocco,'' Sotheby's medieval-book specialist, Dr.
Christopher de Hamel, said in a telephone interview from London, recalling his first trip to one of the world's finest private libraries on hunting, shooting and fishing.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Boys of the Lough, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street (864-5400).
One of the leading traditional Celtic folk ensembles, the Boys of the Lough play highland music that is by turns delicate, buoyant and martial.
Formed over a decade ago, the quintet now includes Cathal McConnell (flute, tin whistle, vocals), Aly Bain (fiddle), Dave Richardson (mandolin, tenor banjo, cittern concertina), John Coakley (guitar, piano, fiddle, tin whistle, bodhran) and Christy O'Leary (uillean pipes).

U.S. JURORS AWARD $7 MILLION DAMAGES IN SLAYING BY KLAN
LEAD: A Federal jury today awarded $7 million in damages against the United Klans of America and six past and present Klansmen in the 1981 slaying of a black man whose body was left hanging in a tree.


Teams Moving Away From Rough Play
LEAD: College hockey appears to have reversed a trend toward rough play and violence this season, according to coaches and administrators.
If this continues, and the college game resumes its emphasis on speed and stick-handling, it will again set itself apart from the National Hockey League.

Schlumberger Loses $2 Billion
LEAD: Schlumberger Ltd., the giant oilfield services company, announced yesterday that it lost $2.18 billion in the fourth quarter.


Withholding Clarity - and Forms; What's the W-4 For?
LEAD: The new W-4 withholding form for Federal taxes has infuriated taxpayers and sent the Internal Revenue Service, chastened, back to the drawing board.
A new new form or revised instructions, or both, will issue soon.
The exercise offers the public and Internal Revenue an important lesson.
Reforming the tax process isn't simple.

LEAD: Stock prices fell slightly in heavy trading yesterday, a day when Wall Street was stunned by the arrest of three executives on insider trading charges.

LEAD: A Board of Elections worker has been indicted in an investigation of potential fraud in Assemblyman Roger L. Green's acceptance of a Liberal Party nomination last year and the gathering of independent nominating petitions on his behalf.


Foote, Cone Net Falls
LEAD: Foote, Cone &amp; Belding Communications reported its fourth-quarter earnings yesterday.
On revenues of $86.85 million, down 1.5 percent from the $88.2 million in the fourth quarter of 1985, there was a net income of $4.1 million, or 98 cents a share, a drop of 48.1 percent from $7.9 million, or $1.89 a share, a year earlier.

LEAD: In the first year after the drinking age in New York State was raised to 21, alcohol purchases among 16- to 20-year-olds declined by half, according to a five-year study released today by the state.

It will be working with regional dealer advertising associations that have their own agencies.

William C. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned here today that the American people would stop supporting the Nicaraguan rebels unless they performed better.


RESTAURANTS
LEAD: YOU enter the dining room at Chez Louis and pass a long serving station where waiters hack away at sizzling roast chickens and divvy up portions of hulking prime ribs and wildly aromatic suckling pig.
A perusal of the premises, where tables fairly sag under the weight of he-man portions, reveals that this year-and-a-half-old restaurant is for serious no-holds-barred eaters.


A SUBWAY WALKER SEARCHES THE LABYRINTH FOR PROBLEMS
LEAD: When Charles L. Stanford wants to take a walk, he often heads for the subway.
As chief engineer of the Transit Authority's track and structures department, the tunnels are his domain and his feet the preferred means of conveyance.


TIMOTHY L. TABOR
LEAD: When Federal marshals finished arresting three prominent arbitragers in its latest round of insider-trading charges, word spread quickly yesterday from trading desk to trading desk on Wall Street.
But that was not so much because the scandal had grown, but rather that the individuals named seemed to be among the least likely to be charged.

Toyota Is Hurt By Strong Yen
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Company's sales and earnings fell in the first half of its fiscal year for the first time since the mid-1970's, the company said today.
In the six months ended Dec. 31, sales were down 4.6 percent and net income was down 44.4 percent.


ART: 14 PICTOGRAPHS FROM ADOPH GOTTLIEB
LEAD: ONE of the classic devices of picture-making in the middle of our century was the pictograph - the boxed or gridded set of disjunct images that gave us plenty to look at and allowed the painter to work with contrast and paradox.
Someone who did these things with notable success was Adolph Gottlieb, whose current show at Knoedler &amp; Company, 19 East 70th Street, consists of 14 pictographs, dated from 1945-51.


INDIAN MUSEUM TO MAINTAIN A PRESENCE IN HARLEM
LEAD: The Museum of the American Indian has agreed to maintain a satellite museum at its present site, 155th Street and Broadway, even if it takes over most of the historic United States Custom House in lower Manhattan.

LEAD:  Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street. ''Harlem Renaissance:


Cheers, and Kicks, in Moscow
LEAD: The mass release of Soviet political prisoners poses an interesting problem for Westerners: finding the right response between churlishness and gullibility.
A good formula for praising the opposition was once advanced by Randolph Churchill.
By all means do so when deserved, urged Winston's father, but accompany every kiss with a kick.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission unanimously agreed today not to intervene in a controversy involving the scrambling of television transmissions via satellite to keep owners of dish antennas from viewing pay television programs without paying.

LEAD: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company sent its stock surging early yesterday when it said it would be announcing a ''major positive business transaction.'' But the stock fell back with the news of the deal, which was relatively small by Wall Street standards.

LEAD: ''BALLARE,'' Twyla Tharp's final premiere in her company's season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is an experiment in fusing the choreographer's modern-dance sensibility with some elements of ballet technique.


VERDICT IN ALABAMA COULD RUIN KLAN GROUP, EXPERT SAYS
LEAD: The $7 million verdict by an Alabama jury against the United Klans of America threatens the organization's financial survival and its popularity among potential members, an expert on Klan activity said yesterday.

EGYPTIANS VOTE ON PARLIAMENT
LEAD: A resident of Cairo casting his ballot yesterday.
Egyptians voted in a referendum called by President Hosni Mubarak to dissolve Parliament so as to pave the way for a new election law to replace rules whose legality had been challenged in court.
The referendum would call for a new Parliament to be elected, probably in April.


NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1987
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-15  Moscow protesters were punched by plainclothesmen in the firmest crackdown on public dissent there in more than a year.
The demonstrators were seeking the release of a Jewish dissident, Iosif Z. Begun.
Page A1  ''Dr.
Zhivago'' will be published serially beginning next January in a Soviet literary periodical, according to a written promise received by a Moscow panel reviewing the work of Boris Pasternak.


RUSSIANS ROUGH UP PROTEST GROUP RALLYING 4TH TIME FOR A DISSIDENT
LEAD: Demonstrators protesting on behalf of an imprisoned Jewish dissident today were shoved and punched by plainclothesmen in the roughest crackdown on dissent in Moscow in more than a year.


A NAVY WEDTECH MEMO MISSTATED NOFZIGER POST
LEAD: A 1984 Navy memorandum describing an inquiry by Lyn Nofziger on behalf of the Wedtech Corporation identified him as ''the President's Political Advisor'' even though he had left the White House staff 13 months earlier.


ART: IN BLECKNER SHOW, AN ARRAY OF PAST MOTIFS
LEAD: ROSS BLECKNER is an artist who has held our attention by never quite staying put.

VERTICAL MARATHON AN ELEVATING EVENT
LEAD: Al Waquie won his fifth straight race up the Empire State Building yesterday, climbing the 1,575 steps in 11 minutes 56 seconds on a bad knee.


ASPIN CRITICIZES BOMBER COST
LEAD: The $802 million requested by the Air Force to fix the B-1 bomber is only part of what will be needed, and the final cost may be more than $3 billion, Representative Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said in a statement released today.

LEAD: Business sales, aided by a year-end spurt of car buying, jumped 2.9 percent in December and inventories fell five-tenths of 1 percent, the largest decline in more than three years, the Commerce Department said today.

More Trade Wind
LEAD: The Senate trade bill, with the wallop of more than 60 co-sponsors, points to protectionist action this year.
While too rigid, the bill has two points in its favor.
It is mercifully free of specific restrictions on imports or countries and it's less protectionist than the House bill.


Raising Death Benefits
LEAD: Representative Mario Biaggi, the Bronx Democrat who was for 23 years a New York City policeman, has introduced a bill to double the $50,000 Federal death benefit that is paid when public safety officers are killed in the line of duty.

Yankees Sign Cerone
LEAD: Rick Cerone, the onetime Yankee catcher who engaged in a couple of brief feuds with George Steinbrenner before he was finally traded to Atlanta in 1984, returned to his former team yesterday after it appeared his career might be nearing a premature end.


Pact on Yugoslav Debt
LEAD: Yugoslavia signed an agreement with the United States today for the refinancing of $220 million of official debt due between May 1986 and the end of 1988, the official Tanjug news agency said.
The agreement, signed in Washington, means Yugoslavia can ''resume the regular fulfillment of obligations toward Governments of 16 industrial countries'' under a multilateral accord signed in Paris last May, the agency said.


AT TOY FAIR, CHATTING DOLLS AND GHOSTLY KNIGHTS
LEAD: The toy buyers came to town this week for the 84th annual American International Toy Fair.
Most of the men wore red or yellow power neckties, and much of what they saw were dolls that had batteries and/or chips in their bodies, enabling them to converse with other dolls.


Atlantic Air Fare Pact
LEAD: The United States and 13 of the 22 member states of the European Civil Aviation Conference have signed an accord on trans-Atlantic air fares to replace existing arrangements that expire in April.
The Europeans said today that, under the new memorandum of understanding, aeronautical authorities of the signatory states will automatically approve North Atlantic fares filed by airlines within specified pricing zones.

Commercial Credit Selling 2 Units
LEAD: The Commercial Credit Company said it has agreed to sell two fleet-vehicle leasing subsidiaries to the New England Merchants Leasing Corporation for about $77 million.
The subsidiaries to be sold are McCullagh Leasing in the United States and Commercial Credit Corporation Ltd., in Canada.
Both companies specialize in fleet-vehicle leasing.


EXPERTS SAY VERDICT ON KLAN MAY CHASTEN OTHER RACISTS
LEAD: The $7 million verdict returned by an Alabama jury against the United Klans of America was hailed today by civil rights leaders around the South, while experts on the Klan said it sent a powerful signal to similar extremist groups.


RAY KNIGHT SOUNDS OFF
LEAD: In his first news conference in Baltimore, Ray Knight, the most valuable player with the Mets in the World Series, made a strong pitch yesterday to become the most voluble player of the Orioles this season.
The 34-year-old third baseman's rapid-fire delivery had veteran Baltimore reporters comparing him with a former Oriole pitcher, Jim Palmer, now a broadcaster.


MET OPERA: AGNES BALTSA IN 'CARMEN'
LEAD: A year ago, when the Metropolitan Opera introduced its latest version of ''Carmen,'' a lack of singing made opening night hard to bear.
The Don Jose, Luis Lima, suffered from throat problems and had to talk his way through much of the evening, while Maria Ewing, with no such problems, did much the same in the title role.

'88 BOYCOTT NOT FEARED
LEAD: The head of the International Olympic Committee said yesterday that he was certain Communist-bloc countries would ignore any call by North Korea to boycott the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul.
Speaking at a news conference in Lausanne, Switzerland, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, said his organization was unwilling to add any sports to the four from the Seoul Games it has proposed placing in North Korea.

DR. HENRY B. HASS IS DEAD AT AGE 85
LEAD: Henry Bohn Hass, a specialist in organic chemistry who is credited with the discovery of gas chromatography, one of chemistry's most powerful analytic tools, died of pnuemonia yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital, Manhasset, N.Y.
He was 85 years old and lived in Queens.


Air Force Cancels $1.2 Billion Project
LEAD: The Air Force took the unusual step today of canceling a $1.2 billion program to equip its F-111 fighter bombers with radar-jamming gear because it disliked the prices of three competing bids.

Pressman Critically Injured In a Robbery at The Times
LEAD: A 63-year-old pressman was critically injured in a robbery yesterday in a sub-basement locker room of The New York Times building at 229 West 43d Street, and an apprentice pressman was arrested, the police said.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: College Basketball  Columbia 81, Yale 72: Sean Couch scored 29 points and Matt Shannon added 16 last night to lead Columbia to the Ivy League victory.
The loss ended Yale's five-game winning streak and dropped the Elis out of a first-place tie in the Ivy League with Cornell.
Yale is 13-8 over all and 6-3 in the league.

Aid Bill Signed
LEAD: President Reagan signed emergency legislation Thursday providing $50 million to help the homeless.


A CURATOR UPSETS THE GETTY
LEAD: Museum officials and others in the esoteric field of antiquities have expressed varied reactions to the news that Jiri Frel, head of the department of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., was relieved of his curatorial duties for helping donors obtain overvalued appraisals of their gifts for tax purposes.


Moscow Sets Grain Goal
LEAD: The Soviet Union has set a 1987 grain harvest target of 232 million metric tons, which would be the country's second- largest yield ever, the official news agency Tass said today.
Agricultural experts at Western embassies said it was the first time in recent years that the Soviet Union had published an annual grain target in advance of the harvest, although it provides five-year-plan targets.


A Letter to Gorbachev
LEAD: Fifty-eight United States senators have signed a letter to the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, expressing concern that new emigration procedures purportedly intended to make it easier to leave the Soviet Union appear to have had the opposite effect.


Medical Initiation Rite Endangers the Public
LEAD: To the Editor:


OLSON IS ENDURING A SEASON OF LOWS
LEAD: Looking at the record book, you get the impression that Billy Olson is bigger than life.
Looking at his career, you get the impression that anything that can go wrong will go wrong if it hasn't gone wrong already.


SPORTS TODAY
LEAD: BASKETBALL  KNICKS VS.
CHICAGO BULLS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (TV - MSG, 7:30 P.M.; Radio -WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.).

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the Wedtech Corporation and lobbying on its behalf by Lyn Nofziger, a former top aide to President Reagan, misstated the date of Mr.
Nofziger's departure from the White House staff.
It was Jan. 22, 1982.


Epitaph for Constructive Engagement
LEAD: A panel appointed by the Reagan State Department to evaluate policy toward South Africa offers this startling judgment: ''The Administration's strategy of constructive engagement has failed to achieve its objectives.''


Boulez and Taxes
LEAD: The world-renowned music director and conductor Pierre Boulez - who is so described in a judgment by a panel of the United States Court of Appeals in Washington - will apparently have to renegotiate a tax settlement with the Internal Revenue Service as a result of a ruling by the court yesterday.


Swimsuit That Alters Its Colors
LEAD: A BATHING suit made with fabric that changes color with the temperature of the wearer and gives a distinctive appearance was patented this week.
The thermally sensitive material contains cholesterol liquid crystals that display the color pattern.


MURA DEHN, A CHOREOGRAPHER AND SPECIALIST IN BLACK DANCE
LEAD: Mura Dehn, a Russian-born dancer and choreographer who became known as a film maker and a specialist in American black dance, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 84 years old.


NOTE AND BOND PRICES DECLINE
LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices drifted lower yesterday, but short-term interest rates were little changed as trading activity subsided in advance of a long weekend.

LEAD: Norway's oil minister said today that the nation would expand the search for oil and gas in the strategically sensitive Barents Sea, close to the Kola Peninsula base of the Soviet Navy.

LEAD: A West German freighter that picked up distress signals in the night rescued 24 men and a woman from a stricken Turkish merchantman in a battering Atlantic storm early yesterday, but three other seamen were lost when their lifeboat capsized at the brink of deliverance.

And who, or what, killed it?
These are the unanswered questions surrounding the discovery of the gallinule, an ungainly bird that has never been seen in flight north of Venezuela.

Early Effort Thwarted
LEAD: Shooting broke out today as the two United Nations trucks loaded with food approached Burj al Brajneh.
Witnesses said the trucks' tires were shot out by unidentified gunmen and the vehicles were abandoned yards from their destination.


JACK TRUDEAU ARRESTED
LEAD: Jack Trudeau, the rookie quarterback from the University of Illinois who started 11 games last season for the Indianapolis Colts, is scheduled to appear in an Indianapolis court Tuesday after being arrested early yesterday morning on charges of disorderly conduct and battery on a policeman.
Trudeau was arrested when, the police said, officers attempted to break up a fight outside a bar between him and another man.

LEAD: A preliminary state audit has found that Victor E. Botnick, a former top aide to Mayor Koch, had failed to properly document 67 out-of-town trips in five years at a cost of more than $57,000.

LEAD: Investors taking quick profits on shares of newly listed Nippon Telegraph and Telephone ended its rapid stock market runup over the past week, brokers said.

ADD IT UP, AND ROMANCE CUTS QUITE A FIGURE
LEAD: Numbers may not be the measure of a holiday's importance, but if they were, Valentine's Day would have few equals.
The holiday for lovers is not only a multibillion-dollar bonanza for purveyors of candy, flowers and greeting cards, but it also generally heralds a flurry of weddings and other amorous adventures, telephoning and restaurant-going, and, if the past is any guide, perhaps even a dip in the crime rate and an upswing in the stock market.

DECEIVING GASOLINE PURCHASES
LEAD: HOW do you know when you fill up your car that the premium gasoline you pay for isn't just regular at a premium price?
How do you know that when you pay for 10 gallons, you get 10 gallons and not 9, or 8?
And how do you know that when the pump says unleaded, it's really unleaded?
You don't.
But your car does.

G.E. Stock Split
LEAD: The General Electric Company said its board had voted to recommend a two-for-one split of its common stock and an increase in the number of authorized common and preferred shares, subject to approval of the shareholders at the annual meeting April 22.
The company, which has 457.1 million shares outstanding, said its board also declared an cash dividend of 63 cents a share, payable April 25 to holders of record March 6.

Children's Chairs Recalled
LEAD: Children's chairs sold in Texas, Missouri and Arizona are being recalled because the paint on them contains too much lead, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.
About 9,000 wooden chairs imported from Mexico in 1985 by De Llano's Mexican Products of Laredo, Tex., are involved in the recall, the commisssion said.


Inflation in Britain
LEAD: Britain's retail inflation rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January from the previous month and was up 3.9 percent from a year ago, the Department of Employment said today.

She was recognized in New Mexico from the leaflet and the authorities were notified.
Edward Michno, the 13-year-old girl's father, was served with an abduction warrant and was being held in jail in Albuquergue.

LEAD: Few people other than seasoned campers realize it, but the best way to guarantee a campsite at a number of national parks is to make a reservation the same way you book a Broadway musical - through Ticketron.
The National Park Service has just renewed its contract with Ticketron Inc. for five more years of bookings at eight parks with 3,324 family campsites.

LEAD: The price of aluminum has been soaring in London, as traders speculate that buyers of the metal from the United States would soon react to surging demand by shopping in Europe.

0.6% JANUARY RISE IN PRODUCER PRICES LED BY OIL SECTOR
LEAD: A record surge in gasoline prices helped push the Producer Price Index for finished goods up six-tenths of 1 percent in January, its biggest advance since late 1985, the Labor Department reported today.


REAGAN CALL BRINGS AID TO BOY
LEAD: Touched by the plight of a 7-year-old boy who needs a liver transplant, sympathizers from a millionaire industrialist to restaurant workers followed President Reagan's lead with more than $400,000 in donations today.


V.A. DISCIPLINES DOCTORS FOR ACCEPTING FEES FROM DRUG COMPANY
LEAD: The Veterans Administration has disciplined at least 33 physicians and other employees after closing an internal investigation into the acceptance of gratuities and payments from a drug company.


CALCIUM, FAT AND SODIUM: CAVEATS FOR TEEN-AGERS
LEAD: The dairy industry has taken up the battle against osteoporosis with vigor.
After years of being criticized for emphasizing nutritious but fattening products - whole milk, ice cream, etc. - the industry has seized upon the opportunity to campaign for increased consumption of calcium to prevent the crippling bone disease that afflicts older women.

New Turn in Bing Affair
Sir Rudolf Bing and his wife, who have fled to Anguilla, are followed by allegations that she is unable to manage her affairs, let alone his.


Holiday Monday
LEAD: George Washington's birthday will be observed Monday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Following are holiday schedules:  Parade - Begins 9 A.M. at Fifth Avenue and 35th Street, moving north to 50th Street and ending about noon.
Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended.
Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning.


Sikh Sought in Hindu Deaths Killed by the Police in India
LEAD: A Sikh wanted in connection with the massacre of 22 Hindus was killed today in a shoot-out with the police, the authorities said.


Icy Rescue In Michigan
LEAD: Brent Rasmussen, at bottom left, and David Bast calling for help Thursday after the ice ridge they were walking on collapsed, sending them into Lake Michigan near Holland, Mich.

X RATING FOR 'ANGEL HEART' IS UPHELD
LEAD: The movie industry's rating board gave an X rating to Alan Parker's new film, ''Angel Heart,'' last week; today an appeals board narrowly upheld the X.


Matsushita Plans Job Cuts in U.S.
LEAD: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, victimized by the strong Japanese yen, said it would cut about 250 jobs at a television plant in suburban Franklin Park, Ill., by the end of February.
The cuts will come through 170 layoffs and 80 early retirements, said Justin Camerlengo, a spokesman at Matsushita's American headquarters in Secaucus, N.J.

GENE FOUND THAT MAKES DEPOSITS IN ALZHEIMER VICTIMS' BRAIN CELLS
LEAD: Researchers said today they had isolated a gene largely responsible for the abnormal deposits that clog the brains of people with Alzheimer's disease.


PRODUCTION ROSE 0.4% IN JANUARY
LEAD: The nation's industrial production increased for the fourth consecutive month in January, the Federal Reserve reported today.
But many analysts were unimpressed by the size of the advance, a slim four-tenths of 1 percent.


Offer Raised For Heritage
LEAD: Heritage Communications Inc., a Des Moines-based cable television operator, said yesterday that an investor group had raised its previously announced bid for the company.


Topics; HEARTS AND TOWERS; Scrambled Logic
LEAD: Television signals are private property and ''theft of private property is wrong.'' That's the clear, simple and sound judgment of Dennis Patrick, newly designated chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.
And that's why the agency wisely refrains from interfering with scrambled television signals.

MONCRIEF ACTIVATED
LEAD: A Milwaukee Bucks guard, Sidney Moncrief, who has missed all but 13 games this season with tendinitis of the right knee, including the last 23, will be activated for tonight's game against the Houston Rockets.
Moncrief, an eight-year pro who has played in five National Basketball Association All-Star Games, averaged 15.8 points a game this season before being sidelined.

By H. J. MAIDENBERG
LEAD: After three mood changes, the stock market closed higher yesterday in active trading.


To Cut Court Calendars
LEAD: In an effort to combat the crack epidemic and to reduce backlogs in the New York City Criminal Court, Sol Wachtler, Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, announced last September that many judges then serving on the Civil Court in New York City would be transferred to the Criminal Court.

NEW YORK, LOOKING BACK WITH PRIDE, BEGINS TO CELEBRATE U.S. CONSTITUTION
LEAD: Declaring that New York's early laws ''set the pattern for the national Constitution,'' Governor Cuomo this week marked the beginning of a three-year state celebration of the United States Constitution with a display of rare state documents in Albany.


Police Dog Gets Two Medals
LEAD: A New Orleans police dog, shot in the face Oct.5 after tracking two suspected car thieves to their hiding place under a house, received two medals Friday as the city Police Department honored its officers.
In a shootout with police, one suspect was killed and the other wounded.
Zeiko, a rottweiler, received the Medal of Merit, the department's second-highest award and the department's Wound Award.


Pistons Draw Record Crowd
LEAD: A crowd of 52,745, the largest regular-season turnout in National Basketball Association history, was on hand tonight as the Detroit Pistons scored a 125-107 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.


Sloane Elman Wed to Barry G. Radick
LEAD: The marriage of Sloane Elman, associate general counsel for the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, and Barry G. Radick, a partner in the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley &amp; McCloy, took place last night at the Carlyle Hotel in New York.
Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony.


FOOD TAMPERING SOLUTION IS ELUSIVE
LEAD: A FEDERAL official and two university professors say that no amount of Federal regulation can protect the public against anyone intent on tainting or tampering with food and drugs, as was done last week with a tea bag in a Princeton, N.J., supermarket.


Shultz's Way
LEAD: Ronald Steel's portrait of George Shultz depicts a reactive Secretary of State, largely unable to initiate policy and to anticipate problems before they arise.
A reactive, problem-fixer Secretary of State with Mr.
Shultz's background as a seasoned negotiator might thrive under a President who is himself masterly at formulating foreign policy.

LEAD: At St.
Mary Magdalen Roman Catholic Church in Wilmington, Del., yesterday Diana Morris Hutz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Rudolf Edward Hutz of Wilmington and Kennebunk, Me., was married to Mark Edmond Hoscheit, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
John C. Hoscheit of Hobe Sound, Fla.

Stephen Breen performed the ceremony Mary S.


Cruises
LEAD: To the Editor: We have just returned from the island of Anguilla in the West Indies where we have vacationed at the same hotel for 10 years.
This year we witnessed a most unfortunate wrinkle in the world of package cruises.
Early one morning a large cruise ship dropped anchor in the bay near our hotel.


A CORRECTION
LEAD: The caption with a photo of Mayor Sharpe James of Newark and Gustav Heningburg that appeared on the Opinion Page of Feb. 1, to illustrate an article by Howard Quirk did not credit the photographer.
The photo was taken by Suzanne Poor.


Shultz's Way
LEAD: Ronald Steel's article contains an error which an astute Wagnerite would pick up.
His reference to Mr.
Shultz as an ''improbably stolid Siegfried'' is improbable mostly because it is Siegfried's father, Siegmund, who drew the sword from the tree.

NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 14 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 14 food establishments cited for violating the health code.


SEOUL REJECTS OFFER BY NORTH
LEAD: South Korea called on North Korea today to reopen suspended talks between the two Governments and rejected a proposal from Pyongyang for a new high-level political and military meeting, officials said.


ROBERTSON GAIN SEEN IN MICHIGAN
LEAD: Strategists for Vice President Bush, acknowledging that they overestimated their candidate's strength, now concede that the Rev.
Pat Robertson won nearly as many delegates as the Vice President in the state's precinct voting last August.


Count Rhode Island In
LEAD: To the Editor:  The New York Giants' Super Bowl victory was a sweet ending to an outstanding season for the team and its millions of fans.
You should be aware that ''The Giant Apple'' (editorial, Jan. 27) underestimated the size of that apple.
We in Rhode Island comprise a large and loyal group of ''New England Giants'' fans, even though the Giants have never played a game in Rhode Island.


OLD 'PETS' FIND NEW HOMES
LEAD: A bloodhound, a whippet, several setters and a pair of hunting dogs - garden sculptures all - helped make the recent Winter Antiques Show an unqualified success.
These zinc, bronze, lead and stone canine figures - life-sized and larger - sparked smiles and lots of laughter throughout the nine-day fair - the first anyone could recall at which there was such a large gathering of dogs.


Koop Says Reagan Rejected Plan to Lead Anti-AIDS Drive
LEAD: President Reagan has rejected a proposal to combine warnings about AIDS with his anti-narcotics campaign, the Surgeon General of the United States says.


MT. SIANI ADMITS FAULT
LEAD: In a statement that left several important questions unanswered, the Mount Sinai Medical Center last week acknowledged that it had knowingly permitted an unauthorized - though successful - heart transplant operation last August on an indigent 26-year-old man from Puerto Rico.
Presbyterian Hospital is the only institution in New York State with heart-transplant authorization, and although Mount


ANSWERS ABOUT NEW YORK'S NEW RULES FOR SMOKING
LEAD: Beginning on May 7, smoking will be banned in most public indoor areas in New York State and restricted on the job and in most restaurants.

LEAD: The position of Senator Norman J. Levy, Republican of Merrick, on a gasoline tax to improve Long Island's roads was misstated in last Sunday's Long Island Weekly section.
A spokesman for Mr.
Levy, James V. Moriarty, said the Senator was opposed to such a tax.

LEAD: Americans trust their spouses and television news anchors more than they trust their President, according to a poll released today.

LEAD: SKI OPERATORS are fond of saying that, ideal as conditions might be, most people have to look out in their backyards and see snow before they ''think skiing.''

POLISH ODYSSEY: WARSAW TO OFF BROADWAY
LEAD: ''Why do you write?'' I was asked by an officer of the secret police in Warsaw. ''An intelligent man does not write.
An intelligent man does not leave any traces.''


DAYTONA RACER DIES
LEAD: JOE YOUNG, a 38-year-old driver from Richmond was killed Friday, and Dr.
Duell Sturgill suffered two broken legs in a wild six-car pileup during a 200-mile race for four-cylinder subcompacts at the Daytona International Speedway.
Young, who was killed instantly, was the 16th driver to die at Daytona since the 2.5-mile track was opened in 1959.

LEAD: The real-estate association that represents New York City's biggest landlords and developers is urging the city to offer special incentives in two districts on the west side of lower Manhattan to prevent corporations from putting their computer operations in the suburbs.

LEAD: Almost a year after its opening, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is still plagued by problems, trade show organizers and exhibitors say.


Q and A
LEAD:  Troublesome Teen-Ager  Question: Most of the families in our 20-unit co-op are quiet and responsible.
In the last few years, however, the teen-age son of often-absent parents has progressively degenerated into an apparent drug addict.
He looks and acts frightening and is physically repulsive.


Lisbon
LEAD: There's a fresh exhilarating spirit about old Lisbon.
The Portuguese seem to have discovered that old is beautiful and brought new life to the fading city center.
Some of the main streets have been closed to traffic, creating lively esplanades with open-air cafes and handcraft stands.


AID OFFICIALS TROUBLED BY MOVES ON CAMBODIA BORDER
LEAD: The sudden relocation of large numbers of refugees under Khmer Rouge control in a closed Thai-Cambodian border camp is worrying relief agencies, a United Nations official said today.

LEAD: To the Editor:

New Rentals Sprouting in Manhattan
LEAD: THREE weeks ago, Pamela S. Jaffe settled into a new apartment in the East Village, ending her odyssey through a numbing stream of rental offices and model apartments uptown, downtown and in between.


AN IRISH ROVER COMES HOME TO THE ABBEY
LEAD: In a remarkable essay entitled ''A People's Theater'' (1919), W. B. Yeats, the founder of the Abbey Theater, described two seemingly opposed yet integrally related traditions in modern Irish drama.

Terrorists in Rome Kill 3 and Steal $900,000
LEAD: In a clockwork assault that authorities said bore the handwriting of terror organizations, a postal van was robbed in a residential neighborhood here today, and three police guards were slain by assailants who made off with $900,000.

LEAD: WITH Tomas Sandstrom out at least six weeks because of a broken ankle, the Rangers have recalled the right wing, Chris Jensen, from New Haven.
Jensen, who was sent to the American Hockey League team two weeks ago, has appeared in 31 N.H.L. games this season with 5 goals and 7 assists. . . .

LEAD: The Administration is deeply divided over a White House proposal that would give states broad new authority to waive Federal laws defining eligibility for benefits under health, education, welfare, housing and veterans' programs.


TREATING INVENTION AS AN ART FORM
LEAD: JACOB RABINOW, 77, an electrical engineer, works as a part-time consultant to the National Bureau of Standards, which sets official standards for all units of scientific measurement.
But he spends most of his time improving hinges or locks or ''just doing something in my head.'' Among his inventions are the automatic regulator once used in car clocks, the letter-sorting machine used by the United States Postal


Blazing Ahead
LEAD: THE NAVY BLAZER, ONCE AS PREDICTABLE as the gray-flannel suit, has undergone a subtle shift in character.
Easygoing and informal in its previous incarnations, it has acquired a new urbanity that is evident in broad, exaggerated shapes and luxurious fabrics such as doeskin flannel, lightweight serge or silk.


TODAY, AMERICAN FORCES ARE HARDLY EVER AT EASE
LEAD: AFTER two weeks of military maneuvers and political speculation, the threat of a United States strike against terrorists in the Middle East seemed to recede last week.
Despite that, large numbers of troops in each of the four military services did not relax.


HOLYFIELD RETAINS TITLE ON KNOCKOUT
LEAD: Evander Holyfield, a born-again Christian, came into the ring today with a reference to a biblical citation stitched to his trunks and ''Jesus Loves You'' on the back of his white satin robe.


Editors' Note
LEAD: An article in The Times Magazine today titled ''Sakharov's List'' describes the events that followed Andrei D. Sakharov's delivery of a list to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, citing 14 men confined by Moscow because of their political or religious views.
Dr.
Sakharov argued that the men should be freed.


NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Los Angeles; Resurrecting A Failed Mall
LEAD: SHOPPING centers age fast, especially in Southern California, and updating old ones often costs more than they are worth.
But in the Crenshaw area of this city, a local developer and the city hope to confound that problem at a cost of $100 million by reviving and expanding the state's first regional shopping mall.

LEAD: THE Interlochen Arts Academy in Michigan celebrates its 25th anniversary this year.
Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, the academy threw itself a grand party, with a concert featuring the Interlochen Arts Academy Orchestra and the violinist Ida Kavafian (Interlochen '69) in a program that included Beethoven's ''Coriolan'' Overture, Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto in E minor, and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No.

DEVILS' DEFENSE FALTERS IN ROUT
LEAD: Tim Higgins, Dave Barr and Gerard Gallant scored within 1 minute 43 seconds in the second period to help carry the Detroit Red Wings to a 5-1 victory today over the Devils.


JOBS GUIDE
LEAD: To underline the need for the business community to work with teachers in preparing students for future employment, the County Chamber of Commerce in White Plains has compiled and published a job-hunting guide based on a survey of vocational opportunities in Westchester.


PIANO: GUSTAVO ROMERO IN RECITAL DEBUT
LEAD: AN interesting and perhaps important debut recital took place at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night.
Gustavo Romero's choice of music was predictable, and it was cast in a predictably Romantic style.
But this young New York pianist has qualities that elevate him a little above the faceless musicality we have come to expect from such events.

BEIRUT REFUGEES'S PLIGHT TERMED GRIM DESPITE ARRIVAL OF AID
LEAD: Despite the arrival of some relief supplies in a besieged Palestinian refugee district here today, conditions in the district were described as desperate, with thousands of people suffering from malnutrition.


SURPRISE!
LEAD: THERE have been scores of horror stories told about them, including the most famous, and doubtless apocryphal, one about a couple being summoned downstairs of an evening by a telephone call reporting an emergency.
When they turned on the lights, they were greeted by a chorus of voices shouting ''surprise,'' but who was more surprised was moot because the couple had raced down without a stitch of clothing.


RIDING OUT SLUMPS IN A VOLATILE MARKET
LEAD: WALL Street's unprecedented surge has made a lot on investors very happy - and very nervous.
Those not content merely to take their gains and run are often forced to ride out the storms of a highly volatile market, hoping that the latest trough is not the start of a prolonged slump.
Some brokers argue that such investors can have their cake and eat it too, by hedging their portfolios with put options.


Chicha, Peru's Favorite Drink
LEAD: If you want to see how incomplete was Pizarro's conquest of the Incas, go to Cuzco.
Step inside the cathedral on the Plaza de Armas, walk past the altar of beaten silver with its monstrance of solid gold, and pause before a 17th-century painting of the Last Supper.
Here Jesus and his disciples sit down to a meal not of bread and wine, but of cuy and chicha - guinea pig and corn beer.

LEAD:  THE SACRED COW AND THE ABOMINABLE PIG: Riddles of Food and Culture, by Marvin Harris. (Touchstone/Simon &amp; Schuster, $6.95.) Hindus won't eat beef, while Jews and Moslems avoid pork and Americans quake at the idea of consuming cockroaches, thought a delicacy in some cultures.
Marvin Harris examines the reasons people eat what they do in this book, originally titled ''Good to Eat.


TRAVELS OF A ROCK
LEAD: THE newest attraction at the Rockefeller State Park Preserve in North Tarrytown is a giant jagged chunk of rock at least 600 million years old.
This mass of free-standing gneiss, almost 20 feet high and 65 feet in circumference, is probably the largest ''glacial erratic'' to be found anywhere in the county.

LEAD: Texaco lost its appeal to get a $10.53 billion award to Pennzoil overturned, but the Texas appeals court reduced punitive damages to $1 billion, from $3 billion, making the total $8.5 billion, plus about $4 billion in interest.
The award had been for ''wrongful interference'' in a Pennzoil deal to acquire Getty in 1984.

LEAD: HIDDEN SYMPTOMS.

LEAD: BRUISED FRUIT.

CHANGERS FOR CD'S GIVE MUSIC BY THE DAY
LEAD: Were special honors to be awarded for dubious achievements, the new compact-disk changers would rank among the leading contenders.
Spinning stacks of CD's for hours on end, they stretch out the music beyond anyone's attention span and make it all seem vapid.
Hailed for their nearly interminable running time, these longwinded changers are the culmination of a trend that - up to a point - made sense.

LEAD: Ralph Nader's public interest lobby and legal agency, Public Citizen, is pondering legal action to try to block the pay increases that recently took effect for members of Congress, Federal judges and senior Government officials.

One of the problems is that any lawsuit would almost inevitably be decided by a judge whose own raise could well depend on his own ruling.

LEAD: When the New York financier Disque D. Deane pledged $20 million to Duke University two months ago, Duke's president, H. Keith H. Brodie, hailed it as a ''landmark gift.'' But now university officials are debating whether to accept the gift because of a condition Mr.
Deane attached to it.

His former fiancee, Carlene Pearson, was arrested two weeks ago for carrying a loaded two-shot derringer at La Guardia Airport, where she was to meet the Mets' right-hander for a reported reconciliation.

LEAD: Poor, rural towns in Maine will no longer dump untreated wastes into once-pristine streams and rivers.
Tumors will no longer grow on flounder at the bottom of Boston Harbor.

HOW TO MAKE TRACKS ALL OVER
LEAD: As cross-country skiers step onto their skinny skis in woodlands, meadows and national parks this winter, a major topic of conversation is skating.
Pushing outward with each ski alternately, a technique known as the V-skate, is filtering down from racing to the recreational level.
Some recreational ski tourers are switching to skating from the slower, traditional stride.


IN FIRST MAJOR EXHIBITION, ANOTHER GIFFORD COMES TO LIGHT
LEAD: THERE used to be only two 19th-century Giffords to consider - the well-known Sanford Robinson (1823 to 1880) and the comparatively obscure Robert Swain (1840 to 1905).
Now there are three, because the work of Charles Henry Gifford (1839 to 1904), uncovered by the historian John I. H. Baur, is having its first major exposure in the show that has just arrived at the Katonah Gallery from the New Bedford Whaling Museum in Massachusetts.

I am no longer a penny-pincher.
I am, however, a penny picker-upper.

JAPAN'S GETAWAY ISLANDS
LEAD: The night ferry from Takeshiba Pier on Tokyo Bay slides away at 10 o'clock from fluorescent-lit buildings, oil refinery flares and the roar of Haneda Airport and heads out into the Pacific Ocean.
Seven hours later, as the vessel approaches Oshima, the first of the seven Izu Islands, flying fish lunge from the bow wave and skim on silver wings across a sea tinted pink by sunrise; wild flowers and evergreen shrubs exhale a delicate perfume.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Golf  Floyd Gains Tie With Eagle on Last Hole: Ray Floyd's last-hole eagle lifted him into a share of the third-round lead yesterday with J. C. Snead in a day of remarkable shooting at the Andy Williams Open in La Jolla, Calif.
Floyd's eagle finished off a 6-under-par 66.
He was tied at 199 with Snead, who also shot 66 on the South course at Torrey Pines.


No Vermont Death Penalty
LEAD: The Vermont Senate today rejected a bill calling for the reinstatement of the death penalty.
The vote was 21 to 8.
The roll-call capped more than a year of intense lobbying by proponents of the death penalty.
Senators on both sides of the issue took careful note of the fact that public opinion in the state seems to be strongly behind the death penalty.

DO LOCAL SCHOOL BOARDS HELP OR HINDER?
LEAD: COMMUNITY School Board 19, in the East New York section of Brooklyn, is composed of people with fairly standard backgrounds for a local New York City school board.
Most of them work for, or are related to, or were once themselves politicians.
There is a former assemblyman, two staff members of two assemblymen, the former staff member of a congressman, the sister of a New York City councilwoman and the chairwoman of the local planning board.


OBLIGING THE NOBLESSE
LEAD: The female figure in the Italian Renaissance was not only idealized as a Neoplatonic manifestation of ''heaven on earth,'' but seen as the embodiment of intellectual refinement.
And with this elevation of the flesh came a new cultural phenomenon - that of the ''honest courtesan.'' These highbrow mistresses, companions to princes, painters, ambassadors and merchants, writes Lynne Lawner in LIVES OF THE COURTESANS: Portraits of the Renaissance (Rizzoli, $35), were at once financially autonomous and perpetually enslaved.

LEAD: The White House commission looking into the Iran-contra affair turned up a trove of previously unknown documents last week and decided to prolong its investigation for a week to evaluate them.

Stress and anxiety in public places are as familiar to us as tuna and cottage cheese.


After Almost 200 Years, Sally Hemmings Still Dogs Jefferson
LEAD: To the Editor:  In his Feb. 7 letter, Judge Bruce McM.
Wright cites as historical fact the story of Thomas Jefferson's slave mistress, Sally Hemmings.
It is simply ridiculous that this patent lie should still be seen in print.
Its origin is almost as old as our Republic.

ALUMINUM WIRING MAY NEED ALTERNATION FOR SAFETY
LEAD: DURING the 1960's and early 70's when copper was in short supply and costs had risen considerably, thousands of homes were built with aluminum wiring instead of the traditional copper wiring.

In dollars, the mini-series, set in a Soviet-occupied United States in 1997, has added up to at least $40 million, or somewhere around $2.8 million per 49-minute (before commercials) hour.

FEUDING OVER CONSISTENT TREATMENT FOR CRIMINALS
LEAD: Two years ago, after tortuous negotiations, Congress and the Reagan Administration reached agreement on a plan to reduce the wide disparity in criminal sentences imposed by Federal judges.
A law was enacted creating the United States Sentencing Commission, which was to abolish the Federal parole system, standardize punishments and thereby remove much of the broad discretion that Federal judges had usually exercised in dealing with criminals.


CORNELL DEFEATS YALE, 86-74
LEAD: Dean Kartsonas scored 26 points to lead Cornell to an 86-74 victory over Yale tonight to remain atop the Ivy League.
The Big Red, 14-8 over all and 8-2 in the league, won its sixth straight game to go a game and a half in front of Penn.
Yale fell to 13-9 and 6-4 in the league.
Kartsonas hit 10 of 11 shots from the field and 4 and 4 from the free-throw line for Cornell.


Of Time And Place
LEAD: OF THE REVIVAL STYLES THAT burgeoned during the 19th century, Gothic Revival is perhaps best remembered in this country for the so-called Carpenter Gothic, or gingerbread, houses built in the mid-19th century.
Characterized by steeply pitched roofs adorned with decorative details, both the architecture and interior design were inspired by medieval English sources.

10% INSPIRATION AND 90% MARKETING
LEAD: AS the inventors told it, the biggest problem isn't coming up with ideas, or even executing them, but getting creations to market. ''I have more than 200 ideas, I just need the right contacts,'' said Abbas Husain, a New Jersey doctor who received a patent this year for a ''safer nail clipper.'' By the end of the conference, more than a dozen of the inventors were convinced they had found a contact on the speaker's platform, or at least someone who could help them make a connection.

Transported to America
LEAD: To the Editor:


How to Make Welfare Pay
LEAD: Work can be oversold as a fix for welfare and a cure for poverty.
Just ask the three million Americans who work full time and still can't escape poverty.
Nevertheless, self-sufficiency through work properly remains the fulcrum of welfare reform.
The challenge is to be realistic about just how much can be achieved through work, both for society and for individual welfare recipients.


RAUSCHENBERG AND JOHNS: MR. OUTSIDE AND MR. INSIDE
LEAD: It is by a conspicuous coincidence that a show devoted to Jasper Johns's paintings of ''The Seasons'' should be on view through March 7 at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway, while simultaneously there can be seen in the new Lila Acheson Wallace wing at the Metropolitan Museum what may well be the single largest work of contemporary art ever to be mounted in a great American museum.

Democrats decided last week to hold their national convention in Atlanta; the Republicans voted last month to take theirs to New Orleans.

HOW DO YOU FEEL ABOUT SPRING TRAINING?
LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.


ON LANGUAGE
LEAD: A MALAPROPISM IS a word or phrase that is amusingly off the mark.
For example, a recent pamphlet circulated by the Department of Health and Human Services dealt with ''inpatients'' but stated that ''hospital insurance covers impatient hospital care.'' (Inpatient is a retronym based on outpatient; used to be, a person receiving treatment in a hospital was merely a patient, and only the hatchet-faced head nurse was impatient.) The eponymous -ism was formed from ''Mrs.

ALUMINUM WIRING MAY NEED ALTERNATION FOR SAFETY
LEAD: DURING the 1960's and early 70's when copper was in short supply and costs had risen considerably, thousands of homes were built with aluminum wiring instead of the traditional copper wiring.
Although this was (and in most cases still is) perfectly legal and in conformance with electrical codes at the time, aluminum wiring has led to problems, and in some cases to hazards.

FROM LEAD TO STEEL, SWITCHING THE SHOT
LEAD: EVEN if you do most of your waterfowling in an area in which steel shot will not become mandatory for another few years, you shouldn't dawdle in facing up to the challenge posed by the Fish and Wildlife Service's announcement last year that such shot will become mandatory for duck and goose hunting throughout the nation by the 1991-1992 hunting season.

Archetypes And Ex-Lovers
LEAD: The truth is quite simple: Robert Ragaini is propagating the worst type of sexism in an effort to justify his own neurotic behavior.
Fear of intimacy has not been shown to be genetically linked to the Y chromosome, as far as I know.
Continuing the myth that women are naturally more emotional and that men are, as he puts it, ''more goal oriented'' is no different from saying that black people naturally have rhythm.
