ISRAEL'S PIONEERS RETURN ON FILM
LEAD: Hizma, Israeli-occupied West Bank Just outside this tiny Arab hamlet in the Judean hills, a hand-painted sign reading ''Dreamers Commune'' points the way to the newest Israeli settlement in occupied territory.
Perched on a hardscrabble hillside 10 miles north of Jerusalem, this stockade-like settlement, with a watchtower at its center, looks to be more out of the Wild West than the West Bank.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a map on Jan. 18 of Istanbul incorrectly showed the locations of two restaurants, and the caption for a photograph incorrectly identified a restaurant.
The Ziya and Samdan (there are other restaurants also called Samdan in Istanbul) restaurants are in the modern city, and the restaurant identified in the caption as the Samdan was actually the Hidiv Kasri.

LEAD: THE Morris County Board of Chosen Freeholders has unofficially approved a $1.183 million package that would maintain services for the elderly, ranging from Meals on Wheels for the homebound to minor home repairs for those too frail to do their own.


Highway A1A
LEAD: To the Editor: Mr.
Leifermann certainly did his share to perpetuate the Blowing Rocks State Nature Preserve as ''one of the least known'' beaches in Florida.
I read the article while on vacation in Deerfield Beach, Fla., and was intrigued by the idea of visiting this attraction.
I consulted the Pompano Beach office of the American Automobile Association for further information on Blowing Rocks and found that none of the travel advisers who were consulted, some of whom were longtime residents of the area, had heard of the preserve.


Braving Epilepsy's Storm
LEAD: I can't describe what strong emotions Kurt Eichenwald's article ''Braving Epilepsy's Storm'' (Jan. 11) evoked in me.
I am a physician, and I, too, have epilepsy.
Shortly after I graduated from medical school, in 1985, I experienced three seizures.

ROSTOPVICH'S CONTEMPORARY ROLE
LEAD: Mstislav Rostropovich's ongoing 60th birthday party is somewhat larger than life, like his cello playing and his image, embodying the genial, sentimental aspect of the Russian bear.
By the end of the New York phase, which began last weekend at Carnegie Hall and will run to March 21, he will have played 15 cello concertos in five programs with three orchestras, conducted four symphonies and the massive War Requiem of his beloved Benjamin Britten and played all six of the Bach cello suites for good measure.

Most bills have died in committee, while those that have survived have gone on to defeat.

LEAD: No American commercial television production has ever come remotely close to the sustained quality of British miniseries like ''Brideshead Revisited,'' ''I, Claudius'' or ''Ascent of Man.'' LITERATURE LOST IN THE THICKETS
LEAD: UNTIL Henry David Thoreau in the middle of the 19th century, America had no great literature of place and scarcely even the beginnings of such a tradition.
Here is an extraordinary cultural phenomenon once we begin to think about it, since it tells us that Americans after 200 years had not yet learned to make significant artistic use of the magnificent lands they called their own.

A Time for Watches
LEAD: THE SOUND IS ALWAYS with me - an insistent, rhythmic series of short happy chirps.
Like a loyal, friendly cricket, it follows me wherever I go.
I hear it at the opera when I rest my head in my hand.
It perches beside my bed, singing as I go to sleep, as I wake up.
It is my link to the world, my conscience, a reaffirmation of order and integrity in the face of hideous gaping chaos.

'KVETCH' ASKS 'WHY COMPLAIN?' AND REPLIES 'WHY NOT?'
LEAD: To kvetch, Leo Rosten wrote in his dictionary-cum-cosmology, ''The Joys of Yiddish,'' is, literally, to squeeze (''Don't kvetch the peaches''); in its verb form it can mean to fuss, to fret, to delay or to shrug, though it has entered the American lexicon as the more generic to complain or gripe.

NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1987
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-25  A secret White House program established at least four years ago to conduct a variety of covert foreign policy initiatives was the origin of the Administration's dealings with Iran and the contras, officials say.
Page 1  Brazil's souring economic situation has seriously eroded political and popular support for President Jose Sarney, tumbling the country into its worst crisis since civilian rule returned here two years ago.


Winds of the Antilles
LEAD: STARTING WITH SICHUAN, moving on to Mexican and flourishing in the riffs of New Orleans, American tastes in food have been moving steadily south and becoming significantly spicy.
Consequently, food watchers and eaters have not been surprised that among the new eats in town is Caribbean cuisine.


With New Senate, New Vulnerability
LEAD: IF speculation about Governor Cuomo's Presidential prospects has given him increased stature, it has done the same for some other players in state government as well.
There is a feeling here among Republicans and even Democrats that this is a vulnerable time for Mr.
Cuomo and that he can ill afford either an embarrassing legislative defeat or the appearance that he is not in full control of government.


Art
LEAD: Nick Ghiz is a sculptor who has a way with abandoned and ephemeral materials.
For some time he worked with wood.
In the last few years he has been building with paper and glue around a wire scaffolding.
He does not want his work to be in any way heavy.
He does want it to be magical.


East Germans Sweep
LEAD: East Germany swept the top three places in the 10-kilometer World Cup biathlon championships today at Mount van Hoevenberg.


HIGH-GLOSS JAGGER AND A 'BORIS' TO BE CHERISHED
LEAD:  Mick Jagger: ''Running Out of Luck''  CBS/Fox Video. 88 minutes. $79.98.


AQUINO TRIUMPHS, BUT HAS YET TO SUCCEED
LEAD: ''SURVIVAL,'' said President Corazon C. Aquino's executive secretary, Joker Arroyo, with a disdainful flick of his hand.


Marcia Hakim a Bride
LEAD: Marcia A. Hakim, the corporate secretary and associate general counsel of Trans World Airlines in New York, was married yesterday to Carl H. Hewitt, a vice president and assistant general counsel of Spear, Leeds &amp; Kellogg, a securities trading firm in New York.
Jean Somerville Kotkin, a leader of the American Ethical Union in New York, performed the ceremony at the couple's home in New York.


BACARDI'S GLASS IS HALF EMPTY
LEAD: A MAN, taking notes, hovers near the bar at Biscayne Babies, a popular haunt for young revelers in the Coconut Grove section of Miami.
In Miami's Casablanca-like climate of international intrigue, he could be mistaken for a spy as he strains to hear exchanges between the bartenders and waitresses above the background din of rock music.


No Headline
LEAD: Dunk: Michael Jordan of the Bulls scoring against the Knicks at the Garden.
Bulls won, 112-108.
Page 4.


St. Louis Board Favors Raise
LEAD: Rejecting arguments that the city cannot afford it, St.
Louis Aldermen have voted in favor of a bill giving them 48 percent pay increases.
The measure, approved Friday 18 to 10, would raise salaries for the part-time positions from $12,500 a year to $18,500.
The board must vote one more time next week, but the bill is expected to pass.


TRYING TIMES FOR A POPULAR PRIME MINISTER
LEAD: BOB HAWKE is a casual, down-to-earth kind of Australian, a former union leader who in 1954 set a world beer-drinking record by guzzling two and a half pints in 12 seconds.
Soon, he will try to set another record by becoming the first Prime Minister from the Labor Party to win a third term.


LOST IN THE JUNGLES OF THE 'SIMPLIFIED' TAX
LEAD: MY husband and I sit here in our den surrounded by files, pads of paper, pencils and two calculators, preparing for our favorite annual event.
The preparation of our taxes.


TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
LEAD: CROSS COUNTRY SKI INNS OF THE EASTERN U.S.
AND CANADA By Marge Lamy, with photographs by George W. Gardner. 124 pages.
The Stephen Greene Press, distributed by Viking Penguin.
Paperback. $12.95.


THE RHINE STRUGGLES TO SURVIVE
LEAD: For tourists, the Rhine will always be a broad brown ribbon running through the soul of Europe.
In the mountain reaches, like the region between Mainz and Coblenz, it winds through wooded hills, its banks lined with sloping vineyards and green gorges capped by turreted castles.


Look: Liberalism!
LEAD: It's poking up everywhere like daffodils through the melting snows of the Reagan revolution.
Six months ago, it was still the L-word, the political philosophy that dared not speak its name.
Careful believers called themselves ''progressives.'' Even brave ones dared no more than ''neo-liberal.'' Old liberalism - social-program liberalism - was discredited.


A GROUPIE FOR GREATNESS
LEAD: SUNFLOWER By Rebecca West.
Afterword by Victoria Glendinning. 276 pp.
New York: Viking. $18.95.


MCI REPLIES
LEAD: To the Editor:


COMEDIES WITHOUT LAUGHS MERIT CRIES OF PROTEST
LEAD: As of this writing, about $71 million has been spent nationwide on tickets to see ''The Golden Child,'' starring Eddie Murphy.
If ticket prices are assumed to be $6 in all parts of the country (though they're sometimes lower), and if discounts for various age groups are overlooked, that gives a low estimate of at least 11,833,333 tickets sold.


Stephen Milstein Plans To Wed Eve Ohringer
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
Sheldon Ohringer of ewlett Harbor, L.I., and New York have announced that their daughter Eve Irene Ohringer and Stephen Milstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Monroe G. Milstein of Mount Holly, N.J., are to be married March 14.


Braving Epilepsy's Storm
LEAD: The ''storm'' of epilepsy must be endured on many levels: biologically and medically, psychologically and socially.
Hiding epilepsy, which even one of Mr.
Eichenwald's physicians erroneously advocated, is the outcome of societal stigma.
It is perpetuated by a society that is frightened by the loss of control and powerlessness that the disorder represents.

LEAD: To the Editor: We at the Nature Conservancy are grateful that Mr.
Leifermann found the Blowing Rocks Preserve special enough to mention, but several statements about the preserve were misleading.
Blowing Rocks is not a ''State Nature Preserve.'' The Blowing Rocks Preserve is owned and managed by the Nature

Inmate's Complaint Sets 2 U.S. Agencies at Odds
LEAD: A bureaucratic dispute that began with an attempt by a Federal inmate to block punishment for his actions in complaining of hazardous conditions has brought two Government agencies to a Cabinet-level confrontation.


GOODBYE, NASHVILLE
LEAD: After more than half a century in Nashville, the headquarters of the United States Business and Industrial Council, an outspoken organization of 1,500 conservative business people around the country, is moving to Washington.
The main reason, it says, is to lobby more effectively on trade issues.


MUSIC: WUORINEN PIECE BY THE SAN FRANCISCO
LEAD: ANYONE wondering why a major orchestra would travel 3,000 miles to give New York yet another performance of Stravinsky's ''Firebird'' Suite or the Brahms First Symphony might have found the answer in the other piece on this program Friday night.
The orchestra was the San Francisco Symphony, that third work was Charles Wuorinen's ''Golden Dance,'' and what seemed to be transpiring at Carnegie Hall was one of those cat-and-mouse games symphony managements like to play with their listeners.

DAVIDS ISLAND
LEAD: THE United States Coast Guard will hold a public hearing at 7 P.M.
Wednesday at the New Rochelle City Hall on a proposal to develop Davids Island, an 80-acre piece of land 3,500 feet offshore, by building 2,000 condominiums and a marina for 850 boats.


PAUL SCHRADER PLUMBS GRASSROOTS ROCK
LEAD: Early in Paul Schrader's new film, ''Light of Day,'' the director jumps from a sequence of a rock-and-roll band performing in a Cleveland bar to short shots of the musicians at their day jobs.
Two of them work in a metal-pressing plant, and just before the camera leaves the scene it shows the factory's current product, commemorative trays of Prince Charles and Lady Diana.


IT'S ALMOST LIKE A VISIT TO ITALY
LEAD: WHEN you walk through the door of Tre Amici in Babylon, you forget you're on Long Island.
The brass railings, fresh flowers on the bar, the antique breakfront and the espresso machine all say Italy.


CHANGING TIMES IN TRENTON
LEAD: IN 1985, The Trenton Times dropped the ''Trenton'' and became, simply, The Times, a move intended to show that the paper was not for Trenton only.


OWLS LEARNING TO GIVE NOTHING AWAY
LEAD: DURING a luncheon at a restaurant on the edge of the city last week, John Chaney, the basketball coach at Temple University, stood before 100 guests who had gathered to honor the city's best high school athletes.


STAMFORD SETS DEC. 31 PARTY
LEAD: WITH New Year's Eve now a memory barely seven weeks old, some Stamford residents and civic leaders are already making plans for a special celebration next Dec. 31 - a downtown party with a costume parade and arts performances, both indoors and out and many of them free.


LIBRARY FINANCING
LEAD: Donna Greene's excellent article on the current dispute between the Westchester Library System and the White Plains Public Library stated that Kenneth W. Leisch, president of the White Plains Board of Trustees, ''pointed out that the Mount Vernon Public Library got a $300,000 allocation from the central system because it had been formally designated as the central library.


CONCERT: CZECH WORKS FROM MUSIC SPECTRUM
LEAD: MUSIC SPECTRUM, a chamber-music series presented for the last three seasons by the Russian-Israeli pianist Boris Berman in cooperation with the Yale School of Music, offered an excellent if rather overflowing concert of Czechoslovak music Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall.


ALUMINUM WIRING MAY NEED ALTERNATION FOR SAFETY
LEAD: DURING the 1960's and early 70's when copper was in short supply and costs had risen considerably, thousands of homes were built with aluminum wiring instead of the traditional copper wiring.
Although this was (and in most cases still is) perfectly legal and in conformance with electrical codes at the time, aluminum wiring has led to problems, and in some cases to hazards.

LEAD: With John Cardinal O'Connor standing in the background, Maria and David Hefner renewed their wedding vows yesterday at St.
Patrick's Cathedral, more than a month after the rector refused to allow the ceremony to take place because Mr.
Hefner is dying of AIDS.

LEAD: AFTER three outbreaks of salmonella illness in three months, health officials and lawmakers in the state are looking for measures to counter this type of food poisoning.

LEAD: The events described in this article are true, the people are real.
However, because the case has not yet gone to trial, the name of the deceased and the names of witnesses and suspects have been changed at the request of the New York City Police Department.


Laker Dream
LEAD: WHEN he was a student at the University of Minnesota, Mychal Thompson dreamed of playing for the Los Angeles Lakers, a franchise that originated in Minnesota.
The Lakers would probably have been willing to give the 6-foot-10-inch center-forward a try, too, but there was just one problem: Thompson and the Lakers were too good for each other.

LEAD: THE six jazz musicians who make up the group called the Leaders -because, in theory, they normally lead groups of their own - have not entirely separated themselves from the privileges of leadership in their performances at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, between Grove and Bleeker Streets, where they are appearing through today.

LEAD: It was the second attempt, and it took the intervention of Governor Cuomo to bring it about, but last week a dozen white teen-agers were indicted in the attack on three black men in Howard Beach that shocked the nation and heightened racial tensions in New York.

More Towers On the Hudson
LEAD: A $636 million hotel and apartment complex will rise on a 13-acre platform over the Hudson and 12 acres of riverfront land between 35th and 40th Streets if the development team chosen by the Koch administration last week survives some community opposition and wins the approval of the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate.


WHEN QUENNS MULTIPLY
LEAD: Positions that feature multiple queens must be handled in slam-bang style, since so much firepower makes slow maneuvering impossible.
What counts is whose move it is, who gets to fire the first shot, who has the attack.


ASIAN CRIME VICTIMS ENDING SILENCE
LEAD: Vietnamese immigrants who have settled in Philadelphia over the last decade have often been silent victims of assault, robbery and extortion by a small gang of Vietnamese youths.
But that silence appears to be ending, say the police, who attribute several recent arrests to the cooperation of Vietnamese crime victims.


IN SHORT: NONFICTION
LEAD: TREASON IN TUDOR ENGLAND: Politics and Paranoia.
By Lacey Baldwin Smith. (Princeton University, $25.) Lacey Baldwin Smith goes further than the title of his book and argues that ''Tudor England imagined political life to be so exposed to naked villainy and so devoid of friendship and loyalty that only a James Bond could have hoped to have survived.


Landmarks
LEAD: To the Editor: The article about American landmarks (Travel, Jan. 18) mentioned the St.
Louis railroad station and its conversion into hotels, shops and restaurants.
That is an excellent conversion.
I remember the station in the 1940's when it was active and contained a very large U.S.O. center for servicemen and women.


DIOGUARDI OUTLINES GOALS FOR L.I. SOUND
LEAD: AS a child, Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi said, he loved to fish in Long Island Sound with his uncles, but he fears his children may never get to cherish such memories.


Pop Music
LEAD: One of the most startling musical events of 1950 was the emergence of a 22-year-old Quechua Indian from the Peruvian Andes with a five-octave voice who sang contralto, mezzo soprano, soprano and coloratura, using growls, chirps and a variety of wordless effects when words would not suffice.
Her first album, ''Voice of Xtabay,'' hit the top of the pop best-seller list at the end of 1950.


MAN SAID TO TAX EARTH'S SYSTEMS
LEAD: The pressures of population growth and economic expansion are starting to exceed the ability of the earth's natural systems to sustain such activity, a new report by the Worldwatch Institute warned today.


Spain Expelling 2 Libyans
LEAD: Spain has told two Libyans suspected of fomenting an independence movement in the Canary Islands that they must leave the islands within 30 days, the Madrid newspaper Ya, a Roman Catholic daily, reported today.
On Friday, the chief Government spokesman and Culture Minister, Javier Solana, said the Libyans' residence permits had been revoked for ''certain contacts'' on the Canary Islands, but he would not elaborate.


120 JOBS MAY REST ON EFFECT ON FISH
LEAD: The Little Androscoggin, a slip of a river that winds through Mechanic Falls in the hills outside Auburn, has become the focus of a fight between state environmentalists hoping to protect the river's brook trout and town residents hoping to see an idle paper mill reopen.


OTTAWA'S BACKYARD WILDERNESS
LEAD: Imagine 88,000 acres of rolling hills, forests and lakes set aside as a natural habitat for white-tailed deer, beaver, the odd wolf and other wildlife.
Imagine it covered by a northern winter's accumulation of snow and frosted with a night's deposit of fluffy new powder.
Then imagine it overlaid with 125 miles of groomed cross-country ski trails - all on the doorstep of Canada's capital.


AN OLD FEAR, A GOOD LAUGH
LEAD: ONE second I was standing square on my feet, shoveling a light covering of snow.
The next I was sprawled on my behind, sliding down the driveway.
I did what a lot of other people have done in the last few weeks.
I fell down.


Bishops Denounce Condoms
LEAD: More than 150 Roman Catholic bishops meeting here have concluded that abstinence and marital fidelity are better weapons to fight AIDS than are condoms, which they believe create a false sense of security, a bishop said Friday.
The group determined that health officials, in promoting condoms, might be misleading the public since condoms do not always prevent transmission of the disease, said Bishop Leroy Matthiesen of Amarillo.


Thatcher Son Marries Texan
LEAD: Mark Thatcher, the son of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, married a Texas millionaire's daughter today in a private Valentine's Day wedding.
The 33-year-old bridegroom is a Dallas auto executive.
The bride, Diane Burgdorf, 26, is a bank employee.

LEAD: AFTER trying such themes as ''Love Thy Neighbor,'' the United Way in Burlington, Vt., went in for shock effect in its charity drive last fall - ''reality,'' the group called it.

LEAD: To the Editor:  James W. Davis manages to ignore some financial and political realities that need to be considered in discussing the issue of a draft.

LEAD: The Mets will not win their division by 21 1/2 games this year, not because they have weakened, but rather because the Phillies, the Cardinals and Pirates will not all collapse at once.

LEAD: EASTERN Connecticut's regional police helicopter program, the first time that several communities in the state have shared a rescue and patrol copter, is working well for participating towns and is attracting the attention of other communities.

LEAD: COME AS YOU ARE: The Peace Corps Story.
By Coates Redmon. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $22.95.) Anyone who has known Peace Corps volunteers in the field cannot help but be impressed by their dedication and diligence.

TALKING: Small Outlets; Setting Up Shop at A Mall
LEAD: AN artist or craftsman working alone often cannot afford the kind of retail space that will best expose his work to the buying public.
With the cost of leasing even a small store on a main shopping thoroughfare prohibitive, his only outlets have been craft fairs, outdoor markets or perhaps - at the expense of a share of the profits - a consignment arrangement with a local art dealer or craft shop.

LEAD: The state's Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, called this weekend for increased state aid for New York City, which, he said, has not asked for enough.

WESTCHESTER GUIDE
LEAD: CLASSES IN NATURE Children can still be enrolled in Pace University's nature program, scheduled from 1:30 to 3:30 P.M.
Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.
The popular sessions, which are limited to 15 participants, have been operated by the university's Environmental Center for more than a decade, introducing children 5 to 7 years old to some of the finer points of animal, plant and aquatic life.


GOOD NOVELISTS, BAD CITIZENS
LEAD: Finally there is something to say about Mona Lisa's smile.
A current theory holds that ''La Gioconda'' is a self-portrait - Leonardo without his beard - and that the smile is, in fact, a trickster's derisive glimmer, a transvestite joke: five centuries of pulling the wool over everyone's eyes.

LEARNING TO COPE WITH ILLNESS
LEAD: ANYONE who has ever been ill for even a few weeks is likely to experience some depression, anger and feelings of dependency.
For the chronically ill, whether they suffer with heart disease, arthritis, kidney failure, diabetes or any other long-term illness, these feelings are intensified, often overwhelming and potentially destructive to the treatment process.

THEY GET LETTERS
LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, read in Time last week that the magazine had received 46,000 letters on various topics last year.
He had a staff member check his own constituent mail and discovered that Time was not even in the race.
He received 537,886 letters on all sorts of topics.

WHEN THE FOCUS TURNS TO FINANCE
LEAD: THE problem with a CD-ROM-stored data base, as I mentioned last week, is that while it is fine for someone delving into history, it will not do for up-to-the-minute information like stock quotations or just-breaking news stories.
For that kind of timely data, one's computer needs access by modem to an on-line data base.

DEALING WITH THE LAWS OF THE LAND
LEAD: I have never been robbed abroad, save for an incident in Ghana in which two soldiers with machine guns took some cash.
That was more like taxation than thievery, however, because the perpetrators were soldiers on duty at a roadblock.
So I never have been properly robbed abroad.
Yet I do worry a bit when I am overseas about the security of my cash and passport.


HAVE THE METS AND YANKS CHANGED FOR THE BETTER?
LEAD: With a pitching staff headed by Rasmussen and Rhoden, the Yankees would appear to have changed for the better.
But wait!
How have they changed?
They lost Ron Guidry, their most versatile, dependable and successful pitcher for the last 10 seasons.
With 15-20 victories gone, the enormous void must be filled by the likes of Hudson, Filson and Tewksbury.

Cable TV
LEAD: What's in a movie title? ''House'' (1986), for instance, conveys nothing, yet it's a perfect fit for the original, entertaining suspense yarn that will be shown on Sunday at 12:45 A.M., Wednesday at midnight and Saturday at 1:40 A.M. on HBO.
This is a brisk thriller about a big Victorian dwelling that inflicts mayhem on its tenants.

NOTES FROM AN INVENTORS CONVENTION
LEAD: NOBODY had built a better mousetrap, but there were plenty of other ideas among the inventors who gathered last weekend in Arlington, Va., for the Seventh Annual National Inventors Conference.
Under the aegis of the United States Patent and Trademark Office, more than 50 inventors from around the country displayed their newly patented creations - ranging from a fortune-cookie folding machine to a shoe that allows its wearer to virtually walk on water - in hopes of attracting some commercial interest.


Correction
LEAD: Because of editing errors, the recipe for Chiu Chow braised duck in the Jan. 25 Food column is wrong in part.
The duck should not be added to the braising liquid until step three, the garlic in step four should be minced, and the cheesecloth bag of spices should not be removed unless the liquid is to be stored for an extended period.

SUDDENLY, A SOVIET VEIL IS LIFTED, REVEALING SCENES OF BITTER YOUTHS
LEAD: On Soviet movie screens, punk rockers spray-paint hostile graffiti on building walls.
In one Soviet journal, a drug addict's diary describes watching a fellow addict slit his wrists and die, and in another a sociologist drily chronicles greed and disaffection among Soviet youth.

LEAD: On Friday, Jan. 17 of last year, when Ronald Reagan or his autopen signed the ''finding'' submitted by Admiral Poindexter sending arms to Iran without notifying Congress, the two officials who ordinarily handled secret arms transfers had not yet returned from a trip to China.

Simon fights criminal allegations against him.

LEAD: Theodore M. Weis, a trumpet player with several classical ensembles in New York, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital on Saturday.
He was 66 years old and lived in Englewood.

LEAD: Most A.F.L.-C.I.O. members became eligible today for low-cost legal services ranging from free consultations and document reviews to discounts on lawyers' fees.


Bridge: New Book by Marty Bergen Contains His Creative Ideas
LEAD: The hardest-working bridge theorist in North America, most experts would agree, is Marty Bergen of White Plains.
His creative ideas have been shown to work in his partnership with Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J., and have been set out in two books entitled ''Better Bidding With Bergen.''


Military Cargo Helicopters Grounded for Gear Problems
LEAD: All Navy and Marine Corps CH-53E Super Stallion helicopters were grounded Saturday for inspection of a gear box problem that was found after a forced landing Oct. 21, a marine spokesman said.


The Winter Game
LEAD: Fred Perry, a former junior-college coach who's the baseball director at the new 135-acre Boardwalk and Baseball amusement complex in Orlando, Fla., is determined to make the game a year-round thing.
That might seem an ambitious undertaking in itself, but Perry, who has visions of turning the park's six diamonds into a baseball mecca, attracting college teams 12 months a year, is even more ambitious than that.

LEAD: To the Editor:


New Lafarge Chief Sees Quicker Pace
LEAD: The corporate restructuring announced last week by the Lafarge Corporation should help cut costs and improve market position, according to Bertrand C. Collomb, the company's new vice chairman and chief executive officer.
But in a sluggish industry, it may be some time before the improvements begin to show for the Dallas-based cement producer.


Inflation Slowed in '86
LEAD: The average increase in consumer prices in 24 industrialized Western countries last year was the lowest in 22 years, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
It said on Friday that prices rose an average 2.8 percent in 1986 for the smallest increase since a 2.4 percent advance in 1964.

RICHARD KENDRICK
LEAD: Richard Kendrick, a retired actor, died at the Bellevue Hospital Center last Tuesday after suffering a stroke.
He was in his early 80's and lived in Manhattan.


East Berlin Bank Plan
LEAD: A major commercial bank said that it was being denied permission to become the first West German bank to establish an office in East Berlin.
A spokesman for Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale (WestLB) said Friday that the bank had been told by West German banking authorities that the application would not be approved.

LEAD: Jose Napoleon Duarte was lauded at a major political demonstration a week ago, as thousands of Government workers, peasants from state-run co-operatives and others dependent on Government patronage were trucked into El Salvador's capital for a show of his ruling Christian Democratic Party's political machine at work.


Earning the Pay
LEAD: Members of Congress are very sensitive about their recent raise to $89,000 a year, fearful that the voters might believe they were over-rewarding themselves.
But Representative Daniel E. Lungren, Republican of California, believes the American people ''are not really upset with us over the rate of pay we receive but with the perceived failure to perform after we get paid.


FOOD FETISH FROM AUSTRALIA
LEAD: One of the mysteries of this country, to an American, is the Australian fondness for a black yeast spread called Vegemite.
It sometimes seems virtually the national food, spread on toast, mixed with hot water to make a drink or added to stews.


RISE IN RETARTED CHILDREN PREDICTED FROM CHERNOBYL
LEAD: Up to 13 of the 300 Soviet children born since the reactor accident at Chernobyl to women who lived nearby are expected to suffer mental retardation because of exposure to hazardous levels of radiation, an American physician who recently returned from the contaminated area said here today.
But none of the children have been observed to have any physical defects, he said.


'Oracle,' a Work By Howell and Tavares
LEAD: ''Oracle'' by Donald Howell and Albert Tavares - an hourlong piece for voices and electronic keyboards presented Saturday at Mr.
Tavares's studio on Eighth Avenue - is based on phonetic syllables derived from ancient chants and on ''text material . . . generated using psychosynthesis, a new psychology developed by Roberto Assagioli as a method of integrating various aspects of the personality through the use of symbolic images created in a meditative state,'' according to the program.

LEAD: Iosif Z. Begun, the Jewish dissident whose continued imprisonment set off violent demonstrations in downtown Moscow last week, has been freed, a senior Soviet official said today.

Mr.

LEAD: AS the hockey season follows its logical progress toward the frenetic stretch drive that portends April's playoffs and payoffs, the rookie coach is continually reminded that he didn't expect this job to be fun.


Colombian Wins Flyweight Title
LEAD: Fidel Bassa of Colombia won the World Boxing Association flyweight title with a unanimous 15-round decision over the champion, Hilario Zapata, of Panama Friday night.
There were no knockdowns.
Bassa, 24 years old, fighting in only his 17th bout, is the sixth Colombian to win a world boxing title.

LEAD: Neighborhood youngsters looking at the wreckage of the Helping Hand Rescue Mission yesterday in Huntington Station.
The building was destroyed by an explosion and fire late Saturday night.

Question Box
LEAD: QUESTION: In major league baseball, which has occurred more frequently, a no-hitter or a batter hitting for the cycle?
Although both are scarce, over the years, it has been slightly easier for a starting pitcher to keep an opposing team hitless for nine innings than it has been for a batter to rap opposing pitchers for a single, double, triple and home run in one game.

STAGE: 'DAZY,' A MUSICAL
LEAD: Late in the second act of ''Dazy,'' a musical set in midtown Manhattan, a homeless man assures the audience, ''You've got to be a romantic to live out on the street.'' The pronouncement, which flies in the face of evidence that most New Yorkers encounter every day, exemplifies the colossal wrongheadedness of a show that portrays street people as muddled bohemian eccentrics down on their luck.

LEAD: The Sports World Specials column in SportsMonday last week reported an erroneous finding by a committee of baseball researchers.

Catching Up
LEAD: *

He's still on the go.
Wieland, a weight lifter who propels himself by using his arms to lift and drag his 123-pound body, is now entered in the Los Angeles Marathon, and this time he hopes to win.

LEAD: It was a few beers past midnight at the Quarter Deck Inn.
Outside, the wind-chill factor pushed 10 degrees, and the weather forecast called for light snow.
Inside, the bar was elbow-to-elbow with smartly sweatered out-of-towners, and the band was earnestly bopping its way through a current hit, ''It's Hip to be Square.


USED U.S. CLOTHES A BEST SELLER IN AFRICA
LEAD: The latest garments for sale at a marketplace in Kinshasa are displayed by a saleswoman brandishing a sharp knife.
She cuts open a 100-pound bale and, as customers eagerly surge forward, out spill pastel polo shirts, khaki short-sleeve shirts and cotton pants - all secondhand.

LEAD: AND so we sat the other night, in the dead of winter, watching Mookie Wilson do his midnight dance.


A Tax Hotline In Michigan
LEAD: A computerized telephone service that will let Michigan taxpayers learn the status of their refunds was introduced Friday by the state Treasurer, Robert Bowman.


Pastor Seeks Inquiry Into Suspect's Death
LEAD: The Rev.
Herbert Daughtry, a Brooklyn minister active in civil rights cases, called yesterday for a special prosecutor and an independent autopsy in the death of a Queens burglary suspect who collapsed last Thursday in a police holding cell shortly after a violent struggle with eight police officers.


For Farm Workers, for Decency's Sake
LEAD: In 1972, America's farm workers asked the Federal Government to insure them the basic dignities to which virtually all other American workers are entitled.
They wanted drinking water in the workplace, which in their case is the fields.
Fewer than half are provided with it.
They wanted to be able to wash pesticide residue off their hands.


Import Limits Called Costly
LEAD: Restrictions on foreign trade cost Americans $50 billion a year, according to Daniel Oliver, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.


Aqueduct Forced To Cancel a Race
LEAD: A malfunction of the starting gate resulted in cancellation of Aqueduct's ninth and final race yesterday and necessitated a refund of $923,507 in triple, exacta and straight bets.


Latin America Debt Warning
LEAD: Latin America will have to get better terms in its foreign debt rescheduling or it will be forced to limit debt service to a percentage of export earnings, officials said Friday.


Books of The Times; Mosaic of the Mind
LEAD: THE SOCIETY OF MIND.
By Marvin Minsky.
Illustrated. 339 pages.
Simon &amp; Schuster. $19.95.
What on earth is a ''society of mind''?
By choosing this phrase for the title of his new book on how people think and feel, Marvin Minsky, the artificial-intelligence expert, is trying to convey his belief that each mind is made of many smaller processes, which he calls ''agents.

Three members of the crew were lost in the sinking.

LEAD: In a scientific advance with potentially valuable commercial application, researchers at the University of Houston and the University of Alabama in Huntsville have produced a superconductive compound that loses all resistance to electricity when cooled to the temperature of liquid nitrogen, the National Science Foundation announced yesterday.

LEAD: Already struggling to contain the highest inflation rate in the country's history, the Brazilian Government is now bracing itself for a new foreign debt crisis brought on by a dramatic slump in its hard currency reserves, according to Government officials.

Beethoven Symphonies By Vienna Philharmonic
LEAD: The Vienna Philharmonic is to play the complete Beethoven symphonies and piano concertos in a six-concert series at Carnegie Hall next month, under the direction of Claudio Abbado and with Maurizio Pollini as soloist.
The performances would be the orchestra's first in New York since 1976.


KAROLOS KOUN
LEAD: Karolos Koun, a Greek theater director whose lively staging of ancient Greek plays won him acclaim in Europe, died last Saturday after suffering a heart attack, according to friends in Athens.
He was 78 years old.

LEAD: Earvin (Magic) Johnson scored 39 points and led Los Angeles back from a 17-point third-quarter deficit to a 106-103 victory over the Boston Celtics, giving the Lakers the best record in the National Basketball Association.

TV: A LOOK AT DUCHAMP
LEAD: Outside a cafe in Cadaques, Spain, the artist Marcel Duchamp is playing chess.
As a camera closes in, he describes the game as part of his passion for play: ''If you play with life, you are just as alive as people who believe in religion or art.''

LEAD: Mario Biaggi sits in a rocker in his office here, his silvery hair framed by the Capitol dome that rises beyond the window.

LEAD: Mimi Williams, 32 years old, always longed to be ordained into the clergy.
But because she was a Roman Catholic and the Catholic Church still refuses to ordain women, ''I knew there was no hope,'' she said.

LEAD: The presidents of all the major Central American countries except Nicaragua met here today and invited the Nicaraguan Government to join them in a new regional peace conference within 90 days.

LEAD: Four years ago this month, after having been turned down by Jacqueline Onassis and Beverly Sills, Mayor Koch named Bess Myerson commissioner of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs.


France Likely To Buy Awacs
LEAD: France is expected to follow Britain's lead and agree within a month to buy at least three Awacs radar planes, Pentagon officials said Friday.


FARM CREDIT CRISIS: BAILOUT DEBATE NEAR
LEAD: The United States Farm Credit System is expected to report a 1986 loss of $2.3 billion to $2.4 billion, virtually assuring that a Federal rescue will be needed this year, according to Government officials.
The report is to be issued Wednesday.


PLEDGING ALLEGIANCE IN MANILA
LEAD: About 4,000 Philippine police officers swore allegiance to the new Constitution during ceremony yesterday.
Similar ceremonies are planned today for soldiers at garrisons nationwide. (AP)


OPEC Pricing Review
LEAD: The Price Differentials Committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet March 9 in Vienna to review the official prices it set last December, according to an oil official of the United Arab Emirates.
The prices went into effect on Feb. 1.

LEAD: On a typical day in Judge Renee White's courtroom, a procession of defendants passed before the bench - accused crack users and crack dealers, young men charged with washing motorists' windows without permission, Senegalese accused of peddling without a license.

LEAD: Northeastern state officials want to create stronger markets for recycled products in an effort to deal with the growing problem of garbage disposal.


Head of Stone Container Capitalizes on Mergers
LEAD: It was not until his last two years of college that Roger W. Stone decided to join his family's business, the Stone Container Corporation.
If the company's commitment to the paper industry was ever in doubt in those early days some 20 years ago, those doubts now have been put to rest.


China to Establish 6 Airlines
LEAD: China will set up six independent airlines by 1988 to operate international and domestic flights, the official New China News Agency quoted Hu Yizhou, director-general of the state-owned airline company, as saying on Saturday.


CONCERT: CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
LEAD: ALEXANDER VON ZEMLINSKY had the misfortune of being born sane in an extravagant age.
Eminent composer of his day, conductor, teacher of Schoenberg, colleague of Mahler, Zemlinsky did everything with enormous technique and thoughtful care; yet he has sunk into musical history, pulled down by the inertia of forgetfulness and neglect.


DANCE: BYRD'S 'REHEARSAL'
LEAD: Donald Byrd has tackled racism, the pain of rejection as an artist and the loss of innocence in his dances.
In ''The Rehearsal,'' a new work performed by Donald Byrd/The Group on Friday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, Mr.
Byrd has created a flawed but often evocative fable, to music by Carman Moore, about a choreographer and his dancers.

LEAD: For a school that's getting a brand-new $8.5 million gym next season, Williams College is making an awful lot of fuss about the old one.

LEAD: ''I am not a horse trader,'' Jacques Delors, president of the European Community's Executive Commission, insisted recently. ''I don't ask for 10, expecting to get 5.''


Mendelssohn Quartet And Namesake's Music
LEAD: The Mendelssohn String Quartet concentrated on music of its namesake at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday evening, and played as though determined to defend the composer against the impression that he was oversupplied with delicacy, elegance and grace, and a little short on true grit.
This listener found himself wishing the performers had embraced the former qualities more fully.


PERKINS, AFTER BUILDING HIS DREAM HOUSE, MOVES OUT
LEAD: When the swirl of rumors began blowing Ray Perkins out of Alabama long before he would actually leave, he hadn't been considering changing jobs at all.
He was happy in Tuscaloosa, successful with the football team and making somewhere around $500,000 a year.
As he told the world when he left the Giants in 1982 to succeed Paul (Bear) Bryant and become athletic director and head coach at his alma mater, this was a ''dream job.

LEAD: Dean Garrett hit a follow shot with four seconds left in the third overtime as Indiana escaped with an 86-85 Big Ten victory over Wisconsin tonight.

LEAD: Dome Petroleum Ltd. and the British Petroleum Company declined to comment today on a published report that the multinational oil company was negotiating to acquire Dome, which is burdened with debt.

LEAD: On 340 square miles of what was a barren desert only a decade ago, Saudi Arabia has built the world's biggest new industrial city.
Jubail is an odorless, litterless, smog-free community with hotels, an airport, highways, schools, mosques, shopping centers, a hospital, baseball diamonds and more than 100,000 imported trees that are irrigated with water reclaimed from the sewers.

Dairy-Deli Association Picks Lempert Agency
LEAD: The Lempert Company, an ad agency in Belleville, N.J., that is particularly skilled at advertising products in the supermarket milieu, has become the agency for the Dairy-Deli Association of Madison, Wis., which plans to spend $6 million to get consumers to buy more in dairy-deli sections of their supermarkets.


THE 1972 ABM TREATY: 2 WAYS TO READ KEY PARTS
LEAD: Following are, in column one, excerpts from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty and, in column two, summaries of the traditional interpretation of the treaty and the current Administration view.
The summaries are based on Congressional testimony, public statements and interviews.
The Soviet Union says it backs the traditional view, held by the United States until late 1985.

STOP GOLF'S TATTLE-TALES
LEAD: In pro football, only one instant-replay official can reverse a ruling.
One too many, some people feel.
And once the next play begins, no reversal is possible.
But in golf, thousands of instant-replay officials are out there, watching and waiting to pounce upon a golfer who breaks a rule even inadvertently, as Craig Stadler did in using a towel to ''build a stance'' in the Andy Williams


'CANDID CAMERA' MARKS 40 YEARS WITH A SPECIAL
LEAD: THE old shows are used in university psychology courses to show people caught in the act of being themselves.
The cast of characters included everybody from Harry S. Truman, taking his walking constitutionals in Manhattan, to Woody Allen, a young comic looking to make an extra dollar.
The program is, of course, ''Candid Camera,'' and tonight at 8 on CBS, it celebrates its 40th birthday with an hourlong special produced and directed - largely pasted together -by Bob Henry for Allen Funt Productions.

LEAD: YEHUDI MENUHIN was back in New York Sunday night playing his violin and conducting the Warsaw Sinfonia at Carnegie Hall.
Mr.
Menuhin is at once the most satisfying and elusive of musicians.
His serenity and sincerity of purpose, that is, remain constant, even when the technique does not.

Foss Premiere to Have Composer as Soloist
LEAD: A chamber music piece by Lukas Foss, written on commission from three institutions, is to be given its premiere today at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.
The piece, for piano and chamber ensemble, is to be played Wednesday at Carnegie Hall in New York City.


BANK OF NEW YORK DEAL
LEAD: The Bank of New York has completed its previously announced acquisition of North American Bankcorp from Banca Commerciale Iataliana.
The deal, said to be valued at about $300 million, represents a move by the bank to tap a wider middle-market commercial loan business.
The principal unit of Norht American is the Long Island Trust Company, which has $1.8 billion is assets and operates 46 branches.


Ex-Head of F.C.C. Named for Intelsat
LEAD: Dean Burch, a former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has been nominated by the United States to head Intelsat, a nonprofit group of 112 nations that runs a worldwide satellite communications network.


ARREST OF PALESTINIAN ALIENS IN LOS ANGELES TO BE REVIEWED, U.S. AIDE SAYS
LEAD: The top investigations official of the Immigration and Naturalization Service has requested an inquiry into the arrest of eight immigrants here, purportedly affiliated with the radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, and their planned deportation on the ground of subversive activity.


Edwin M. Appel, 70; Led Accounting Firm
LEAD: Edwin M. Appel, a founder and senior partner of the accounting firm of Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon &amp; Company and a philanthropist, died of cancer Sunday in Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif.
He was 70 years old and lived in New York.

Pointless Search
LEAD: Dale Brown, Louisiana State's basketball coach, after a 60-52 loss to Alabama: ''I don't know where the missing persons bureau is, but if we go there, maybe we can find our of fense.''


MORE PALESTINIANS LEAVE BESIEGED AREA:
LEAD: A boy crying as he and relatives were relocated yesterday to the Mar Elias district in Beirut from the Burj al Brajneh center.
About 500 Palestinians, mostly women and children, have been allowed to leave Burj al Brajneh, which has been besieged by Shiite Moslem militiamen.
United Nations relief workers were not allowed to bring food into the center, but Shiites lifted a four-month blockade of two Palestinian districts near Tyre to allow entry of food trucks.

J, tell him about Thomasina Robinson.
She's all of 46, and she plays basketball too.


Barclays Has Talks in Zambia With Anti-Apartheid Leaders
LEAD: Barclays International, a British bank that pulled out of South Africa last year, held talks here today with the African National Congress, the the anti-apartheid group said.


White House Secretariat?
LEAD: History itself may not be enough of a teacher for future Presidents, according to the Center for the Study of the Presidency.
The group, based in New York, proposes the establishment of a ''small, permanent, nonpolitical advisory secretariat'' in the White House, to provide ''an institutional memory'' from one administration to another.


5 FROM COMMUNE QUESTIONED
LEAD: Florida officials today interviewed five District of Columbia women who said they were the mothers of six children taken into custody here with two men earlier this month.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. Why is the distance between stars measured in light years?
And how long, in miles, is a light year?
A.
The stars are spaced so far apart that any measurement of the distance between them in familiar units would be unwieldy, according to Dr.
Joe Patterson, professor of astronomy at Columbia University.

Remedial Work for School Boards
LEAD: Robert Wagner Jr., president of New York City's Board of Education, thinks community school boards are so steeped in politics and patronage as to stifle education reform.
His views are echoed in a Bronx grand jury investigation of local boards.
Mr.
Wagner proposes appointed rather than elected boards, stripped of authority to hire and dismiss principals and other administrators.

NEW BID REPORTED FOR FREEING WAITE
LEAD: The Lebanese Druse leader Walid Jumblat traveled to Damascus today amid reports that efforts to free Terry Waite, the missing Anglican envoy, had been renewed.


Impressive Cast
LEAD: Zhu Jianhua, the Chinese high-jumper, and seven Rumanians, led by the 1984 Olympic 3,000-meter gold medalist Maricica Puica, will participate in the Mobil Indoor Championships at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 27, meet organizers announced yesterday.
Zhu won the bronze in the Los Angeles Olympic Games and is currently tied for the fifth-best jump in history at 7 feet 10 inches.

Jazz 109, Celtics 89: Karl Malone scored 25 points and pulled down 15 rebounds, and the Utah reserves outscored the Boston bench, 56-6, at home.

FRENCH STORE STUDYING 4 SITES IN CITY
LEAD: Au Printemps, the largest French department-store chain, with three units in Paris alone, is studying four sites in Manhattan as candidates to be the site of its first New York store.


U.S.-Japan Chip Pact
LEAD: The European Community is to ask the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to set up a panel to examine a trade accord on computer chips between the United States and Japan, a European Community spokesman said.
He said the request would be made at the next GATT council meeting in Geneva on March 4 and would concern only the Japanese part of the agreement.

LEAD: The most influential leader of the Nicaraguan rebel alliance, Adolfo Calero, resigned today in a power struggle that threatens the future of the Washington-backed anti-Sandinista forces.

More Than Bureaucrats on the Bench
LEAD: Not long after being elevated to the Supreme Court, Justice Antonin Scalia has come out fighting for the judges he left behind on the lower rungs of the Federal judiciary.

Judges are getting increasingly bogged down in ''trivial'' cases that overwhelm and bore them.

CORRECTION
LEAD: A chart Saturday with an article about a $7 million judgment against the United Klans of America in a 1981 slaying incorrectly identified one division of the Klan.
The group based in Fayetteville, N.C., is the Southern National Front, formerly known as the Confederate Knights of the Ku Klux Klan.

LEAD: For the first time since the Iran-contra arms scandal arose, it may now be possible to glimpse its full dimension.

Lea Seeks Comeback
LEAD: Charlie Lea, the one-time ace of the Montreal pitching staff, has signed a minor-league contract with the Expos' Class AAA team in Indianapolis.
The move circumvented an arbitrator's ruling last week that prohibited clubs from dealing with their own unsigned free agents until May 1.
The 31-year-old Lea, who missed the last two seasons with a rotator cuff injury, will now be able to attend Montreal's major-league training camp beginning in West Palm Beach, Fla., next week as an invitee.

Justice Scalia, in Public, Considers a Hypothesis
LEAD: It is rare for a member of the Supreme Court to engage in an animated public debate and submit to interrogation on disputed legal issues.

PIANO: MITSUKO UCHIDA IN RECITAL AT TULLY HALL
LEAD: MITSUKO UCHIDA, who made her international reputation principally -and her young American reputation almost exclusively - as a Mozart pianist, played Schubert, Schoenberg and Chopin Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall.
All of it was first-rate, but the real surprise was the Chopin Third Sonata.
I cannot recall ever hearing such a spirited, affirmative, beautifully conceived performance of this wonderful work before.

LEAD: Existing homes sold at the fastest pace in history during the last three months of 1986, a real estate trade group said today.


PUTTING A MODEM TO THE TEST
LEAD: THERE I was, at 11 P.M., trying to access the Dow Jones News/Retrieval Service with a software package I was reviewing, but something was distinctly suspicious.
I could tell from the fact that all I could hear was the winter wind roaring in the ice-covered trees outside.
The word ''dialing'' flashed on the monitor screen before me, but no sound emanated from the PC's Limited 286 computer except the rather excessively loud whir of the fan.

British Bank Board
LEAD: Britain plans legislation to tighten controls on the Bank of England by adding a sixth independent member to the board of banking supervision and by doubling the maximum insolvency deposit to $:20,000, the Treasury said.
Independent members, who sit on the supervisory board along with top Bank of England officials, would be appointed jointly by the Chancellor of the Exchequer and the governor of the Bank of England, it said in a statement.

The China Daily said the new wage policy is vital to the success of economic reforms aimed at revitalising companies.


THIS ALL-STAR IS BLUE-COLLAR
LEAD: When Rick Green was introduced to the crowd at Le Colisee in Quebec for the first of two games he played last week, tiny bluish-white lights that had been strung across the ceiling twinkled at the mention of his name.
Spotlights followed his strides until he took his place along the blue line occupied by the National Hockey League all-stars.

RECITAL: GAITHER-GRAVES
LEAD: MAREDA GAITHER-GRAVES'S recital Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall was consistent in its satisfactions and limitations.
The former stem from a wide-ranging and heartfelt sympathy for the songs she chose.
What the soprano seems to lack is the ability to produce a free-flowing, attractive sound at dynamic levels above the softest.


FALSE STOCK REPORTS BY AUSTRALIAN
LEAD: Trading was suspended today in the shares of a company headed by Alan Bond, the Australian financier, after he admitted that he had made misleading statements about the value behind the securities.

Justice Official Asks Panel Restore to Death Penalty
LEAD: The Justice Department today urged a Congressionally created panel to issue guidelines that would restore the death penalty for certain Federal crimes, including treason, espionage and assassination of a President.

LEAD: Built in splendor by a German congregation, kept in its waning days by a Polish congregation and finally abandoned, New York's oldest synagogue building is now owned by a Spanish sculptor who dreams of turning it into an artists' colony.

Cauthen May Return
LEAD: Steve Cauthen, who rode Affirmed to victory in each of the 1978 Triple Crown races and has ridden in England in recent years, may have a homecoming in the Jim Beam Stakes March 29 at Turfway Park in Florence, Ky.
Clive Brittain, the British trainer and a friend of Cauthen's, has nominated Bengal Fire and Rumboogie for the $500,000 guaranteed Beam Stakes, a major preparatory race for the Kentucky Derby.


20 ARE INJURED
LEAD: A slow-moving Metro-North commuter train collided last night with an empty train returning to Manhattan at a switching point in the South Bronx, injuring 20 passengers and halting service to and from Grand Central Terminal, officials said.

MCREYNOLDS LOSES IN RULING ON SALARY
LEAD: On a day when the Yankees made the biggest news and spent the most money, the Mets were content to fashion their own modest but winning box score on labor matters yesterday: one victory in arbitration, two signings without arbitration.


BOWIE KUHN LIVES
LEAD: The Old Commish is back.
Abandoning the stuffed shirt in which the image-makers portrayed him, Bowie Kuhn has put on his flannel wood-chopping shirt to flail away at some of the owners - particularly the benefactors of our local playpens.


Textile Bill Is Sought
LEAD: Congressional supporters of the textile industry said today that they are planning a new effort to legislate import curbs designed to build a broader coalition than last year, when a Presidential veto of textile quotas was nearly overriden.


Connors Optimistic
LEAD: Jimmy Connors, whose right knee was injured in the final of the United States Indoor championships in Memphis last Sunday, will be sidelined for only a short period of time, according to his attorney. ''Jimmy had the knee examined and X-rayed by doctors in St.
Louis Monday, and there appears to be no ligament or cartilage damage,'' Irving Blumberg, the attorney, said in a statement released by ProServ, the company managing Connors's business affairs.

Liberty Does Not Say, 'Give Me Your Dollar'
LEAD: To the Editor:


U.S. INDUSTRY IN JANUARY AT 79.7% OF CAPACITY
LEAD: American industry operated at 79.7 percent of capacity in January, the best showing in almost a year, as the manufacturing sector continued to provide signs that the worst of its trade problems may be ending.


Steel Output Rises
LEAD: Steel production rose to nearly 1.399 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 5.7 percent from the previous week's 1.323 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 65 percent of capacity during the week, compared with a revised 61.4 percent in the previous week.


Pakistani to Visit India
LEAD: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan will visit India this weekend for talks with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, an Indian spokesman announced today.
Tension arose between the two countries last month when both massed their armies along their border.
At a meeting in New Delhi two weeks ago, the two Governments agreed to a partial withdrawal of troops.


Birds at Nevada Refuge Are Killed by Cholera
LEAD: An outbreak of cholera was responsible for the deaths of some of the 1,500 birds at a wildlife sanctuary, but officials still do not know what killed more than three million small fish.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Mass Murderer Held Sane
LEAD: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled today that George Banks was legally sane, and it upheld his conviction for murder and his death sentence in the slayings of five of his children and eight other people in 1982.
The court, voting 5 to 2, said that Mr.
Banks ''suffered from a mental defect'' but ''was legally sane and competent to stand trial.


DELAY IN ANOTHER
LEAD: Soviet authorities said today that the imprisoned dissident Anatoly Koryagin had been freed by a decree, but that Iosif Z. Begun remained in prison pending a decree approving his release.


Hospital Criticized In Care of Youth
LEAD: A state health department investigation found that a Brooklyn emergency room failed to administer oxygen to an 18-year-old Brooklyn youth who was rushed there by ambulance while suffering an acute asthma attack on Dec. 8, City Council president Andrew M. Stein said yesterday.


RISE IN ELDERLY CHANGING FACE OF RURAL AMERICA
LEAD: It happened long before she expected.
It found her totally unprepared.
But Betty Eggland, like thousands of other elderly residents of rural America, has discovered that she is alone in her life but not in her predicament.

Economic Scene; Japanese View U.S. Industry
LEAD: PRESIDENT REAGAN met with a group of top business leaders in the East Room of the White House yesterday to discuss America's loss of competitiveness in world markets - and what can be done about it.
The Scottish poet Robert Burns suggested that we should see ourselves as others see us, and nobody seems to see the problems of American industry more clearly these days than do the Japanese.


U.S. IS PRESSING NEW ABM VIEW IN THE GENEVA ARMS NEGOTIATIONS
LEAD: American negotiators have been telling Soviet officials in Geneva that Washington's new, broader interpretation of the 1972 ABM treaty is justified, officials said today.


RELUCTANT MILLIONAIRE CLAIMS LOTTO WINNINGS
LEAD: A 20-year-old college student from Brooklyn finally stepped forward yesterday, shyly and almost fearfully, to become a millionaire.


PLAN TO SELL TV RIGHTS ON PAPAL VISIT ASSAILED
LEAD: A plan by Roman Catholic officials to auction television rights for coverage of a September visit by Pope John Paul II has set off an uproar among broadcasters and some church leaders.


Europe Shaping Response to Gorbachev's Moves
LEAD: With West Germany taking the lead, Western European nations have started to shape a response to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of change in the Soviet Union, in the hope of exerting influence.

LEAD: Labor Secretary Bill Brock, left, talking with Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., at session of the organization's winter meeting in Bal Harbour, Fla.
Speaking before the 35-member council, Mr.
Brock indicated that the Reagan Administration might try to revive a below-minimum wage for teen-agers if Democrats and labor unions persist in efforts to raise the current minimum wage of $3.35 an hour.


American Air Altering Fares
LEAD: American Airlines plans to raise its cheapest discount fares and stiffen ticket cancellation penalties, beginning March 2, it said yesterday.

Tubman's life was agony.

DIAL-A-RESTAURANT
LEAD: DIAL AND DINE, an eight-month-old restaurant-referral service, invites people to call for ''up to the minute'' advice about more than 1,000 Manhattan establishments.
The service also makes reservations, ''assuring you a table that might not otherwise be available,'' according to its advertisements.


INTEREST RATES RISE MODESTLY
LEAD: Short- and long-term interest rates rose modestly in quiet trading yesterday as market participants focused on changes in the dollar and overnight interest rates while waiting for tomorrow's Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker.


CONCERT: JENS NYGARD
LEAD: JENS NYGAARD has developed a real following for his chamber-orchestra concerts at Alice Tully Hall with the Jupiter Symphony, and after attending Monday's string-orchestra program, one can understand why.
Not everything was perfect, but all of it was seriously intended, and the best was positively buoyant.


BIG BRITISH RETAILER TO ACQUIRE CYCLOPS
LEAD: Dixons Group P.L.C., Britain's largest electrical-equipment retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Cyclops Corporation, the Pittsburgh-based steel-products maker and specialty retailer, for $384 million in cash.


A Tax Dispute Stalls the Japanese Parliament
LEAD: Growing opposition to a plan to overhaul Japan's tax system has brought Parliament to a standstill and threatens to weaken the political strength of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.


SPACE CENTER COMEBACK SEEN
LEAD: The director of the Kennedy Space Center said today that by the end of 1987 the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and its contractors would have refilled all 2,000 center jobs lost as a result of the space shuttle Challenger's explosion.


ENNO W. ERCKLENTZ
LEAD: Enno W. Ercklentz, a retired banker and industrialist, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Louisiana-Pacific
LEAD: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation said that its accounting firm, Arthur Andersen &amp; Company, would qualify its opinion on the Portland, Ore.-based forest-products company's financial statements.
The company said the move is a result of the high number of asbestos-related claims affecting the Fibreboard Corporation, a subsidiary.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1987
LEAD:  International A3-12, B24


Trudeau Trial Set
LEAD: Jack Trudeau, the starting quarterback for the Indianapolis Colts, is to go on trial April 2 on charges of disorderly conduct and battery on a police officer arising from a fight outside an Indianapolis bar.
Trudeau, 24, and a friend, Joseph C. Venkus, 25, were arrested early last Friday.
After they pleaded not guilty, Trudeau was released on his recognizance, and Venkus, a law student, was freed on $500 bond.


MORE POLICE ADDED TO WASHINGTON SQ.
LEAD: More police officers, including some on scooters and others with dogs trained to sniff out drugs, have been assigned to patrol the Washington Square Park area in Greenwich Village in a stepped-up effort to control drug sales there, police officials said yesterday.

HOUSTON'S INNOVATIVE SOLUTION TO A PRESSING SEWER PROBLEM
LEAD: FEW people have much idea what happens to their sewage, but Houstonians know all too well.
Every time it storms in this flat, low-lying city, the inadequate sewers back up, the streets flood, the bayous overflow.
Building has been stunted in many parts of town because the city has had to impose a limit to the number of taps entering each sewer line; developers trade their ''toilet rights.

LEAD: Several companies whose stock was reportedly traded by Wall Street insiders said yesterday that they were only just beginning to consider their legal options.


The Deficit Still Drives the Dollar
LEAD: Treasury Secretary Baker demonstrates extraordinary skill as a diplomat and as a politician with his campaign to persuade Japan and West Germany to stimulate their economies.
By threatening to let the dollar fall unless he gets his way, he undercuts protectionist pressures at home and simultaneously reminds the allies of their dependence on American markets.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article on Saturday about cable television's presentation of a sampling of Soviet television programs and a column in the Arts and Leisure section Sunday commenting on the programs misstated the process by which some American universities obtain the broadcasts.
The Orbita Technologies Corporation developed and sells the equipment to receive broadcasts from Soviet television satellites.


NOMINEE FOR C.I.A. SAYS AGENCY ERRED ON IRAN ARMS DEAL
LEAD: Robert M. Gates told a Senate committee today that the Central Intelligence Agency had actively avoided gathering information about how the Nicaraguan rebels were raising money.


CITY AGREES ON HOUSING IN THE BRONX
LEAD: The Koch administration and a coalition of the city's leading developers said yesterday that they had reached agreement on a plan to build 1,015 new condominium apartments for middle-income New Yorkers in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx.


Festival of New Plays From Africa to Open
LEAD: The Ubu Repertory Theater, a company founded in 1982 to acquaint Americans with new French theater works in English translation, opens its festival of new plays from French-speaking Africa today with ''The Daughter of the Gods,'' a tale written by the Senegalese playwright Abdou Anta Ka and based on an African folk legend.


LAW FIRMS ACTIVELY LEASING OFFICE SPACE IN MIDTOWN
LEAD: Law firms took more office space in midtown Manhattan last year than any other category of tenant, nearly tripling their demand over the previous year, according to a new study of 1986 leasing activity.


CUOMO APPLAUDED FOR DETAILED COMMENTS ON POLICY ISSUES
LEAD: Governor Cuomo of New York won generally favorable reaction today for his most detailed policy comments yet on issues from a defense against missiles to foreign trade.


Boy, Seeking Liver, to Be Tested
LEAD: Ronnie DeSillers waving to classmates yesterday at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., as he was put aboard an air ambulance for flight to Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh.
The 7-year-old boy's plight attracted national attention, including a telephone call and a donation from President Reagan, after money collected for his medical bills was stolen.


TWO MORE MEN SEIZED IN 'PIZZA' CASE SHOOTING
LEAD: Two more suspects in the shooting of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial on a Greenwich Village street were arrested yesterday, bringing to five the number of men held in what authorities say was an attempted murder for hire at a price of $40,000.


THEATER: 2 VIVID PORTRAITS OF BOOKER T. WASHINGTON
LEAD: HE was a consummate politician who denied ever being political.
He was also a brilliant orator who publicly stood for a saintly humanism while secretly pulling strings to undermine radical opponents with whom he emotionally sympathized.
Those are the complex, double-edged portraits of Booker T. Washington presented by two gripping new plays that have recently opened in celebration of Black History

LEAD: The chairman of the National Governors' Association said today that President Reagan's plan for revising the welfare system was inadequate.
He said the nation should instead look to a plan being formulated by the governors that would immediately require a large number of those on the welfare to go to work.

LEAD: A 45-year-old Brooklyn man was found stabbed to death last night in his ransacked apartment in the Bensonhurst section, the police said.

LEAD: James Broad of the United States reportedly is refusing to fight Gerrie Coetzee of South Africa, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, in Pretoria because of a Pretoria high school's decision to bar a black youth from a track meet.
The fight, billed as crucial to Coetzee's hopes of a comeback, was scheduled for March 21.

MUSIC: AT TOWN HALL, PHILHARMONIA VIRTUOSI
LEAD: ALTHOUGH Rodrigo's ''Concierto de Aranjuez'' stands as one of the most popular works in the history of the phonograph, the classic guitar is an instrument easily bruised when it comes into contact with a live orchestra.
Its peculiarly seductive sound, at once intimate and distant, tends to lose its power to enchant when thrown into competition with heavier voiced instruments.

BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1987
LEAD: MARKETS  Stock prices soared to further records as Wall Street chose to ignore the latest insider-trading scandal and concentrated instead on positive economic signals.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,237.49, after rising 54.14 points, its largest one-day climb ever.
Trading was a brisk 187.8 million shares, as the market got a push when word spread throughout Wall Street that Robert Prechter was predicting that the Dow would advance to the 2,300 level before any correction.

LEAD: The three-story row house could be the pride of its blue-collar Brooklyn neighborhood.
The freshly painted facade suggests the home of hard- working families.


Theus Extends Pact
LEAD: Reggie Theus, the nine-year pro out of Nevada-Las Vegas, has signed a three-year contract extension with an option on a fourth year with the Sacramento Kings.
Including the fourth year, the contract is valued at $750,000 a year, according to team officials. ''I'm just happy we got it done,'' Theus said about the pact signed last Sunday night in Chicago after eight months of negotiations.


Hambrecht Aide Plans Expansion
LEAD: As head of his own small investment banking company, John A. Fisher was the architect of many of the mergers and acquisitions of California's premium wineries.
His deals included the purchases of Ridge Vineyard Inc. and Chateau St.
Jean by Japan's Otsuka Pharmaceutical Ltd. and Suntory Ltd., respectively.

Dyer said.

In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, American Can said that it had purchased the Lomas shares as an investment.

AN ALBUM OF HTE DOOMED: THE ART OF AUSCHWITZ
LEAD: Compared with the volumes of reminiscence and commentary that have been written about Auschwitz, the drawings, paintings and graffiti daubed and scratched on the walls of the death camp by its inmates are enigmatic and incomplete.
And yet these marks, which an American photographer has systematically searched out and recorded, are among the few enduring expressions that prisoners and victims left of their suffering.

LEAD: IT wasn't easy for the 6-year-old boy to tell his mother that her stepbrother was abusing him physically and sexually.
It was even harder when she told him to stop telling lies.
Only when the boy eventually told a teacher, who intervened, did the mother take her son seriously and force the stepbrother to move out.

LEAD: In an effort to demonstrate broad-based support that has yet to appear in the public opinion polls, Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York today announced the formation of a Presidential steering committee.
It is composed of 800 prominent Republican elected officials, state party workers, conservative activists, sports figures and executives of major corporations.

LEAD: Rush-hour service on PATH trains to Hoboken, N.J., and Jersey City was halted for more than an hour yesterday afternoon when third-rail insulation caught fire under the Avenue of the Americas, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

LEAD: Billy Donovan had 23 points, 10 assists and 5 crucial free throws over the final 25 seconds as Providence beat Seton Hall, 91-87, tonight in a Big East Conference game.
But just as impressively, Donovan played the last 10 minutes with a bloody nose.

LEAD: YOU are not likely to be seeing the Museum of Broadcasting's current tribute to Ingmar Bergman on your television screen anytime soon, but the exhibition is significant as a reminder to viewers that television quality need not be limited to a schedule monopolized by sitcoms, action-adventures and mini-series.


Apartheid Pullout By Kentucky Fried
LEAD: The Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation said that it was joining a growing number of American companies leaving South Africa because of apartheid.
The fast-food chain, a subsidiary of RJR Nabisco Inc., said that it would withdraw its assets, although no date was given for departure.

LEAD: Pressed to take a stand on an issue that has touched off heated debate in legal circles nationwide, the American Bar Association today proposed a relatively modest set of changes in the system of recovering damages for personal injuries.

The six were charged yesterday in a civil complaint.

Heck's Cutbacks
LEAD: Heck's Inc., a discount store chain, said that it would close 29 of its 158 stores, cut its headquarters staff and eliminate stock dividends in an attempt to stem its losses.
Heck's said that the cutbacks would save it more than $4 million.
The retailer has not reported an annual profit since 1983.

In the West's Interest
LEAD: Hard-line American observers of the Soviet Union for years have insisted, with much evidence on their side, that the heirs of Lenin presided over an inherently expansionist nation but a failing society -economically unworkable, bureaucratically paralyzed, viciously repressive, so rigidly and fearfully controlled by a small elite that its people could develop nothing like the skills and initiative to compete in the modern world.


Interpublic Net Up
LEAD: The Interpublic Group of Companies released its fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, which showed that revenues were up 16.5 percent, to $240.4 million, from $206.4 million in the 1985 period.
Net income came to $14.6 million, or 67 cents a share, up 2.8 percent from $14.2 million, or 65 cents a share, a year ago.


46 DEAD, 111 HURT AS 2 TRAINS COLLIDE IN SAO PAULO SUBURB
LEAD: Two crowded commuter trains collided on the outskirts of Sao Paulo today, and officials said 46 people were killed and more than 100 injured.


Energy Dept. Rejects Rallies At Nevada Nuclear Test Site
LEAD: Because of growing incidents of civil disobedience, antinuclear protesters will no longer be allowed to demonstrate on a section of the Nevada Test Site, the Energy Department announced today.


NEWEST SOVIET REVELATION: A CASE OF POLICE BRUTALITY
LEAD: The police in a North Russian city tortured suspects by beating and slow suffocation to extract false confessions, according to a Soviet magazine this week.


EXPRESS GRINDS TO HALT AS SOCCER TEAM FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
LEAD: The Major Indoor Soccer League suffered another setback in the metropolitan area yesterday when the New York Express filed for bankruptcy under Chapter XI.


CONRAIL REGISTRATION IS FILED WITH S.E.C.
LEAD: The Consolidated Rail Corporation, in a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commisssion, indicated yesterday that it expected to raise between $1.29 billion and $1.52 billion in the public sale of the Government's 85 percent interest in the railroad.

LEAD: ONE of the most heartening advances in American taste within recent years has been the acceptance of certain fish long associated with particular cultures, such as Italian, French and Greek.

LEAD: The Israeli police, in an unusual action against Jewish critics of the Government's human-rights record, have closed the offices of a Jerusalem information agency sympathetic to Palestinians and arrested four workers.

LEAD: The first preview for ''Starlight Express,'' the new musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Richard Stilgoe, has again been postponed, from this Thursday until Tuesday, Feb. 24, according to a spokesman for the show, Bill Evans.

Dressing Up a Cucumber
LEAD: IN the sparse months of winter, cooks must often make do with vegetables that are limited in variety and quality.
Winter tomatoes, for example, which are shipped unripened thousands of miles, are usually too pallid to add to green salads.
Cucumbers may not be at their peak of flavor in February, but to my taste they are preferable.


For the Records
LEAD: Monday night was one for the books in women's basketball.
Or three for the books, actually.
In San Jose, Calif., Cindy Brown of Long Beach State, a 6-foot-2-inch senior forward, scored 60 points in a 149-69 rout of San Jose State, a game in which two N.C.A.A. women's records were eclipsed: most points by a player (58, by Lorri Bauman of Drake three years ago) and by a team (139, by Grambling against Jarvis


EXPORT THRUST A REAGAN GOAL
LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would travel around the nation in the weeks and months ahead to promote a legislative program aimed at making America more competitive in the world marketplace.


YANKEE STAR A BIG WINNER
LEAD: Don Mattingly won his salary arbitration case and will earn $1,975,000 this season.
Page D29. (NYT/Joe Traver)
