NUTRITIONISTS TAKE AIM
LEAD: DESPITE its near-mythic status, milk is a food to be evaluated in the diet like any other, experts say.
Is the richness of whole milk worth the extra 8 grams of fat (72 calories) per cup, compared with skim milk's 0.4 grams of fat?
Is milk, or its products, responsible for widespread, unexplained gastric discomfort?


LEADER'S RESIGNATION IS DESCRIBED AS PART OF U.S. CAMPAIGN TO SHORE UP REBEL CAUSE
LEAD: A contra leader's resignation from a top political position Monday was part of an effort promoted by the Reagan Administration to overcome Congressional doubts and address the movement's continued failings, according to American officials and leading contras.


WEST BEIRUT FIGHT KILLS AT LEAST 24
LEAD: Shiite Moslem militiamen fought an alliance of Druse and Communist gunmen for a third day today in the fiercest factional fighting in West Beirut in three years.


500 Blacks Boycott Schools
LEAD: About 500 black students stayed home today to protest the school board's failure to name a black as assistant school superintendent, boycott leaders said.
The 1,650-student school system is 34 percent black, and protest leaders said 95 percent of the black students stayed home.
The Rev.
Michael Cathey, a spokesman for a group of black parents, said the school board had ''renegged'' on a promise to appoint a black as assistant superintendent.


JURORS SELECTED FOR TUROFF TRIAL IN A FRAUD CASE
LEAD: Three present and former city officials were listed as possible witnesses yesterday as jurors were selected in the trial of Jay L. Turoff, the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission who is accused of participating in a bribery scheme.


Queens Fire Kills Mother and Child
LEAD: A fire that may have started in a clothes dryer enveloped a house in smoke yesterday, killing a Queens woman and her 18-month-old daughter.

Caterpillar Plans To Close Plant
LEAD: Caterpillar Inc., a leading manufacturer of construction equipment, said that it would close a plant in Davenport, idling 1,393 hourly and salaried workers.
The Peoria, Ill., company had said last month that it might close the plant.


Children's Museum to Grow
LEAD: A planetarium and a four-level addition will be part of a $14 million expansion plan for the Children's Museum here, museum officials announced Monday.
The expansion will add 78,000 square feet of exhibition, office and storage space to the 228,000-square-foot building.

LEAD: Maj.
Gen.
John K. Singlaub, a retired United States Army officer who has played a major role in advising and raising money for the Nicaraguan rebels, is now spending much of his time on what he describes as a treasure hunt in the Philippines.

P.L.O. IS BOLSTERED BY KUWAITI MONEY
LEAD: A new influx of Arab money will bolster the Palestine Liberation Organization's political base in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, in a move seen here as undercutting King Hussein of Jordan.

Southern Storm Followed by Bitter Cold and Sleet
LEAD: In the wake of a storm Monday that led to at least 17 deaths, Vernon Lloyd carried hay past ice-coated trees to the cattle on his farm in Jacksonville, N.C.
A new storm yesterday produced sleet and snow in the South, closing schools in 10 states, while in New York State, temperatures dropped to 18 degrees below zero in the Adirondack region.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD:  ORAL HISTORY


HARVARD HOCKEY: AMONG THE ELITE
LEAD: As an 18-year-old prep school senior, Chris Biotti was the first draft choice of the Calgary Flames in 1985.
Two seasons later Biotti is not out in the provinces learning the hockey trade with a minor league team, he is at Harvard.


Baker International
LEAD: Baker International Inc. said it had agreed to sell the domestic operations of its electrical submersible pump division to Trico Industries for an undisclosed amount.
The sale of the unit would move Baker a step closer to completing its previously announced plan to merge with the Hughes Tool Company.


Becor Western To Go Private
LEAD: Becor Western Inc., a Milwaukee-based mining equipment manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to be taken private in a $238 million leveraged buyout following the sale of its aerospace unit to Lucas Industries.


A SMALLER COMPUTER INTRODUCED BY COMPAQ
LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation introduced a high-powered portable computer yesterday that is smaller and lighter than the company's earlier models.


Billboard Industry's Campaign
LEAD: IN recent years, the billboard industry has been inching through difficult days of the kind unknown since its business boomed after cigarettes were forced off TV in the early 1970's.
In response, the Outdoor Network USA, advertising representatives for 36 operators whose billboards are visible to about 85 percent of the nation's population, is beginning its own trade advertising campaign next Monday to stimulate interest in the national advertising marketplace.


For Free Elections in Pakistan
LEAD: A state of anarchy is developing in Pakistan.
Its consequences should be cause for alarm to Congress and to the American people.


Man Held in Burglary Is Tied to 22 Holdups
LEAD: A man arrested Monday and charged with the burglary of a hotel room in Greenwich Village was wanted for 22 bank holdups in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn, the police reported last night.


U.S. OVERTURNS SCORING FOR FEMALE FIREFIGHTERS
LEAD: A court-ordered scoring system intended to increase the number of female firefighters in New York City was overturned yesterday by a Federal appeals court.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Agency people, and I would say here from the Director on down, actively shunned information.
We didn't want to know how the contras were being funded, in part, because we were concerned it would get us involved in crossing the line imposed by the law.
And so we actively discouraged people from telling us things.


THE POP LIFE
LEAD: IT'S only February, but one of the year's most important jazz albums has just been released: the alto saxophonist-composer Tim Berne's ''Fulton Street Maul.'' The album is a major event both for Mr.
Berne's music - which is by turns wild and woolly, intimate and thoughtful, in about equal proportions - and for the fact that it has been released by Columbia Records, a major label that rarely issues such uncompromising music.


Market Place; Fund Diversity In Managers
LEAD: MOST money managers believe in diversifying their investments, but George F. Keane, president of the Common Fund, which oversees $2.1 billion in endowment assets, carries that principle one step further.
He believes in a diversified portfolio of managers.


PRODUCTION RETURNING TO U.S.
LEAD: Armed with new technology and eager to shorten supply lines, some American manufacturers have started to bring overseas operations home or switch from foreign to domestic suppliers.
The homeward move has been augmented by the fall of the dollar against foreign currencies, notably the Japanese yen.


RJR Nabisco Study Of Tobacco Spinoff
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc., a major food and tobacco company, confirmed that it was studying the possible spinoff of its tobacco business into a limited partnership.
The company had denied Wall Street speculation last month that it might get out of the tobacco business, which has stagnated because of health concerns.


20 May Be Indicted In Wedtech Inquiry
LEAD: The Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, said yesterday that a bribery and corruption investigaton into the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, may eventually lead to as many as 20 indictments.


DMITRI KABALEVSKY, RUSSIAN WHO COMPOSED 'COMEDIANS'
LEAD: Dmitri Kabalevsky, a Soviet composer best known for his suite ''The Comedians'' and the Overture to his opera ''Colas Breugnon,'' has died at the age of 82, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, said yesterday.
Tass provided no details of Mr.
Kabalevsky's death but said that leaders of the Soviet Government and the Communist Party had signed an obituary describing him as ''innovative and brilliant.


SOVIET OFFERS TO ALLOW CHEMICAL-ARMS INSPECTIONS
LEAD: The Soviet Union said today that it would allow on-site, international inspection of its chemical weapons stockpiles.
The Soviet move was made during the longstanding negotiations on a ban on chemical weapons at the 40-nation Geneva Conference on Disarmament.

Cattle Prices Advance While Coffee Declines
LEAD: Cattle futures prices advanced yesterday as meatpackers entered the market aggressively.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Mike Boddicker of the Orioles and Gene Nelson of the A's, pitchers awaiting arbitration, reached agreement with their clubs. . . .
Brian Tribble, who is awaiting trial on drug charges stemming from Len Bias's death last June, is wanted by the police in Hyattsville, Md., on charges of reckless driving, and fleeing and eluding a police officer in connection with a chase in Maryland yesterday.


16 LAROUCHE AIDES INDICTED FOR FRAUD
LEAD: A Virginia grand jury today indicted 16 followers of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the conspiracy theorist, on securities fraud and other felony charges.


Ex-State Senator Disbarred After Tax-Fraud Conviction
LEAD: Former State Senator Joseph R. Pisani, who served seven months in a Federal prison for tax evasion, was disbarred yesterday after the state Appellate Division found him guilty of professional misconduct.


WARD, CITING SUSPECT'S DEATH, ISSUES BAN AGAINST HOGTYING
LEAD: Five days after the death in police custody of a burglary suspect whose shackled hands and feet were trussed behind his back, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward issued an order yesterday banning the practice.


Our Greedy Colleges
LEAD: Many of our colleges are at it again.
As they have done annually for the past six years, they have begun to unveil tuition increases that far outstrip the inflation rate.
Next year, tuition is expected to rise 6 percent to 8 percent - even though inflation during 1986 was about 1.8 percent.

POLAROID AND KODAK POST PROFITS
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Polaroid Corporation, the two leading American photography companies, today reported improved results for the fourth quarter of 1986 and for the year.


IS NOTHING SACRED? MILK'S AMERICAN APPEAL FADES
LEAD: FOLLOWING are types of milk that are available commercially.
Unless otherwise noted, the definitions are from the National Dairy Council.


SHULTZ AND SHAMIR DISAGREE OVER PARLEY
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz clashed today with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel over whether an international conference, possibly including the Soviet Union as a participant, should even be considered as a vehicle for starting peace negotiations in the Middle East.


STOCK RECORDS SET IN FACE OF SCANDAL
LEAD: Stock prices soared to another record yesterday as Wall Street shrugged off the anxiety generated by its latest insider-trading scandal.


OWNER: DEVILS ARE NOT MOVING
LEAD: Despite a continuous decline in attendance and losses of $8.5 million since moving to New Jersey for the 1982-83 season, John McMullen, the owner of the Devils, said today the franchise had no plans for leaving New Jersey.


THE NEW STYLE IS FIZZY
LEAD: THEIR penchant for sweet carbonated beverages gave rise to scores of soft drinks and to fruit-flavored, low-alcohol wine coolers.
In the next year or so, baby boomers may have a new drink designed with their taste preferences and health conerns in mind: carbonated milk in an array of flavors - strawberry, orange, coconut, pina colada, mint, cola, even rum.

A 'BUG' GOES TO THE AID OF PLANTS
LEAD: RESEARCHERS reported last weekend that they had successfully used a novel biotechnological approach to increase the tolerance of plants to insects, viruses and herbicides.
The advances have potential application in commercial agriculture.


ADVANCED CHIP FOR I.B.M. UNIT
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation today became the first personal computer maker to put the vanguard one-megabit memory chip in one of its desktop machines - a precursor of some major technological changes expected in the computer giant's products.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A diagram in Science Times yesterday with an article on osteoporosis carried two misplaced labels.
It is osteoclasts that play a role in normal bone breakdown; osteoblasts are involved in the rebuilding of bone.


Salomon Official To Try Real Estate
LEAD: Raymond L. Golden has left his job as chief financial officer at Salomon Brothers Inc. to join the Trammell Crow Company, the big real estate company based in Dallas.


Dept. of Ties and Tails
LEAD: When some small-town politicians get elected to the United States Senate, they feel compelled to try to move up to a new social echelon and dress accordingly.
But not Warren B. Rudman of Nashua, N.H.
When a columnist invited Senator Rudman the other day to the March dinner of the Gridiron Club, he declined - solely, he said, because he would have been required to don white tie and tails for the occasion.


L.I.R.R. AND SIGNALMEN REACH TENTATIVE PACT
LEAD: The Long Island Rail Road and the Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen reached agreement yesterday on a tentative contract, leaving only a coalition of four craft unions without a contract accord.


MANY TOP LEADERS SHIFTED IN VIETNAM
LEAD: Vietnam reorganized its Government today, replacing the Interior and Defense Ministers along with at least a dozen other officials, according to the Hanoi radio.


NEW YORK'S HIGH COURT UPHOLDS CITY LAW BARRING CLUBS' SEX BIAS
LEAD: The state's highest court today unanimously upheld a New York City law that could force several of the city's most prestigious all-male clubs to admit women.

MATTINGLY WINS $1.975 MILLION IN ARBITRATION
LEAD: Don Mattingly, who had been prepared to accept a negotiated two-year contract for $3.85 million, learned yesterday that he is more than halfway to that total.
He won his salary arbitration case against the Yankees with a $1,975,000 salary, the largest ever gained in the 12-year history of arbitration and the largest ever earned by a player in the 85-year history of the


Power Agency Sets Refunding
LEAD: The M-S-R Public Power Agency of California, which services Modesto, Santa Clara, and Reading, is tentatively offering $271 million of refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 6.91 percent for bonds due in 2019 through underwriters led by E.F.
Hutton &amp; Company.


AMID PROTEST, BUMPURS CASE NEARS ITS END
LEAD: Summations in the six-week manslaughter trial in the Eleanor Bumpurs case were completed yesterday in a noisy session interrupted by a 25-minute demonstration in a packed courtroom in the Bronx.


Parachutist Is Arrested
LEAD: A California man was arrested after he parachuted from a small plane to a landfill near the World Trade Center yesterday, the police said.
The man, John Carta, 41 years old, of Sacramento, jumped ''apparently because he's not jumped in New York before,'' a police spokesman, Officer James Coleman, said.


We Can't Afford the Health Plan
LEAD: The American family has a dilemma.
Our grandparents face the possibility of catastrophic illness, and we are asked to help pay for care that we cannot afford.

Bond Reduced for Two In Child Neglect Case
LEAD: A judge reduced bond from $100,000 to $20,000 today for two men held for two weeks on charges of child neglect after being found in a city playground with six children.

LEAD: The J.C.
Penney Company said yesterday that it would start a home-shopping television service this summer in Chicago at a start-up cost of $40 million.

Islands Without Fear
LEAD: This column is about a large bunch of wonderfully hideous marine iguanas, some herds of sea lions, a few penguins and how meeting them gave me the most unexpected and exhilarating sensation in decades of travel.
Even if you do not particularly care for animals do read on because psychic and social significance are lurking lower down.

Civil Remedy
LEAD: It's not unusual for corporations to correct dangerous practices because they fear civil damage suits.
The risk of multimillion-dollar judgments attracts their attention in ways that even criminal charges against individual officers might not.
What is unusual is for such a judgment to be rendered against a corporation called the United Klans of America - and for it to come from an all-white jury in


Service America
LEAD: The Allegheny Beverage Corporation said it had canceled its plan to spin off the Service America Corporation to shareholders because of recent disappointing results.
It said it would seek to improve the food-service operations and increase earnings.


CITY SEEKS TO CANCEL CONTRACT FOR BUS-STOP SHELTERS
LEAD: New York City's Bureau of Franchises, citing nonperformance, has moved to impose $3.3 million in penalties and cancel the contract with the company that builds and installs bus-stop shelters.

LEAD: Workers closing off Manhattan-bound lanes on the upper roadway as preparations began for a $42 million reconstruction project.

LEAD: THE Fresk Quartet, which hails from Sweden, is best known in the United States for its recording of the complete string quartets of Wilhelm Stenhammar.

STUDY OF 50 BREAK-INS SHOWS NO CLEAR PLOT ON POLICY CRITICS
LEAD: On July 19, 1983, in Oakland, Calif., someone broke into the office of the Guatemala News and Information Bureau, a center for research on human rights and other issues in Guatemala.
The burglar smashed a window to gain entry, rummaged through a filing cabinet and drawers and scattered papers.
No valuables other than petty cash were taken.

Koch Seeks Extension of Clean Air Deadline
LEAD: Mayor Koch meeting yesterday with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in the Senator's Washington office.
The Mayor urged Mr.
Moynihan and other members of Congress to extend the Clean Air Act deadline, saying that New York City ''couldn't possibly live with'' the economic sanctions that would result if it fails to meet the air-quality standards for ozone and carbon monoxide.

DOMINGO TO SING IN 'AIDA' AT LUXOR
LEAD: Placido Domingo is to sing Radames in a production here of ''Aida'' at the 3,500-year-old Pharaonic temple, the structure that Giuseppe Verdi had in mind when he wrote the opera about doomed lovers in 1869.


A NEWS CHAIN'S FAMILY FIGHT
LEAD: Freedom Newspapers Inc., the nation's 14th-largest chain by circulation, was born of dissension.
R.
C.
Hoiles, a scrappy newsman from Ohio, founded Freedom in the early 1930's, a few years after a quarrel with a brother led him to break up their small newspaper partnership and strike out on his own.


Surgery for Dawkins
LEAD: Darryl Dawkins, the Nets center, underwent surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday to correct back problems that have sidelined him for all but six games this season.
Dawkins underwent microsurgery on his back last May to repair nerve damage. ''We're hopeful the operation was successful and Darryl can play again,'' said Coach Dave Wohl in a statement.

LEAD: SHE is still surprised that she got the job.


Peru Cannot Pay I.M.F.
LEAD: Peru has told the International Monetary Fund that it will not be able to pay $252 million in past-due obligations to the lending agency, a finance official said today.
He said that depressed prices for Peru's leading exports prevented it from meeting the payments on its $782 million debt.

Bush Names New Press Aide
LEAD: Vice President Bush named a new press secretary Tuesday.
He is Larry Thomas, a former political writer for The San Diego Union who has been spokesman for Gov.
George Deukmejian of California since 1982.
Mr.
Thomas, who is 39 years old, succeeds Marlin Fitzwater, who replaced Larry Speakes earlier this month as the chief White House spokesman.

LEAD: IT would be easy to hang shelves, cabinets, large mirrors or other heavy objects on a hollow interior wall if you could always place the objects directly over vertical studs inside the wall - that way, you could just drive in nails or screws long enough to go through the plaster or dry wall and into the stud.

LEAD: The two major political parties today announced the creation of a bipartisan commission to sponsor Presidential debates in the 1988 general election campaign.


BAIL IS DENIED 2 IN SHOOTING IN 'PIZZA CONNECTION' CASE
LEAD: Two suspects were held without bail yesterday on Federal murder-for-hire charges involving the shooting of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial.


Chief Justice Who?
LEAD: Opening his speech to the American Bar Association convention in New Orleans the other day, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said he had just seen a public opinion survey, conducted for the Hearst Corporation, showing that his name had been designated by 43 percent of those asked to identify the current Chief Justice of the United States from a list of four names.


EX-POLICE DIVISION HEAD CLEARED ON TIES TO MOB
LEAD: The former head of the New York Police Department's Intelligence Division has been been cleared in an internal inquiry of any wrongdoing concerning his relationship with a man linked to organized crime, department officials said yesterday.


The Next Librarian?
LEAD: Jaroslav Pelikan, Sterling Professor of History at Yale University, has emerged as one of the leading candidates to succeed Daniel J. Boorstin as Librarian of Congress.


REPORT PREDICTS GREAT LAKES COULD RECEDE IN 6 TO 10 YEARS
LEAD: The rain-swollen Great Lakes, responsible for extensive shore and property damage, could take 6 to 10 years to recede to their average levels with normal rainfall during that time, a study says.

The Happiest Laker
LEAD: The standard practice among professional sports teams is to administer a thorough physical to any player obtained in a trade.
Any unexpected problem, such as a weak knee or perhaps a previously undetected back ailment, usually voids the transaction.
No questions asked.

LEAD: A move to lift remaining economic sanctions against Poland, expected to be announced by the White House Thursday, is part of a plan to improve relationships gradually with countries of Eastern Europe and to lessen their dependence on the Soviet Union, a top State Department official said today.

But in the midst of this teeming competition, the Sylvan Wind Quintet has distinguished itself for its venturesomeness of programming and stylishness of performance.

PONDERING BEETHOVEN'S METRONOME
LEAD: IN Beethoven's later years, the metronome was becoming recognized as a valuable tool for a composer to indicate preferred tempos.
Deaf and ill-tempered, complaining about the trouble it took, Beethoven nonetheless worked away at the task of supplying his publishers with tempo indications not only for the music he was composing, but also for scores he had already composed.

A LOOK AT BLAIR HOUSE IN MID-RESTORATION
LEAD: When the draperies were removed five years ago from the windows of Blair House, the President's guest house for visiting heads of state, they disintegrated.

THE STAGE: 'KVETCH,' STEVEN BERKOFF COMEDY
LEAD: ''KVETCH,'' as in the title of Steven Berkoff's new comedy, is a complaint, which, if allowed to fester, can become an anxiety attack.
As the play begins (at the Westside Arts Theater), we hear Mr.
Berkoff's voice offstage, intoning an introduction to his tale of comic woe.
As an actor, the playwright specializes in villainy, and his doom-filled narration starts the evening on a properly prophetic note.

How the President Can Fight Terror
LEAD: Faced with the problem of extortion by terrorists, and understanding the principle that rewarding an act encourages its repetition, Western leaders energetically endorse the rule that there must be no negotiations for hostages.
Yet when hostages are taken, they routinely become exceptions to that rule, and Western leaders routinely find themselves willing - no, rushing - to negotiate.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo today called for an end to the longstanding system of ''member item'' appropriations, a practice that has allowed lawmakers to allocate millions of dollars to special projects in their districts outside normal state procedures.

LEAD: The board of Dome Petroleum Ltd. has approved in principle the company's plan to reschedule $6.1 billion in debt, a company spokesman said.

Lucky to Sell Chain
LEAD: Lucky Stores Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Yellow Front Stores subsidiary for about $50 million to a corporation owned by Kenmare, a private company controlled by Daniel J. Sullivan.
Yellow Front, based in Phoenix, operates 104 general merchandise stores in eight Rocky Mountain states.
The sale is the latest of several divestitures by Lucky, a grocery chain based in Dublin, Calif., which is restructuring in an attempt to avoid a takeover by the New York investor Asher B.


Big Board Tightening Standards
LEAD: In Wall Street's first institutional reaction to the shadow cast by the insider trading scandal, the New York Stock Exchange sent a special bulletin to its member firms yesterday requiring them to tighten procedures to insure that securities laws are not being violated.


REPORT FAULTS PENTAGON ON POLYGRAPH TEST PROJECT
LEAD: A pilot program in which the Department of Defense has been using polygraphs to screen applicants for sensitive security clearance has been conducted in a way that makes it impossible to judge the validity of the testing to detect lies, according to a draft report requested by Congress.

Topics: Legal Restraints; Bound by the Law
LEAD: Hogtying is regularly practiced on farms, ranches and in slaughterhouses to weigh, butcher and otherwise restrain four-legged creatures.
A variant is irregularly practiced by the Mafia: a thick cord is wrapped around the victim's throat and then fastened to his hands and feet, which are bound behind his back.

LEAD: Robert M. Gates appeared today to be headed for Senate confirmation as Director of Central Intelligence after more than nine hours of hearings that underscored the depth of Congressional unhappiness with the Reagan Administration's Iran dealings.

LEAD: The General Electric Company is going modern by taking some curlicues out of its famous symbol and shortening its name to G.E. in its dealings with the public.

LEAD: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that he would present credit union records - thought to have been destroyed - to prove that Jay L. Turoff, the former head of the New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, had betrayed his office by participating in a bribery conspiracy.


A Nomination in Peril
LEAD: In six years in office, President Reagan has been able to appoint many conservatives to Federal judgeships, enjoying the Republicans' control of the Senate, which passes on such nominations.
But now that the Democrats have regained the majority in the Senate, they have served notice on the White House that nominations for judgeships will be subjected to the closest scrutiny, and one may already be headed for some trouble.

MENTAL SOUVENIRS ROM THE FAR EAST
LEAD: A GOOD gardener, like all creative folk, is perpetually on the scrounge: for seeds, yes, and cuttings and new ways to beat the greenfly, but also for ideas.
A gardener travels with his own garden in the back of his mind, subliminally sorting all the plants he possesses, ever ready to borrow a detail here, a plant combination there, to be incorporated into the patchwork back home.


JAPAN ASKS 10% CUT IN CHIP OUTPUT
LEAD: In an attempt to control mounting friction over semiconductor trade, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry has asked Japanese semiconductor makers to cut production of some computer memory chips by 10 percent in the first three months of this year.

Boyd Loses Pay Bid
LEAD: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd lost his salary arbitration case and will receive $550,000 this season, the Boston Red Sox announced.
The 27-year-old right-hander, who had a career-high 16 victories last season against 10 losses with a 3.78 earned run average, was seeking $695,000.
Boyd earned $375,000 in 1986 in helping Boston win its first pennant since 1975.


THE GLOW OF WOOD PANELING: DESIGNERS EXPLORE ITS VARIED USES
LEAD: AS with fine wines, there is a culture and vocabulary that surround fine woods -for centuries, gentlemen who wanted to panel their homes and clubs sent to the ends of the earth for burled woods, fiddleback veneers and choice cuts centered on heartwood, the core of a tree.

LEAD: The General Services Administration today unveiled a collection of 15 posters that depict Depression-era and abstract art and are intended to enhance the decor of Federal offices.


CONSULTANT EXPECTED TO BECOME REAGAN AIDE
LEAD: White House officials said today that they expected President Reagan to name a retired official of The Associated Press as the new communications director.


Independent Millsport
LEAD: Millsport, a sports marketing unit that was established within Doyle Dane Bernbach in 1981, has become an independent company.
It made that move by buying itself back from the Omnicom Group, which D.D.B., now DDB Needham Worldwide, helped to form.
James R. Millman remains president and chief executive.


CAMBODIAN-REFUGEE ABUSE REPORTED
LEAD: More than 250,000 Cambodians, many of them survivors of the Khmer Rouge era and victims of an eight-year-old war against the Vietnamese who ousted it, continue to be vulnerable to abuse in refugee camps in Thailand, according to the New York-based Lawyers Committee for Human Rights.

In Moscow: Louder Than Words
LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev has found the way to begin persuading his own people and the West of his sincerity.
He doesn't merely give speeches about peaceful intentions abroad and glasnost - openness - at home.
He frees Russians who have been unjustly imprisoned.
The other day it was the release of Anatoly Koryagin, who blew the whistle on the use of phony psychiatric institutes to punish dissenters.

A Wimpy Winter
LEAD: As New York winters go, this one has been undistinguished, showing no direction and not much will.
The tipoff came in early December when forsythia bushes wishfully started to flower, either with laggard yellow blooms from last spring or impatient blooms for next.
Later in the month some obligatory snow came, and then quickly went, leading some snowdrops to pop up prematurely and then be stiffened by a cold spell.


CONTRA CHIEF ASKS DEADLINE ON CHANGE
LEAD: Arturo Cruz, the contra leader who is engaged in a struggle for control of the anti-Sandinista movement, is expected to set a deadline for major changes Thursday in the American-backed rebel organization, according to several of Mr.
Cruz's aides.

A Russian Sailor Defects
LEAD: A Soviet sailor who told the Swedish police he did not like the Soviet system defected when his ship's crew was allowed ashore for shopping.
A police spokesman said the man was 28 years old and had a wife and 3-year-old son in the Soviet Union.


PLAN FOR LIVE SOVIET TV IN U.S. SHIFTS
LEAD: International legal tangles are altering The Discovery Channel's plans to broadcast more than 60 hours of Soviet television programs live to an American audience each week.
Instead, the channel is relying heavily on tapes of the Soviet programs.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Celtics 113, Mavericks 96: Kevin McHale scored 28 points as Boston snapped a two-game losing streak last night.
Boston, which avoided its first three-game losing streak since 1983, silenced the sellout crowd of 17,007 fans in Reunion Arena early.
The Celtics surged to a 67-46 halftime lead after outscoring the Mavericks by 37-17 in the second period, and they built a 31-point lead midway through the third quarter.


HUMAN ERROR CITED IN RAIL CRASH
LEAD: Human error caused Tuesday evening's crash in the Bronx of two Metro-North Commuter Railroad trains that injured 27 people and delayed throngs of commuters, the railroad's president said yesterday.

Bridge: Responding Styles Changing Among Tournament Players

Pouring Money Into Hollywood
LEAD: THE movie industry is in the doldrums: The number of film releases has increased while ticket sales have remained flat and revenues from ancillary markets such as network television have dwindled.
But that environment has not stopped the producer Jerry Weintraub from creating Hollywood's largest start-up company.


The Next President?
LEAD: The other evening, after a lapse of four or five years, Robert S. Strauss, a former Democratic national chairman, revived his chili party for the Washington press corps at the Madison Hotel.
The host's speech was uncharacteristically brief and nonpolitical, but when one guest asked him informally who would be the next President, he said, ''I wouldn't be surprised if it was Bob Dole.

FAUCETS SAY 'TOO HOT'
LEAD: YOU are standing at the sink, washing the dishes, when your neighbor flushes the toilet, robbing the tap of its cold water and turning it hot.
Before you can jerk your hands from the water, the temperature soars to somewhere near the boiling point, turning your hands fire-engine red.

A.B.A. Picks President-Elect
LEAD: Robert D. Raven, a lawyer from San Francisco, was selected Tuesday to become president of the American Bar Association next year.
Mr.
Raven, a 63-year-old senior partner in the firm of Morrison &amp; Foerster, was named president-elect of the 330,000-lawyer group.
He will succeed Robert MacCrate, a New York lawyer who will take over as the association's president in August.


The Buchanan Aggravation
LEAD: Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House director of communications, has been criticized before, but perhaps never with such passion.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An obituary of Oliver H. Renninger by The Associated Press yesterday described his career incorrectly.
Mr.
Renninger helped assemble the plane involved in 1908 in the first reported modern-day airplane crash, but he was not aboard when the plane crashed.


Office Set to Buy Ads For Cable TV Networks
LEAD: Cable television has reached an important milestone: the establishment of a central advertising buying office for most of the cable networks.


Eurobond Broker Is Planned
LEAD: Fundamental Brokers and M. W. Marshall Brokers, both subsidiaries of the Mercantile House Group, have set up a brokering unit for Eurobonds, financial sources said today.

FAST-FOOD OUTLETS: A NEW PROTOTYPE
LEAD: IN sponsoring a recent student design competition, the McDonald's Corporation has turned to the generation that grew up under the golden arches - the company's logo - for ideas to develop prototypes for its restaurants.
The competition, which was co-sponsored by the American Institute of Architectural Students, called for a ''new, unique concept'' to convey ''a sense of place within the community and display sensitivity to the environment.

LEAD: THE March issue of United Airlines' monthly in-flight magazine will no longer be called United.

Finance Plan For Europe
LEAD: The president of the European Community commission, Jacques Delors, today proposed the most radical changes in the group's financing since it was created 30 years ago.


HIGHCHAIRS COMBINING FUNCTION AND STYLE
LEAD: HANDSOME and functional highchairs are sometimes hard to find.
The most useful are made of materials that are easy to clean and will not absorb the food that a baby inevitably spills.
To be avoided are chairs upholstered in cloying pastels or animal patterns that clash with a room's decor.
A search of stores turned up five highchairs that vary in style from a simple molded plastic bucket seat to an elaborate turn-of-the-century wicker version.

AN ARTIST'S JOURNEY FROM OBSCURITY TO SUCCESS
LEAD: In the fall of 1981, the artist Ross Bleckner showed his newest paintings at the Mary Boone gallery in SoHo.
They were unusual works -mostly paintings of vertical stripes that resembled Op Art - and the show was a flop.
Not a single major critic reviewed the show, and only one of the works sold.

LEAD: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., today announced an elaborate process through which the 13-million-member labor federation would seek a single Presidential candidate to support in the 1988 elections.


TAGGING FISH OFFERS NETFUL OF REWARDS
LEAD: As you are sorting out and refurbishing your saltwater angling gear for the coming season, you might give thought to becoming a tagger of fish.
Last year was the busiest in almost a decade in the American Littoral Society's fish-tagging program, and the organization would like to see an even more active 1987.


An Inner-City Trip On 30's-Style Trains
LEAD: THOSE for whom the words ''Newark'' and ''subway'' summon a vision of urban despair may find a trip on the Newark subway a good way to dispel it.
Unlike that other subway system to the east, which on its good days merely moves people, Newark's anachronism of a line can also transport the spirit.


Shipyard Orders Drop
LEAD: The number of merchant ships on order from shipyards worldwide was 3.6 percent lower at the end of 1986 than it was three months earlier, Lloyd's Register of Shipping said today.
There were 2,168 vessels on order at the end of December, compared with 2,249 at the end of September, the London-based trade publication reported.


Schoolboy Dies Of Heart Failure
LEAD: A 17-year-old high school basketball player who died during a game Tuesday night suffered from heart disease, the state Medical Examiner's office said today.

LEAD: New York City has lost more than $4.5 million in state aid for the maintenance of shelters for the homeless because of failures to correct fire and health code violations, City Councilman Abraham G. Gerges charged yesterday.

LEAD: Walt Michaels, the former coach of the Jets, has reportedly told National Football League officials that he suspects collusion among the 26 owners has prevented him getting another coaching job.
Michaels, who has not coached in the N.F.L. for four years, met Tuesday at the league's offices in New York with Don Weiss, the league's executive director, and Jay Moyer, counsel to Commissioner Pete Rozelle, The New Haven Journal Courier reported.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. Custom storm windows that were installed last year sweat on the inside in cold weather.
Is this normal, or is the installation faulty?
Can I do anything?
A.
Usually this is caused by a lack of adequate weatherstripping on the prime (original) windows.
This lets warm, moist air from inside seep around the sash into the space between the two windows.

Record Ford Profit Sharing
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that its workers would share in its strong 1986 earnings by receiving a record $370 million in profit-sharing payments.
Each of the 164,000 eligible employees would receive an average check of more than $2,100, the company said.

LEAD: Amid mounting reports of dangerous side effects, the Federal drug and customs authorities are trying to halt the flow of powerful Mexican diet pills that have been drawing more than 100,000 Americans annually to doctors just across the Mexican border.


STAGE: MUSIC AND PUPPETS IN 'DEFENDERS OF THE CODE'
LEAD: AS a science fact musical, Theodora Skipitares's ''Defenders of the Code'' is an innovative advancement for this puppeteer and theatrical conceptualist.
In her previous work, Ms.
Skipitares has been concerned with such subjects as the Revolutionary War and the Age of Invention.
Now she expands her canvas in order to probe and to test everything from creation myths to theories of eugenics.

LEAD: A defense summation in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial yesterday ridiculed two Mafia informers, portraying one as a fearful liar and the other as a professional killer.


NEW YORK POLITICIANS ARE SURPRISED
LEAD: Governor Cuomo's announcement last night that he would not seek the Democratic Presidential nomination caught many Democratic and Republican leaders throughout New York State by surprise.


7 BIG NATIONS SEEK STABLE CURRENCIES
LEAD: Seven of the biggest industrial democracies are to meet this weekend in Paris, where they are likely to adopt a new method to calm volatility in their currencies, official sources and economists said today.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A Geneva dispatch on Feb. 13 about a United Nations report on executions in Iran characterized the Bahai International Community incorrectly.
It is not an opposition group but a religious group whose members have been persecuted in Iran.


RULING ORDERS ALBANY TO RELEASE DOCUMENTS
LEAD: New York State's highest court ruled unanimously today that Albany officials must give the public ''maximum access'' to an estimated 900,000 pages of records from the administration of Erastus Corning 2d, who served as Mayor here from 1942 until his death in 1983.

LEAD: The timing of the latest wave of arrests in the still-unraveling Wall Street insider trading imbroglio could not have been more painfully poignant for students in the nation's leading business schools.


Coke's Net Up by 66.1%
LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 66.1 percent, largely because of a hefty gain from the initial public offering of stock in its bottling operations.


'A Little Princess' On Channel 13
LEAD: In this age of the silicon-veined microchip, the unfriendly takeover and the arbitrager rampant, what could be more tempting than to dismiss as a wallow in Victorian sentiment the three-part ''Wonderworks'' presentation of ''A Little Princess,'' scheduled to begin tomorrow at 8 P.M. on Channels 13 and 21?


Bush, Bullets Hot, Recalls the Alamo
LEAD: When Vice President Bush said last week that ''there might be a little bit of friction'' in the future between some of his policies and those of the Reagan Administration, some who take an interest in such political affairs saw it as the equivalent of fleeing the Alamo just as the bullets started flying.


OPERA: 'ALBERT HERRING,' BY BRITTEN, AT JUILLIARD
LEAD: BENJAMIN BRITTEN'S ''Albert Herring'' is a farce with serious undertones and the Juilliard American Opera Center, in staging it on Wednesday evening, properly bore down on the broad comedy but did not overlook subtler aspects of this 40-year-old chamber opera.
First staged at Glyndebourne in 1947 and given its American premiere at Tanglewood two years later, it was Britten's first attempt at comic opera and a surprisingly mature attempt at that.


GUNMEN BLOW OUT BEIRUT'S WINDOW ON WAR
LEAD: The parrot by the bar imitated the whistle of incoming shellfire; Fat Tommy, the huge, surly cat, slept wedged between the Reuters and the Associated Press news tickers in the lobby, and the telephones and telexes usually worked.


Heating Costs Decline
LEAD: Milder than normal weather over the North Central states helped Americans save $300 million on heating costs in January, the Government said today.
January temperatures ranged from 1 degree to 6 degrees Fahrenheit above normal in the upper Midwest and northern Plains region.
That helped cut the average heating bill in the region by between $13 and $22, according to the Climate Assessment and Information Services Center, a Federal agency.


REAGAN LIFTS POLISH TRADE CURBS, CITING PROGRESS ON HUMAN RIGHTS
LEAD: President Reagan lifted economic sanctions against Poland today, calling the action a reward for the release of political prisoners and other moves toward reconciliation with supporters of the banned Solidarity movement and the Roman Catholic Church.


Market Place; Cautious Tack For Hot Fund
LEAD: MANY mutual funds with ''aggressive growth'' as their investment objective are pouring money into the stock market these days.
But the Strong Opportunity Fund - a big winner last year with a total return of 59.9 percent in this venturesome category - has switched lately to a more conservative tack.


SECOND DUE TODAY
LEAD: The dissident psychiatrist Anatoly Koryagin, pale and emaciated from six years in prison and labor camp, was reunited today with his wife on a street in Kharkov, friends told a Dutch rights group.


IN NEW YORK CARARETS, THE OLD IS STRIKINGLY NEW
LEAD: PROBABLY more than any other area of popular music, cabaret venerates show-business traditions and the accumulated wisdom of life as expressed in popular song.
Or, to quote the title of a Peter Allen-Carole Bayer Sager song, in cabaret ''Everything old is new again.'' ''New'' can mean many things, from a personal vision that has mellowed and deepened over several decades to an artist like the 30-year-old singer-pianist Michael


CALCULATING THE LIABILITY IN CAPITAL GAINS RUSH
LEAD: This tax filing season is likely to prove a bit more agonizing than usual for investors who unloaded billions of dollars' worth of stocks, mutual funds and other assets last year before capital gains rates went up.


Barred Journalist Sues for Information
LEAD: Lawyers for Patricia Lara, the Colombian journalist detained and then expelled from the United States in October, filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday seeking to obtain Government documents pertaining to her case.


NEW U.S. LAW APPEARS TO DETER ILLEGAL ALIENS
LEAD: The new immigration control law appears to be having a marked and growing effect in deterring Mexicans and other foreigners from entering the United States illegally.


Wanted: Middle-Aged Rambos
LEAD: A growing number of Americans are calling for a revival of military conscription, partly on the grounds that the present volunteer Army is not drawing enough applicants qualified to handle today's sophisticated weaponry.


Housed in Connecticut, but Taxed in New York
LEAD: To the Editor:


City Expands Program On the Use of Condoms
LEAD: An expanded New York City Health Department program to promote the use of condoms was announced yesterday by the Health Commissioner, Steven C. Joseph.


Drawing the Curtain on Arms Control
LEAD: Considering that we are a litigious society, it is hardly surprising that the debate over the future of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty has turned into a legal wrangle.


Bronx Chant: 'Gator! Gator!'
LEAD: In the Yankee clubhouse on the first day of spring training, there were handshakes all around - the casual reunion handshakes of old friends and the firm introductory handshakes of new teammates.


Sewerage Bonds From Wisconsin
LEAD: The Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage District is offering $100 million of tax-exempt bonds with yields ranging from 4.90 percent for those maturing in 1993 to 5.50 percent in 1997 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.


U.S. FAULTS TEHERAN AND MOSCOW IN REPORT ON RIGHTS ABUSES IN '86
LEAD: Iran's human rights record last year was marked by ''serious abuses,'' including political killings, torture and violent repression of religious minorities, the State Department said today.


Hewlett Profits Increase 6.4%
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it earned $116 million, or 45 cents a share, in its first quarter, up 6.4 percent from $109 million, or 43 cents a share, a year ago.


YANKEE PITCHERS GO TO THE VIDEOTAPE
LEAD: They filed in slowly but surely this morning, first Rick Rhoden and then the others: Al Holland, Charles Hudson, Rod Scurry, Joel Skinner, Rick Cerone, Mike Armstrong.
It was the day for pitchers and catchers to report, and also the day for the Yankee manager, who is beginning his second season, to offer a state of the spring message in his most encouraging terms.


A.T.&amp;T. to Develop New Unix Model
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that it plans to develop with the Microsoft Corporation a new version of its Unix computer operating system for the 80386 microprocessor built by the Intel Corporation.
Unix is an advanced software system that enables users to manage a variety of data through its multi-tasking and multi-user functions.





THEATER: 'THE MADERATI' BY RICHARD GREENBERG
LEAD: ''THE glitterati were as thick as porterhouse steaks,'' says Rena deButts, a contemporary hostess with the mostest, on the morning after throwing a party for all the rising young novelists, artists and photographers in Manhattan.
According to ''The Maderati,'' Richard Greenberg's new comedy about Rena (Mary Joy) and her soigne crowd, the glitterati are actually thicker than porterhouse steaks and a great deal tougher besides.


TYPE OF ALZHEIMER'S TIED TO GENE
LEAD: A potentially crucial clue to the cause of Alzheimer's disease was reported yesterday by scientists studying the mysterious brain disorder.


2 New York Stations To Accept Condom Ads
LEAD: Both the New York stations of the CBS and NBC television networks announced yesterday that effective immediately they would accept condom advertising as long as it was related to combating AIDS.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Ford Motor earnings misstated the Chrysler Corporation's performance for the fourth quarter.
Its earnings rose $108.6 million above the fourth quarter of 1985.


SOVIET MISSION IS PROTEST TARGET FOR SHARANSKYS
LEAD: As demonstrators chanted behind police barricades, Natan Sharansky, the Soviet dissident now living in Israel, stood with his family and friends yesterday in a ''prison cage'' near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations on East 67th Street.


Brazil to Cut Payments
LEAD: The Brazilian Government, facing an acute shortage of hard-currency reserves, has decided to reduce interest payments on its foreign debt, Government officials said today.
They said the reduction would be made while Brazil negotiates long-term arrangements with commercial creditors.


ART: JANET FISH STILL LIFE NOT SO STILL
LEAD: WHEN the outside world began to penetrate Janet Fish's still lifes in the late 1970's, it was as a mere bit player.
Her oversized glass objects were still the center of interest.
Plates by the stack, legions of tumblers, bowls and other containers, they reposed on their tables coruscating in bright daylight - no dishwashing problems here, but then no food or drink to cause them, unless it was the fruit and vegetables that materialized about the same time as the inserts of urban and rural landscape.


10 Die in Pakistan Bombing At Afghan Guerrillas' Office
LEAD: A bomb exploded outside the office of an Afghan guerrilla group today, killing 10 people and wounding 62, the authorities said.
Angry Pakistanis later attacked Afghan refugees, and up to four people were reported killed.


ART: THE INK DRAWINGS OF PETER DRAKE IN SHOW
LEAD: WITH all the attention paid to Neo-Expressionist painting, relatively little notice has been taken of the number of younger artists whose approach is rooted in German Expressionist drawing and graphic art.
The ink drawings of Peter Drake (at the Curt Marcus Gallery, 578 Broadway, at Prince Street, through March 4), as well as the work of artists like Sue Coe and Paul Marcus, offer a purer, less self-conscious form of expressionism than any branch of Neo-Expressionist painting.


Shultz and Shamir Ask Soviet To Ease Its Emigration Curbs
LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel and Secretary of State George P. Shultz called on the Soviet Union today to relax restrictions on emigration.


Dining Out Guide: Seafood
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
THE DOLPHIN, 227 Lexington Avenue, near 33d Street (689-3010) - ** (April 12, 1985) Exceptionally fresh and well-prepared seafood is presented at this trim, neat Murray Hill restaurant with brick along one wall and blond wood paneling on another.


Contra Leader Withdraws Threat to Resign
LEAD: Arturo Cruz, the Nicaraguan rebel leader, today dropped a threat to resign and pledged he would fight to give the guerrilla movement a ''democratic political dimension which it lacks.''


Timeworn Tim
LEAD: Coach Tim Baab of John Carroll University, bemoaning the length of the basketball season: ''I love the game, but I love my mother-in-law too, and I wouldn't think of living with her for six months.''


Mother Is Accused Of Role in Girl's Rape
LEAD: A Bronx woman was arrested yesterday and charged with restraining her 6-year-old daughter while three men raped the girl on separate occasions and then gave the mother money or drugs, the police said.


SURINAME STUDENTS BATTLE POLICE
LEAD: Students throwing rocks clashed with policemen in downtown Paramaribo, the capital, today as protests against the military Government of Lieut.
Col.
Desi Bouterse intensified, according to witnesses.


Plea Made in Gun Case
LEAD: Carlene Pearson, the former fiancee of Dwight Gooden, pleaded guilty yesterday to attempted criminal possession of a weapon.
She will be given five years' probation when she is sentenced April 3.
Three weeks ago she was arrested at La Guardia Airport when the police said they found a loaded, stolen two-shot derringer pistol in her handbag.


New Old Crosley
LEAD: Ever since round and gray Riverfront Stadium opened in 1970, Cincinnatians have missed the quaint atmosphere of the Reds' previous home, Crosley Field.
So when the suburban town of Blue Ash developed a 12-diamond amateur baseball complex that included two professional-sized fields, City Manager Marvin Thompson asked, ''Why not make one like Riverfront and one like Crosley?


Diner's Journal
LEAD: THE ornately tiled vaulted ceiling supported by stout columns and ceramic covered walls is reminiscent of a New York subway station before spray paint was invented - which, in fact, it was at the turn of the century.
This fanciful room later became a rathskeller in the Vanderbilt Hotel, 4 Park Avenue, at 33d Street.


Egypt-I.M.F. Accord
LEAD: Egypt has agreed to a package of economic reforms with the International Monetary Fund in order to receive $250 million to $300 million, diplomats said today.
Under the agreement, Egypt would have to increase prices on a range of subsidized consumer goods, a sensitive subject in view of riots 10 years ago that forced the late President Anwar el-Sadat to cancel price increases.


CREDIBILITY OF PROSECUTION'S KEY WITNESS IN TUROFF TRIAL IS ASSAILED
LEAD: Defense lawyers yesterday attacked the credibility of the government's key witness in the fraud trial of the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, telling jurors that the witness was desperately trying to stay out of jail and at one time said he wanted to ''blow up'' a credit union to hide his criminal transactions.


Amerika The Dull
LEAD: The main point of the television series ''Amerika'' so far is to reconfirm that propaganda is its own nemesis, by dint of boredom.
The idea of the United States falling under Soviet occupation, without resistance, sounded provocative.
But now one wonders why all the controversy.
The film simply falls flat.


THE STAGE: 'NEVER IN MY LIFETIME'
LEAD: The continuing brutality of the conflict between the English and the Irish is captured with empathetic awareness in Shirley Gee's ''Never in My Lifetime.'' The play, winner of the 1984 Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, is having its American premiere here by the Hartman Theater Company.
As expected, there are no villains or martyrs in this war-torn stretch of Northern Ireland.


Arms Operation Made Wide Use of Danish Ships
LEAD: A Danish connection to the Iran-contra affair has become clearer in the last week, largely as a result of a court case here.


GROUPS OF FINANCIAL ANALYSTS SENDS LARGE GIFT TO NEEDIEST
LEAD: Financial analysts with Wall Street investment concerns have contributed $28,956.50 to the 75th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.


NEW GUARD, NEW WAYS IN OLD PALM BEACH
LEAD: To most people, Palm Beach conjures images of dowagers and diamonds, of parties and mansions, of heiresses and scandalous liaisons.
Some of that is still true, but it is no longer the whole story.


DOLLAR IS MIXED IN U.S. AFTER EUROPE REBOUND
LEAD: The dollar closed narrowly mixed yesterday in hectic trading as currency markets in Europe and New York reacted to the news that the finance ministers of seven leading industrial nations would meet this weekend in Paris.


'December Flower'
LEAD: PUBLIC television's ''Great Performances'' is on an impressive drama roll these days, thanks to a number of wonderful performances.
Last Friday, Sir Alec Guinness and Leo McKern brought countless touches of grace to Graham Greene's ''Monsignor Quixote,'' a story set in Spain about a simple village priest and the local Communist politician.

LEAD: The investor Irwin L. Jacobs, renewing his four-month-old bid for the Borg-Warner Corporation, said today that he intends to begin a tender offer for no less than $44 a share in cash, if a friendly merger cannot be arranged soon.

LEAD: A bipartisan coalition of key legislators, joined by nearly 200 organizations, announced today that two major civil rights measures would be their top priorities for the 100th Congress.


'97 Notes Issued By Bear Stearns
LEAD: The Bear Stearns Companies yesterday offered $100 million of 8 1/8 percent senior notes due in 1997 at a price of 99 7/8 to yield 8.15 percent, or 95-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.


A Hard Swallow In St. Louis
LEAD: For a man who has been pressing St.
Louis to build him a 70,000-seat domed football stadium, Bill Bidwill, the Cardinals' owner, has come up with a curious demand.
He wants the city fathers to ban beer there, an idea akin to banning speeches in Washington.


When Prices Outstrip Hope
LEAD: WHAT does it mean when a pair of 17th-century gilded silver salvers, a French commode, a 19th-century rosewood cabinet, a Regency vase and a Victorian partners' desk are all sold for prices far in excess of the auction houses' estimates?
Have the professionals goofed, is the current buoyancy of the art market responsible, are low presale estimates a ploy to attract potential buyers or was it a bidding war between two collectors?


IN BROOKLYN, LIFE WITHOUT TELEPHONES
LEAD: For Alfred Rodriguez, having a phone could mean getting a job.
For Miriam Maldanado, it is the difference between fear and a sense of security.
And for the Victoria Insurance Agency, it is vital for business.


BROADWAY
LEAD: TWO months ago, Martin Richards, one of the producers of ''Roza,'' said there was no talk of moving it to Broadway and no interest in doing so.
Mr.
Richards is still saying part of the same thing but not quite all.
Now there's talk, sort of, and interest in, certainly, but absolutely no commitment to the Great White Way - until and unless everything works out well at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles.

LEAD: Warner Communcations Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire 50 percent of Gulf and Western's domestic movie theater operations.
While the companies refused to disclose the amount of the investment, analysts estimated that Warner would spend about $145 million.

POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Jack Gilford, Downstairs Theater Bar at the West Bank, 407 West 42d Street (695-6909).
On this weekend 48 years ago, Jack Gilford was part of the opening show at the legendary Greenwich Village nightclub Cafe Society, along with Billie Holiday, the blues singer Joe Turner, the boogie-woogie pianists Albert Ammons, Meade Lux Lewis and Pete Johnson, and a band led by the trumpeter Frankie Newton.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration encountered unexpectedly sharp criticism of its trade policies from a Senate committee today, signaling the harsh treatment the White House can expect for the 1,600-page trade bill it has just sent to Congress.

LEAD: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the number of games the New York Rangers have played since their founding.
The game last night was their 3,944th.

LEAD: The Transit Authority plans to make subway trips speedier, but increase waits for some buses in what officials are calling the most comprehensive series of schedule changes since the service cuts of the 1970's.

LEAD: A former associate of a white supremacist group has pleaded guilty to bombing and murder charges and agreed to tell the authorities about his colleagues.

City Salutes Giants
LEAD: The Giants, who were not given a ticker-tape parade at city expense, nevertheless got a salute from New York yesterday.
In a ceremony at City Hall attended by a few players and club officials, Mayor Koch, who once called the Giants a ''foreign team,'' said: ''These champions are so mighty that they can plant one foot west of the Hudson and the other east of the Hudson.

LEAD: Fighting continues in Beirut: Once, the words made the heart sink.
Now, they have echoed for a dozen years; too long.


ART: MET BOCHNER SHOW AT SONNABEND GALLERY
LEAD: MEL BOCHNER, who started his career as one of the premier Conceptual artists of the late 1960's and early 70's, has evolved over the past decade into a maker of abstract paintings.
His path has not always been easy to follow, and this makes the artist's current exhibition at Sonnabend Gallery (420 West Broadway, at Spring Street) a particularly welcome and useful one.


CONCERT: ROSTROPOVICH WITH THE PHILHARMONIC
LEAD: IF music were ever reinstated as an Olympic event, Mstislav Rostropovich might walk away with all the gold medals.
As a way of celebrating his 60th birthday, the ebullient cellist, conductor and pianist is in the midst of a strenuous two-month series of concerts in New York, Boston and Washington that should qualify him to be known as music's marathon man.


A GUIDE TO SLIDING, GLIDING AND RIDING ON A WINTRY DAY
LEAD: AS winter moves into its final month this weekend, New Yorkers may already be dreaming of spring.
Nevertheless, many cold-weather pleasures still await the intrepid outdoor explorer.
The crowds are gone from the area's parks and gardens, and if tranquillity is ever to be found in the city, this is the time to look for it.

BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1987
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL  The Group of Seven industrial nations will meet in Paris this weekend, and they are likely to adopt a new method to calm volatility in currencies, officials and economists said.
But they said the United States would not commit itself to propping up the dollar.
The finance leaders will discuss the concept of reference zones, which would set guidelines for how much a currency should rise or fall in relation to other currencies.

LEAD: Dr.
Edward H. Rynearson, a retired Mayo Clinic physician who argued against prolonging the lives of those with incurable diseases, died here Tuesday in an automobile accident.
He was 86 years old.

LEAD: The sign above the door of an old factory building here says ''Shion Shalom Prayer Hall'' in Hebrew and English.
Inside, worshipers in prayer shawls and yarmulkes read from the Torah at Saturday Sabbath services.


British-Dutch Truck Venture
LEAD: Britain's troubled state-owned Leyland Trucks, once a takeover target of the General Motors Corporation, will be combined with the Dutch company DAF under a joint venture announced today.

Newspaper Switch By Agency
LEAD: HOLLAND &amp; CALLAWAY, an ad agency that has evolved into a media promotion specialty shop, has resigned The Daily News account to work on the promotion of New York Newsday.
Jim Callaway, the president, said his new client should be billing as much as the old, and that was around $5 million.


A NEW LURE BY BUILDES: THE CONDOP
LEAD: Roused by the termination of special property tax breaks 15 months ago, Manhattan developers rushed nearly 12,000 new apartments onto the high-priced end of the residential market.


RISK LURED 3 COLORADO SKIERS PAST SAFE AREA TO DEATH
LEAD: Three skiers who died in an avalanche near Breckenridge Wednesday were taking additional risks by skiing outside the boundaries of downhill ski slopes, an increasingly common practice that has made this one of the deadliest years for skiing in recent Colorado history.


'Miss U.S.A. Pageant' Tops 'Amerika'
LEAD: Final figures from across the United States gave ''The Miss U.S.A.
Pageant'' on CBS an upset victory over the third installment of ABC's mini-series ''Amerika'' on Tuesday night, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company.


DIRECTOR IN FILM DEATHS TESTIFIES ON CHILDREN'S PERIL IN FATAL SCENE
LEAD: The director John Landis testified today that he did not tell the parents of two children who were killed in the filming of the movie ''Twilight Zone'' how large the special effects explosions would be on the movie set or how close the children would be to those explosions.


CATHARINE W. HOPPIN
LEAD: Catharine Wellington Hoppin, an educator and former head of the Professional Children's School in New York, died Feb. 7 at her home in Stonington, Conn.
She was 89 years old.


VOLCANO IN OCEAN ASTOUNDS SCIENTISTS
LEAD: A team of oceanographers has piloted a small submarine into the eye of an underwater volcano near Hawaii and reports finding a strange new world.


Early Retirements At I.B.M. Center
LEAD: Nearly half of the employees at the International Business Machines Corporation's distribution center in Greencastle have chosen to retire early rather than transfer when the plant closes next month.
Dale K. Bennett, a spokeswoman for I.B.M., said that about 400 employees planned to take early retirement and that 500 had decided to take jobs at other I.B.M.


NEW YORK COURT STUDY SAYS SYSTEM IS FASTER
LEAD: A year-old program intended to streamline justice in New York City by assigning all stages of a case to one judge has speeded the pace of criminal cases through the courts, administrators said yesterday.
But they said it has also left a growing number of more difficult cases clogging court calendars.


SHORT-TERM RATES PLUNGE
LEAD: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday as traders were encouraged by statements from Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that the central bank had not tightened monetary policy.


Convertible Debt: 2 More Offerings
LEAD: The recent surge in stock prices has encouraged more offerings of convertible debt issues, including two yesterday totaling $200 million.


How Public Remarks Became Classified Data
LEAD: The Government has long made liberal use of its authority to classify information as ''secret.'' But a question has arisen over whether it recently went a few steps too far.

LEAD: To the Editor:


FROESE THROWS GLOVE AT REFEREE IN ROUT
LEAD: All night they came at him, infringing on the area that he believed was rightfully his, and they hemmed him in.
So he pushed at the opposition and he railed at the officials and finally, with one angry motion, Bob Froese let his temper go.
The Ranger goalkeeper threw his glove at the referee.


The Editorial Notebook; Silencing Liu the Just Judge
LEAD: Andrei Sakharov, Yelena Bonner, Natan Sharansky.
Americans know these names: they are heroes fighting the evil Soviet system.
Their Chinese counterparts, also courageously fighting repression, are nameless and unknown.
That's partly because Americans pay so much attention to the Soviet Union.
It's also because Americans think of the Chinese as the good-guy Communists.

LEAD: The tenor saxophonist Archie Shepp will lead a quintet - with the trombonist Grachan Moncur 3d, the pianist Dave Burrell, the bassist Cameron Brown and the drummer Beaver Harris - tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785).
Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M.

LEAD: After deliberating for six hours yesterday on two competing takeover offers, the board of Piedmont Aviation Inc. opened the bidding to all interested parties.


HENRY-RUSSELL HITCHCOCK DEAD AT 83
LEAD: Henry-Russell Hitchcock, one of the country's most distinguished architectural historians and teachers, died of cancer yesterday in New York.
He was 83 years old.


Soccer for Youth
LEAD: To acquaint young Americans with Brazil and its renowned soccer talents, Pele is organizing a program to send 80 youth soccer teams from the United States to play in Brazil this summer.
Pele and Julio Mazzei, his friend and adviser, said the players would be between the ages of 12 and 18, with eight teams going to Brazil every week from June 19 until the end of August, and each guaranteed eight games there.


ART: 72 OF THE NEWEST OF MODERN'S DRAWINGS
LEAD: IT is six years since the drawings department of the Museum of Modern Art last mounted a show of new acquisitions.
During the period in question, 554 drawings by 217 artists were acquired.
Seventy-two of the drawings in question - roughly one-eighth of the total intake - are in the current show of recently acquired drawings acquisitions at the museum.


FILM: 'IRA,' DOCUMENTARY
LEAD: YOUR response to ''Ira, You'll Get Into Trouble'' is likely to be related to your feelings about the student commotions of the late 1960's.
Stephen A. Sbarge's cinema verite documentary, completed in 1970 and now at the Thalia, follows an attractive group of New York City high schoolers who try to organize against what they view as a repressive establishment.


Mexico Pays Off Loan
LEAD: Mexico has paid off a $1.1 billion bridge loan from central banks of 16 countries and the United States Treasury Department, the Government said today.
The credit, approved last August, provided funds while Mexico negotiated a new long-term loan agreement with foreign commercial banks.
Nearly half the bridge loan was provided by the United States, with the Treasury Department contributing $272 million and the Federal Reserve Bank, $273 million.


AT THE MOVIES
LEAD: IN ''Duet for One'' Julie Andrews plays Stephanie Anderson, a virtuoso concert violinist whose brilliant career and seemingly successful marriage are both cut off when she contracts multiple sclerosis.
The role is a milestone in Ms.
Andrews's career for many reasons - it is one of the most emotionally demanding and dramatic parts she has played and it exposed her to the suffering of a group of people she came to respect and admire.


TANGLED TRAIL ENDS TODAY FOR LEVINE
LEAD: When Dennis B. Levine telephoned one of his secret insider-trading confederates soon after being arrested last May 12, the confederate was less than eager to talk.
But Mr.
Levine, who had used his considerable charm to recruit a handful of Wall Street professionals into his scheme, assured the other person that his call was safe.


FILM: 'SQUARE DANCE,' STARRING JASON ROBARDS
LEAD: AS anyone who took square dancing at summer camp knows, ''home'' is the position from which all steps originate and the spot to which a dancer returns after do-si-do-ing.
This is the signally simple metaphor that hangs over ''Square Dance'' like a heart-shaped, helium-filled balloon with a slow leak.

LEAD: To the Editor:


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Lloyd Upset in Florida: Chris Evert Lloyd's comeback to tournament play ended quickly as Kate Gompert upset the world's second-ranked player, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2, last night in the third round of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Florida, at Boca Raton.
In the other late match, second-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany needed only 34 minutes to beat Sara Gomer of England, 6-0, 6-0, allowing 19 points in the 12 games.

Economic Scene; Japanese Stress Regions in U.S.
LEAD: WHERE American economists commonly believe that the way to eliminate this nation's huge trade deficit is to lower the value of the dollar, Japanese economists maintain that the basic answer to America's trade problem lies in more vigorous industrial growth and better-balanced regional development.


New Grievance by Union
LEAD: While several prominent and talented free agents remain unsigned, the Players Association is about to intensify its conspiracy case against the owners.
The association will file a second grievance today, charging that the clubs violated the labor agreement by acting in concert with each other on free agents.


Cotton Prices Tumble; Grain and Soybeans Up
LEAD: Cotton futures plunged sharply yesterday in high volume, extending the decline for a full week.


VOLCKER SEES SLIGHT '87 GAINS
LEAD: The Federal Reserve expects the economy to grow by 2 1/2 percent to 3 percent this year, slightly faster than in 1986, while unemployment drifts down a bit from current levels, Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, told Congress today.
