SENATE HEARING SPLIT ON PARENTAL BILL
LEAD: A bill requiring employers to give time off to parents of newborn or newly adopted children received its first Senate hearing today.
Supporters and opponents differed over the need for a national policy on leaves for child care, as well as over whether the 18-week, unpaid leave provided by the bill would place an undue burden on small business.


SPECIAL TOYS FOR SPECIAL PLAY
LEAD: Six-year-old Douglas Masterson, who has cerebral palsy, used to watch while his younger brother Joey played with toys that flashed, made interesting noises and moved across the floor of their home in Levittown, L.I.


A Tale of 2 Suburbs: Racism and Realtors
LEAD: RACISM is easy to spot when it is dressed in a white robe and pointy hat.
But the racism that keeps one suburb lily-white, while a neighboring suburb quietly grows more and more black, is a trickier, more elusive racism.


Advanced Genetic
LEAD: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company based in Oakland, Calif., said that it had received preliminary approval from the California Department of Food and Agriculture to conduct field experiments on Frostban, genetically altered bacteria that protect fruit and nut crops from frost damage.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Faster Subway Rides


JUDGE BARS TACTIC IN WAR CRIME CASE
LEAD: The defense lawyer in Israel's trial of a war crimes suspect from a Nazi camp questioned today whether ''wishful thinking'' might have motivated the accusations of survivors of the Treblinka death camp.


The U.N. Today: Feb. 20, 1987
LEAD:  SECURITY COUNCIL


A SURPRISING SOPRANO AT TOWN HALL
LEAD: The Surprising Soprano was as surprised as anyone, he insists, when his career in operatic parody opened up in 1969. ''It was not my idea.
I didn't know I could do these things,'' said Michael Aspinall shortly after his arrival from Rome last week.
The blame, he alleges, lies with ''a friend of mine who wanted to do it, and wanted me to try to sing duets with him.


Small Risk, Devastating Consequences of AIDS
LEAD: To the Editor:


FLAMINGO HEADING FOR A LAST WHIRL
LEAD: The last Flamingo.
Like such titles as ''The Last Picture Show'' or ''The Last Convertible,'' the phrase suggests the end of an era and an institution.
Pessimists are applying it to the Flamingto Stakes here Feb. 28, the first of the year's seven Grade I prep races for the Kentucky Derby and possibly its last edition as racing fans know it.


CUOMO REMARKS BARRING RACE FOR THE PRESIDENCY
LEAD: Following is an excerpt from a transcript of Governor Cuomo's question-and-answer session last night on a statewide radio broadcast:  Q.  We have about four minutes left Governor.
If we can get back to what I asked you at the beginning of the broadcast and you said maybe we'd talk about it later; it's almost later.


NOVEL BAILOUT OF A TEXAS BANK
LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it had arranged an innovative bailout of the troubled BancTexas Group of Dallas that would transfer management control of the holding company and its 11 banks to a little-known merchant banking concern called Hallwood Group Inc.


THE EVENING HOURS
LEAD: ''ROBERT CARMEL is here,''


'HOMELAND' LEADER IS TARGET OF RAID
LEAD: More than 20 men armed with machine guns, mortars and grenades attacked the presidential palace in the black homeland of Ciskei early today but were repulsed by guards, the authorities said.


IRISH VICTOR FALLS 3 SHY OF MAJORITY
LEAD: Charles J. Haughey's incomplete victory - three seats short of a parliamentary majority - in the national election Tuesday has brought him to the crossroads of the most dramatic career in modern Irish politics.


METRO DATELINES;
LEAD: The family of a 23-year-old woman from Peekskill who died a year ago after taking an Extra-Strength Tylenol capsule laced with cyanide sued its maker and a distributor yesterday for $94.5 million.


Addendum
LEAD: * Harrison &amp; Star is a new health-care ad agency at 70 West 36th Street.


FILM: 'DEATH BEFORE DISHONOR'
LEAD: THE movies are looking for a few good men, to change the face of American foreign policy and out-Rambo Rambo in the process.
The latest of these hopefuls is Gunnery Sgt.
Jack Burns, who in ''Death Before Dishonor'' is a marine with a mission.
Stationed in the fictitious Middle Eastern country of Jemal, Burns (Fred Dryer) must stand by helplessly while his commanding officer (Brian Keith) is kidnapped by Arab terrorists.


FILM: BRAZIL'S 'BARRAVENTO'
LEAD: ''BARRAVENTO'' (''The Turning Wind''), opening today at the Public Theater, is the first feature by the highly regarded Brazilian director Glauber Rocha, who died at the age of 42 in 1981.
The film, made in 1961, is about the efforts of Firmino, part revolutionary, part devil, to free the fishermen in his native


Japan Rate Cut Appears Near
LEAD: The Bank of Japan is expected to announce a cut in its basic interest rate Friday.


Peskanov Recital
LEAD: The violinist Mark Peskanov will play works by Mozart, Richard Strauss and Aaron Copland at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night at 8 o'clock, accompanied by the pianist Rita Sloan.
Tickets are $10; information: 362-1911.


BROWN MAKES A PERSONAL CALL
LEAD: Did Kansas attempt to recruit the well-traveled Lloyd Daniels after his recent arrest?
According to sources at Nevada-Las Vegas, Kansas contacted the Brooklyn-born Daniels within days of his arrest on drug charges in Las Vegas.
In an interview yesterday, Larry Brown, the Kansas coach, said that contact had indeed been made, but that the purpose of the call was not to recruit


LEBANESE SENTENCED IN MILAN
LEAD: A court in Milan today convicted a Lebanese of smuggling explosives into Italy and sentenced him to 13 years in prison.


Periodicals Collection Gets $1 Million Gift
LEAD: The New York Public Library's periodicals collection has received a gift in excess of $1 million to endow the position of chief librarian for periodicals and journals.
The endowment is also to provide for an annual award for ''excellence in journalism,'' with details to be announced.


Inquiry on Hutton Unit
LEAD: A Federal grand jury is investigating whether the E. F. Hutton Group violated reporting requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission at its Providence, R.I., office between 1981 and 1984, the company disclosed yesterday.
It made the disclosure in an S.E.C. filing.


Beirut Fighting Defies New Cease-Fire Effort
LEAD: There was more heavy fighting in West Beirut today as regular Syrian and Lebanese soldiers took up positions at main intersections to try to enforce a cease-fire.


William Esty Gets 2 Cigarette Accounts
LEAD: The William Esty Company, which last year lost Salem cigarettes, the mentholated brand it had introduced for R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, has now been assigned Kool, an even better-known menthol from Brown &amp; Williamson, as well as Kim, a new cigarette product in this country.


INQUIRY GROWS IN GOLDINE LINK WITH BOESKY
LEAD: New York City's Department of Investigation is examining the role that City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin played in a 1985 corporate takeover battle that benefited both the city's pension funds and Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street speculator, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.


SOVIET SOCIOLOGIST CANDID ABOUT OFFICIAL DISREGARD FOR HER SCIENCE
LEAD: A highly critical assessment of Soviet sociology that was recently published in Pravda is remarkable for its candor even in this era of openness under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.


New Italian and downtown Indian.
LEAD: SOMETIMES I get the feeling that New Yorkers could survive quite adequately without restaurant critics.
This disquieting thought came to mind several weeks ago during an exploration on the East Side in which I ''discovered'' Primola, a seven-month-old Italian restaurant that, as it turned out, had already been uncovered long before by legions of amateur restaurant scouts.


Still Upward Upstate
LEAD:  Potsdam (N.Y.) State, the Division III basketball titan, gained its 54th consecutive victory Tuesday night and is closing in on San Francisco's streak of 60 straight (1955-57), the second-longest run in N.C.A.A. history. (U.C.L.A. won 88 in a row from 1971 to 1974.) Just as impressive, Potsdam is aiming to become an unbeaten N.C.A.A.


Among the '88 Aspirants
LEAD: Announcing a Presidential candidacy these days has become a major production, particularly for lesser-known hopefuls eager to become better-known.
On Monday, for example, a chartered DC-9 will carry 20 members of Congress and assorted reporters from Washington to St.
Louis for the noon announcement of Representative Richard A.


RODINO LIKENS IRAN ARMS SALE TO WATERGATE
LEAD: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Peter W. Rodino Jr., today compared the Iran arms affair to the Watergate scandals and warned against White House efforts to ''cover up.''


Disposable Camera Plans
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company and Fuji Photo Film U.S.A.
Inc. said separately yesterday that they planned to market disposable color cameras.


Koch Names Payne New Probation Chief
LEAD: James A. Payne, an assistant corporation counsel, was named the city's probation commissioner yesterday by Mayor Koch.


Crossland Savings
LEAD: The Crossland Savings Bank of Brooklyn said it has agreed in principle to take over the Western Savings and Loan Association, a troubled savings institution based in Salt Lake City.
In return for control over Western's $400 million in assets and 13 branches in four states, Crossland agreed to inject Western with $50 million in fresh capital.


U.S. TOLD TO SPEED A MISSION TO MARS
LEAD: Two leading proponents of exploration of Mars urged Congressional committees today to reject plans of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to delay an unmanned mission to the planet.


U.S. DETAILS RULES FOR DRUG TESTING
LEAD: The Reagan Administration announced details today on a sweeping drug-detecting program that will require about a million Federal workers to submit urine samples under strict controls to prevent cheating, including direct observation of urination in some cases.

REAGAN FILLS POSTS IN COMMUNICATIONS AND POLITICS
LEAD: President Reagan filled two vacancies at the White House today.
He named Frank J. Donatelli, a Washington lawyer, as political director and selected John O. Koehler, a former executive with the Associated Press, a news agency, as communications director.


FRENCH CINEMATIC TREATS AT THE MODERN
LEAD: SINCE invitations to advance screenings are reserved for the special few, the rest of us can be very grateful to the Museum of Modern Art for its ''Perspectives on French Cinema'' series, which offers previews of a batch of movies fresh off the plane from Paris.
This year's edition, which opens today, offers a dozen features, 11 of which will be shown twice through March 3 at the museum's Roy and Niuta Titus


U.S. SEEKING PYROTECHNICS EXPERT IN BOMBINGS AT ABORTION CLINICS
LEAD: A fireworks expert who worked at last year's Statue of Liberty celebration is being sought in the bombings of several New York City abortion clinics, Federal officials announced yesterday.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Pierce Turner, the Old Town Bar, 45 East 18th Street, and Kenny's Castaways, 157 Bleecker Street.
An Irish folk vaudevillian, Pierce Turner writes Celtic-flavored folk-rock songs suffused with affection for his hometown of Wexford.
Recently he recorded a delightful solo album of his tunes, ''It's Only a Long Way Across'' (co-produced by Philip Glass and Kurt Munkacsi), that evocatively mixes his barroom reveries with snappy electronics.


Serving Notice on the Contras
LEAD: No matter what happens in Nicaragua, the fellow who seems to speak for the State Department is General Micawber: Something hopeful is always about to turn up.


REPEAT: JOHNSON SAYS METS WILL WIN
LEAD: For the first time since Jesse Orosco struck out Marty Barrett and wiped out the Boston Red Sox 115 days ago, there were Mets on a baseball field in uniform today.


BODIES FOUND IN COLORADO AVALANCHE
LEAD: Rescue workers using a sled to transport body of a victim of avalanche Wednesday near the Breckenridge Ski Area.
Three bodies have been recovered, including that of Martin Donnelan of Peekskill, N.Y.
A fourth victim is being sought.

M'Farlane Account
LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, told a Presidential review board in his hospital room today that he had taken part in an effort by White House aides to hide President Reagan's key role in the initiation of the Iran arms sales, according to a source familiar with the board's investigation.


Bridge: New York Event Will Pair Top Players and Amateurs
LEAD: Once a year some of New York's less experienced tournament players have the opportunity to play with experts.
The event is the Greater New York Bridge Association's Pro-Am event, scheduled for 7:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Penta Hotel, 33d Street and Seventh Avenue in Manhattan.
Reservations are needed.


'Platoon' Is History
LEAD: To the Editor:


KNICK'S NEW CAST PRODUCES SMASH HIT
LEAD: Coach Bob Hill, who had been relying on the younger Knicks to carry the team toward its uncertain future, turned to some forgotten veteran players last night, and the result was the end of a four-game losing streak.


Roberta Peters
LEAD: The soprano Roberta Peters will sing works by Scarlatti, Schubert, Meyerbeer, Faure and Noel Coward at the 92d Street Y tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock, accompanied by the pianist Jakov Kreizberg and the flutist Paul Dunkel.
Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50.
The 92d Street Y is at 1395 Lexington Avenue.


DREXEL IS SUED BY STALEY
LEAD: Staley Continental Inc. filed a $200 million suit against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday, charging that the investment banking firm tried to ''extort'' the company into a leveraged buyout.

STATEN ISLAND REACHES THE FINAL
LEAD: Yesterday was by far the easiest day the College of Staten Island's basketball team has had in a while.
The only thing the Dolphins had to worry about was basketball.


At Last, a Little Help for the Homeless
LEAD: It's been 18 months since the philanthropist Leonard Stern offered a $1 million challenge grant to push Help I, a shelter for families now living in welfare hotels.
From that day, Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, has put his energy and resourceful leadership into the effort.
Yet only now is the project starting to move at last, and it will take an additional year before the first occupants arrive at their new transitional home.


Blue Retires
LEAD: Vida Blue retired yesterday, less than a month after signing as a free agent with the Oakland A's.
A team spokesman, Jay Alves, said the decision was a surprise.
The 37-year-old left-hander helped the A's to world championships in 1972, 1973 and 1974 and had a career record of 209-161. ''My physical condition is good, so while I am still in good health I have decided to retire,'' Blue said.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 381 money market mutual funds increased by $168.4 million, to $236.18 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $516.1 million, to $65.83 billion.
Assets of the 198 general purpose funds were down $241.9 million, to $62.75 billion.


FILM: RACHEL WARD IN 'THE GOOD WIFE'
LEAD: ''THE GOOD WIFE,'' set in the long-ago 1930's, is Marge Hills (Rachel Ward), an earnest, reliable friend to anyone in need in the rural New South Wales town where she lives with her husband, Sonny (Bryan Brown), a hard-working logger.
When a baby's expected in the community, Marge becomes the unpaid midwife.


Wetlands Wipeout
LEAD: To the Editor:


TAMPA RELEASES GOODEN DATA
LEAD: The City Attorney today released copies of a report on the arrest of Dwight Gooden and four companions who fought with Tampa police officers last December after his car was stopped by the police.


Stocks Rise to Record for Third Day
LEAD: The stock market rose modestly yesterday to its third record in a row, as speculation grew over the direction of interest rates and the dollar's value.


Myers Chamber Opera
LEAD: The composer-keyboardist Amina Claudine Myers will present her chamber opera ''When the Berries Fell'' tonight at 8 o'clock at the Triplex at Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street (618-1980).
It is scored for keyboards, percussion and Ms.
Myers's Voice Choir.
Tickets are $8; $6 for students

Japan Investment in U.S.
LEAD: Japan ranked third in direct investment in the United States during a 12-year period beginning in 1974, a trade organization said in a report released today.
The Japan External Trade Organization said Japan made 1,154 direct investments, or 14.2 percent of the total, in the United States from 1974 through 1985.


Arms and Shamir
LEAD: At a breakfast Thursday with Yitzhak Shamir, the Israeli Prime Minister, a reporter asked what Israel's current policy was with respect to selling arms to terrorist nations. ''Israel is the only country fighting terrorism,'' he replied. ''We are successful.'' As for the arms shipments to Iran in which Israel assisted, he added: ''The Iran affair was an exception.


NETS' RALLY COMES UP SHORT
LEAD: During the first timeout of tonight's game, with the Nets ahead by 13-11, George Karl, the Golden State Warriors' coach, tried to bolster his struggling club.
He described the Nets as a ''depressed team.''


DARLING JOINS MILLIONAIRE CLUB
LEAD: Ron Darling won his bid for $1.05 million in salary arbitration yesterday and immediately noticed a bizarre pattern.


Management Science Goes to Tucker Wayne
LEAD: Tucker Wayne &amp; Company, Atlanta, won the account of Management Science America, an independent supplier of computer software, last week.
Today its first ad, on three consecutive pages, is scheduled to appear in The Wall Street Journal and a number of trade publications.


AFFLUENT VOTERS WOOED ON CHICAGO'S LAKEFRONT
LEAD: The mountainous waves of a brimming Lake Michigan that pounded this city's lakefront in recent weeks could serve as an apt symbol of Chicago's current political season.


FILM: FREDI M. MURER'S 'ALPINE FIRE'
LEAD: LIKE its title, Fredi M. Murer's ''Alpine Fire'' is ultimately a lot more corny (and a lot less meaningful) than one wants to believe while watching it.
The Swiss film is the first fiction feature to be made by Mr.
Murer, who, until now, has specialized in documentaries, and who clearly knows how to photograph scenery and weather under difficult conditions.


OLD CROTON AQUADUCT FOR WALKERS, NOT WATER
LEAD: The Old Croton Aqueduct no longer carries New York City's water supply from a river in northern Westchester County to a reservoir on 42d Street, 41 miles south.
Instead, hikers, joggers and cross-country skiers travel on top of this 19th-century engineering marvel, part of which is a linear park.


PAKISTAN'S NUCLEAR AIMS WORRYING U.S.
LEAD: Senior United States officials have begun expressing new concern that Pakistan is moving toward the development of a nuclear bomb, in spite of pledges that it has no such intentions.


TV Shopping Plan By Dayton Hudson
LEAD: The Dayton Hudson Corporation plans to start a live, one-hour television show this spring offering viewers a chance to buy just about everything sold in its Dayton's stores except furniture and appliances.
Dayton Hudson thus joins a growing list of major reatilers getting into the televised shop-from-home business.


DR. HENRY BLUMENTHAL
LEAD: Dr.
Henry Blumenthal, a historian of Franco-American relations at Rutgers University for many years, died Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center.
He was 75 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.


The Real Threat
LEAD: Many estimable people have protested the ABC television network's political soap opera ''Amerika,'' trying to keep the series off the air.
I think they have missed the point.


WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING Kemp Opens Fire, Sort of
LEAD: A year before the first votes of the 1988 Republican Presidential competition, it is too early for rivals of Vice President Bush to criticize him openly.
That might look like an attack on President Reagan.
But it is always possible to open fire on a secondary target close to Mr.
Bush, on the theory that the Vice


FILM: 'EAT AND RUN'
LEAD: A BALD and very fat man, supposedly an extraterrestrial named Murray, stomps through ''Eat and Run'' devouring every Italian he meets, after which he belches loudly and spits out a button or two. ''Eat and Run'' doesn't get any funnier, and not much of it even measures up to that comic pinnacle.
As co-written and directed by Christopher Hart, this comedy specializes in schoolboy humor at its most mirthlessly stupid.


Orlando String Quartet
LEAD: The Orlando String Quartet will play Beethoven's String Quartet in F (Op. 59, No. 1, ''Razumovsky'') and Dvorak's Piano Quintet in A (Op. 81), with the pianist Lilian Kallir, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.
Admission is $12; information: 570-3949.


TRIAL HEARS WHITEHEAD DID NOT WRITE TO JUDGE
LEAD: An emotional 11-page plea for understanding signed with Mary Beth Whitehead's name and sent last May to the judge in the Baby M case was not written by Mrs.
Whitehead, but by a close friend, testimony revealed today.


JACKSON CHALLENGES CADETS TO RETHINK ROLE
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson challenged the next generation of American military leaders tonight to assess the nation's security in domestic as well as international terms.


FILM: 'BILLY GALVIN'
LEAD: JACK GALVIN, the title character's father in the family drama ''Billy Galvin,'' likes to watch the Muppets on television.
He calls people ''Yardbird,'' and can't stand it when his wife forgets to close the kitchen cabinet door.
These details, in John Gray's simple, big-hearted and essentially familiar film, are meant to say a good deal more about Jack's character than they actually do.


Small Risk, Devastating Consequences of AIDS; Which Researchers?
LEAD: To the Editor:


'My Dear Alex'
LEAD: Richard M. Nixon, who does not issue book endorsements every day, wrote: ''Not since George Orwell, to my knowledge, has there been a broad political satire to match 'My Dear Alex.' This book not only affords reading pleasure; it illuminates and provokes.
It should command a wide audience and serious critical attention.


DECISION SAID TO RESHAPE CONTEST IN '88
LEAD: Governor Cuomo's decision not to run for President has drastically altered the shape of the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, political experts said last night, and has left Gary Hart as the party's one candidate with truly national backing.


DIOCESE DROPS TV PLAN ON POPE
LEAD: Roman Catholic officials, yielding to complaints from broadcasters and some church leaders, today dropped a plan to auction television rights for coverage of the visit of Pope John Paul II in September.

A PLEA FOR HELP
LEAD: Early this month, a man I know received a letter from an old acquaintance that, after the personal salutation, began, ''Happy New Year to you and your family.
I need your help.
I am presently in Nassau County Jail.
I am charged with arson.
I am to be sentenced February 24, 1987.''

Appeal for Aid
LEAD: Lebanon's Prime Minister and other Moslem leaders formally asked Syria today to send more troops to West Beirut to end the worst factional fighting the Moslem part of the capital has seen in 12 years of civil war.


Fly Williams Shot
LEAD: James (Fly) Williams, a former standout in college and the American Basketball Association, was listed in guarded condition in Booth Memorial Hospital in Queens with gunshot wounds.
He was shot by an off-duty court officer after a dispute Tuesday night with a third man over money.
A companion of Williams, Derrick Washington, was also shot and both men were charged with attempted robbery, unlawful imprisonment, weapons possession and menacing, according to the police.

LEAD: Two founders of a securities firm whose collapse touched off a financial crisis in Ohio have been sentenced to jail by a judge who expressed contempt for the plea bargains the prosecutors had reached.


When to Shift Family Assets
LEAD: DAN FORBES, a New York City businessman, and his wife, Eileen, decided recently to put their jointly owned family home in Glen Head, L.I., in her name.
They are in the process of doing the same with some of their securities as well.

BUSINESS DEDUCTIONS: PARTY ENDING FOR MANY
LEAD: For many taxpayers, the greatest challenge is finding ways to justify writing off as a business expense such seemingly personal expenditures as country club memberships, night-school classes, dinner at Lutece or even a midwinter trip to Palm Beach.


VERY HAPPY RETURN FOR SATOR

LEAD: The Alaska Permanent Fund, one of the most unusual public finance devices ever concocted in the United States, will earn enough this year to give the state $150 million to help it through a financial crisis, salt away $100 million or so to repair inflation's nibbles at principal, and still give every man, woman and child in Alaska about $675 to spend, save or toss into the wind.

Pat Cummings Injured
LEAD: Pat Cummings of the Knicks suffered a torn ligament in his right index finger during Thursday night's 120-105 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers at Madison Square Garden.
The forward will miss at least two games.
According to Dr.
Norman Scott, whether surgery will be necessary will not be determined until the swelling subsides, which probably won't occur until the middle of next week.


No Headline
LEAD: A chart in some copies of Business Day yesterday, with an article about international financial meetings this weekend in Paris, incorrectly described one proposed way of keeping currencies within trading ranges against other currencies.
If the dollar strengthened beyond the top limit of a proposed range against the yen, for instance, the countries involved might try to bring the dollar back down by selling dollars or buying yen; if the dollar weakened too much, the countries might buy dollars and sell yen.


ANTI-VIRAL DRUG INVESTIGATED
LEAD: Federal regulators and a House subcommittee said today that they were investigating whether a California company failed to report adverse reactions to ribavirin, an anti-viral drug.


Nunn Rejects '88 Bid For at Least 6 Months
LEAD: Senator Sam Nunn told Georgia Democrats tonight that he would not mount a Presidential campaign over the next six months, but he refused to rule out the possibility of later entering the race.


GEORGE F. TIBBLES
LEAD: George F. Tibbles, a composer and television writer who put Woody Woodpecker's laugh to music and got an Academy Award nomination for the effort, died last Saturday at the Eisenhower Medical Center.
He was 73 years old.

Appeal to Block Bar on Hogtying Denied by Judge
LEAD: A Manhattan judge yesterday denied a New York City police union's request to block a departmental ban on hogtying prisoners.


Allied Bancshares To Combine Units
LEAD: Allied Bancshares Inc. said that it would combine its 20 subsidiaries within Harris County, which encompasses Houston, into a single institution.
The new bank, to be called Allied Bank N.A., is expected to have assets of about $7.12 billion and deposits of $5.5 billion, according to Jay C. Crager, Allied's chief financial officer.


Hoechst Near Celanese Link
LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission cleared the way today for the American Hoechst Corporation to complete its $2.8 billion takeover of the Celanese Corporation, following Hoechst's promise to sell a variety of assets to ease Government antitrust concerns.

WHERE THE TITANIC BELONGS
LEAD: A Texas oilman in cahoots with a French Government research institute plans a return to the Titanic for treasure and live TV.
Picking over shipwrecks in international waters is legal, but these remains need care and control.


A WOBBLY WIN FOR IRELAND'S HAUGHEY
LEAD: It was the economy, not the ''national question,'' that mattered most in Ireland's election this week.
Voters clearly blamed Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald for bad times and a jobless rate that is now second worst in the European Community.
His defeat was not a repudiation of his Government's landmark agreement with Britain on Northern Ireland.


S.M.U. Awaits Decision
LEAD: Southern Methodist University officials said today they expect to learn by Wednesday whether the school's football program will be shut down for two years for violating National Collegiate Athletic Association rules while the Mustangs were on probation.

SIR HUGH GREENE, 76, DIES IN LONDON
LEAD: Sir Hugh Carleton Greene, a former director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation and a brother of Graham Greene, the novelist, died of cancer Thursday at a London hospital.
He was 76 years old.
Sir Hugh headed the BBC television and radio networks from 1960 until 1969.
He joined the BBC in 1940 as head of its wartime broadcasts to Germany after having served as chief correspondent in Berlin for The Daily Telegraph until shortly before the outbreak of World War


MAN HE SENTENCED IS CHARGED
LEAD: A former chairman of New York University's anthropology department, whose brilliant career was wrecked by a drug conviction six years ago, was accused yesterday of sending poisoned Valentine's Day chocolates to the Federal judge who sent him to prison.

Canada Inflation Eases
LEAD: Canada's annual rate of inflation fell to 3.9 percent in January from 4.2 percent in December, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today.
In this week's federal budget, Finance Minister Michael Wilson projected that inflation would average 3.9 percent for 1987, down from 4.1 percent in 1986.


GERALD HAHN
LEAD: Gerald Hahn, a painter and associate professor of art at Queens College, died of Hodgkin's disease on Monday at the Westchester County Medical Center.
He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Mike Brown, a Pittsburgh Pirate outfielder, has signed a contract for a reduced salary.
Brown, who made $225,000 in 1986, will earn $212,500 for the coming season under a settlement reached by the team and his agent, Steve Greenberg. ...
The California Athletic Commission approved a boxing license for a former heavyweight boxing champion, George Foreman, at a full commission hearing yesterday, according to his promoter.

Five Children Killed In Apartment Blaze While There Alone
LEAD: Five children, age 2 and younger, who were left alone in an apartment were killed today when fire broke out at a public housing project, the authorities said.


China Shows Growth of 9%
LEAD: Industrial growth in China in 1986 declined to just over 9 percent, from a runaway 18 percent in 1985, thanks to better control of the economy, Chinese officials said today.


THE BLENDING OF 2 PAINT STORES
LEAD: In its 118 years in business, the paint store S. Wolf's Sons has become a New York City institution, supplying paint that coated ocean liners, the exterior of the Empire State Building and many of the benches in Central Park.


Israeli Hospital Strike Halts
LEAD: Israeli hospital workers returned to their jobs today after a five-day walkout that President Chaim Herzog denounced as an ''abuse of the right to strike.'' The 9,000 clerks and maintenance workers at the hospitals of Histadrut, the nation's main labor federation, promised to halt their protest while a committee examines their demand for a 14-percent pay increase.

Cold-Water Drill
LEAD: Coast Guardsmen practicing survival and rescue techniques yesterday in New York Harbor off Governor's Island.
In a man-overboard exercise, Chief Petty Officer Lynn Fuller, dressed in a survival suit, acted the part of victim as Apprentice Fireman Anthony Forestiere swam out and pulled him to a boat, where he was lifted aboard.


Japan to Reduce Rate
LEAD: The Bank of Japan, as expected, today announced a half-point cut in its basic interest rate, to an all-time low of 2.5 percent.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.B.A.
Lakers 110, Bulls 100: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, becoming the first National Basketball Association player to score 36,000 career points, connected on a skyhook and hit two key free throws in the final 2 minutes 32 seconds last night for the Lakers in Chicago.
The Lakers insured the outcome on two baskets in the final 54 seconds by Magic Johnson, who added 28 points.

LEAD: Two real estate developers and three former executives of the Sunrise Savings and Loan Association of Boynton, Fla., were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of misapplication of funds.

100,000 Rally For Punjab Politicians
LEAD: More than 100,000 Sikhs rallied in the state of Punjab today in support of secular political leaders who face a challenge from religious figures for leadership of India's Sikhs.


Howser Returns
LEAD: For the first time since being diagnosed as having brain cancer, Dick Howser is back on the job as manager of the Kansas City Royals. ''It's a special feeling,'' said Howser, who officially reported to spring training at Fort Myers, Fla., Thursday. ''But to tell you the truth, not from day one in the hospital did I ever feel like I would not be here.


Frenchman-Soviet Deal
LEAD: A French business executive with ties to the Communist Party said today that he had signed a deal on two-way trade with the Soviet Union worth $1 billion.
Jean-Baptiste Doumeng said he signed the deal on a recent trip to Moscow.
He said some of the goods going to the Soviet Union would be supplied by his own business and others by French and foreign subcontractors.

On Renaming the Omni
LEAD: By the time the Democratic National Convention in Atlanta rolls around in 1988, the name of the Omni, the auditorium where the big political gathering will be held, probably will have been changed to include CNN, for the Cable News Network, which has the contract to operate the auditorium.
And if the newscasters in the network anchor booths are going to be accurate, they will have to mention the name of their upstart competitor every time they say where they are speaking from.


U.S. Issues Down Moderately
LEAD: The credit markets marked time yesterday as participants moved to the sidelines to await the outcome of several important developments.
As a result, prices of Treasury notes and bonds declined moderately in very light dealings.


Carlton Optimistic
LEAD: Steve Carlton, who for years did not talk to the news media, said in an interview that he expected to win a job with his old team, the Philadelphia Phillies. ''I have no qualms of being able to win a job,'' the 42-year-old left-hander was quoted yesterday in USA Today.
Of his pitching problems in 1986, the four-time Cy Young Award winner said: ''I can't explain it in simple terms, but the only two problems I had the last two years were range of motion and mechanics.

Appeals Board Upholds 'Angel Heart' X Rating
LEAD: An appeals board has decisively upheld the X rating given two weeks ago to Alan Parker's new movie, ''Angel Heart,'' and narrowly upheld by a different appeals board last week.
Tri-Star, the distributor of ''Angel Heart,'' has already announced that the movie will be re-cut for an R rating.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency has begun investigating the dumping of hazardous chemicals at nearly 100 sites along a gas pipeline extending from Texas to New Jersey, an agency offical said today.

J.A.L.-Boeing Deal
LEAD: The Boeing Company said Japan Air Lines had ordered three 747-300 jetliners and four 767-300's, and had upgraded an earlier order in a deal totaling $575 million.
The orders include the substitution of two 767-300's for two previously ordered 767-200 models of the wide-body twinjet.
The lengthened 767's are to be delivered between next September and June of next year, while one 747 is for delivery in December and the other two next year.


NEW LAW LEAVES IMMIGRANTS CONFUSED AND FEARFUL
LEAD: Whether Frank, a 24-year-old Salvadoran, becomes a United States citizen may well depend on the memory and honesty of the man who employed him at a small Bronx factory in 1980.
Frank flew to New York last week from his home in San Francisco hoping to find his former boss.

Atari Profits Up 54.4%
LEAD: Buoyed by strong sales of its ST personal computer and a resurgence in the video game market, the Atari Corporation today reported fourth-quarter earnings of $23 million, or 87 cents a share, up 54.4 percent from $14.9 million, or 64 cents a share, a year ago.
Fourth-quarter 1986 results include an extraordinary credit of $11 million.


Broncos Seek Jackson
LEAD: The Denver Broncos will try to acquire Bo Jackson before the National Football League draft in April, according to Coach Dan Reeves.
Jackson, the 1985 Heisman Trophy winner from Auburn, earlier turned down the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to pursue a baseball career.
He is under contract to the Kansas City Royals but has a buyout clause that would allow him to play pro football.

LEAD: The Northwestern Steel and Wire Company said its directors had reviewed and decided to reject a revised offer to merge with a company to be formed by Bennett Lebow, a private investor.
Negotiations have been discontinued.

Alarm Boxes and Telephones Out In Brooklyn Area
LEAD: A construction crew working on underground cable at Hart and Irving Streets that was severed putting 38 fire alarm boxes in Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant out of commission for 10 hours.
Extra fire and police patrols were added for the area.
The mishap occurred in the same area of Brooklyn where telephone service to 41,000 customers was knocked out by an electrical fire Wednesday.

LEAD: Dennis B. Levine, the former investment banker whose arrest last May led to the unraveling of the most serious insider-trader scandal in Wall Street history, was sentenced here today to two years in a Federal prison and ordered to pay $362,000 in fines.

LEAD: The New York City hospital system yesterday dropped plans to award a $10.5 million contract for new ambulances to the sole bidder.

LEAD: A man was killed early yesterday morning when an Amtrak train with 11 passenger cars rammed his pickup truck and dragged it a quarter of a mile, the police said.


Rumor of Possible Sales To Soviet Spur Grains
LEAD: Rumors that the Soviet Union might be in the market for American grain sent wheat futures prices sharply higher yesterday and spurred advances for other grain and soybean futures.


Model Acquitted in Barbados
LEAD: Jerry Hall, the American fashion model, was acquitted today on charges of possession of 20 pounds of marijuana.
Miss Hall, 30 years old, companion of the rock musician Mick Jagger, was arrested Jan. 21.
She testified this morning that a package containing marijuana that had been sent from nearby Mustique Island was not hers.


DOW DROPS 8.85 POINTS, ENDING RECORD STREAK
LEAD: Stock prices ended moderately lower yesterday on a late wave of profit taking and computerized selling.


THE DANCE: 'COPPELIA'
LEAD: ''Coppelia'' was pleasant entertainment when the New York City Ballet danced it Thursday night at the New York State Theater.
Yet the performance had its bothersome aspects.

Dollar Dips In Advance Of Talks
LEAD: The dollar fell slightly yesterday in light, cautious trading as traders waited to see what finance ministers would accomplish this weekend in their attempt to stabilize currency markets.


Unfortunate Split Can Make No-Trump a Good Choice
LEAD: Players who elect to play in six no-trump, rejecting a 5-3 fit in a major suit, usually do it for match-point reasons: they are hungry for the extra 10 points.


N. Philip Bastedo, 78; Led Hospital Trustees
LEAD: N. Philip Bastedo, a lawyer and former president of the trustees of the Hospital for Special Surgery, died Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.


A LOGICAL SYSTEM
LEAD: To the Editor:


L.S.U. Names Dean
LEAD: The Louisiana State University Board of Supervisors named Joe Dean athletic director from a field of four nominated by a search committee.
A former L.S.U basketball star, Dean, 56 years old, succeeds Bob Brodhead, who resigned under pressure in December after two months under suspension for two violations of the state ethics code.


Norway Oil Output Up
LEAD: Norway's North Sea oil output rose to 1.06 million barrels a day in January, from 1.049 million in December, its highest level since production began 16 years ago, operators said today.
The total is expected to fall this month as Norway carries out a voluntary 7.5 percent output cutback on all its fields in support of measures by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase oil prices by curbing supply to world crude markets.

PUTTING THE PLEASURE BACK INTO GROCERY SHOPPING
LEAD: The size of Manhattan supermarkets will never change.
With rare exceptions, there will never be room for more than two shopping carts per aisle.
But their style, quality, cleanliness and sometimes their service are changing, generally for the better.
A price must be paid, of course, and it is added to the cost of the food.

A PERSONAL VICTORY
LEAD: Mario Cuomo's announcement that he will not be a Presidential candidate should not have been as surprising as it apparently was to most political buffs.
His boomlet was mostly in the eyes of expectant beholders and for months he had been telegraphing in numerous ways that he was reluctant to run, and felt perhaps that he would not.


CUOMO PROPOSING A $1.7 BILLION CUT IN PERSONAL TAXES
LEAD: Governor Cuomo today proposed a new $1.7 billion cut in New York State personal income taxes, a sudden announcement that came just a day after the stunning declaration that he would not seek the Presidency in 1988.


THE MOMENTOUS DECISION NOT TO RUN FOR PRESIDENT
LEAD: When politicians decide not to run for President, it's news.
Whether the reasons they give -especially the family reasons cited by Mario M. Cuomo Thursday, or by Edward M. Kennedy in 1982 - seem to explain it all or not, there is something that seems unusual in proclaimed self-denial by a politician prominent enough to be thought of a serious candidate to begin with.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs.
Theodore Kaplan of Smithtown, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Phyllis E. Kaplan to Martin Stephen Kalish, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Herbert Kalish of Short Hills, N.J.
Ms.
Kaplan is president of Ziba Designs in New York and Bennington, Vt., a designer and manufacturer of fabrics, wall coverings and rugs.

LEAD: The article ''Youth Cases Put Strain on Mental Aid''  [ Feb. 1 ]  includes statements by Dr.
Carolina Hedlund of the Northern Westchester Guidance Clinic that may leave the reader with an erroneous impression - namely, that all private practitioners in psychotherapy charge fees beyond the reach of low-income families.

True Fat
LEAD: Concern about osteoporosis, a crippling bone disorder that afflicts mainly elderly women, has spawned a cynical campaign by the dairy industry aimed at teen-age girls.


Indiana Beats Iowa As Alford Gets 24
LEAD: Keith Smart scored 13 of his 17 points in the first half, and Steve Alford came out of a shooting slump to score 24 as Indiana beat Iowa, 84-75, today in a Big Ten game.


ABOUT LONG ISLAND
LEAD: EVERYBODY I know who once spent every summer at the same ''summer place'' remembers one summer as the End of an Era.
And of course that's not necessarily so.
Memories lie, and they are full of murk.
But such ''eras'' have a way of floating up through the murk of one's memory in winter, the year's murkiest season.


CITY LAW, 7; MENS' CLUBS, 0
LEAD: The men's clubs of New York came one step closer to a reckoning last week when the Court of Appeals in Albany upheld by a vote of 7 to 0 a city law that would force some of them to admit women.


WHAT'S NEW IN JEWELRY
LEAD: EVERY night before Dorothy Noce goes to bed, she flicks on her television and goes jewelry shopping. ''I've bought three gold chains for my girls, five for myself, and one for my daughter's boyfriend,'' said Mrs.
Noce, a resident of Ridley Park, Pa., one of the areas reached by the Home Shopping Network's satellite.


CIVIL ACCORD SEEN IN TOXIC DUMPING
LEAD: A pipeline company that has acknowledged dumping a toxic substance, PCB's, along its right of way is unlikely to face criminal charges filed by the Environmental Protection Agency, officials of the agency said today.


FAST LEARNER
LEAD: If dealing with sudden wealth is one of the things you are supposed to learn in business school, Melanie Richards, a 20-year-old business major in her third year at Baruch College, must have been listening in class.
She bought a Lotto ticket before the Nov. 8 drawing, watched carefully as her numbers were posted on television, hid her $12 million winning ticket in a safe in her Brooklyn home, told no one outside her family, sought legal and financial advice and finally - after coming down with chicken pox and recovering from it - turned in the ticket last week.


A RETURN TO CONTINENTAL CUISINE
LEAD: SAVORIES RESTAURANT in Port Jefferson is a restaurant that is bucking the trends.
A few years ago, before American restaurants were the rage, Savories featured American food.
About a year ago, the restaurant changed ownership, and Savories now serves the currently out-of-fashion Continental cuisine.

LEAD: Greece said today that it had postponed a visit to Washington by its Defense Minister and protested recent statements by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that it viewed as supporting Turkish interests over its own in Cyprus.


WELFARE THAT WORKS
LEAD: 'What we want to do is turn what is now primarily a payments system with a minor work component into a system that is first and foremost a jobs program, supported by an income assistance component.
Our proposal focuses on education, training and employment for the families now dependent on the welfare system, along with a decent living standard with which these families can support their children while they strive for self-sufficiency.


THE DRIVE TO EXCEL
LEAD: THEY KNOW DAVID Kuo well in the mathematics department of the Bronx High School of Science.
They have known him since the first day of his first year, when he told the chairman that he understood everything in freshman geometry.
They gave him a test and discovered he was right; he answered all the questions correctly.


BRAVING THE YAMASHITA 'CURSE'
LEAD: The Yamashita treasure, a hoard of stolen gold and jewelry said to have been hidden in the Philippines by a Japanese general during World War II, has the reputation of laying a curse on anyone possessing it.
That did not stop John K. Singlaub, the retired American Army general, from requesting permission to hunt the hoard in 209 locations.

EXORCISE REYKJAVIK
LEAD: To go beyond their Iceland summit meeting, Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev have to retreat to where they were before that fateful meeting.
Reykjavik now blocks the way to useful arms limitations with grand illusions about space-based defenses and a world without nuclear weapons.
Reagan officials and critics share that view: a summit that turned into a nadir.

Miller said. ''People were calling him names.''

AN ADOBE MAZE FOR MODERN EXPLORERS
LEAD: On a bright day in winter the ruins of Casas Grandes are deserted except for a caretaker hoeing weeds around one of the unexcavated mounds.
He comes to collect the admission charge of 120 pesos (about 13 cents) from the foreign visitors, expresses regret that the government in Mexico City has not yet sent brochures to replenish his stock, and goes back to work, leaving us with the ancient plazas, the ceremonial mounds and the adobe maze all to ourselves.

KNICKS AND NETS: A COMEDY IN FOUR ACTS
LEAD: Nine-year-old kid is being questioned by a judge during a custody hearing.
Judge says, ''Kid, do you want to live with your father?'' Kid says, ''No, my dad beats me.'' Judge says, ''Well, then, do you want to live with your mother?'' Kid says, ''No, my mother beats me, too.'' Judge says, ''Well, who do you want to live with?

DANCE: PITTSBURGH ALLOY
LEAD: THE Pittsburgh Dance Alloy is a company of dancers whose way of moving is appealingly direct, keen-edged and quietly lyrical.
Founded 10 years ago, the group is dedicated to presenting work by a wide variety of contemporary modern choreographers.
But the company was sold short by the five dances it presented Wednesday in a New York debut program at the Theater of the Riverside Church.


THE A B C's OF SKIING WITH THE KIDS
LEAD: Cars in the parking lot at the Sugarbush Ski Resort have added baby seats.
The slopes are dotted with pint-sized skiers.
At the resort's day-care center, 40 children -from 3-month-old Spike to 5 1/2-year-old Justin - are turning graham crackers into graham cracker crumbs while their parents are skiing.

LEAD: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut rank among the top five states in establishing and enforcing programs to protect the environment, according to a private report issued today.

LEAD: FOR a man who had just scored 25 points and grabbed 13 rebounds to lead his team to a 128-122 victory over the Denver Nuggets, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar of the Los Angeles Lakers got a curious reward Wednesday night.
When he returned to the Laker dressing room in McNichols Arena he was served with court papers notifying him that Alex English of the Nuggets had filed suit against him in a court in Denver seeking repayment of $150,000 in debts.

LEAD: An audit by the General Accounting Office says millions of dollars of United States aid to Liberia has been diverted to Government officials in the last six years, according to a summary of the report made public yesterday by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.


IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD: FLIPPING FOR IT.
By Daniel Asa Rose. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) This first novel feels like a detective story, though it's about the pains of divorce.
The dialogue is matter-of-fact; the action, over a four-week period, moves episodically; the secondary characters are colorful and talk cynically, with dark humor.

LEAD: To the Editor: A Travel Advisory item on Jan. 18 heralded the ''first time in its 300-year history'' that Lloyd's of London ''has opened its doors to the public.'' Classical Music
LEAD: There is no doubt that writing for an orchestra is a risky proposition for a composer.

LEAD: TO preserve the dwindling supply of open land for ecological and recreational purposes, Connecticut should acquire another 100,000 acres -about 3 percent of the state's land area - by the year 2000, a state panel recommended last week.


The Job Machine Has Not Broken Down
LEAD: THE United States has had enormous success in creating new jobs - nearly 13 million during the current recovery.
Even though our unemployment rate is still quite high, a larger proportion of our population is working today than ever before.
But some of our factories have closed down.
And more and more jobs are in services.

LEAD: THE sixth graders in Hilary Cooper's class are learning to write research papers.

Cooper said.
For the past month, she has been patiently showing them how to take notes, compile a bibliography, and produce an outline.

Auto Imports

HOW TO GET THE BEST VIDEO TAPE
LEAD: Looking for a good buy in blank video tape is like looking for a bargain in soap.
Pricing depends chiefly on the local store, competing products seem similar, and you can't tell much from the package.
The only guidance usually comes from advertisements.
This is not without value, for some ads can be quite informative.

WINTER'S TALE: TOO LONG, TOO COLD
LEAD: THIS is the winter of my discontent, and like failing eyesight, forgetfulness, and cellulite, it is very much a byproduct of middle age.
I used to love winter.
The brisk weather, the beautiful snow, and the opportunity to ski were welcome, but too brief, changes in the cycle of the year.
I don't love winter now.

Snakeskin And Sex
LEAD: It is true, as Warren Sloat pointed out in his article ''Snakeskin'' (About Men, Jan. 25), that young rattlesnakes are more dangerous, but not because they are quicker.
Older snakes develop sphincter control and save some venom for the next bite; young ones give you the whole shot right off - more venom.


In the Running
LEAD: THEY didn't make it to California for the Super Bowl, but a couple of members of the Chicago Bears will be jetting to the West Coast today in quest of a consolation prize of sorts.
Willie Gault and Richard Dent are going to Los Angeles in hopes of picking up a Grammy Award Tuesday night.
They were among the Bears featured in ''The Super Bowl Shuffle,'' which became a rap hit after the Bears won the 1986 Super Bowl and is one of five Grammy finalists for the best song by a rhythm and blues group.

A SLIVER OF THE OLD BAHAMAS
LEAD: North of the Caribbean and east of Florida is a 1,000-square-mile area in the Atlantic dubbed bajamar, or shallow sea, by Spanish explorers nearly 500 years ago.
And almost lost in the midst of bajamar's opaline waters, tucked in among 600 or so outcroppings of land, which comprise the Bahamian archipelago, is an island whose dimensions are so meager that it could easily be overlooked by more adventurous travelers.


IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD: OUR FRIEND MANSO.
By Benito Perez Galdos.
Translated by Robert Russell. (Columbia University, $25.) Perez Galdos is one of the treasures of 19th-century Spanish fiction. ''Our Friend Manso'' (1882), here translated into English for the first time, reflects his prodigious, inexhaustible curiosity about the human condition and the limits of the novelist's art.


Back to the Field
LEAD: THE salary arbitration season ended yesterday with Dick Schofield, the California Angels' shortstop, winning a $475,000 salary.
Don Sears, the arbitrator who heard the case Friday, awarded Schofield the salary he wanted over the Angels' $305,000.
Schofield earned $210,000 last year.
The final totals for arbitration this year had clubs winning 16 cases and players 10.

When the Jungle Turns to Wasteland
LEAD: FROM New York's Columbus Avenue to the world's tropical forests, the life and death of trees occupied the attention of many scientists at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science last week in Chicago.
They assessed the effects of acid rain in the Adirondacks, issued dire updates on the spread of deserts in sub-Saharan Africa and discussed the benefits of agroforestry, the practice of growing crops side by side with nitrogen-fixing trees.


PARIS WHEN IT SIZZLES
LEAD: EVERYONE SEEMS INTERESTED in what goes on at the Paris couture these days.
Granted, the interest may not be quite as intense as it was in the 1930's, 40's, 50's, even into the 60's, before European ready-to-wear took over.
In those olden, golden days, the Paris couture was the be-all and end-all of creativity.

WHAT'S NEW IN JEWELRY
LEAD: JEWELRY designers are pushing color as much as status and design in their offerings these days.
Imports of all colored stones, from the rarest emeralds to the most common amethysts, have nearly quadrupled over the past 10 years, according to the United States Bureau of Mines.
By November, the value of 1986 imports had reached $368.4 million, surpassing total imports for 1985.

FRENCH WITH AN ENGLISH ACCENT
LEAD: THE LARGE OAK refectory table is worn with the rich patina of age, as well it might be after more than 300 years of use.
The fireplace is a gaping maw where whole boars and lambs rotate easily on the spit.
The light filtering through the lead-paned windows and lapping at the tapestry-covered walls is gentle, like the docile, comforting landscape at Clapham House, the beautiful 18th-century East Sussex manor of Sabine and Patrick Brassart.

Norfolk said it would not match that offer, but Piedmont said it would entertain other offers.

True Progress
LEAD: From the day Thomas Edison first recorded sound 100-odd years ago, man has had to exert himself to listen.

ANOTHER MILESTONE IN CONDUCTIITY
LEAD: In the imperfect world of physical phenomena, superconductivity seems almost too good to be true.
When certain substances are cooled to near absolute zero, they lose their resistance to electricity.
Thus current can be conducted through them without energy loss, allowing the development of more efficient power lines and magnets powerful enough to propel trains.

Turkey
LEAD: To the Editor: Richard Reeves' article ''A taste of Istanbul'' (Travel, Jan. 18) was extremely interesting.
To his elegant list of eating places I would like to add another, one of my favorites, Beyti in Yesilyurt, a small suburban village only 10 minutes from Istanbul airport in Yesilkoy.
This is strictly a meat restaurant, offering a variety of delicious grills, mostly of lamb.

LEAD: Somewhere on a 50-acre plot outside Lafayette, La., a man sits on an old Ford tractor.

No one is nearby.
Cars that pass by the area are as far away as a drive to the distant land of left-center field at Yankee Stadium.
The man on the tractor knows that spot and that stadium well.

Low-Wage Jobs
LEAD: To the Editor:  Barry Bluestone and Bennett Harrison greatly overdramatize the significance of the shift toward low-wage jobs over the period 1979 to 1985 (''The Grim Truth About the Job 'Miracle' ,'' Forum, Feb. 1).
They couch their statistical results in terms of the distribution of the net change in jobs by wage level and by part-time/full-time employment, without showing the corresponding changes in the distribution of all jobs.

Art
LEAD: There was no reason for Robert Bevan (1865-1925) to be anything more than an amiable but predestined second rater.
An Englishman, born by the English Channel, he could have vegetated quietly and invisibly.
But as it happened he had a fund of intellectual and esthetic curiosity that led him to art school in Paris and to Pont-Aven in Brittany when the influence of Gauguin was very much alive there.

Turkey
LEAD: To the Editor: I read with regret the articles on Turkey (Travel, Jan. 18).
I am disappointed because all those places were stolen from the Greeks.
You mention that Turkey is one of the few countries in the world that feed their own people without outside help.
This is correct, but I wish you had also mentioned that the land on which Turkey produces its surplus is the same land the Greeks created and fertilized before the Turks invaded it.

JAZZ WINDS BLOW IN FAVOR OF ERIC DOLPHY
LEAD: History is written by survivors.
In jazz, living musicians deliver final judgments on their predecessors; they decide, consciously and intuitively, what styles and ideas will stay current, and it doesn't hurt if the inventors of those styles are still alive and blowing.
At the moment, as jazz's younger generation rediscovers the 1950's and 1960's, the contributions of such vital, active musicians as Sonny Rollins, Wayne Shorter and Ornette Coleman are justly celebrated.

LEAD: The Phantom of the Opera was at least there, at the opera house.
Last week a report by the State Comptroller disclosed that attendance figures compiled by New York City cultural institutions had included thousands of phantoms who weren't there at all.


SPARE NO EXPENSE, AND ADD THE SAFFRON
LEAD: SOME friends who returned from Spain recently brought me a large packet of saffron as a present.
I was extremely pleased, not just because it is the world's most expensive spice, but because I love it so much in rice dishes and with seafood.


Panel Sets 1988 Limit On Campaign Expense
LEAD: The Federal Election Commission has given the flock of 1988 Presidential aspirants a financial target to aim for as they line up their campaigns: $26.7 million.


East Germans Oust American
LEAD: A 69-year-old American held by East Germany for protesting atop the Berlin Wall has been expelled and sent to the West, a United States spokesman said Friday.
The American, John Runnings of Seattle, had been held in East Germany for three months.

THE MAN WHO WEARS THE STAR: James W. Kinnear; Winning Friends for Texaco When It Needs Them Most
LEAD: MOST of the closed-circuit television cameras that had for about a decade watched over the well-manicured grounds at Texaco Inc.'s Westchester County headquarters have been turned off.
The main entrance is still well guarded, but the uniformed guards are gone from the other gates, where employees, and even occasionally visitors, can come and go, unstopped.


SHAMIR, REAGAN STRESS THE UP SIDE
LEAD: American and Israeli officials did their best last week to ease strains prompted by the Iran-contra affair.
President Reagan met with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and praised ''the close and special relations'' with Israel, ''a major non-NATO ally.''


RECITAL: GIBBONS ON HARPSICORD
LEAD: JOHN GIBBONS presented a first-class program of harpsichord music by Rameau, Bach, Domenico Scarlatti and Antoine Forqueray at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday night.
Mr.
Gibbons, currently a professor at the New England Conservatory and a member of the Boston Museum Trio, plays with a charged dynamism that does not preclude subtlety.

TALKING: Appraisals; Stripping Away the Mystery
LEAD: BECAUSE an appraisal is pivotal to the approval or denial of a mortgage loan, an equity loan or a request for refinancing, the professional real-estate appraiser is frequently held in awe by buyers and homeowners.


SEEKING THE GRAY WHALE
LEAD: From February through late April friendly, giant gray whales -they're about 45 feet long and weigh between 17 and 35 tons - pass the California coast on their 6,000-mile migration from Mexico's Baja peninsula to their summer home off Alaska.
Grays are one of the environmental movement's success stories.

LEAD: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India conferred at dinner this evening and expressed satisfaction at the way they had defused a crisis over troop buildups on their border last month.

LEAD: YES, Dick Howser conceded, there were a few changes in the manager who won the World Series in 1985.

TOTAL IMMERSION IN A FLOOD OF FRENCH
LEAD: My own private dream has always been to speak graceful and fluent French; I have also always wanted to rent a house in Provence.
Last summer, having made arrangements for the latter, I attempted the former; I signed up for the total immersion course at Berlitz.
In my preliminary interview I rated myself somewhere between ''fairly good command'' and ''speaks with proficiency.

TOOTH FAIRY PUTS THE BITE ON DAD
LEAD: GREG had waited for this day for a long time.
He had witnessed his older brother, Chris, losing several baby teeth, followed by the inevitable visit from the Tooth Fairy.
Finally, one of his own teeth had fallen out, and at last he could look forward to the reward being under his pillow.


Turkey
LEAD: To the Editor: ''Where History's Sweep Conquers the Visitor'' by Frederic Raphael (Travel, Jan. 18) was really a delight (Turkish).
It warmed the cockles of our hearts.
My wife and I have been vacationing in Turkey for about six years.
Wherever we traveled, always by public bus, we were befriended by the warmest, most caring people we have met in our travels.

LEAD: A change of tactics proved the cure for Theatrical's habit of finishing second when the Irish horse led at every call under Pat Day to win the $200,000 Hialeah Turf Cup by a neck over Long Mick today at Hialeah Park.

BEAUTY
LEAD: THE INVENTORY AT THE cosmetics counter reads like an anatomy textbook.
Lips, the T-zone from the forehead down the nose to the chin, arms, legs, hands, throat and breasts - all have been singled out for individual treatments.
Today, though, the facial feature of the moment is the skin around the eyes.

LEAD: RUNNING two miles through the rugged foothills of the Santa Cruz mountains, the Stanford Linear Accelerator has been described as the world's longest shed.

Man Killed at Kenyan Border
LEAD: A man of unknown nationality was shot to death just inside Kenya on Thursday after crossing the Ugandan border with Ugandan soldiers in hot pursuit, the official Kenya News Agency said today.
The Kenyan police arrested two of the soldiers and are holding them for investigation, the agency said.
A Kenyan at the doorstep of his house was shot in the leg during the incident.

CALIFORNIA ON A COZY SCALE
LEAD: If you want toys or bicycles in Half Moon Bay, a coastal farming community about 30 miles south of San Francisco, you go to the small blue house on Main Street just across the Main Street Bridge.

IN SHORT: FICTION
LEAD: MANDELA'S CHILDREN.
By Ora Mendels. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) Part thriller, part psychological portrait, part history, ''Mandela's Children'' (the title refers to political offspring) tells the story of Ruth Harris, a white woman brought up in Johannesburg.
An ardent student activist there in the 60's, she is now a United States citizen, divorced, with a grown son.

LEAD: ''H arlem Renaissance,'' at the Studio Museum in Harlem, at 145 West 125th Street, is a serious and substantial historical exhibition, well researched and well installed.

LEAD:  Nonpurchasing Tenant  Question: What would be my position if the owner of my rent-stabilized apartment in a nonevict co-op defaulted in maintenance payments?. . .

C., Manhattan  Answer:  If the owner of your apartment failed to make maintenance payments, the co-op board would take legal action against the owner, not against you.

WHERE DECONSTRUCTION BEGINS

Roman Artichokes, Herald of Spring
LEAD: Italians eat according to the seasons of the year.
Although they import many out-of-season fruits and a few vegetables from Africa, South America and Israel, a truly good Italian cook - and the country is full of them - prizes home-grown produce in a way that many Americans do not.
And what is grown locally is more precious than what comes from even 100 miles away.

TARGET QADDAFI
LEAD: EIGHTEEN AMERICAN WARPLANES SET out from Lakenheath Air Base in England last April 14 to begin a 14-hour, 5,400-mile round-trip flight to Tripoli, Libya.
It is now clear that nine of those Air Force F-111's had an unprecedented peacetime mission.
Their targets: Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi and his family.


WHERE COLD AND FOOD ARE THE TOOLS OF TORTURE
LEAD: MORE gaunt men with prison haircuts went home last week from Soviet penal colonies.
The Jewish dissident Iosif Z. Begun was freed and Anatoly Koryagin, a psychiatrist locked up for exposing the abuse of Soviet mental hospitals, was reunited with his wife.
By the end of the week, Soviet authorities said the number of prisoners pardoned by Government decree had passed 150.

Television
LEAD: Getting James Baldwin's ''Go Tell It on the Mountain'' to television took a great deal of time and dedication on the part of its producers, Robert Geller and Cal Skaggs, but the effort was worth it as can be seen once again on American Playhouse, Monday at 9 P.M. on channels 13 and 49.
It is a lovely film, rich in detail and emotional reverberations.

JAZZ: ELSON AND HORNS

But on his own, Mr.
Elson also composes pieces that combine his studio skills - precise articulation and machine-tooled ensemble riffing - with forays into extended harmony, shifty rhythms and wry humor.

Turkey
LEAD: To the Editor: My husband and I, having spent a week on the Anatolian coast of Turkey last October, certainly share Mr.
Raphael's enthusiasm for Turkey.
We only regret that more was not said about the coastal resort town of Bodrum and the beauty of the Anatolian landscape.
We rented a car in Izmir in order to go south to Bodrum for a few days, and the drive through the mountains and the broad, cotton-growing valleys was marvellous, going past great herds of black goats and the occasional camel.

LEAD: THROUGHOUT Bowie Kuhn's years as baseball commissioner, Lee MacPhail was one of his staunchest supporters.
They even had a common critic, George Steinbrenner.
Ironically, though, it was MacPhail who played a role detrimental to Kuhn in two significant episodes in his 16-season tenure: the resignation he submitted over an expansion dispute in 1976 and his ouster as commissioner in 1983.

Catching Up
LEAD: Dr.
Brent M. Pratley, the former part-time Brigham Young University football surgeon who faced the possibility of losing his medical license when accused of having prescribed excessive addictive medication to players, reached a settlement with Utah licensing authorities last week.
Under the agreement, Pratley admitted failure to maintain records indicating reasons for the prescriptions, and his penalty is that for the next year he will be allowed to prescribe narcotics only in hospitals and will also perform some community service.


Only Rain for the Roses
LEAD: In its season finale last Wednesday night, the girls' basketball team at Carbondale (Pa.) Sacred Heart High School was beaten by Riverside High of Taylor.
The score was 75-32, and play was even more lopsided than that.
Riverside mercifully used all its scrubs after halftime, with the result that Sacred Heart got the upper hand in the fourth quarter, 13-12, the only period all season in which an opponent was outscored by the Lady Roses, who finished 0-19.

DAVID SUSSKIND, TALK-SHOW HOST, DIES AT 66
LEAD: David Susskind, the television producer and one of the country's earliest and best-known television talk-show hosts, was found dead, apparently of natural causes, yesterday afternoon in his hotel suite in midtown Manhattan.
He was 66 years old.
Although Mr.
Susskind had given up ''The David Susskind Show'' last September after nearly 30 years on the air, he was still active and had produced four television specials in the last year.

Insider Moves Seen By Perot in 1984
LEAD: H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had questioned him about illegal insider trading that might have been committed by others during negotiations in 1984 over the sale of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation to the General Motors Corporation.


Simpler Explanations
LEAD: To the Editor:


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: BOXING  Honeyghan Keeps Titles: Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain stopped Johnny Bumphus in two rounds at London's Wembley Stadium to retain his World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation welterweight titles.
Referee Sam Williams of Detroit halted the bout - scheduled for 15 rounds - after 55 seconds of the second round when the challenger, from Mount Laurel, N.J., was caught on the ropes.


Promotion in Justice Dept.
LEAD: President Reagan plans to nominate Richard B. Abell, the Deputy Assistant Attorney General for the Office of Justice Programs, to be the Assistant Attorney General in charge of that office, the White House said Friday.
Mr.
Abell, 43 years old, has been deputy assistant since 1983.
Before that, he was director of program development for the Peace Corps.

YANKS HOPE IT'S NOT TOO LATE FOR JOHN AND NIEKRO
LEAD: The injuries seem to be more frequent and the recovery time much longer as each season passes for Tommy John and Joe Niekro.
They are well beyond their most productive years as pitchers, too old to be considered the centerpieces of any rotation yet feeling too young to simply walk away from the game.


Question Box
LEAD: QUESTION:  What pitcher has been a 25-game winner the most times?
Cy Young, a 511-game career winner who averaged better than 23 victories a season, won 25 or more games in 12 of his 22 seasons, and no pitcher ever did better.
But eight of those 25-game years came before the turn of the century: seven with Cleveland of the National League from 1891-98 and one with St.

This Country Needs Oil From the Alaskan Arctic
LEAD: To the Editor:


Washington Watch; Underpayment Of Oil Royalties
LEAD: VARIOUS states and Indian tribes are winning considerable support in Congress for their renewed efforts to obtain proper oil and gas royalty payments that the Interior Department is supposed to collect from producers.


DANCE: THE JERSEY BALLET OFFERS 'LET'S GO SOUTH'
LEAD: The administrative roster for the New Jersey Ballet Company is filled with familiar names.
The company's two artistic advisers are Edward Villella and Eleanor D'Antuono.
Carolyn Clark, the company's director, Joseph Carow, its associate director, and George Tomal, the resident choreographer, are alumni of American Ballet Theater.


COPTER RESCUES 2 STRANDED ON ICE
LEAD: A 15-year-old boy and girl were rescued unharmed yesterday afternoon by a police helicopter crew that plucked them, one at at time, from a chunk of ice on which they drifted precariously for an hour in Little Neck Bay.


MUSIC: MIYATA PLAYS THE SHO
LEAD: THE sho is a Japanese mouth organ that resembles a diminutive stalagmite and sounds like a bright, reedy, almost excruciatingly pure harmonium.
An instrument of limited range but rare sonic beauty, it is almost unknown in the United States.
As such, Mayumi Miyata's sho recital at the Asia Society Saturday afternoon was of more than usual interest.

LEAD: Nearly five years after it nationalized the country's banking system, the Mexican Government has begun an effort to return at least partial ownership to private hands, but in a way that has raised charges of favoritism and irregularities here.

LEAD: The 23 men and women with AIDS who live in Bailey House, a Greenwich Village residence for homeless victims of the deadly disease, have been denied Federal social security benefits that were to pay their room and board and provide their pocket money.

A Subway Solution
LEAD: To the Editor:


Washington Watch; Updated Consumer Price Index
LEAD: Whenever the Government updates one of its price gauges, such as the Consumer Price Index, the typical assumption of economists is that the revised figures will show less inflation than under the old method of calculation.
They figure, for one thing, that retrospective adjustment of prices for quality improvement - often the result of technological advance - tends to exert a downward bias.


Suspect in 350 Crimes Charged in 2 Rapes
LEAD: A Staten Island man, who the police said was a suspect in several hundred crimes committed over the last two years in New York City and on Long Island, was arrested Saturday on charges that he had committed two rapes and a burglary.


TRIAL OF SUSPECTED TERRORIST LEADER OPENS IN PARIS TODAY AFTER 2 1/2 YEARS
LEAD: After two and a half years of public uncertainty and seeming hesitation by the Government, a trial will begin Monday in the case of Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, the suspected terrorist leader whose imprisonment apparently prompted a bloody series of bomb attacks here last year.

RANGERS FALL AGAIN
LEAD: It happened last night at Madison Square Garden: Phil Esposito covered his eyes and shook his head.
Then he admonished his team during an intermission, and then, at the end of the evening, he publicly chastized three players by name and the team at large.
It seems that paradise with the Rangers came swiftly to a close last night.

THE THEATER: 'FREE FALL'
LEAD: ''FREE FALL'' begins in the cockpit of a small plane floating above the darkened stage of the 45th Street Theater.
A husband-and-wife team of stunt fliers is trying to land at a fogged-in town in Maine - visibility negative.
Lou, the husband, wants to go on to Boston, but Sam, the wife, is at the controls, and she is determined to find a hole in the fog and bring the ship down.

C.I.A. NOMINEE TIED TO '85 MEMO URGING IRAN ARMS DEALS
LEAD: Robert M. Gates, the nominee to be Director of Central Intelligence, agreed to send the White House a memo in 1985 that favored arms dealings with Iran, even though he knew its reasoning was at odds with conclusions reached by his analysts at the Central Intelligence Agency, intelligence sources said today.





HOYAS BEAT SYRACUSE BY 72-71
LEAD: The coventional wisdom against Georgetown this season has been that when you stop Reggie Williams, you stop the Hoyas.


Bacardi to Split Stock
LEAD: The Bacardi Corporation said its board had declared a 1-for-1,000 reverse stock split that would take the company private, subject to shareholder approval at the April 27 annual meeting.
It said holders of fewer than 1,000 shares would receive $41 for each share held, and holders of more than 1,000 shares would receive fractional new shares instead of cash.


Car Runs Red Light And Kills Couple
LEAD: A Pennsylvania couple were killed as they left a casino when a car driven by a drunken driver ran a red light and struck them, the police said.

LEAD: Conservative activists, dismayed by the Reagan Administration's recent failure to advance their agenda, are pressing Republican Presidential hopefuls to embrace a foreign policy in the 1988 campaign that would put them to the right of President Reagan on some issues.


REPORT WARNS OF OIL CRISIS IN 1990'S
LEAD: Declining domestic crude oil production and the growing dependence of the United States on petroleum imports could lead to an energy crisis in the 1990's far worse than those experienced in the 1970's, according to the draft report of a Federal advisory committee.

Music Noted in Brief; Jane Jarvis Performs On Piano at Zinno
LEAD: Simply watching Jane Jarvis enjoy herself while she plays piano at Zinno, 128 West 13th Street, is a refreshing experience.
It is also a reminder that the obviously happy pianist has become a rarity in today's jazz world.
The likes of Fats Waller and Erroll Garner are part of a fading past.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Armteck Corp., New Haven, previously known as the Armstrong Rubber Co., promoted Paul C. James, Ivor J. Evans and Sherman O. Lyon to executive vice president, and appointed Harley Rankin Jr. senior vice president, finance and chief financial officer.


Boarder Babies: Progress, but Too Slow
LEAD: Inez Holder has no grandchildren of her own.
That's one reason she decided to become a foster grandparent to abandoned or abused ''boarder babies'' in New York City hospitals.
Admirably, Mrs.
Holder spends 20 hours a week at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn feeding and cuddling some of the 20 boarder babies there on any given day.


Library Acquires Papers Of Lincoln Center Chief
LEAD: The New York Public Library has acquired the papers of William Schuman, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer and former president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
The collection, which is expected to be available to scholars in the library's music division by September, encompasses 50 years of the composer's correspondence, programs, scrapbooks and speeches, and it documents the growth of Lincoln Center.


BASEBALL OWNERS ARE STRIKING BACK
LEAD: Despite record salaries gained by Don Mattingly and Jack Morris, club owners scored a smashing success in salary arbitration this year.
The owners, who have tried diligently - the players say in some ways illegally -to lower salaries, emerged with the lowest percentage increase in arbitration-affected salaries since 1975, the second year of the procedure's existence.


IN MIAMI, SPEED HAS EDGE ON RELIABILITY
LEAD: Earlier this month Porsche dominated the 24-hour sports car race at Daytona, sweeping the first five places in the opening event on the International Motor Sports Association's Camel GT calendar.


COURTS DEBATE JUDGES' ROLE WHEN GIRLS SEEK ABORTIONS
LEAD: She was 14 when she became pregnant.
She told her mother, and her mother called the clinic to set up an abortion.
That was where the law came in, about the same time as the morning sickness.
A bundle of nausea, anger and fear, she went to the same state court that handles juvenile delinquents, with braces on her teeth and a fullness in her womb.
