LEAD: The Islanders and the Devils have had problems winning in recent weeks, but their game here this evening was a vivid sign they may be headed in different directions in the last quarter of the regular season.

The Strategic Bomber Mess
LEAD: The Air Force has three kinds of strategic bombers - one in the hand, one in the bush and one in the wild blue yonder.
There are B-52's, the newest frames of which were built in 1962.
There is the new B-1 now coming on line but plagued with problems; fixing them could cost $3 billion or more.
And there is the Stealth or Advanced Technology Bomber, due in the 1990's, whose only certain feature is its daunting cost.

THE MAN WHO TURNED ART UPSIDE DOWN, INSIDE OUT
LEAD: Andy Warhol in the early 1960's was the indispensable man of American art - the one who turned everything upside down and inside out and got away with it.
He made paintings that bore no trace of the human hand, let alone of traditional skills.
He made sculptures that looked just like the boxes that came up with the delivery boy.

LEAD: Syrian troops were being welcomed as ''peacekeepers'' by at least some Beirut residents today, as they were in 1976 and as the Israelis and then the Americans were, in some quarters, in 1982.


Tunnels for British Toads
LEAD: The Fauna and Flora Preservation Society, concerned about the mass slaughter of toads by traffic, said today it is working with a concrete manufacturer to build tunnels under a street west of London, near Henley-on-Thames, to give toads safe passage during the annual journey to ponds where they mate.

LEAD: The president of CBS News, Howard Stringer, plans to visit his Washington bureau today to discuss a subject that has the 1,222 employees of CBS News in a state of excitement and dread: CBS News has to be reinvented, and soon.

LEAD: Petro G. Grigorenko, a Red Army general who became an outspoken critic of the Soviet Government, died in exile Saturday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness.
He was 79 years old and lived in Sunnyside, Queens.

John Lehman's Navy
LEAD: Secretary of the Army, Navy or Air Force is an imposing title.
But Presidents often use the jobs for patronage, appointing people with little knowledge of military affairs.
The services adeptly keep these civilian masters busy cutting ribbons and launching ships.
John Lehman, retiring now after six years as Secretary of the Navy, is a startling exception to the rule of ineffectuality.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: The Food Notes column in The Living Section on Feb. 11 gave incorrect figures for the sodium content of lobster and crabmeat.
Three ounces of fresh lobster contains 212 milligrams of sodium; three ounces of crabmeat contains 314 milligrams.

LEAD: MARKETS  Stock prices ended lower in a wild, unpredictable session as the market reacted to Brazil's decision to suspend payments on its foreign commercial debt.
Traders said a sharp drop in stock index futures caused heavy program selling of stocks in early trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average nearly recovered fully from a drop of almost 45 points, but a sharp reversal in the final hour left the blue-chip index 18.70 points lower, at 2,216.54.

IS NOTHING SACRED? CONSTANTS OF SCIENCE SUBMIT TO REVISION
LEAD: A CONSTANT is something that is never supposed to change.
But an international coalition of scientists, undaunted by that definition, has just changed more than 100 of the fundamental constants upon which the work of science depends.

MINNEAPOLIS STUDY PLACES ORIGINS OF 911 CALLS
LEAD: Five percent of the businesses and residences in Minneapolis generated 64 percent of the calls for police assistance last year, according to a study made public today.

LEAD: Harnischfeger Industries said that a group led by Columbia Ventures Inc. had proposed to acquire the crane manufacturer for $19 a share, or about $383.8 million total.

Mobil Offers Notes
LEAD: The Mobil Corporation is offering $200 million of notes due in 1993, at a price of 99 3/4, to yield 7.185 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company, which picked up the issue in competitive bidding.
Rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&amp;P., the five-year notes yield about 42-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.


CONCERT: A RARE WORK BY LOEFFLER
LEAD: CHARLES MARTIN LOEFFLER, an Alsatian composer who lived from 1861 to 1935 and spent the latter part of his career in Massachusetts, is best remembered today - when he is remembered at all - for his ''Pagan Poem,'' a rhapsodic and rather wonderful work for large orchestra that was a favorite of Leopold Stokowski.


It's Raining Red On Gerry Faust
LEAD: When 35,000 people showed up last fall to watch the University of Akron open its football season against little Salem College of West Virginia, university officials had every reason to expect the best from their bold move in the spring.
At that time, they had announced that Gerry Faust would be arriving from Notre Dame to take over as coach and that the Zips would be moving up from Division I-AA to I


Interest Seen In Allied Units
LEAD: Garfinckel's, Bonwit Teller and the Plymouth Shops have drawn the most inquiries from possible buyers of the divisions offered for sale by the Allied Stores Corporation, sources close to the concern said yesterday.


GOING OUT GUIDE
LEAD:  YOUTH MOVEMENT


BEGUN, FREED DISSIDENT, RETURNS TO MOSCOW TO THE SOUND OF CHEERS
LEAD: Iosif Z. Begun, the Jewish rights advocate who was freed from prison on Friday, returned home to a jubilant welcome today, pledging to devote himself to the cause of human rights in general and the rights of Jews in particular.


SQUEEZING STORED DATA
LEAD: MEMORY, memory - is there ever enough of it?


More Tests for Potvin
LEAD: The Islanders have scored 13 goals in their current two-game winning streak, four more goals than they had managed in their previous six games, but the renaissance has had its price in injuries.
There are now a half-dozen regulars missing from the lineup.
Denis Potvin, the defenseman, who left Saturday's game against Montreal with a bruised left knee, will undergo further testing today.


DANCE: 'PAN-AMERICAN'
LEAD: MORAL fervor dominated ''Pan-American Festival II'' at the Emanu-El Midtown Y on Sunday night.
One in a series of dance concerts bearing the overall title of ''Out of the Blue,'' the program featured two choreographic protests against oppression.


Our Towns; One-Man Team: A Game Wrestler Gets Off the Mat
LEAD: According to sociologists, the average teen-ager is getting more complicated by the minute.
However, Gus Dastous is not.
As 16-year-old Gus often says, ''Cycling takes up my summer and wrestling takes up my winter.''


Teacher Is Killed; Reward Is Offered
LEAD: A schoolteacher was bludgeoned to death, and the teachers' union is offering a $5,000 reward for an arrest and conviction in the case.
The teacher, Bertha Rodgers, 47 years old, was found dead Friday in her apartment at 655 West 183d Street in the Washington Heights section.


Private French TV Franchise Sold
LEAD: The French press magnate Robert Hersant and the Italian television producer Silvio Berlusconi have won the franchise to run France's private television Channel Five.
The Hersant-Berlusconi bid was one of two for the network.
The other was from Sir James Goldsmith, publisher of the Express magazine group.


TERROR'S CHILDREN: MENDING MENTAL WOUNDS
LEAD: RECENT efforts to treat and study young survivors of civil war and terrorism have yielded important new insights into the special emotional needs of violence-scarred children.


EXPERTS TESTIFY ON WHITEHEAD AS A PARENT
LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead's personality and her approaches to child-rearing were the dominant topics in daylong testimony today from two mental-health experts retained by Baby M's legal guardian.


30 SEIZED IN COLUMBIA EVICTION PROTEST
LEAD: Thirty demonstrators, including some who had to be carried to police vans, were arrested yesterday for trying to prevent the eviction of a woman from an apartment building owned by Columbia University.


Canada-Venezuela Talks
LEAD: Marcel Masse, Canada's Energy, Mines and Resources Minister, began talks this week with top Venezuelan oil officials to promote cooperation in oil matters.
Mr.
Masse's five-day visit, which began Sunday, is the first ministerial level contact in five years between this member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and Canada, an independent producer.


Researchers Study Dirt In the Diet
LEAD: Researchers working with a grant from a company involved in lawsuits over dioxin contamination are studying used diapers to determine how much dirt from playgrounds and backyards makes its way into children's diets.


AIDS IN THE WORKPLACE: DISRUPTIONS GROWING
LEAD: The number of cases of AIDS and AIDS-related diseases has caused increasing confusion and disruption in New York City's work force.
Employers and employees are reacting to AIDS victims in ways ranging from support and financial assistance to ostracism and dismissal.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q. What causes infestations of lice?
A.
Basically, people get lice from other people, according to Dr.
Stanley Green, an entomologist at Pennsylvania State University.
Lice spread between people who share personal items and articles of clothing.
Lice can infest anyone, regardless of their personal hygiene.

BABY M TRIAL SPLITS RANKS OF FEMINISTS
LEAD: The moral and ethical issues raised by the Baby M custody trial have left feminists torn between supporting a woman's right to use her body as she chooses and opposing the elements of exploitation that seem present in many surrogate-mother cases.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: I very much hope that the pro- cess of restoration, the process of democratization, which has already begun will continue and will bring an end to the repressions of those who speak out for human rights and of those Jews who call for the right of returning to their homeland.
Those are my dreams, those are my hopes.


2 PLAYWRIGHTS SHARE AWARD
LEAD: The Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, which honors ''a woman who deserves recognition for having written a work of outstanding quality for the English-speaking theater'' was awarded last night to Ellen McLaughlin and Mary Gallagher - two American dramatists.


MAGIC SEEKS FUTURE AS KNICK
LEAD: Long-suffering fans of New York basketball who must be wondering when, and even if, all the losing will end, can take heart from this fantasy: Magic Johnson wants to be a Knick.
Honest.
Johnson, the odds-on choice for this year's most valuable player award, said Sunday that he hoped to finish his career in New York with the Knicks.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article on Feb. 14 about Soviet programming being offered on cable television by the Discovery Channel and a column in the Arts and Leisure section on Feb. 15 commenting on the programs described the availability of the Discovery Channel in New York City incorrectly.
The Discovery Channel is carried by Brooklyn Queens Cable Television, a service available in Flushing, College Point, Beechhurst, Whitestone, Bayside, Douglaston and Little Neck in Queens and in the Dyker Heights, Fort Hamilton and Bay Ridge sections of Brooklyn.

LEAD: Lee M. Thomas, the low-key Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, is doing something out of character for the Reagan Administration.

ROUTE FOR RHODEN: WINNING QUIETLY
LEAD: Players were slowly filtering through the clubhouse on the first day of camp, but Rick Rhoden seemed content as he sat at a table in the middle of the room at Fort Lauderdale Stadium.
He had already dressed by mid-morning, already unpacked his bags and settled into the routine that is baseball in the spring.

LEAD: A Federal trustee overseeing the Hunt brothers' bankruptcy cases said today that a Federal bankruptcy judge had scheduled a special meeting this week with the Hunts and two of their biggest creditors.

CONCERT: PORTER-GARCIA DUO
LEAD: AMY K. PORTER and Thomas Garcia form a flute and guitar duo that draws together two attractive musical personalities but seems inherently limited by the repertory available to it.
At the group's Weill Recital Hall concert Saturday afternoon, Miss Porter was a particularly strong performer, technically robust and musically forceful.


MUSIC: WAGNER BY OPERA ORCHESTRA
LEAD: EVE QUELER'S Opera Orchestra of New York makes its reputation putting on operas we would not otherwise see or else by causing distant divas, known by reputation or rumor, suddenly to materialize on a New York stage.


Labor Penalty For Designer
LEAD: Norma Kamali, the award-winning New York fashion designer who glamorized sweatshirts, has been fined $10,000 by the state Department of Labor on charges that some of her workers were producing garments in their homes.


Bally Confirms Trump Deal
LEAD: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Donald J. Trump's 9.9 percent interest in Bally at a premium.
Bally paid Mr.
Trump, whose organization owns the Trump's Castle and Trump Plaza casino hotels in Atlantic City, $68.6 million for 2.6 million shares and conditionally agreed to repurchase the rest of his stake for $15.1 million, Bally said in a news release.


Yves Saint Laurent May Sell Off Units
LEAD: The fashion house Yves Saint Laurent International said it may shed some operations, including part of the Charles of the Ritz cosmetics line that it bought from the Squibb Corporation for more than $600 million three months ago.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Academic Not-So-Freedom at SUNY
LEAD: To equate Zionism with racism has become a cliche of anti-Israel animus.
But is acceptance of this belief, even if bigoted, grounds to deny a professor tenure?
It apparently was at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, dealing a blow to academic freedom, a concept meant to encompass even the most bitter differences of opinion.

FORUM BEGINS TODAY ON AIDS TESTING
LEAD: A national forum beginning here Tuesday will be confronting some of the most difficult and contentious issues posed by the AIDS epidemic, including how far society should go to identify carriers of the AIDS virus.
The extraordinary meeting is sponsored by the Centers for Disease Control, the main Federal agency charged with tracking the spread of epidemics.


Village Inn Restaurants Pick a Kansas Agency
LEAD: Village Inn Pancake House, a 27-year-old restaurant chain based in Denver, has named Barkley &amp; Evergreen Advertising of Shawnee Mission, Kan., as its ad agency.
The budget is $4 million advertising.


TRANSIT AUTHORITY IS CRITICAL OF ITS NEWEST SUBWAY CARS
LEAD: Nine months after they began to enter service, the newest subway cars in New York City's fleet - the R-68's -are performing ''unacceptably,'' according to the Transit Authority, which is considering switching to a rival manufacturer for the final 200-car order.


RULING ON MERGER TALKS DUE
LEAD: At a time of intense preoccupation with takeover maneuvers and insider trading, the Supreme Court agreed today to clarify the circumstances in which companies must publicly disclose their merger negotiations.


U.S.-SOVIET GRAIN TALKS RESUME
LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union resumed grain talks here today amid reports in the marketplace that Moscow had recently purchased up to one million metric tons of American corn.


LED INTERNATIONAL FOOD COMPANY
LEAD: Henry John Heinz 2d, chairman of the H. J. Heinz Company and the father of Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, died today in Florida.
He was 78 years old.
He died at the family's winter home in Hobe Sound after a short illness, a company spokesman, Mike Kelly, said in a brief statement.

The Dialects of Birds
LEAD: BIRDS sing in dialects as distinct to the avian ear as the difference between a Boston and Mississippi accent is to humans.
But there has been a long debate over the significance, if any, of local differences in the songs of a particular species.

LEAD: THE 134-year-old Mount Sinai Medical Center has been driven by circumstance into 20th-century marketing and will soon be unleashing its first multimedia advertising campaign.

A.T.&amp;T. Stock
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it proposed to increase the number of its authorized shares of common stock to 1.5 billion, from 1.2 billion.
A.T.&amp;T. said it would ask its shareholders to approve the proposal, made in its 1987 proxy statement, at its annual meeting on April 15.
The company, which currently has 1.07 billion shares outstanding, said it had no current plans to issue the additional stock.


Condom Brand Reassignment
LEAD: Ansell-Americas of Tinton Falls, N.J., the United States arm of an internatonal condom manufacturer, has assigned its Lifestyles brand to Margeotes/ Fertitta &amp; Weiss.
No budget has been set.

LEAD: Hills of gypsum waste upriver from New Orleans have set off public protests and name-calling that have reached the highest corporate offices in the region.

Crude Oil Prices Slump To Lowest of the Year
LEAD: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products slumped yesterday, at what analysts said was a critical juncture for OPEC in its attempt to stabilize oil prices at $18 a barrel.


Moderate U.S. Growth Seen
LEAD: The United States economy should grow at a moderate rate this year, accompanied by rising inflation and a slight drop in the unemployment rate, economists for some of the nation's biggest corporations predicted today.


SCIENCE TRIES TO HARNESS BACTERIAL OVERACHIEVERS
LEAD: APPEARING as green slime on a damp wall, as scum on a stagnant pond and, as dots and filaments in any bit of soil under a microscope, they are not among the earth's more prepossessing organisms.
But the family of bacterial species known as blue-greens can boast an unsurpassable lineage, eons of high achievement and dazzling creative powers, according to biotechnologists now trying to harness the microbes for the further service of mankind.

Talking Business with Bowers of United Airlines; Discount Fares' Recent Impact
LEAD: At the end of January, Continental and Eastern airlines cut their lowest discount fares by 40 percent on most domestic flights.
The rest of the industry followed.
There was a catch, however: Once a customer bought a ticket, it was nonrefundable.

LEAD: ''THE NAZI CONNECTION'' takes off at the Kennedy Space Center in 1969, as one of the United States moon shots reaches its successful climax.
The focus is not on the spacecraft, however, but on some of the scientists who celebrate the achievement - Germans who had been spirited to this country after World War II.

On the First Amendment
LEAD: The question of how much members of Congress should be paid is very current, what with criticisms of the latest effort to raise legislative salaries.
But it is not a new problem, according to John Agresto, deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, who is participating in that agency's observance of the bicentennial of the Constitution.


'NO TALKING WAS NECESSARY'
LEAD: While being treated for brain cancer, Dick Howser couldn't possibly manage the Kansas City Royals this season.
Deep down, everybody knew that, especially the Royals, who had hired Billy Gardner as a standby successor to the 50-year-old manager who had been stricken midway through last season.
But as spring training approached, the Royals displayed the dignity of granting Dick Howser the dignity he deserved, the dignity he had earned.

Shuttle O Rings in 4th Firing Test
LEAD: A test of a redesigned space shuttle booster rocket today showed that in moderate temperatures O rings prevented the escape of pressurized gases that shot through a seal causing the explosion that destroyed the Challenger, officials said.


Education Board Sets Refunding in Florida
LEAD: With few new financings in the exempt market yesterday, investor demand was strong when the Florida Board of Education tentatively priced $300 million of refunding bonds.
Underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. offered the issue with a maximum yield of 6.74 percent for 6 5/8 percent bonds due in 2013, at a price of 98 1/2.

DR. FRANK A. CALDRONE, EARLY W.H.O. AIDE
LEAD: Dr.
Frank A. Calderone, an authority on preventive medicine and on public health who was a leading figure in the World Health Organization in its formative years, died of emphysema on Feb. 10 at Doctor's Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 85 years old and lived in Old Brookville, L.I.


BILLY SMITH KEEPS HIS TORCH AFIRE
LEAD: In the old days, he could get by with lots of sleep, spaghetti and concentration.
His Islander helmet and broad-timbered goaltending stick were accessories of combat, and solitude was his preferred method of game preparation.
He had a Machiavellian zest for the payoffs of the playoffs, and he bloomed with importance each spring.

LEAD: The Continental Basketball Association today announced a program that will enable players disqualified from playing in the National Basketball Association because of drug use to play in the C.B.A.

LEAD: The trial of Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, the Lebanese terrorism suspect, opened before a special court today, but Mr.

LEAD: The personal computer industry is bracing for the imminent arrival of a new generation of desktop machines whose power and ease of use, some predict, will again transform the way people and companies handle information.

LEAD: FOR the third year, the New York City Ballet has closed its winter season with a special program to benefit the company's Dancers' Emergency Fund.


Perry Is Convicted
LEAD: Aulcie Perry Jr., a former basketball player who became an Israeli citizen and was hailed as a sports champion there, was convicted in Brooklyn Federal Court last night of smuggling heroin with a street value of $1.8 million into the United States.
Judge Mark A. Constantino said sentencing would be set for the end of March.

LEAD: Unless the Administration quickly puts its arms control act together, time may soon run out for an agreement with the Soviet Union.
Just a year is left before the Iowa caucuses, and an election campaign is hardly conducive to serious negotiations with Moscow.

GATT Meeting Urged
LEAD: The United States, as expected, has requested a meeting of a special General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade committee on aeronautical affairs to discuss the United States-European Airbus dispute, a GATT spokeswoman said today.
The request for a meeting on March 5-6 came in a letter to the GATT secretariat on Friday.


SYRIANS ON PATROL IN EFFORT TO KEEP WEST BEIRUT PEACE
LEAD: Syrian troops went into action today within 24 hours of their arrival in Beirut, trading gunfire with militiamen and setting up checkpoints in an attempt to stop the fighting here.


A.M.C. Reports A Profit Again
LEAD: The American Motors Corporation today reported its first quarterly profit in two years: $20 million, or 10 cents a share, on sales of $938.3 million in the fourth quarter of 1986, in contrast to a loss of $6.7 million on sales of $1.1 billion a year earlier.

Harper &amp; Row Publishers Inc. said its board had approved a recapitalization plan providing for the creation of a new class B common stock having 10 votes a share.

LEAD: The chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees indicated today that they were ready to abandon the budget law's $108 billion deficit target for 1988, saying the goal cannot be met without gimmicks.

LEAD: They will not be greeted with open arms but with speeding feet.
Many American women, who once resisted the invasion, now welcome it, and by Friday night perhaps the greatest international array of track and field stars ever assembled for an indoor meet in this country will be in New York.


Japan Vehicle Output Off
LEAD: Japan's production of cars, trucks and buses declined for the fourth consecutive month in January, dropping 3.3 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today, linking the sluggish production to a slump in domestic sales.
The association said that 936,916 vehicles were produced last month.


Surgery for Leconte
LEAD: Henri Leconte said yesterday he would undergo back surgery in Paris in the next few days and miss at least seven weeks of tennis.
The Frenchman said he suffered a herniated disk when he fell while playing in a tournament last week in Indian Wells, Calif. ''I felt a light crack when I fell on my back,'' he said.


COMPANY NEWS;
LEAD: Conoco Inc. announced a $400 million project today that would allow an offshore oil and gas production platform to be used in substantially deeper water than had previously been possible.


News Corp.'s Net Up 21.8%
LEAD: The News Corporation, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch, reported today that its second-quarter profit rose nearly 21.8 percent, to $87.6 million (American), or 32 cents a share, compared with $71.9 million, or 26 cents a share, in the corresponding period in 1985.


The Pits Of Crime
LEAD: What a squalid, no-class bunch of criminals the Wall Street gang was.
All they wanted out of crime was disgustingly excessive wealth.
They had no romance in their souls, no instinct for crime conceived on the legendary scale and not a trace of social responsibility.

THREE WHO REDIRECTED FASHION
LEAD: The exhibition at the Fashion Institute of Technology called ''Three Women,'' which opens to the public this morning, spans economically and occasionally with great beauty the development of fashion in the 20th century.
The women are Madeleine Vionnet of the Paris couture, whose work dominated the l920's and 1930's; Claire McCardell, the leading sportswear designer in New York in the 1940's and l950's, and Rei Kawakubo, the most inventive member of the Tokyo school of design, who began attracting attention from the fashion world in 1981.

POLICE CHECKING REPORTED CHASE OF BLACK YOUTHS
LEAD: The police said yesterday that they were investigating incidents in Queens on Sunday in which a group of black youths were reportedly chased by a group of young whites.
One white youth was said to have been armed with a gun and others with baseball bats.


More Goodyear Plants May Close
LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said that it might close more plants as a part of the restructuring plan it adopted to thwart the takeover efforts of the British-French financier Sir James Goldsmith last year.
In a letter to employees, Robert Mercer, Goodyear's chairman, said that the Akron, Ohio, company would be 12 percent smaller when the restructuring was completed.


Coffee Quota Talks
LEAD: Major coffee consuming nations said today that they were ready to join producers in talks about ways of steadying dramatically reduced world coffee prices through a system of export quotas.
Coffee prices surged in reaction to a report that the International Coffee Organization would successfully negotiate new export quotas.


NETS ARE BESTED BY BIRD'S 35
LEAD: The Nets played well enough tonight to beat most teams.
But their opponents were the Boston Celtics, who have the talent, the poise and the know-how.
And, of course, they have Larry Bird.
Those ingredients came together in the final 4 minutes 44 seconds, and Boston made up for a poor first half and went on to beat the Nets, 116-103, at the Hartford Civic Center.

NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1987
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-10, B4  President Reagan cannot remember if he approved in advance the first American-sanctioned arms shipment to Iran in 1985, said a senior official who is familiar with the President's testimony to the Tower Commission.
Page A1  Limited immunity will be granted this week to some witnesses to compel their testimony on the Iran-contra affair, the chief counsel of the special Senate investigative committee said.


CHICAGO IS ELECTING CANDIDATES FOR MAYOR TODAY
LEAD: With a 19-month primary-election campaign behind them, and more to come, Chicago's voters will choose the Democratic and Republican candidates for mayor Tuesday.
The candidates, in turn, will slug it out in another six-week campaign leading up to the general election April 7.


Hurricane Chief in New Role
LEAD: Dr.
Neil Frank, the director and energetic voice of the National Hurricane Center here since 1974, will soon switch from forecasting to broadcasting.
Dr.
Frank, who is 55 years old, said he had received a ''multiyear contract at a very attractive salary'' with KHOU-TV in Houston.
He will start his new job early this summer, after the Atlantic hurricane season begins and when he becomes eligible to collect his pension for 30 years of Federal service, The Miami Herald reported Sunday.


New Thai Army Chief Confronts Government
LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda, who dismissed the country's army commander last May because of his interference in politics, is now being challenged by the commander's successor.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Gianni Poli, winner of the New York City Marathon last October, withdrew from the Los Angeles Marathon yesterday because of a cold. . . . .
The New Orleans Saints signed Michael Waters to a contract yesterday.
Waters, a 6-foot-2-inch, 230-pound free-agent running back, was a ninth-round draft choice of the Jets in 1985 out of San Diego State, but was cut during training camp.


SELECTION PLAN REVISED FOR TOWING COMPANIES
LEAD: New York City's Transportation Department, aiming to break a longtime arrangement, announced yesterday a new method for choosing companies to tow disabled cars from city highways and bridges.


MORE ARGENTINE OFFICERS FACE TRIALS
LEAD: After a deadline passed at midnight Sunday for bringing court charges, most members of the Argentine armed forces were no longer facing the threat of prosecution for killings, torture and other abuses committed from 1976 to 1983 in an anti-leftist campaign.

LEAD: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, who set world records twice in the seven-event heptathlon last year, was named the 1986 winner of the Sullivan Award as the nation's top amateur athlete tonight.


A GAULTIER SHOP IN NEW YORK
LEAD: Jean-Paul Gaultier has a shock in store for New Yorkers at Bergdorf Goodman, where the French designer's first New York boutique opened last week.


INTRODUCING AMIGA
LEAD: COMMODORE, the Pennsylvania company that makes the C-64 and C-128 home computers, will introduce two new versions of its Amiga computer at a trade fair in Germany next month.
The new Amigas will go on sale in the United States a month later.


Nuclear Plant Hearing Reset
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission postponed the public hearing scheduled for today on a proposal to ease emergency evacuation requirements at some nuclear reactors until 2 P.M.
Tuesday because of the city's snowfall, which shut Federal offices here.
The rule change would permit full-power operation of the Shoreham plant of the Long Island Lighting Company.


D'Amato's Brother Quits Assembly Post
LEAD: Armand P. D'Amato, a Republican Assemblyman from Nassau County since 1972, announced his resignation yesterday from the State Legislature.

Boy Admits Killing for Shoes
LEAD: A 15-year-old boy charged with beating and shooting another youth to death for his tennis shoes pleaded guilty today to a reduced charge of second-degree murder.
Assistant State Attorney Brad Stetson said he would recommend the maximum 17-year prison term for the youth, Levertis Walter Fowler.
Circuit Judge Bill Parsons set sentencing for March 6.


IN THE MAIN, REAGAN BACKS GOVERNORS' PLAN ON WELFARE
LEAD: President Reagan told the nation's governors today that he endorsed major parts of their plan to require the recipients of welfare benefits to work, if able, in return for child care, medical insurance and other aid.


Iran's Threat to the U.S.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration, though publicly proclaiming its arms delivery to Iran to have been an aberration of policy, tells us by its continued overtures to so-called moderates in Iran that its passion has not abated.


GLENWAY WESCOTT, 85, NOVELIST AND ESSAYIST
LEAD: Glenway Wescott, one of the last of the major expatriate American writers who lived in France in the 1920's and 30's, died of a stroke Sunday night at his home in Rosemont, N.J.
He was 85 years old.

AMR, RULING OUT BID, STUDIES PAN AM ASSETS
LEAD: The AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, said yesterday that it had no intention of making a bid for Pan American World Airways Inc. but that it would be interested in considering acquiring assets of the carrier if it put them on the market.


Study to Look at Why So Many Blacks Smoke
LEAD: Researchers at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst have been awarded a $2.5 million Federal grant to investigate why more blacks smoke than do members of other ethnic groups and to develop programs to stop urban blacks from smoking.

LEAD: Leaders of Connecticut's General Assembly, no strangers to partisan quarrels at the State Capitol, had a nonpartisan disagreement today.

LEAD: At the Lockheed Corporation's Rye Canyon research complex in the mountains 30 miles north of here, technicians are busy completing a $58 million state-of-the-art flight simulator capable of creating a stunningly realistic environment for testing cockpit designs.

LEAD: Moses Malone, who has averaged more than 30 points and 14 rebounds while leading the Washington Bullets to three victories in four road-game victories last week, has been named the National Basketball Association Player of the Week.

CYANIDE IN FOOD FORCES JERSEYAN TO BE TREATED
LEAD: A man from Mercer County became sick and was briefly hospitalized Monday after drinking half-and-half tainted with cyanide, the State Health Department announced today.
He had bought the cartonat a local supermarket.


Bonn Accord On Tax Cuts
LEAD: The three parties forming the West German coalition Government announced an agreement today on a tax revision package that would cut the highest income tax rate to 53 percent, from 56 percent.

Della Femina Clarifies Lifestyles Resignation

And he offered a copy of his letter dated ''18 February'' to prove it.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1987
LEAD:  Companies


Shaping Chateaubriand
LEAD: THE most tender cuts of beef come from the long, roughly cylindrical tenderloin, and right in the center of that strip is what is known as the chateaubriand -the most prized cut of all.
This piece of beef, which usually weighs about two pounds and can feed three to four diners, is traditionally cooked on a hot pan with just a little oil.


Advertising; Companies' TV Buying Discussed
LEAD: WITHOUT an atmosphere of communication and trust and without the delegation of enough authority to get the job done, an advertiser company intent on setting up its own network TV buying operation might as well forget the whole thing.


Two Men Sentenced In Bird Stuffing Case
LEAD: A retired Long Island taxidermist and his son who had been found in possession of 293 stuffed birds, including a bald eagle and a peregrine falcon, were sentenced yesterday to prison for violating a Federal statute intended to protect migratory birds.


TREASRUY BILL RATES HIGHER
LEAD: Interest rates on Treasury bills were mostly higher yesterday as uncertainty over rates again caused a flight to shorter-term maturities.


REPRESSION LESS OBVIOUS NOW IN POLAND
LEAD: Two leading Solidarity figures recently wrote a letter of complaint to Poland's Interior Minister.


GARDNER HOPING HOWSER RETURNS
LEAD: In his first full day as the manager of the Kansas City Royals, during a time of the baseball year that usually seems carefree, Billy Gardner said he would be happy to see his predecessor, Dick Howser, return to the job he left on Monday.


FOOD NOTES
LEAD: Weekend of Wine


NEW PAPERS IN LONDON STIR AN OLD-SYLE WAR
LEAD: A city that started the week with one afternoon newspaper had three today.
As a result, it found itself witnessing an old-fashioned circulation war complete with fireworks along the Thames, dancing publishers and exchanges of insults that were wickedly inventive even by British standards.


Inflation Up in Europe
LEAD: Retail prices in the 12 countries of the European Community rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, twice the rate of the previous three months, community officials said today.
The inflation rate for the year ended Jan. 31 was 2.7 percent, the community said.
It said that the highest inflation rates for January were recorded in Portugal, at 1.2 percent, and Greece, at 1.1 percent.


HIS STOCK IN TRADE IS COOKS AND CLOUT
LEAD: WHEN Jonathan Waxman, the celebrated young California chef, came to New York in 1983 to open what is now Jams restaurant, the first person he went to see for advice on staffing was a rubicund and genial former butcher named Marc Sarrazin.
When Daniel Boulud and Patrice Boely, who are today the chefs at Le Cirque and the Polo, respectively, arrived in Manhattan four years ago, their first business lunch was with Marc Sarrazin.

JUDGE DECLINES TO DISBAND JURY STUDYING BIAGGI
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday refused to disband a grand jury that is investigating Meade H. Esposito, the retired Brooklyn Democratic leader, and Representative Mario Biaggi.


A DAY AFTER CARDINAL'S APPEAL, BOMBING SUSPECT SURRENDERS
LEAD: A man wanted in the bombings of several New York City abortion clinics surrendered quietly to Federal agents in lower Manhattan yesterday, less than 24 hours after John Cardinal O'Connor delivered a televised plea for him to turn himself in.


Greyhound Union Approves Contract
LEAD: The Greyhound Corporation said the union representing workers at its Greyhound Lines Inc. had approved a new three-year labor contract with the investor group that is acquiring the bus company.
The agreement, reached last month, reduces the mileage rate paid to Greyhound's 8,000 drivers and eliminates many work rules the investor group said prevented drivers from driving more miles.


IKE VERN
LEAD: Ike Vern, a freelance magazine photographer and documentary film maker, died Monday after heart surgery at the Texas Heart Institute of St.
Luke's Hospital in Houston.
He was 70 years old and lived in Orlando, Fla.
He was a former resident of Manhattan.


911 Service Restored To Phone Customers
LEAD: New York Telephone yesterday restored 911 service to 28,000 Brooklyn customers who had been unable to dial the emergency number for almost a week, a company spokesman said.


A PHYSICIST AND RESEARCHER
LEAD: Dr.
George H. Vineyard, a former director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I., died of cancer Saturday at University Hospital in Stony brook, L.I.
He was 66 years old and lived in Bellport, L.I.


CABARET: KRESTON AND LAHM
LEAD: JAN WALLMAN'S Restaurant-Cabaret, which left Cornelia Street more than a year ago, reopened last week at 49 West 44th Street, with a pair of performers who frequently appeared in the downtown room - Judy Kreston and David Lahm.
Although the new club is normally to offer a different performer every night of the week, Miss Kreston and Mr.


Moslem Terrorists Are Different
LEAD: To the Editor:


OFFICIALS DERIDE PROPOSAL ON NUCLEAR EVACUATIONS
LEAD: Governor Cuomo of New York led a parade of governors, senators and representatives today in a blunt attack on a proposal that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission ease emergency evacuation standards at commercial power reactors.


DEAVER REPORTED TO GET A WARNING ABOUT INDICTMENT
LEAD: Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff and a close friend of President Reagan, has been warned that he must plead guilty to criminal charges or face indictment by a Federal grand jury, people with knowledge of the investigation said today.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: N.B.A.
Lakers 97, Suns 93: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who towers above all other players in total points scored, recorded a first last night: he sank a 3-point field goal.
Abdul-Jabbar, who finished with 19 points, grabbed a long rebound in front of the Lakers' bench and connected on his 3-pointer with 55 seconds left in the first half.

ELEANOR B. STEVENSON
LEAD: Eleanor B. Stevenson, who, with her husband, Willaim E. Stevenson, received the Bronze Star for their work with the American Red Cross in World War II in Europe, died Sunday at her home in Shell Point Village in Fort Myers, Fla.
She was 84 years old Mrs.
Stevenson went with her husband when he volunteered to established wartime Red cross units in European theaters of war.


Oversight Is Faulted In Aid for the Elderly
LEAD: New York City's Department for the Aging exercised ''poor oversight'' of $32 million in contracts for services provided for the elderly in 1983-84, according to a State Comptroller's audit released yesterday.


HUGE STELLAR EXPLOSION DETECTED CLOSE ENOUGH FOR CAREFUL STUDY
LEAD: Astronomers reported yesterday that the gigantic explosion of a massive star has occurred much closer to the Earth than any observed since 1604.
Because such nearby supernovas are so rare, this event is likely to have a dramatic effect on scientific understanding of how stars, galaxies and the entire universe have evolved through the ages.


Texas Flights Delayed By Computer Failure
LEAD: A computer system monitoring flights in the Houston area failed today, causing scores of delays for almost three hours in southern Texas and New Orleans, the authorities said.


COMPANY NEWS;
LEAD: Deere &amp; Company, the world's largest farm equipment maker, said today that it lost $192.6 million in the first quarter, largely because of a strike that lasted throughout the period.
A year ago, Deere lost $26.9 million.

Do Unto Pretoria as We Do Unto Warsaw
LEAD: To the Editor:


School District Bonds in Colorado
LEAD: Cherry Creek School District No. 5 of Arapahoe County in Colorado is tentatively offering $113.1 million of refunding bonds through underwriters led by Kirchner, Moore &amp; Company.


DANCE: ATLANTA BALLET
LEAD: THE Atlanta Ballet has been a welcome resident company of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College for three years.
But the program the company presented on Saturday night was a disturbing one.
The dearth of interesting new ballet choreographers is by now a commonplace, so the program's bland tone wasn't so terribly unusual.


FINANCE BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Barris Industries is offering $60 million of 6 3/4 percent convertible senior subordinated debentures due 2012 at par through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $22.25 a share.


CHINA WATCHERS SAY TURMOIL CUT DENG'S POWER
LEAD: Some China watchers based in Hong Kong have concluded that Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, has been severely weakened in the recent political turmoil in Beijing and may no longer exercise real power.


SLOPES NOW MORE FUN, AND SAFER
LEAD: AIDED by computer simulations that give a better understanding of what happens when a ski pounds against the snow, engineers are making significant improvements in the design of ski equipment.
The advances can be found in virtually every piece of gear from boots and bindings to poles and gloves.


Hallwood's Chief Revives Companies
LEAD: Anthony J. Gumbiner, the 42-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Hallwood Group Inc., has spent 13 years working to reverse the sliding fortunes of distressed companies.
His company is now focusing on financial institutions.


CUTTING FAT WITHOUT ADMITTING TO IT
LEAD: The old-fashioned definition of military discipline holds that when the commander says to jump, the soldier jumps -and asks how high on the way up.


WITNESS SAYS HE AGREED TO 'PAY OFF' TUROFF IN TAXI METER SCHEME
LEAD: A New York City landlord testified yesterday that he agreed to pay Jay L. Turoff, the former head of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, a percentage of his shares in an electronic taxi meter company in exchange for Mr.
Turoff mandating the use of such meters by all taxis in the city.


High Court On Liability
LEAD: The Supreme Court today limited, very slightly, the jurisdiction of state courts to impose liability in personal injury suits on foreign manufacturers whose components are used in products sold here.

Authority Seeking Merchants Who Will Sell Subway Tokens
LEAD: The Transit Authority is seeking local merchants to sell subway and express bus tokens in their shops, the agency's president, David L. Gunn, said.


PARKING BUREAU: STRIDES AFTER TURMOIL
LEAD: Scarred by scandal and barely functioning a year ago, the Parking Violations Bureau lay at the heart of New York City's biggest corruption inquiry in a generation.

LEAD: Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North filed suit today against the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, challenging the constitutionality of the Federal law permitting appointment of a special prosecutor.


SUMMATIONS END IN 17-MONTH-OLD 'PIZZA CONNECTION' TRIAL
LEAD: Summations ended yesterday in the ''pizza connection'' drug case, setting the stage for jury deliberations to begin today in one of the longest criminal trials in Federal court history.

LEAD: Surgeons were transplanting a liver tonight into 7-year-old Ronnie DeSillers of Florida, who received an outpouring of support from Americans after money for his transplant was stolen.

Jordan Gets 34 As Bulls Win
LEAD: Michael Jordan scored 34 points while Dominique Wilkins managed only 22 tonight, and that was about the difference as the Chicago Bulls beat the Atlanta Hawks, 113-103.


SARMA AND STRUDEL
LEAD: THE Mesabi iron range of northeast Minnesota has its fair share of fast-food restaurants and streamlined supermarkets, but it also has a mother lode of ethnic-food traditions from at least 40 countries.
At Mary's Cafe in Hibbing, a luncheonette with oilcloth on the tables and an old-fashioned counter, the Irish cook makes chicken soup with German dumplings, Yugoslav sarma (stuffed cabbage) and Cornish pasties.

RECREATION BARGE WITH POOL AND CAFE IS URGED
LEAD: Departing from its more usual role of critic, the Parks Council, a civic watchdog organization, has been developing ideas of its own for New York City's waterfront, and yesterday it unveiled an unusual one: floating a recreation center, complete with 10-lane swimming pool and open-air cafe, on a barge somewhere along the water's edge.


LAWYER IS SAID TO TIE GARCIA TO BRIBE CASE
LEAD: A San Juan lawyer has told investigators that he funneled more than $4,000 a month in bribes to the wife of Representative Robert Garcia on behalf of a South Bronx military contractor, according to officials familiar with the inquiry.


SEND NIXON TO ARMS CONTROL TALKS AS TOP NEGOTIATOR, CUOMO URGES
LEAD: Governor Cuomo, exercising his new freedom from Presidential politics, today proposed making former President Richard M. Nixon the nation's chief negotiator on arms control.
At the same time, he offered some chilly observations about Gary Hart, the front-runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination.


I.M.F.-LIKE PACT SEEN FOR BRAZIL
LEAD: Regional bankers and others familiar with the Brazilian debt crisis said yesterday that they expected a compromise to emerge under which Brazil would agree to a package of reforms similar to an International Monetary Fund economic program.
In return, the banks would issue new loans and restructure old ones.

NICARAGUA EXTENDING THE STATE OF EMERGENCY
LEAD: The Sandinista-controlled National Assembly voted Monday to extend the five-year-old state of emergency for another year.


WINE TALK
LEAD: ONLY 15 years ago, Louis M. Martini, a Napa Valley winery, marketed California's first post-Prohibition bottle of wine labeled ''merlot.'' Today, 174 American wineries make merlot.
At least 110 are in California.
Success of this nature and on this scale shows how a kind of second-class wine can move into the first class under the guidance of an artful wine maker.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article yesterday about the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize for plays by women misattributed the winning works of the two recipients.
Mary Gallagher wrote ''How to Say Goodbye''; Ellen McLaughlin wrote ''A Narrow Bed.''


BLAZERS BURN PATH DOWN KNICK LANE
LEAD: For three quarters last night in Madison Square Garden, the Portland Trail Blazers paraded freely down the Knicks' lane.


2 RULINGS FOR DEFENDANTS REVERSED BY HIGH COURT
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that police officers who searched the wrong man's apartment in a multiunit dwelling had not violated the Constitution because their mistake was reasonable.


Robertson Davies Wins 1987 Literature Medal
LEAD: The Canadian novelist Robertson Davies has been chosen the recipient of the 1987 Medal of Honor for Literature.
The National Arts Club presented the medal to Mr.
Davies yesterday at a dinner at its headquarters, 15 Gramercy Park South.


A Fan in New Hampshire
LEAD: With the 1988 New Hampshire primary just a year away, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. has enlisted a prominent resident of the state in his undeclared Presidential campaign.


South Korea Seizes 13 And Tries to Stop Rally
LEAD: The Government moved against its opponents on two fronts today, announcing the arrests of 13 purported campus revolutionaries and later seeking to block an indoor rally by the mainstream opposition.


PACERS FIND RIGHT REMEDY
LEAD: The Dr.
Jack Ramsay coaching cure-all that produced 785 victories in Philadelphia, Buffalo and Portland, appears to be putting the Indiana Pacers back on the road to respectability.

LEAD: In the 15 years that William Connell was chief aide to Hubert H. Humphrey, the assistant's daughter, Carey, had occasion to watch the voluble Senator and later Vice President extensively.

DAVID'S 'FAREWELL' SELLS FOR A RECORD FOR THE ARTIST
LEAD: A painting by the 19th-century French artist Jacques Louis David was auctioned yesterday at Sotheby's for a record price for the artist.
Both the seller and the buyer were anonymous.


TAKEOVER CLOUDS FUTURE FOR CARLING CHAIRMAN
LEAD: Pierre Des Marais 2d has been a mayor, president of an aircraft company and, since last October, chairman of Carling O'Keefe Ltd.
But his position at Canada's third-largest brewery has now become uncertain.


Japan's Economy Slow
LEAD: Japan's economy is likely to stay sluggish in coming months as the high value of the yen dampens business, according to Government figures issued today.
The leading economic indicator for December was 50, up from 41.7 in November.
Above 50 implies a pickup; below 50 implies a slowdown.


OPERA: MARTTI TALVELA IN MET 'BORIS GODUNOV'
LEAD: MARTTI TALVELA first appeared in the title role of the Metropolitan Opera's ''Boris Godunov'' 13 years ago and immediately established himself as the Boris of his generation.
The tall and hulking Finnish basso returned to the role of the demented Czar Monday night in the opera's first performance of the season, giving no sign of wanting to abdicate his title.


BENNY CARTER NEARS 80
LEAD: BENNY CARTER arrived in New York from California last Wednesday to start a week of rehearsals for the retrospective concert he will play with the American Jazz Orchestra tomorrow evening at 8 in the Great Hall of Cooper Union.
The concert is part of a continuing celebration of his 80th birthday, which falls on Aug.


Johnson Competing for Starting Job
LEAD: Howard Johnson taking batting practice yesterday at the Mets training camp in St.
Petersburg, Fla.
He is Manager Davey Johnson's choice to play third base, but the rookie Dave Magadan has other ideas.
Page A21. (AP)


Fighting Continues in Taiwan's Parliament
LEAD: Chu Kao-cheng, right, a member of the opposition Democratic Progress Party, being restrained after he and Chou Su-fu of the ruling Kuomintang, left, engaged in a fist fight on the floor of the legislature.
On Monday, about 30 members of the legislative assembly took part in a brawl during a swearing-in ceremony.


Local Bacterium Makes Good
LEAD: In their quest for a new antibiotic, researchers at the Squibb Institute for Medical Research sifted through soil samples taken from around the world.
They tested millions of bacteria, looking for just the right one to combat serious hospital-acquired infections, such as pneumonia and septicemia, caused by gram-negative organisms.

Treasury Plans Dealer Rules
LEAD: The Treasury Department has proposed new rules requiring all entities that deal solely in Government securities to register with the Government and meet minimum capital standards.
The proposed rules would restrict dealers in their handling of customers' securities and set new record-keeping and reporting requirements.


LAWS URGED TO PROTECT IDENTITIES IN AIDS TESTING
LEAD: Top public health officials and civil liberties advocates voiced unanimity today on the need for strong legislation to protect those who take the AIDS test from discrimination and from unauthorized release of their names.


Newell to Purchase Anchor Hocking
LEAD: The Newell Company, a maker of homeware and hardware products, said today that it had agreed to acquire the Anchor Hocking Corporation for $338.2 million, ending a five-month long takeover battle.


Eyeing China's Market
LEAD: American manufacturers eager to open up new markets for their goods in China are organizing a campaign to persuade Congress that nations like China that are experimenting with deviation from a controlled economy are not receiving fair treatment under existing United States trade laws.

LEAD: To the Editor:


A Worthy Cause
LEAD: Greg Louganis, holder of 41 United States diving titles and a double gold medalist at the 1984 Olympic Games, was named yesterday as the winner of the Jesse Owens International Trophy, then said he had begun an educational crusade against alcoholism, an addiction that he began to fight in himself 3 1/2 years ago.


LIBYA'S A-BOMB EFFORT CITED
LEAD: Libya sought to acquire the ability to produce nuclear weapons in 1981 negotiations with Edwin P. Wilson, a former Central Intelligence Agency official, and other arms dealers, according to a report made public today.


2 New Witnesses Tell of Racial Clashes
LEAD: Detectives investigating a series of confrontations between white and black youths in Bayside, Queens, early Sunday were told by two new witnesses that one of the blacks had fired a gun during one of the incidents, a police spokesman said yesterday.


MANDATORY TESTS FOR AIDS OPPOSED AT HEALTH PARLEY
LEAD: A consensus appeared to be emerging today against widespread mandatory testing for infection with the AIDS virus as public health officials began an extraordinary two-day meeting to discuss ways to curb the spread of the deadly viral disease.


William M. Masland, Pilot on Historic Flight
LEAD: William M. Masland, a former pilot who in 1943 commanded the first round-the-world flight by a commercial aircraft, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Manhasset, L.I.
He was 79 years old.


EDWIN McARTHUR, CONDUCTOR AND ACCOMPANIST, DIES AT 79
LEAD: Edwin McArthur, a conductor, accompanist, singing coach, composer and biographer of Kirsten Flagstad, died yesterday at his studio in Manhattan, immediately after giving a lesson.
He was 79 years old and lived in Hackensack, N.J.

LEAD: The 25 assists posted Monday night by Nate McMillan in the SuperSonics' victory over the Clippers tied an N.B.A. rookie record set 13 years back by Ernie DiGregorio.
McMillan's total also ranks among the nine highest in league history.

LEAD: To the Editor:


The President Can't Remember
LEAD: Ten weeks ago, White House aides bridled at the joke about the Iran-contra crisis: What did the President forget and when did he forget it?
As things have turned out, it was no joke.


Murdoch TV Stake
LEAD: The News Corporation, which recently sold its television holdings in Australia to buy the nation's biggest media concern, plans to reacquire a minority stake in the properties.
The News Corporation, an international media company based here and controlled by the publisher Rupert Murdoch, sold its TV interests and other assets to the Westfield Capital Corporation of Sydney for about $555 million.


WILIAM T. FAIRBOURN
LEAD: William T. Fairbourn, who retired from the Marines with the rank of major general and then spoke out against the nuclear arms race, died Saturday.
He was 72 years old.


'GRACELAND' ALBUM WINS GRAMMY
LEAD: Paul Simon's controversial ''Graceland'' was named album of the year at the Grammy Awards ceremony here tonight. ''That's What Friends Are For,'' the upbeat ballad that raised $750,000 for AIDS research, won three Grammys, and Steve Winwood won record of the year.

CORN SALE TO SOVIET STIRS LITTLE HOPE OF ANY MORE
LEAD: American and Soviet officials confirmed yesterday that the Soviet Union had bought 39.3 million bushels of corn, its first purchase of American grain since last summer.


SIZING UP DOLE, HIS STYLE AND HIS CHANCES FOR '88
LEAD: In a move that virtually assures a full-fledged Presidential drive by Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican plans to announce next week the formation of an ''exploratory committee'' for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988.


FARRAR STRAUS IS ADDING A ROYALTY
LEAD: In a break with publishing tradition, Farrar, Straus &amp; Giroux will pay authors a royalty on copies of their books that are remaindered - that is, sold at a fraction of their original price after their regular sales life is exhausted.


NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1987
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-12  The President was briefed regularly on the Administration's Iran arms dealings as they took place, the special Presidential commission examining the Iran-contra affair has concluded, sources say.

Col.
Oliver L. North filed suit against the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, challenging the constitutionality of the law under which the prosecutor was appointed.


MARKET FOR BANK BONDS HALTS AGAIN IN LONDON
LEAD: A multibillion-dollar market in bank bonds ground to a halt today as sellers found that there were no willing buyers for their securities.
The trading collapse left some of the world's largest banks and financial institutions stuck with large quantities of unsellable bonds, dealers said.

LEAD: The American Express Credit Company is offering $200 million of 7 3/4 percent notes due in 1997 at a price of 99.80 to yield 7.778 percent through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

WASHINGTON IS VICTOR IN CHICAGO MAYORAL PRIMARY
LEAD: Mayor Harold Washington, this city's first black Mayor, became the first mayoral incumbent Tuesday to win renomination in Chicago in the last decade.


REDMEN A KEY CLUB TO BIG EAST FINISH
LEAD: St.
John's and Syracuse have never really needed a reason to go at each other in basketball.
Each meeting between the intrastate rivals, it seems, has been for a share of first or second place in the Big East Conference.
Syracuse has won four of the last seven meetings, and the average score of those seven games has been 76-73, with three decisions determined in overtime.


Revlon Group, Germaine Monteil
LEAD: The Revlon Group is negotiating to acquire Germaine Monteil, a small, privately owned cosmetics company, and has expressed an interest in buying parts of Charles of the Ritz.
Yves Saint Laurent, the fashion house, said earlier this week that it might sell some of the businesses of Charles of the Ritz, including that company's cosmetics line.


Tigers Sign Evans
LEAD: The Tigers' first baseman and designated hitter, Darrell Evans, who became a free agent when he was not tendered an offer by the Tigers by Dec. 20, signed a one-year contract with Detroit yesterday.
Evans, 39, earned $760,000 last season in the final year of a three-year contract.
He batted .241 with a team-high 29 home runs and 85 runs batted in 151 games.


INSIDE
LEAD: Law Vague on Birth Pacts  In the absence of laws, surrogate motherhood arrangements are being improvised with no supervision by doctors or lawyers.
Page B2.
Welfare Plan Backed  The nation's governors overwhelmingly approved a plan to require every able-bodied welfare recipient to work or get training.


Zawoluk Sentenced
LEAD: Bob Zawoluk, the former St.
John's basketball all-American who pleaded guilty last month to charges of attempted arson and criminal mischief, was sentenced by Nassau County Court Judge Raymond Harrington to five years' probation with the condition that he get in-patient treatment for alcohol problems.


ROCKET BUILDER CUTS FEE ON SHUTTLE UNITS, AVERTING SUIT BY U.S.
LEAD: The space agency and the builder of the booster rocket whose failure destroyed the space shuttle Challenger have reached an agreement under which the builder will reduce its fees by $10 million and take no profit from $409 million in work needed to fix future rockets, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.


By It's in the Palm
LEAD: Roy Face, the former Pittsburgh reliever, when asked to explain the difference between the forkball he threw two decades ago and the split-finger fastball Mike Scott throws today: ''The money.''


BETTE MIDLER ON BARBARA WALTERS SPECIAL
LEAD: TONIGHT'S edition of ''The Barbara Walters Special'' -on ABC at 10 o'clock - is the 37th in a series of periodic celebrity interviews.
Perhaps inevitably, even as Ms.
Walters seems to become younger and more glamorous with each passing year, even as the ratings remain strong, the format has gone soft in the center and dull around the edges.


Sunny Side Up
LEAD: It's been understood for some time that college baseball's power has gone South: The last 20 N.C.A.A. championships have all been won by Sun Belt teams from Florida to California, compared with eight titles by Northern teams the previous 20 years.


2 Restored Botticellis Are Unveiled in Florence
LEAD: The Uffizi Gallery has unveiled two newly restored 15th-century masterpieces by Botticelli - his ''Annunciation'' and ''The Birth of Venus.''


Justice Diluted in Argentina
LEAD: Some of the most notorious torturers and commanders of Argentina's ''dirty war'' have now been granted amnesty.
A historic process of legal accountability begun on the basis of clear principle has been transformed into an unsatisfying and potentially dangerous mess.
President Raul Alfonsin, who deserves most of the credit for that noble beginning, also deserves most of the responsibility for this unseemly ''punto final,'' or full stop.


STAGE: PORTER SONGS IN 'GAY DIVORCE'
LEAD: ''THE GAY DIVORCE,'' in 1932, was Fred Astaire's last Broadway show.
Retitled ''The Gay Divorcee,'' it was the first film to co-star Astaire and Ginger Rogers as romantic partners.
Our memories of the Cole Porter musical derive primarily from the movie, despite the fact that Hollywood excised all but one of the Porter songs.


CONTRIBUTIONS TO NEEDIEST SET A RECORD
LEAD: With one week remaining in its 75th annual appeal, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has already received a record amount of contributions - $3,012,124.06.
The previous record was $2,726,331.40, set in last year's campaign.
The current appeal ends on March 3.
Contributions came from the Lucy Foundation in Manhattan, $100; Julie and Eugene DeWitt of Manhattan, $250; Louise and Andrew Bergman of Manhattan, $1,000; D.


Iowa Lieutenant Governor to Lose Farm to Foreclosure
LEAD: Lieut.
Gov.
Jo Ann Zimmerman last year on her family's farm.
She and her husband, Tom, are slated to have their home in Waukee sold at auction next week to satify a mortgage.
They also face foreclosure on 292 acres about 25 miles away on which they raise cattle.
She won election last year by appealing to distressed farmers.


51 SITES OF PCB IN 12 STATES NAMED BY HOUSTON CONCERN
LEAD: A Houston-based gas pipeline company today released the names of 51 sites in 12 states where it has acknowledged burying toxic PCB's.
The largest number, 17, are in southern Pennsylvania.

LEAD: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth expressed concern yesterday about the growing number of grievances in baseball and threats of legal action against the club owners.
But Tom Reich, a lawyer and player agent deeply involved in the ongoing free-agent dispute, suggested that the commissioner's concern was misplaced.

NEW PRESSES SPUR DETROIT PRODUCTIVITY
LEAD: ABOUT half-a-dozen men stand around anxiously eyeing their watches as three enormous sets of stamping dies slide out of the press line and another group of dies advances on a conveyor to take their place.
As a problem with automated transfer arms causes the minutes to tick on, brows knit in frustration.

LEAD: The Nets lost again tonight, and Chuck Daly, the coach of the Detroit Pistons coach, explained why.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: ONE recent evening a neighbor arrived in my kitchen after I had finished the advance preparation for cooking a chateaubriand, which was on my work counter uncooked.
A puzzled look crossed my friend's face and he asked, ''What cut of beef is that?'' It occurred to me at that moment that probably not one person in a hundred would be able to identify a chateaubriand, perhaps the most coveted piece of beef of all.

The winning dog was Ch.
Mshindaji's Special K.

LEAD: The announcements last week of next year's seasons at the Metropolitan and New York City Operas reflect not only the delicate attempts of each company to balance finite resources against artistic responsibility, but also a renewed cooperation that in another field might raise the eyebrows of a finicky antitrust lawyer.

LEAD: The Flamingo Stakes here Saturday begins the countdown to the Kentucky Derby nine weeks later, which means that the syrupy sentiment surrounding that race will begin to flow: Owners will remember the night the old mare delivered the little foal who has grown into a Derby dream, and trainers will recall that magical morning workout when their colt first flashed the glimmer of brilliance that could win him the coveted roses at Churchill


Class Experiment Injures 17
LEAD: Seventeen junior high school students were injured today when a science experiment went awry, the authorities in this southern Illinois community said.
A police dispatcher said a reaction between water and sodium was believed to have caused an explosion.
Five students were admitted to nearby hospitals, most with face burns and eye problems and 12 were treated and released, according to hospital spokesmen.

LEAD: Taylor Mattingly was getting anxious to leave.
He tugged gently at his father's ear, shifted from one lap to the other, then finally won his freedom and was placed on the clubhouse floor amid a crowd of reporters.
But he did not stray far.


PANEL ON THE HOMELESS URGES DOUBLING-UP IN APARTMENTS
LEAD: The growth in the number of homeless families in New York City could be limited if state and Federal policies were changed to encourage single adults and families to share apartments, a mayoral commission said yesterday.


SHULTZ AND DODD IN SHARP EXCHANGE
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz accused a member of Congress today of undermining the Reagan Administration's policy in Central America by trying to run his ''own foreign policy.''


METROPOLITAN DIARY
LEAD: LETTER from our friend the Daydreamer:


The Color of Money
LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, fresh from an international meeting in Paris on currency exchange, appeared on Capitol Hill Tuesday sporting a vivid emerald green necktie.
He told reporters he had adopted the fashion note because ''it's the color of the dollar.'' Economic analysts interpreted this as evidence that the Secretary, accused in the past of ''talking down the dollar,'' had committed himself to strengthening its position on world markets.


Klaus Barbie Trial in May
LEAD: Klaus Barbie, the Gestapo chief of Nazi-occupied Lyons, will go on trial May 11 on charges of crimes against humanity, court officials said today.
Mr.
Barbie, 73 years old, is accused of having deported hundreds of Jews and Resistance members to death camps.


MID-FEBRUARY AUTO SALES FELL 25.8%
LEAD: Sales of new domestically assembled cars fell 25.8 percent in the middle 10 days of February despite rebates, subsidized financing and other incentives, the nation's eight major manufacturers reported today.


CONCERT: ACADEMY OF ANCIENT MUSIC
LEAD: A PERFECTLY unified attack of wind instruments is one of the trickier things to obtain in orchestral playing, and ''authentic'' period wind instruments are supposed to be especially difficult to play, so Christopher Hogwood and the Academy of Ancient Music scored something of a point with their very first sound in Avery Fisher Hall Sunday evening: a beautifully blended, clean, unanimous and well-tuned entry of flute, oboes and bassoon in the opening bar of Schubert's Fifth

2 Children Are Found Dead In Burning House in Queens
LEAD: Two children were found dead yesterday in the attic of a burning house in Queens, fire officials said.


Crude Oil Prices Drop To Under $17 a Barrel
LEAD: Oil futures prices slumped below $17 a barrel yesterday, reaching a level last seen before OPEC agreed to curtail production in December.


French TV Battle Grows as Rightist Wins Contract
LEAD: A battle over political interference in French journalism intensified Monday when a business group dominated by a rightist press baron was awarded a television franchise that France's conservative Government took back from its original owners, accusing them of being Socialist sympathizers.


Go, Army!
LEAD: Always eager to bestow some international glitter on his race, Fred Lebow, director of the New York City Marathon, traveled abroad a few weeks back and, at the very least, came up with his fair share of brass.
While taking in the Manila Marathon, Lebow was approached by Gen.
Fidel V. Ramos, the Chief of Staff of the Philippine armed forces.


Teacher Shot Outside School
LEAD: Two men with handguns fired at a teacher today, hitting her with one shot, just after she had brought her 4-year-old daughter to nursery school, the police said.
The authorities said they had no motive or witnesses.
The teacher, Leonette Taylor-Coleman, 38 years old, of New Rochelle, was admitted to New Rochelle Hospital with a bullet wound to the buttocks and was in stable condition, said a spokesman for the hospital, Frank Hall.


More Matters Than the Money Markets
LEAD: Key finance ministers met in the opulent chambers of the Louvre last weekend and agreed to the minimum.
They pledged to juice up the West German and Japanese economies and cut the American budget deficit.
On the diving dollar, which prompted the meeting, they concluded that it has dropped enough for now, and that it's time for a breather.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: In voting by the Boxing Writers Association of America, Mike Tyson, the undefeated World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, has been named winner of the Edward J. Neil Memorial award as the 1986 fighter of the year. . . .
Vinny Pazienza, undefeated in 18 pro bouts, will meet the International Boxing Federation lightweight champion, Greg Haugen, at the Providence Civic Center in May, according to Lou Duva, Pazienza's manager.


Mission to Start Liquidation
LEAD: A state Superior Court judge today approved the liquidation of the Mission Insurance Company and four subsidiaries.
The decision ends a long struggle by the State Department of Insurance to keep the units afloat and shifts the burden of about 13,000 liability claims to a state guaranty fund.


This Mitt Calls For a Big Hand
LEAD: Jesse Orosco's magical flying glove, the one that seemingly defied gravity and never came down after the Met reliever flung it into the air in triumph at the conclusion of both the league playoffs and the World Series last year, is enchanted after all.


TV TAKING A FRANK LOOK AT BETTY FORD'S DRAMA
LEAD: Most television biographies of famous people have turned out to be unabashed glorifications of their subjects. ''The Betty Ford Story,'' which is to be shown Monday on ABC with Gena Rowlands starring as Mrs.
Ford, is something of an exception.
While it is clearly sympathetic to the former First Lady, the main focus of the two-hour television drama is her alcoholism and drug dependency during the years after Gerald Ford lost the Presidential election of 1976.


Change of Emphasis
LEAD: Saying it cannot keep pace with the growing cost of maintaining Division I athletic programs, Utica College in upstate New York will drop all of its National Collegiate Athletic Association programs to Division III in 1988, President Lansing Baker said yesterday.
Utica will be unclassified during the 1987-1988 academic year.


22 SHIITES FROM PARTY OF GOD DIE FIGHTING SYRIANS IN BEIRUT
LEAD: Syrian troops killed 22 Shiite Moslem militants in hand-to-hand combat and 3 Druse militiamen in West Beirut today, police and hospital authorities said.


PANEL SAID TO FIND REAGAN WAS TOLD OF IRAN DEALINGS
LEAD: The Tower Commission has concluded that President Reagan, far from being remote from the Administration's Iran arms dealings, was briefed on them regularly as they took place, according to officials familiar with the commission's report.


West Virginia Upsets Temple
LEAD: Tyrone Shaw scored 16 points and West Virginia used an effective box-and-one defense to upset Temple, 64-61, in an Atlantic-10 Conference game, snapping the Owls' 15-game winning streak.


Litton Acquisition
LEAD: In its second deal in two days, Litton Industries said it had agreed to acquire the Lamb Technicon Corporation for more than $100 million in stock.
Lamb, which is based in Warren, Mich is a leading supplier of manufacturing systems for the domestic and international automotive industry.

Economic Scene; Dollar Accord: A Timely Step
LEAD: AS it turned out, after all the delays, the meeting of the Group of Five to Seven in Paris -it turned out to be a Group of Six because Italy walked out - was well timed.
For, without the Paris agreement, the decision of Brazil last Friday to suspend interest payments on medium- and long-term foreign debt could have caused the dollar to go into a free fall.

LEAD: The United States Justice Department has widened its probe of money transfers through Switzerland in the Iran-contra arms controversy to 21 persons and companies, including a Florida-based concern that may have received profits from the arms sales and transferred them to rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government,


ESCAPED PRISONER CAPTURED
LEAD: An inmate who rode out of the maximum security prison here on a movie crew's truck was recaptured in South Dakota, officials said today.
The prisoner, Daniel F. Duane, 32 years old, was arrested Monday night in Rapid City, S.D., by a trooper who noticed that a tail light was out on the automobile he was driving, officials said.


Dollar Declines in U.S. After Gaining Abroad
LEAD: The dollar turned lower against most key currencies in domestic trading yesterday after firming in overseas markets.
Trading reflected a reluctance among dealers to take any major positions following the weekend currency agreement.

FOSSILS ARE FASHIONABLE
LEAD: 1.Links to the Past  Kris Perry is inspired by fossils she picks up on the beach in Florida, and she uses them in her designs for cuff links and money clips.
Some of the fossils are trilobites, invertebrate insects that lived 550 million years ago.
The cuff links, in sterling silver, cost $29.50 and can be found at Gorsart Clothes, 9 Murray Street, between Church Street and Broadway.

On the Road to a Shuttle Launching
LEAD: A NASA technician examining the underside of the Space Shuttle Discovery yesterday in Cape Canaveral, Fla.
The Discovery is being prepared for a scheduled launching next February in what will be the first shuttle flight since the Challenger exploded in January 1986, killing all seven crew members.


Drug Stocks Help Dow Advance 6.74, to 2,223.28
LEAD: With drug stocks providing a pocket of strength in an otherwise sloppy market, Wall Street was able to move ahead slightly yesterday although trading volume was much lighter.


SOME WRITE-OFFS NOW HARDER
LEAD: For years, many individuals have looked to the tax code for help in subsidizing some of their more costly personal possessions, such as luxury cars and home computers.


HUGHES TIE TO BAKER HITS SNAG
LEAD: The Hughes Tool Company yesterday objected to a consent decree being worked out to settle antitrust objections to its proposed merger with the Baker International Corporation.


Saab-Scandia Net Up
LEAD: Saab-Scandia A.B., the Swedish automotive group, said today that it increased its 1986 earnings by 14.6 percent, largely because of booming heavy truck sales.
The president, Georg Karnsund, said the company made a pretax profit of 3.32 billion crowns, or $510 million, on sales of 35.22 billion crowns, or $5.41 billion, with the truck division accounting for about two-thirds of earnings.


Getty Museum Is Buyer Of David's 'Farewell'
LEAD: The curator of paintings of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., Myron Laskin, said yesterday that the museum had purchased Jacques Louis David's ''Farewell of Telemachus and Eucharis'' at Sotheby's in New York on Tuesday.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo, who had already scheduled 14 trips this year to various parts of the United States, said yesterday that he was also planning a series of trips to foreign countries.


TW Service Chairman Is Planning to Retire
LEAD: After a provocative career in which he sold Trans World Airlines, liquidated its parent company and formed its smaller successor, TW Services Inc., L. Edwin Smart, said yesterday that he would retire as chairman and chief executive officer on April 22.


The Tempered Dole
LEAD: When he ran unsuccessfully as the Republican candidate for Vice President in 1976, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas developed a reputation - some political professionals said it was a liability -for being especially sarcastic in attacks on his opponents.
Now, as a probable Presidential contender, he has tempered his language somewhat, though he remains one of the wittier people in public life.


Reagan Meets With Blacks on Education Cuts
LEAD: President Reagan met with the Rev.
Jesse Jackson and two other prominent blacks today to discuss the impact the Administration's proposed 1988 budget cuts might have on education on poor children and working-class families.


Rainier Agreement
LEAD: The proposed acquisition of the Rainier Bancorporation was approved today by the board of the Security Pacific Corporaton of Los Angeles.
The transaction, expected to be completed in the third quarter after shareholder and regulatory approval, would form a corporation with assets of more than $72 billion, with the Seattle-based Rainier contributing $9.2 billion.

KOCH GETS PERSONNEL REPORT ON POLICE
LEAD: A special mayoral committee, issuing its final report, yesterday recommended extensive changes in the way the New York City Police Department recruits, trains, promotes and manages its 28,000 officers.


Pagliarulo Works Hard, Rain or Shine
LEAD: By the time the players arrived and dressed, the field was already soaked by an overnight rain.
Lou Piniella, the Yankee manager, had wanted to conduct a full workout today, but the conditions made anything like infield drills or batting practice too difficult.
And yet Mike Pagliarulo did not seem disturbed.

G.S. Musulin, Who Got G.I.'s Out of Yugoslavia, Dies at 72
LEAD: George S. Musulin, a World War II veteran who helped evacuate 400 American airmen from Nazi-occupied Yugoslavia in 1944, died Saturday of complications of diabetes at the age of 72.
He lived in McLean, Va..
