JOYNER LOOKS UP TO HIS LITTLE SISTER
LEAD: Al Joyner regarded his sister with a mixture of respect and affection.
After all, she was the first Joyner to bring a trophy to their home in East St.
Louis, Ill.
Now, he talks often and easily about her accomplishments as America's top female athlete, and what she has meant to him.
Meanwhile, she eyes him as a mischievous older brother, someone she has to keep under control.

LEAD: It didn't take Hubie Brown long to find a niche following his dismissal by the Knicks nearly three months ago.
He has worked as a television commentator for the Detroit Pistons and will work for CBS during the national collegiate tournament in March and the National Basketball Association playoffs.

'How Men Think'

A COMPETITION INVIGORATES THE THEATER LANDSCAPE
LEAD: THE presentation this week of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize to Mary Gallagher and Ellen McLaughlin for their plays ''How to Say Goodbye'' and ''A Narrow Bed,'' respectively, reaffirms the contribution made to the theater by this prestigious competition.
For nine years, the Blackburn Prize - named in honor of the late American actress Susan Smith Blackburn - has been awarded to a woman for writing an outstanding English-language play.

IN SHANGHAI, PROGRAMS THAT EMPLOY THE ELDERLY
LEAD: ON Sundays especially, the crowds are so thick on Nanjing Street, Shanghai's Madison Avenue, that they spill into the road, impeding bicycle and automobile traffic.
Through this flood of shoppers, like salmon fighting their way upstream, old men with battery-powered megaphones and red armbands reading ''On Duty'' weave in and out, shouting: ''Be careful of pickpockets.


Talking Deals; Gambling On a Novel
LEAD: WHEN James Clavell negotiated a $5 million advance for the rights to his novel ''Whirlwind'' last year, everyone in the publishing industry knew he had carved out a good deal for himself.
No author had ever been guaranteed such a sum.
And, based on a reading of the first 200 pages of the book, several other publishers were convinced it was not of the caliber of his previous best sellers, including ''Tai-Pan,'' ''Shogun'' and ''Noble House.


Accord on 'USX'
LEAD: The USX Telecenters Corporation, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it would change its name after an out-of-court cash settlement with the giant USX Corporation, formerly known as the United States Steel Corporation.
USX Telecenters, a telephone retailing franchiser that had trademark rights to its name, had filed suit against the giant steelmaker in July after learning it had switched its name to USX.

Ecuador Wants Further Delay
LEAD: Ecuador, which stopped interest payments on its $5.4 billion in private debt last month, said today that it wants to continue the debt suspension until June.

SOVIET CONDUCTS A NUCLEAR TEST
LEAD: The Soviet Union today conducted its first nuclear test in more than a year and a half, exploding a device on its testing range in Soviet Kazakhstan.

LEAD: Hans W. Becherer, executive vice president of Deere &amp; Company, has been named president and chief operating officer, making him the heir apparent to Robert A. Hanson, Deere's 62-year-old chairman.


FROM 'HOW TO' TO HISTORY
LEAD: BOOKS devoted to architecture and design are traditionally vehicles for showing, not telling - pages of breathtaking photographs supplemented by little more than glorified captions.
Now some current design books have surprisingly interesting and scholarly texts, while some how-to manuals are presented in true coffee-table form - large formats, full-color photographs and brief texts.

LEAD: A private fund-raiser said today that Lieut.
Col.

LEAD: The dollar ended slightly lower against most major currencies in very light trading yesterday, as many dealers remained on the sidelines awaiting further clues on the state of the American economy.

LEAD: A San Juan, P.R., lawyer said yesterday that he was unaware that legal fees he received from the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, might have been intended as bribes for Representative Robert Garcia of the Bronx.

JUDGE BARS INDICTMENT OF DEAVER TO MULL CONSTITUTIONAL CHALLENGE
LEAD: A special prosecutor said today that he would ask a Federal grand jury to indict Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff, on four counts of perjury.
But a Federal district judge temporarily barred any indictments after Mr.
Deaver's lawyers challenged the constitutionality of the law authorizing appointment of special prosecutors.


3 MEN ACCUSED OF ROLE IN FRAUD FOR $3 MILLION
LEAD: A Queens lawyer and two other men were charged yesterday in the theft of $3 million in real estate from an 85-year-old Greenwich Village widow.
Prosecutors said she was tricked into signing the transfer papers and left destitute.


FOREMAN'S SECOND WIND
LEAD: On the road outside Houston that chilly morning several months ago, George Foreman had run his four miles.
As a boxer who became the world heavyweight champion after he dethroned Joe Frazier in a second-round knockout in Jamaica in 1973 until he was knocked out by Muhammad Ali in Zaire in 1974, he had never done more than four miles in his morning roadwork.


Jordan in Line for Post
LEAD: Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff under President Jimmy Carter, is expected to be named the executive director of the Assocation of Tennis Professionals at a news conference in Key Biscayne, Fla., today.
The association represents the male players on the Grand Prix tour.
Jordan, who is 42 years old and lives in Atlanta, was one of five candidates interviewed by a search committee formed last September when Mike Davies was dismissed as the executive director.


RECITAL: JUDITH BETTINA
LEAD: JUDITH BETTINA is that welcome rarity, a contemporary music specialist who has a beautiful voice.
That is an advantage bestowed only occasionally on music like Milton Babbitt's or on brand new songs, of which Miss Bettina offered nine in the course of her recital Tuesday at Merkin Concert Hall.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article yesterday about the discovery of a supernova misstated the distance to the exploding star.
The supernova is 50,000 parsecs, or 163,000 light years, from Earth.

POLITICS AND FRUGALITY
LEAD: As chairman of the Budget Committee, Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, could be assured lots of big campaign contributions if he would seek them.
But when he announced yesterday that he would seek another term next year, he vowed once again to accept no contribution over $100 and to accept nothing at all from political action committees.

LEAD: The dropout rate of New York City high school students last year was significantly higher than reported by the Board of Education, an educational-monitoring group said yesterday.


No Viacom Reply On Redstone Offer
LEAD: Viacom International Inc. failed to respond to a revised bid for the company by Sumner Redstone, whose Arsenal Holdings Inc. is trying to acquire Viacom.
Mr.
Redstone, who already controls 19.6 percent of Viacom's stock, had requested an answer by yesterday afternoon.
Sources close to Viacom said that its board had a regularly scheduled meeting today and would consider the proposal at that session.


THE JAMES BOND OF ANTIQUE DEALERS
LEAD: His name is Lovejoy, and he is the sharpest antiques dealer in East Anglia.
He scowls at a pair of fake Regency flintlocks.
He sighs over a perfect jade carving.
And he is full of pithy observations: ''Greed, desire, love and death.
In the antiques world you get them all.''

LEAD: The film director John Landis ended his testimony Tuesday in the manslaughter trial resulting from three deaths in the ''Twilight Zone'' set, saying that he had believed the fatal film scene was safe as planned but that he would never film it again.

CONCERT: RUDOLF FIRKUSNY AND THE JUILLIARD QUARTET
LEAD: THERE were no musicians taking part in Tuesday evening's concert at the 92d Street Y who had studied with Mozart or Schumann, possibly through an oversight of the management.
However, the other composer on the program, Leos Janacek, was fortunate in having a prize pupil to champion his music.
Rudolf Firkusny, who began piano studies in Czechoslavakia at age 5 with Janacek, is probably the strongest surviving link with one of the 20th century's quirkier geniuses.

LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission has ordered the Orkin Exterminating Company to roll back fees for about 200,000 customers who had signed lifetime agreements.

Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about fundamental scientific constants misstated the newly established value of Avogadro's Number, a constant used in chemical calculations.
It is 6.0221367 X 10#2#3.

'Gray Market' Ruling
LEAD: The Federal Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has upheld a ruling that permits ''gray market'' trading.
The ruling, which involved a suit filed on behalf of Cal Circuit Abco of Woodland Hills, Calif., held that buying foreign goods cheaply overseas and reselling them in the United States without concealing their origin does not violate the trademark rights of an American subsidiary of the manufacturer.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.Our 25-year-old brick house has aluminum windows and a gas furnace in the basement.
The basement is just high enough to store garden equipment, but it is too wet for general storage.
At one end it is only two feet above the ground.
The windows in the house are completely wet with condensation all winter, and the outside walls and ceilings in several rooms are covered with mildew.

CONCERT: COLUMBUS BRASS
LEAD: THE Columbus Brass -named for the avenue, rather than the explorer or the town in Ohio - presented an engaging debut at Merkin Concert Hall Monday night.
The members of the group - David Bilger and Alex Holton, trumpeters, Kenn Finn, trombonist, Cynthia Jersey, hornist, and Andrew Rodgers, tubist - play with expertise, humor, musicality and collegial warmth.


VINCENT H. HERRMANN
LEAD: Vincent H. Herrmann, a retired government bond dealer on Wall Street, died Tuesday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I.
He was 80 years old and lived in Mattituck, L.I.

LEAD: Improvement of the Air Force's troubled B-1B strategic bomber, needed to make the plane capable of slipping past newly identified Soviet defenses, will cost billions of dollars in coming years, according to senior Air Force, Congressional and industry officials.

LEAD: Milos Forman's film ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' is closing here after a run of 573 straight weeks, the distributor said today.


Home Shopping Game on CBS
LEAD: Home Shopping Network Inc. said it would start broadcasting in June a half-hour program on all four television stations owned and operated by CBS.
The program, called ''The Home Shopping Game Show,'' will be broadcast five times a week on CBS stations in New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and Philadelphia.


Driver Accused of Murder
LEAD: A truck driver accused of deliberately driving his rig into a tavern, killing a woman and injuring 18 people, was charged today with murder and 42 other counts.
The driver, Kenneth W. Metzler, 33 years old, the authorities said, drove his vehicle at nearly 50 miles an hour into the Benchwarmer Pub and Eatery on Saturday.

N.C.A.A. BANS FOOTBALL AT S.M.U. FOR '87 SEASON
LEAD: Southern Methodist University has been barred from fielding a football team next fall and will be permitted only a limited schedule in 1988 because athletic officials improperly paid about $61,000 to players, the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today.


FAWN HALL STEPS INTO THE LIMELIGHT
LEAD: She is blessed with a physical presence made for cameras and her name is straight out of a paperback mystery.

HIGH COURT BACKS BASING PROMOTION ON A RACIAL QUOTA
LEAD: A sharply divided Supreme Court, rejecting the Reagan Administration position, ruled today that judges may order employers to use strict racial quotas temporarily in promotions as well as hiring to counter severe past discrimination against blacks.


VATICAN PRELATE SAID TO FACE ARREST IN MILAN BANK COLLAPSE
LEAD: Milan magistrates investigating the 1982 collapse of the Banco Ambrosiano were reported today to have issued arrest orders for Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, the American prelate who runs the Vatican bank, and at least two other bank officials.


Look Who's Charging Impropriety
LEAD: If Michael Deaver is right that the Federal independent counsel law is unconstitutional, then he can be prosecuted only by the Justice Department run by his former White House associate, Attorney General Edwin Meese.
If Lieut.
Col.
Oliver North is right on the same question, he too can only be prosecuted by lawyers of the same Attorney General Meese - who has rightly disqualified himself because of a political conflict of interest.


A Question for Cuomo
LEAD: ''The decision I've made I think is best for my state, best for my family and, I think also, best for my party.''

LEAD: William S. Paley, the founder and chairman of CBS Inc., has been admitted to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center with pneumonia, according to a hospital spokesman.
Mr.

JOHN A. LOWE
LEAD: John A. Lowe, a former assistant United States Attorney in Manhattan, died Friday of a cerebral aneurism at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.
He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan and Westhampton Beach, L.I.

Peres in Cairo on Trip That Has Stirred Anger
LEAD: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel arrived here today on a mission that has sharply divided the governing Israeli coalition.


NEED TO WIDEN AIDS TESTING SEEN AS HEALTH FORUM ENDS
LEAD: Participants in a federally sponsored conference on the control of AIDS reached broad agreement today on the need for wider testing for infection with the AIDS virus, provided it was voluntary and accompanied by adequate counseling and safeguards to keep results confidential.

LEAD: THE Salzburg Musici - 19 string players trained at the Salzburg Mozarteum, currently making their first American tour - played Vivaldi, Handel, Bach, Mozart and Britten at Carnegie Hall Monday night under Oswald Sallaberger.

CASE AGAINST LANDLORD DROPPED IN OUSTER OF SUSPECTED DRUG RING
LEAD: A Criminal Court judge yesterday dismissed all charges against a Brooklyn landlord and another man who were arrested last month for ousting a suspected crack-dealing operation from the landlord's Bedford-Stuyvesant apartment building.

Washington for re-election.

LEAD: TO THE HOME SECTION:


Still Fighting the Raise
LEAD: Ralph Nader's Public Citizen organization has found a new way to oppose the salary increases that recently went into effect for members of Congress.
It has enlisted Senator Quentin N. Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota, and Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire, to tack resolutions rescinding the raise onto every ''must pass'' measure voted on in the Senate.

A Point in Time
LEAD: Long before our species had an identity, let alone a telescope, there was a dark space in the Greater Magellanic Cloud as it might have been seen from Earth.
On Tuesday, shortly before dawn, a light went on in that dark space and by chance, a Chilean observer with a telescope noticed it.
What he saw, he realized after studying a routine photograph, was an event that had taken place about 163,000 years before.


THEATER: STUART SHERMAN'S ONE-ACTS
LEAD: EVEN by Stuart Sherman's own minimalist standards, his ''Evening of One-Act Plays'' at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art is miniature theater.
Seven short plays, some as brief as blackouts, are sandwiched between two mini-movies.
But those who have followed the peregrinations of this artist from his solo performances to his fragmented, environmental trilogy about Chekhov, Strindberg and Brecht should find that the current evening of short Sherman helps to fill in the blanks.


46 Seized in Protest At Columbia Eviction
LEAD: Forty-six people, including a New York State Assemblyman, were arrested yesterday for trying to prevent the eviction of a woman from an apartment owned by Columbia University, police officials said.

Adler, Schwartz Gets Stillman Automotive
LEAD: Adler, Schwartz Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has become the agency for the $1 million Stillman Automotive account, which formerly consisted of six New Jersey dealerships that used four different New Jersey advertising agencies.
Consolidation of the franchises and advertising occurred in January.

Hoyt Barred for Season
LEAD: LaMarr Hoyt, the 32-year-old former Cy Young Award winner, was barred from baseball for the 1987 season by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth yesterday for Hoyt's involvement in three illegal drug incidents over the last year. ''While our first priority is to provide help to those who need it, we will impose discipline where appropriate,'' the commissioner said.


G.&amp;W. Sees Rise in Profit
LEAD: Gulf and Western Inc. told securities analysts yesterday that an ''exceptional performance'' by its motion picture operations would result in earnings for the first quarter of 1987 of about $1.10 a share, double the 55 cents a share reported a year ago.
The estimates were said to be substantially higher than expected.


SELECTING THE RIGHT TREE
LEAD: IF you arrange the planting of a street tree, take time to consider your selection since you will be looking at it - and caring for it - for years.
An experienced landscape contractor can help choose a species suitable to your site's sun, wind, neighboring species, sidewalk and street widths, and maintenance needs.


No Health Threat Seen In Jersey Cyanide Case
LEAD: The cyanide found in half-and-half sold in an Acme supermarket in Lawrenceville was not the result of tampering and did not pose a health threat, the State Health Department said today.


Man Held in Assault On Blacks in Queens
LEAD: A 20-year-old Manhattan man was arrested last night and charged with having been part of a group of whites that the police say attacked and chased a group of black youths in this area of Queens early Sunday morning.

JAZZ: TIMELESS ALL-STARS
LEAD: THE Timeless All-Stars play the kind of hard-bop that dreams are made of -thoughtful, virtuosic, soulful, fine-tuned and spunky.
The sextet, which is appearing through Sunday at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street), has brought the tenor saxophonist Harold Land back to New York for the first time since the early 1970's.

Outlook for Hong Kong
LEAD: Hong Kong expects a $230 million budget surplus in the fiscal year beginning April 1 as a result of a strong economy, Financial Secretary Piers Jacobs said today.

HOMOSEXUALS APPLAUD REJECTION OF MANDATORY TESTS FOR AIDS
LEAD: Spokesmen for prominent homosexual rights organizations expressed relief today that participants in a Federal conference on the control of AIDS had firmly rejected proposals for widespread mandatory testing to detect individuals who are infected with the AIDS virus.


PURDUE SURPRISES INDIANA BY 75-64
LEAD: Troy Lewis scored 18 points, including a 3-point field goal that halted a rally in the second half, to lead sixth-ranked Purdue to a 75-64 Big Ten Conference victory over No. 3 Indiana tonight.

LEAD: An indicted terrorist suspect appeared today before the Basque regional parliament to argue his candidacy to head the Basque government.

Corrections
LEAD: The headline of a Washington dispatch Tuesday about the "Star Wars" missile defense characterized Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's remarks incorrectly.
He said a test scheduled in 1988 could lead to deployment as early as 1994; he did not say deployment was likely by then.

FILM: 'WORKING GIRLS'
LEAD: ON its surface, Lizzie Borden's ''Working Girls'' seems to be a remarkably even-tempered view of prostitution, at least as practiced by the women who work in a small, expensive, immaculately maintained Manhattan bordello.


Pryor Is Arrested on Rape Charge
LEAD: Aaron Pryor, the former junior-welterweight champion, was jailed without bond today on charges of raping a woman and keeping her tied up in his house for 24 hours after an argument over his suspected cocaine use, the police said.


Durables Report Lifts Bonds
LEAD: An unexpectedly sharp decline in durable goods orders for January lifted prices of fixed-income securities yesterday in active trading.
The 7.5 percent decline was seven times greater than what participants in the credit market had expected.


The U.N. Today: Feb. 27, 1987
LEAD:  GENERAL ASSEMBLY


THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS  Retracing the Steps Leading to Six Arms Sales: Charts From the Report; Transaction Four: February 1986 Sale of 1,000 U.S. TOW Missiles
LEAD: STEP 1: Ghorbanifar provides Khashoggi four post-dated checks for $3 million each.
STEP 2: Khashoggi deposits $10 million in Lake Resources account on Feb. 10.
STEP 3:  $3.7 million is transferred to C.I.A. account at Swiss bank on February 10 and 11.
STEP 4: C.I.A. certifies availability of funds to Defense Department for purchase of 1,000 TOW's.

BICENTENNIAL ADS FOR CONSTITUTION
LEAD: The Commission on the Bicentennial of the Constitution, concerned that Americans know too little about the document that guarantees their freedoms, has begun an advertising campaign.


THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Discovery; How the Tower Inquiry Stumbled on Aid Effort
LEAD: John G. Tower said today that his panel did not have time to investigate the network of private aid to the Nicaraguan rebels that was discovered as part of its inquiry into the National Security Council staff.


JAMES COCO, CHARACTER ACTOR ON STAGE AND TV AND IN FILMS
LEAD: James Coco, the roly-poly actor who parlayed his sizable girth into a successful career in character parts that ranged from the comic to the terrifying, died Wednesday night after suffering a heart attack.
The actor, who was 56 years old, was pronounced dead at St.
Vincent's Hospital, where he had been taken from his home in Greenwich


Mark Helias at Visiones
LEAD: The bassist Mark Helias is to lead a quintet - with Tim Berne on alto saxophone, Robin Eubanks on trombine, Herb Robertson on trumpet and Bobby Previte on drums - tonight at Visiones, 125 Macdougas Street (673-5576).
Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $4 cover and a $7 minimum.


U.S Eases Net-Worth Rule to Help Thrift Units
LEAD: Responding to heavy pressure from Congress, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced a new policy that would permit beleaguered thrift institutions, particularly in the depressed Southwest, to continue operating, even if their net worth falls to almost zero.

Panel to Study Market Rules
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had set up a committee to determine whether its self-regulatory system needs to be changed.
A number of securities analysts and lawmakers have said the system needs to be reviewed because of the pervasive problems that have become known as a result of the insider trading scandal.


THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Vice President; Bush Insists the Intention Was Not Arms for Hostages
LEAD: Vice President Bush said today that he agreed it would be ''wrong'' for the United States to trade arms to Iran for the release of American hostages, but insisted the Adminstration had no such intention.

LEAD: The Tower Commission found documents in the safe of Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North suggesting that tens of millions of dollars were provided to the Nicaragua rebels and others through a private network of corporations and nonprofit organizations that Colonel North helped organize.

EXCERPTS FROM THE TOWER COMMISSION'S REPORT  APPENDIX A
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the report of the President's Special Review Board, which was made public yesterday in Washington:


U.S.-Cuba Cold Front
LEAD: On one thing, Cuban and United States officials agree.
Relations between the two countries are worse now than at any time since U.S. diplomats returned to Havana in 1977.
The top-ranking United States diplomat here, Curt Kamman, was abruptly withdrawn in January and Washington has made clear he will not soon be replaced, a deliberate slap.

LEAD: Arthur A. Collins, a pioneer in radio communications, avionics and telecommunications who was founder of the Collins Radio Company, died Wednesday at Gaston Episcopal Hospital in Dallas, the city where he had lived for the last 14 years.
He was 77 years old.

Illinois Road Unit
LEAD: The Illinois Toll Highway Authority is tentatively offering $139.7 million of bonds with a maximum yield of about 6.897 percent for a issue due in 2007 through underwriters led by L.F.
Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.
Yields on serial bonds range from 4 percent in 1988 to 5 percent in 1992, 6 percent in 1997 and 6.60 percent in 2002.


Chairman Resigns At Best Products
LEAD: Andrew M. Lewis's resignation was announced yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the Best Products Company, a big catalogue-store retail chain founded by his father and mother.
The company gave no reason for Mr.
Lewis's resignation.


3 Bands at the Ritz
LEAD: Two British bands - Chameleons U.K. and the Mighty Lemon Drops -and the California band Camper Van Beethoven are to perform tomorrow at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800).
Camper Van Beethoven is to open at 11 P.M.; tickets are $12.50 in advance, $13.50 Saturday.


A SHEARSON SALE MAY BE IN WORKS
LEAD: The American Express Company has been planning to sell a significant minority stake in its Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. securities brokerage subsidiary to the public, or to a foreign financial concern, in a step that could sharply increase Shearson's capital, sources close to the companies said yesterday.

STAGE: 'HUNGER ARTIST,' KAFKA IN LIFE AND WORK
LEAD: WHEN Franz Kafka was readying ''The Metamorphosis'' for publication, he implored his editor not to allow pictures of Gregor Samsa's transformation into a cockroach. ''Not that, please not that!'' the author wrote. ''The insect cannot be depicted.
It cannot even be shown from a distance.'' The publisher complied, illustrating ''The Metamorphosis'' instead with a door opening into darkness - an image at once more abstract and yet more terrifying.


2,100 IN PENTAGON TESTS SAID TO HAVE AIDS VIRUS
LEAD: The Pentagon, more than halfway through its screening of military personnel on active duty for infection with the AIDS virus, has identified about 2,100 men and women who were infected, according to sources familiar with the situation.


JUDGE ACQUITS SULLIVAN IN SHOTGUN SLAYING OF BUMPURS
LEAD: Two years and four months after an elderly, mentally disturbed woman was slain by two shotgun blasts in her Bronx apartment, the police officer who killed her was cleared yesterday of all charges in connection with her death.


AFGHAN PLANES SAID TO KILL 35 IN PAKISTAN RAIDS
LEAD: Afghan warplanes bombed two Pakistani villages today, killing at least 35 people, wounding more than 200 and wrecking scores of homes and businesses, Government officials said.


Mets' Strong Point Is Likely to Be Even Stronger
LEAD: Now for the bad news for all those teams casting evil on the Mets: Dwight Gooden is developing a straight change-up to go with that lightning speed.
Rick Aguilera is working on a split-fingered fastball.
And Bob Ojeda is adding new grips and illusions to go with the four pitches already in his repertory.


Paperback on Report Is Planned Next Week
LEAD: The Tower Commission report will be published next week by Bantam Books and Times Books, which is owned by Random House.


YOUTH SEX RING INVOLVING CRACK IS SHUT IN JERSEY
LEAD: A sex-for-drugs ring that operated here for the past eight months using girls as young as 10 years old has been broken and the authorities are looking for eight of the girls involved, the police said today.


Free Citicorp Concert
LEAD: The singer Carrie Smith is to give a free concert this afternoon at 5:30 at the Citicorp Center Atrium, Lexington Avenue at 53d Street; the number for more information is 559-2330.


FILM: 'BEYOND THERAPY,' A MATCH MADE IN THE ADS
LEAD: PRUDENCE and Bruce, two yuppies who still have a few years left before hitting the age of mandatory retirement, are a match made not in heaven but in the personals column of New York magazine.
Everything goes wrong when, after she answers his ad, they meet for the first time in a French restaurant.


Winfield Arrives Looking for Harmony
LEAD: Dave Winfield arrived today and wondered aloud why there should be any unnecessary pressure in the Yankee camp this season.


Tower Report: Wall St. Calm
LEAD: WHAT will be the economic consequences of the perceived weakening of the Reagan Administration?
The Tower Commission's report on the National Security Council and the Iran-contra affair, released yesterday at a nationally televised news conference, deepened the impression of a rudderless Administration.


Warrants for Vatican Bankers Raise Legal Problem for Italy
LEAD: Italian Justice Ministry officials confirmed today that warrants had been issued for the arrest of three senior Vatican bank officers charged as accessories in fraudulent bankruptcy in the collapse of Banco Ambrosiano in 1982.
The officials said the Government was studying ways to serve the warrants.

LEAD: Senate confirmation of Robert M. Gates as Director of Central Intelligence appeared to be jeopardized today by the Tower Commission's finding that the Central Intelligence Agency prepared a key 1985 assessment of the situation in Iran in close cooperation with the National Security Council staff.


BRAZIL TALKING TO NATIONS, NOT BANKS, ON DEBT
LEAD: In what is seen as a major change of strategy, Brazil has decided to go over the heads of foreign creditor banks and seek a long-term solution to its debt crisis in direct negotiations with governments of the United States and other industrial nations.

SPINKS STRIPPED OF TITLE
LEAD: Michael Spinks, who became the first light-heavyweight champion to win the heavyweight title when he defeated Larry Holmes last April 19, has been stripped of the crown by the International Boxing Federation.
The action disrupts his plans to defend the title against the winner of the bout between Mike Tyson, the World Boxing Council champion, and James (Bonecrusher) Smith, the World Boxing Association champion.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch on Wednesday about cleanup of asbestos in schools misstated provisions of a House action to compel the distribution of Federal funds.
The money, which was rescinded, would be restored to the Environmental Protection Agency unless Congress votes by March 15 to take away the $47.5 million appropriated last year.


ISLANDERS PUSH PENGUINS AROUND
LEAD: The Islanders shoved and jostled Pittsburgh's skaters, daunted Pittsburgh's goaltender, and eventually produced an inelegant but effective 5-4 victory tonight against the Penguins, who have not won at Nassau Coliseum in 13 games.

LEAD: Raymond Eyes will retire from his positions as president of the McCall Publishing Company and publisher of both McCall's and Working Woman magazines on March 31.

Frenchman Says Ex-Captors Were Suspect's Kin
LEAD: A former hostage testined today that two of his captors in Lebanon were brothers of Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, on trial for complicity in the killings of an American military attache and an Israeli diplomat in Paris.


FREDRIC R. MANN, ARTS PATRON
LEAD: Fredric R. Mann, an industrialist and patron of the arts who helped finance music centers in Philadelphia and Tel Aviv, died of cancer yesterday morning in Miami.
He was 83 years old and had homes in Miami, Philadelphia and Manhattan.

LEAD: Mice from a strain that suffers uncontrollable shivering, convulsions and early death have been cured through gene transfer techniques, possibly advancing work on some neurological ailments in humans.

Suns Dismiss MacLeod General Manager
LEAD: Jerry Colangelo, saying the Phoenix Suns ''needed a change in direction and a change in attitude'' yesterday dismissed Coach John MacLeod, who was in his 14th season, the longest span with the same team among active coaches.
Dick Van Arsdale, a former Knick and All-Star guard for the Suns who does color for the team's radio and television broadcasts, was named interim coach for the remainder of the season.

LEAD: Alexander Schneider will conduct the Brandenburg Ensemble in music by Bach and Telemann at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday afternoon at 3.

LEAD: Officer Stephen Sullivan, acquitted yesterday in the shooting of Eleanor Bumpurs, will be restored to full duty and continue to work in the office of the Chief of Detectives, in a unit that does videotaping and provides other technical support for criminal investigations.

ENERGY PRICES UP A BIT; TECHNICAL FACTORS CITED
LEAD: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products advanced slightly in dull trading yesterday.
But analysts attributed the recovery to technical factors and said it was still unclear whether the market's descent had been arrested, or whether this was only a pause before a further decline.


Guerrilla Warfare and the Budget: Senator Phil Gramm

PILOT TRAINING PLANNED FOR WIND SHIFT
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it planned to make it mandatory for airline pilots to undergo a training program on how to cope with one of aviation's deadliest hazards: the abrupt shift in winds at low altitudes.


A MIX OF ARCHETYPES AND AUTOBIOGRAPHY IN THE NEW PASTELS OF JENNIFER BARTLETT
LEAD: LIKE almost all her best work, Jennifer Bartlett's new pastels at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street, are a mix of symbolism and autobiography.
Large in scale and confident in tone, they fill the entire gallery without any flagging of energy.
Fundamentally they are made up of the same three disparate elements, combined and re-combined in a landscape that she got to know a year or two ago on the North Shore of Long Island.

UPTOWN DRAMA GRUPS JOIN FORCES IN FESTIVAL
LEAD: The Third Annual East-West Theater Festival is an attention-getting event that unites 10 performing troupes from Manhattan meridians on either side of Fifth Avenue.
The companies, between now and March 22, will have staged 19 different productions, available to festival ticket holders at a rock-bottom rate of $25, or less than $1.50 a show.

EXCERPTS FROM THE TOWER COMMISSION'S REPORT  APPENDIX D: AFTERMATH
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the report of the President's Special Review Board, which was made public yesterday in Washington:  THE N.S.C.
STAFF TRIED TO BUILD THE STORY


Owens-Illinois Asks Resignations
LEAD: Owens-Illinois Inc., which hopes to cut operating costs by $32 million a year, is offering all 2,000 of its salaried administrative employees incentives to quit.
Sam Allen, a company spokesman, said he did not know how many job reductions would achieve the $32 million in savings, but added, ''If not enough people accept the offer, then there will be involuntary cutbacks.


Jetliner Clips Plane on Runway
LEAD: A small plane crossing a runway at Los Angeles International Airport was clipped by a Continental Airlines jetliner taking off with 91 people aboard Wednesday, but nobody was hurt, officials said today.


Debt
LEAD: Kansas Power and Light Co. is offering $50 million of Aa-1/AA rated 8 5/8 percent first mortgage bonds due 2017 at 99.15, to yield 8.705 percent, through Dillon, Read &amp; Co.
Nonrefundable for five years, the bonds yield 1.04 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

A DAY IN THE LIFE OF THE BETTY FORD CENTER
LEAD: Just beyond Palm Springs, known as Southern California's golf and tennis ''playground of the stars,'' in a world of smoothly paved roads named for Bob Hope, Frank Sinatra and Gerald Ford, is what some might call a last resort.

IT'S OFFICIAL: A CUTBACK IN PERMITS FOR PARKING
LEAD: New York City's Transportation Commissioner, Ross Sandler, has a simple message for thousands of government workers, their relatives and friends who are abusing or manufacturing official parking permits: halt.


Japan Vehicle Record
LEAD: Japan's exports of cars, trucks and buses rose 6.8 percent in January from the comparable period of 1986, setting a record for the month, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association said.
The increase was the first in seven months, and followed a 17.8 percent drop in December - the sharpest decline since 1979, when the association began to compile statistics under the current system.

LEAD: IT may seem slightly insane.
But Crazy Eddie Inc., the home-electronics retailer that had a 61 percent profit jump in the nine months ended Nov. 30, will probably experience its first period of lower earnings as a public company in the fourth quarter, ending this month.
The retailer, whose wildly gesticulating pitchman stresses low, low prices, went public in


JORDAN'S 58 POINTS TOPPLES NETS
LEAD: Michael Jordan scored 58 points, the most ever by a Chicago player in a regular-season game, to lead the Bulls to a 128-113 victory over the Nets tonight.

AT THE MOVIES
LEAD: WHEN the Academy Award nominations were announced recently, some New Yorkers were surprised, others indignant, and some even affronted. ''Hoosiers,'' which garnered two nominations - one for best musical score and another for Dennis Hopper as best supporting actor - had not yet even opened in New York.


McGraw-Hill Cuts South Africa Tie
LEAD: McGraw-Hill Inc., one of the world's largest publishing and information-services companies, said it would end all operations in South Africa, citing the country's racial and political unrest.
McGraw-Hill said it was negotiating to sell its subsidiary, the McGraw-Hill Book Company (South Africa) Ltd., to local management.

DAVID TAYLOR
LEAD: David Taylor will play a program of works for bass trombone at the 92d Street Y tomorrow night at 8.
The concert will include the world premiere of George Perle's ''Sonata a Cinque'' and what is believed to be the American premiere of Erik Satie's ''Musique d'Ameublement,'' as well as music by Frederic Rzewski, Charles Ives, Duke Ellington and others.


COMINGS AND GOINGS
LEAD: Kevin Allen, a former offensive tackle with the Philadelphia Eagles and the ninth player taken over all in the 1985 draft, interrupted jury selection in his trial in Atlantic City yesterday to plead guilty to aggravated sexual assault last Sept. 1.
The plea was made under an agreement that dismissed other charges.


PEOPLE
LEAD: Gerald J. Kaufman has joined Muller Jordan Weiss as senior vice president, creative director, consumer products.

Dow Declines by 9.56; Economic Data Cited
LEAD: The stock market continued to retrench yesterday as Wall Street reacted to unfavorable economic news.


About That Police Parley
LEAD: The Police Foundation has decided to restrict its symposium on law enforcement next Thursday in Washington to representatives of organizations in the United States.
One result of that move is that Sir John Hermon, chief of the Royal Ulster Constabulary in Northern Ireland, will not participate in the symposium, as had been previously indicated.

CHARGES AGAINST MOTHER IN DEATH OF BABY ARE THROWN OUT
LEAD: A judge today dismissed criminal charges against a young San Diego woman who faced a possible jail term for her conduct while she was pregnant.
The prosecutor had said the woman's failure to seek medical help led to the death of her infant boy.

Fair, Respectful -- and Humiliating
LEAD: Their words were polite, as befits commissioners judging the President of the United States, especially considering that he invited them to investigate his own office.
The conclusions were put tactfully, but what the Tower commission report comes down to is blunt, indeed humiliating: In the Irancontra affair, the President failed to supervise national security policy, the most sensitive function of the government.


Big Plans In Little Rhodey
LEAD: He started out wanting to be a college basketball coach, but in the last dozen years Dan Doyle Jr. has vastly broadened those early horizons.
After three seasons as coach at Trinity College in Hartford, Doyle picked up a master's degree from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, promoted 15 Sugar Ray Leonard fights, coached the Irish national basketball team, established the Irish-American Sports Foundation and staged the Shamrock Games in Ireland and in his hometown, Worcester,


San Antonio Bond Sale Gets Warm Reception
LEAD: A $160 million competitive bond sale by San Antonio was well received by investors yesterday, when the issue of tax-exempt revenue bonds was priced through an underwriting group led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham &amp; Company.
The revenue bonds issued by the city's utility system are one of the highest rated in the country.


Garden a Factor in Meet
LEAD: The USA/Mobil Indoor Track and Field Championships could come down to a board game today.


On the Deaths of Pets, Lost or Abandoned
LEAD: To the Editor:


Naples Journal;  From Earthquake and Decay, a New Flowering?
LEAD: Along Via Stadera, in a neighborhood they call Purgatory, hoodlums of the Camorra, the Neapolitan version of the Mafia, sprayed gunfire this month at a group of laborers building apartments for people left homeless after the earthquake six years ago.
Those gunshots shook some of the brighter assumptions about this gracefully decaying Mediterranean city.


POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
LEAD: Henry Threadgill, Fred Hopkins and Andrew Cyrille, Jazztrack, Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, east of Seventh Avenue South (645-2387).
The saxophonist Henry Threadgill and the bassist Fred Hopkins were two-thirds of Air, the new-jazz trio that played fast and loose with Mr.
Threadgill's compositions in ways that were droll and bluesy and smart, often all at once.

Diner's Journal
LEAD: SAFARI GRILL, the stylish urban encampment that got off to a rousing start nearly two years ago, then suffered from attrition in the kitchen and lack of direction, is on the comeback trail.
A new chef has taken command - David Lawson, formerly of Stars in San Francisco and Marshal's Bar and Grill in Paris.

LEAD: The Washington Square Contemporary Music Series will present its 10th anniversary concert at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Sunday night at 8.
The program will include works by Gyorgy Kurtag, Milton Babbitt, Todd Brief, Brian Fennelly and Louis Karchin.
Admission is $5; information: (212) 362-8719.

Pesch Raises Medical Offer
LEAD: Leroy A. Pesch renewed his bid today to acquire American Medical International Inc., sweetening his offer $2 a share, to $22, or a total of $1.91 billion.


A SALUTE TO WOMEN'S HISTORY
LEAD: Women's History Month, a citywide celebration of the experience of women past and present, begins Sunday.
Organized by the New York City Commission on the Status of Women, it will provide a chance to remember pioneering American women including Harriet Tubman, the escaped slave who was deeply involved in the Underground Railroad, and Amelia Earhart, the aviator.


CHILE BANK AGREEMENT
LEAD: Chile and its foreign creditor banks have agreed to a financing deal that will save the country $440 million next year, and will give it Latin America's second-lowest interest rate, after Mexico's, on overseas bank loans, bankers said yesterday.
Bankers also reported that Venezuela has reached agreement with the committee representing its commercial creditors on revisions to a $21 billion debt-rescheduling package signed last year.

LEAD: William Lyons, who had been chairman of the executive committee of Nadler &amp; Larimer, which was acquired by the Mickelberry Company, has joined the multitudes of consulting concerns.
But his is distinctive because it is named William Lyons Associates, and his associates have a total of 200 years of advertising experience.

Bias Jury Report Criticizes School
LEAD: The grand jury that investigated the death of Len Bias, the Maryland basketball player issued a report today that strongly criticized the university's athletic program.
Bias died from a cocaine overdose last June 19.


Soviet, Spurned by U.S., Renews A-Test
LEAD: The Soviet Union conducted an underground nuclear test today, ending an 18-month moratorium, but offered to stop again if the United States joined in.

Giant Diamond Is Sold
LEAD: An Australian mining company, Bridge Oil, has sold a huge West African diamond of gem quality for $1.6 million.
Bridge's chairman, Robert Strauss, said the 100.2-carat stone was the most valuable diamond from the Aredor mine in Guinea.

ED PASO'S BATTLE FOR WATER ENTERING CRUCIAL PHASE
LEAD: Had a twist of cartographic fate put this arid city across the border in New Mexico, where it appears to belong culturally, economically and geographically, it would not now be going through such agony to quench its growing municipal thirst.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Science Times on Feb. 17 about osteoporosis described dual photon absorptiometry, a screening technique, incorrectly.
The radiation associated with this method is minimal -- only about one-tenth the dose used in a routine chest X-ray.


N.F.L. Uncertain On London Game
LEAD: The National Football League said yesterday that although an exhibition game next summer at Wembley Stadium in London was likely, the teams had not yet been selected and any formal commitment was three weeks away.

DAVID CALE, SPINNER OF DREAM TALES
LEAD: The voice is caressing, with an undertone of urgency, a hint of menace.
With its suburban London accent full of tangy insinuation, it is an ideal instrument for the telling of scary ''believe it or not'' tales in which lurking night stalkers contemplate unspeakable crimes.
Yet David Cale, the 28-year-old comic monologuist who is appearing at the Kitchen, has deeper things on his mind than campfire Grand Guignol.

THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS  Retracing the Steps Leading to Six Arms Sales: Charts From the Report; Transaction Two: September 1985 Sale of 408 Israeli TOW Missles
LEAD: STEP 1: Ghorbanifar provides Khashoggi with $4 million post-dated check.
STEP 2: Khashoggi deposits $4 million to Nimrodi-controlled account on Sept. 14.
STEP 3: Nimrodi notifies Israeli officials that funds have been received.
STEP 4: Israel delivers 408 TOW anti-tank missiles to Iran on Sept.

A LATE GIFT BRINGS AID TO NEEDIEST
LEAD: A regular contributor to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund wrote a note of apology for being late.


Heritage Cable Acquisition Set
LEAD: Heritage Communications Inc., the 10th-largest American cable television company, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by Tele-Communications Inc. and an investor group for $885 million.


Benefits of Arbitration
LEAD: To the Editor:


Hurricane Tracker Is Lofted
LEAD: A Delta rocket was launched late today with a $55 million weather satellite aboard that is intended to fill a critical surveillance need in this year's hurricane season.


The Bumpurs Case Endures
LEAD: The verdict of a State Supreme Court justice clears a New York City police officer, Stephen Sullivan, of manslaughter charges in the fatal shooting of Eleanor Bumpurs.
But no decision can clear the system: social service failures and unwise police procedures contributed heavily to this tragedy.
This case must not end with one officer's acquittal.

EX-SOLDIER ACCUSED OF STEALING 2 COPTERS IN SCAM
LEAD: The former maintenance chief for a company whose helicopter crashed in the Hudson last October, killing a radio reporter, was accused by Federal prosecutors yesterday of stealing two $115,000 helicopters from the Air Force when he was an Army private in 1980.


French Order Boeing Awacs
LEAD: The French Government placed a $940 million order today for three radar early warning planes from the Boeing Company and took an option to buy two more in the next eight months.

DEMOCRATS AND CUOMO IN TAX SPLIT
LEAD: In a major break with the Cuomo administration, the Democratic leadership of the Assembly today rejected the Governor's tax-cut plan as too small and proposed a completely new tax code with a flat rate of 6.75 percent on all income, both corporate and personal.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Washington Talk page Feb. 17, about Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia misstated the Court's history on prior restraint of publication of Government secrets.
In 1980, in Snepp v.
United States, the Court upheld an agreement under which a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency had to submit anything he wrote about the agency for prepublication review and deletion of any national security secrets.


TEMPORARY LOAN FOR ARGENTINA
LEAD: The United States and other countries have decided to grant a $500 million short-term loan to Argentina while it completes negotiations for a $2.15 billion financing package with commercial banks.

PERMANENT NET
LEAD: Ray Williams, who returned to the Nets for a third time in his pro career by signing successive 10-day contracts, was re-signed yesterday for the remainder of the season.
With Otis Birdsong injured, Williams has provided the Net backcourt with experience at both guard positions.
Against the Detroit Pistons Tuesday night, the 6-foot-3-inch, 32-year-old Williams had 23 points and 9 assists.


Hulk of Ship Involved in 1973 Disaster Towed From the Harbor
LEAD: The Sea Witch under tow yesterday.
The former container ship was being taken from the Brooklyn Navy Yard to Camden, N.J., where she will be scrapped.
On June 2, 1973, the ship collided with the Esso Brussels, a Belgian-registered oil tanker, south of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, and caught fire.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD: Tennis  Fernandez Upsets Shriver: Fifteen-year-old Mary Joe Fernandez upset fifth-seeded Pam Shriver, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday to accompany Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd into the third round of the $1.8 million Lipton International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla.

THE EVENING HOURS
LEAD: MOST partygoers are used to doormen graciously ushering them out of their cars or limousines and through the front door of the city's most elegant nightspots.
But at Christie's on Monday night, at an auction and dinner to celebrate 60 years of Martha Graham's choreography, some guests entered the party the unfashionable way, through the back door.


A Juvenal Quotation Opens Tower Report
LEAD: Appendix B of Tower Commission report, a narrative of how the Iran-Contra affair evolved, begins with ''Quis custodiet ipsos custodes.'' It is Latin for ''Who will guard the guardians themselves?''

CARING CHIEF SUCCEEDS AT CENTER FOR JUVENILES
LEAD: When Rose Washington became director of the Spofford Juvenile Center in the South Bronx in 1983, she moved her office from what was called the ''penthouse'' on the eighth floor to a corridor between two dormitories on the first floor.


THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: The Tower Report  INQUIRY FINDS REAGAN AND CHIEF ADVISERS RESPONSIBLE FOR 'CHAOS' IN IRAN ARMS DEALS; Reagan Also Blamed
LEAD: A special review board portrayed President Reagan today as a confused and remote figure who failed to understand or control the secret arms deal with Iran, and who thus had to ''take responsibility'' for a policy that in the end caused ''chaos'' at home and embarrassment abroad.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 381 money market mutual funds increased $720.4 million, to $236.90 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $356 million, to $66.19 billion.
Assets of the 198 general purpose funds were up $211.5 million, to $62.94 billion.

NETTLES JOINS BRAVES
LEAD: Graig Nettles, the 42-year-old veteran third baseman who had his finest years with the Yankees, joined the Atlanta Braves' spring training camp in West Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday at the invitation of General Manager Bobby Cox.
Nettles did not re-sign with San Diego after the 1986 season, in which he batted .218 with 16 home runs and 55 runs batted in.

ACTION ON S.M.U. IS SWIFT AND DECISIVE
LEAD: One of the most persistent criticisms of the National Collegiate Athletic Association has been that it was slow and indecisive in dealing with universities that violated rules aimed at insuring fair competition.
Investigations usually took two years and when punishment did come, the critics said, it was often the proverbial slap on the wrist.

There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.


CITING CRASHES, KOCH CURB ON TOW TRUCKS
LEAD: Tow trucks speeding to crash sites in New York City contributed to 7 deaths, 800 personal injuries and 1,200 collisions from 1983 through 1986, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

Record Japan Trade Surplus
LEAD: Japan's seasonally adjusted surplus on its current account hit a record in January, rising 11.6 percent from the previous month and defying predictions that the strong yen would lessen the nation's trade imbalances.


RETURN TO DUGOUT UNLIKELY FOR MARTIN
LEAD: Billy Martin, who said he was preparing to assume a broader role in the Yankee front office this season, arrived in camp today and indicated that his days as a manager might be over.
He did not appear disturbed as he considered the possibility. ''I can handle it,'' he said.
The former Yankee manager, who spent last season in a limited role in the television broadcast booth, said he would likely decide this season whether he would turn his attention to other projects and give up any thought of a return to the dugout.


Chicago Merc Changes Due
LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said that within the next month it is likely to enact several sweeping changes that would affect trading of futures on the Standard &amp; Poor's 500-stock index.
Changes under consideration include ending ''dual trading,'' in which floor brokers trade for their own accounts as well as execute customer orders.


DANCE: A GALA FOR CANADA'S BALLET
LEAD: Everybody, or nearly so, got into the act to celebrate the National Ballet of Canada's 35th anniversary at the O'Keefe Center here.
Halfway along, the Ontario Minister of Culture, Lily Munro, popped out of a gift box in a tutu and waved a scepter, magic-wand style, at Toronto's Mayor and hopeful beneficiaries from the arts community.


TEXAS, IN EMERGENCY, TO FREE 185 FROM CROWDED PRISONS
LEAD: Gov.
Bill Clements certified today that the Texas prison system was in a state of emergency, clearing the way for the immediate release of about 185 inmates and the subsequent release of perhaps hundreds of others.


Memorial Service for Henry John Heinz 2d
LEAD: Senator John heinz escirting hi mother, Drue, from a memorial service for his father, Henry John Heinz 2d, yesterday in Pittsburgh.
Mr.
Heinz, the chairman of H. J. Heinz &amp; Company, was responsible for directing the disbursal of more than $300 million in grants to Pittsburgh and Pennsylvania organizations.

ENFORCING WARRANTIES ON REPAIRS
LEAD: When Anita Rubin's 1982 GMC Suburban broke down last year, she took it to Aamco.
After all, as the nation's largest transmission-repair chain boasts in advertisements: ''11,000,000 Americans have trusted Aamco.
You should, too!''


Yount Signs Pact
LEAD: Robin Yount, the 13-year veteran who led the Milwaukee Brewers in batting last season, signed a multi-year contact with the team yesterday.
Yount's contract is reportedly for three years at approximately $1 million a season with incentive and loan clauses.
Yount, 31 years old, had signed a three-year contract with an option for three more years following the 1983 season.


HOWARD BAKER WILL HEAD STAFF WITH MANDATE TO REORGANIZE; Reagan Flustered, Tower Reports
LEAD: Members of the Tower Commission said today that they were surprised and dismayed by President Reagan's lack of knowledge about the Iran-contra affair during their two lengthy discussions last month.


AWAITING THE LIBRARIAN
LEAD: The White House might be excused if the selection of the next Librarian of Congress is not the biggest item on its agenda, given what needs to be done about Iran, the Nicaraguan rebels and the like.
But the post is one of the most important ones for American intellectuals, who are volunteering advice.


BERENYI'S GOAL: A SUMMER IN MONTREAL
LEAD: In the early days of a spring training already characterized by the absence of some important free agents and charges of a management conspiracy to control the marketplace, there remains a more basic, if less glamorous, rite of spring.
Bruce Berenyi, now wearing the uniform of the Montreal Expos with a minor-league contract and no guarantee of a spot on the major-league roster, threw on the sidelines this week in two sessions, each lasting 10 minutes.


CITY DELAYS ITS VOTE ON MALL TO DISCUSS DEVELOPER'S GIFT
LEAD: A developer's offer of $250,000 to a Queens merchants' group has led to a sudden and unusual postponement in what was expected to be routine New York City approval for a shopping mall in Rego Park.

Six Officers in Miami Injured in Drug Sweep
LEAD: A police undercover operation against crack dealers ended late today with one suspect dead, two police officers wounded in police crossfire, and four other officers injured when the suspect ran them down with his car, officials said.


Bridge; At Tournament, Some Felt Computer Was Setting Traps
LEAD: Tournament players sometimes suffer from a mechanical anthropomorphism, a delusion that the computer, as it randomly deals the cards, understands bridge and is setting traps for them.


Oxychem Adding
LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, a leading energy concern, said its Oxychem subsidiary had agreed to acquire the vinyl chloride monomer unit of the Shell Oil Company, as part of its efforts to expand its chemicals business.
Vinyl chloride monomer is the main raw material used in the production of polyvinyl chloride.


U.S. BLAMES EUROPE FOR LACK OF OZONE-PROTECTION ACCORD
LEAD: The United States accused some European countries and industrial concerns today of seeking to delay effective measures to protect the earth's ozone layer from destructive industrial chemicals, as a conference on the ozone threat ended without substantial movement toward an agreement.


New Start, New Prime Minister
LEAD: The Tower commission, with its honest and constructive report, Thursday gave President Reagan a new opportunity.
He seized it yesterday by naming Howard Baker as White House chief of staff.
These are good starts on a long and difficult road back to credibility for the President.


SATELLITE LOFTING CONTINUES STRING
LEAD: The flawless launching of a weather satellite Thursday marked the sixth straight success for an American space program that a year ago was in disarray.


JUROR REMOVED IN 'PIZZA' TRIAL AFTER A THREAT
LEAD: A juror in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial was removed from the deliberations yesterday because a member of her family received an apparently threatening telephone call.


Where The Buck Stops
LEAD: What happened to Ronald Reagan?
How did a commanding President who stood tall with the public and could work his will with Congress allow his Administration to lapse into the evident ''chaos'' certified by the Tower commission?

MEDICARE PATIENTS LOBBY IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
LEAD: Residents of the Riverside Rest Home in Dover, N.H., lobbying Thursday in Concord.
The group is backing a bill to increase the monthly spending allowance to $40 for Medicare residents of rest and nursing homes in the state.
The current amount is $25 for those in rest homes and $30 for those in nursing homes, if they also receive Medicaid.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Cargill Profit
LEAD: Cargill Inc., the largest agricultural business in the country, has reported its highest pretax profit in 12 years despite a prolonged slump in the agricultural sector.
The privately held company reported a 66 percent increase in fiscal year 1986 earnings in a prospectus issued by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, the lead agent for a $150 million Cargill bond offering.

Thrift Unit Sale
LEAD: Glenfed Inc., the nation's fifth-largest thrift holding company, said it had agreed to buy the Guarantee Financial Corporation of California for about $205 million.
Under the agreement, Guarantee stockholders would exchange each of their shares for Glenfed stock worth $33.
Guarantee has 6.2 million shares outstanding.


STATE CABLE TV CHIEF IS DOUBTFUL ON KOCH PLAN TO ASK FOR NEW BIDS
LEAD: The head of the State Commission on Cable Television has expressed doubts about Mayor Koch's plan to inject competition by seeking new bids for cable service in most of New York City.


WRITERS AT CBS AND ABC NEWS VOTE TO STRIKE
LEAD: Writers at CBS News and ABC News have voted to strike the two networks and several network-owned radio and television stations at 11:59 P.M. tomorrow, when their three-year contracts expire.


City Opera Company To Have 6-Week Tour
LEAD: The New York City Opera National Company will undertake a six-week tour of the Northeast, Southeast, Midwest and Canada, beginning next Saturday at the Walt Whitman Auditorium of Brooklyn College, the City Opera has announced.
The company is to perform Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly,'' sung in Italian with supertitles, for all 32 performances.

LEAD: After decades of disagreement, a national consensus has quite suddenly emerged among liberals and conservatives, Republicans and Democrats, governors and members of Congress and the Reagan Administration on an approach to overhauling the nation's welfare system.

Transplant Patient Improves
LEAD: A 7-year-old Florida boy who received a life-saving liver transplant is making a strong recovery and will be moved out of intensive care a day ahead of schedule, a Children's Hospital spokeswoman said today.
The condition of the boy, Ronnie DeSiller, improved from critical to serious, said the spokeswoman, Lynn McMahon.

Tri-Star Ends Theater Move
LEAD: Tri-Star Pictures Inc. said yesterday that it had ended discussions on the proposed purchase of movie theaters owned by United Artists Communications Inc. of San Francisco.
The acquisition would have been worth $500 million.


ISRAELI ESPIONAGE DEPICTED IN COURT
LEAD: Jonathan Jay Pollard, a convicted spy, portrayed himself today as a loyal American who helped Israel and cited ''extremely detailed'' requests for American intelligence data as evidence of Israel's highly coordinated espionage effort.


M.T.A. SEEKS 150 BUSES DESPITE FUND STALEMATE
LEAD: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved the purchase of 150 more buses for New York City yesterday even though the money to buy them is still tied up in a dispute over its five-year capital improvement plan.


NETS OVERTAKE PACERS
LEAD: The Nets went from very bad to very good in a matter of minutes tonight in beating the Indiana Pacers, 125-115, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
When the Nets were bad, they gave up 72 points in a first half that included a 17-0 Pacer run in just under three minutes, and they trailed by 19 points with 8 minutes 23 seconds remaining in the third quarter.


A Tangled Web of Legal Issues, Potential Violations of Law
LEAD: The Tower Commission's report raised what it called ''far-reaching legal questions'' about the Iran-contra affair that the special prosecutor and the Congressional investigative committees will try to resolve in the months ahead.


Brazilian Minister Asks Smoother Capital Flow
LEAD: Brazil's Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, called today for ''streamlined financial machinery'' to insure long-term capital flows to debtor nations as he seeks to turn Brazil's suspension of debt payments into broad intergovernmental discussions on debt reform.


VOLUME OFF
LEAD: With Wall Street ignoring the troubles in the Reagan Administration and its own scandals, stock prices managed to gain slightly yesterday, although investors seemed distracted and trading volume was reduced.


TOUGHER BUSINESS TAX RULES FAIL TO DAMPEN ENTERTAINING
LEAD: Remember all that talk about darkened theaters and shuttered restaurants when Congress was voting last year to restrict the deduction for business entertainment and meals, the corporate world's everyday tax break?

LEAD: A few days ago, at a White House press briefing, reporters asked whether President Reagan's memory was failing.

Louis, and the New York Philharmonic have put together a most satisfying program for their current round of concerts at Avery Fisher Hall (heard yesterday afternoon, the program will be repeated tonight and Tuesday night at 8).


FUTURES/OPTIONS Cattle Contracts Surge; Grains Up, Energy Off
LEAD: Cattle futures prices rallied strongly yesterday, with the nearby live cattle contract advancing the 1 1/2-cents-a-pound limit for daily trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1987
LEAD: The Economy


GORBACHEV OPPOSITION: HOW SERIOUS
LEAD: Aleksandr Gelman, a playwright, gave them a name: ''the newly discontented.''


A Correction:
LEAD: A letter by Alan Sokal published yesterday misidentified him as a professor of politics at New York University.
He is a professor of physics.


Guatemala Aided Contras, Despite Denials, Panels Says
LEAD: The Guatemalan military provided assistance for several years to rebels trying to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government, despite public assertions of neutrality in the conflict, according to the Tower Commission report and officials familiar with the activities.


Endowment Broadens Challenge-Grant Rules
LEAD: The Challenge Grant Program of the National Endowment for the Arts has broadened its criteria for eligibility, the agency has announced.
Arts groups may now apply for a challenge grant for projects in a variety of areas, not only for fund-raising campaigns to increase their endowment or to erase their debts, as in previous years.


An Xercise in Xplanation
LEAD: ''X,'' the 24th letter of the English alphabet, outshines the others.
The only other letter that comes close to X in ubiquity is Z, the symbol for sleep, etc.


ITT Near Accord On Army Radios
LEAD: The ITT Corporation appears to have solved production problems that had plagued a new generation of jam-proof radios and as a result, contract payments for the equipment may soon resume, the Army said.
New data from a series of tests conducted early this month on the so-called Sincgars equipment indicates the radios would meet the Army's standard for reliability, an Army statement said.

Nicaragua Derides the Tower Report
LEAD: A Sandinista Government spokesman said today that he believed the Tower Commission's report was intended more to protect the United States Presidency than to find the full truth behind the Iran-contra dealings.


Great White Fleet, an American Symbol
LEAD: To the Editor:


USX Rating Cut
LEAD: Following a similar move by the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation, Moody's Investors Service Inc. has lowered its ratings on about $7 billion of the USX Corporation debt and preferred stock.
Both securities rating services cited depressed conditions in oil and gas, businesses that represent roughly two-thirds of USX's annual sales, as reasons for the downgrading.


BRAZIL SITUATION SPURS ACTION ON OTHERS' DEBTS
LEAD: Galvanized by Brazil's economic crisis, international banks and Western governments took steps this week to prevent the situation from snowballing throughout Latin America's debtor countries.


HOWARD BAKER WILL HEAD STAFF WITH MANDATE TO REORGANIZE; Reagan's Request Came as Baker Was on Verge of Presidential Bid
LEAD: Howard H. Baker Jr. said today that he was on the verge of deciding to run for the Presidency when President Reagan asked him to take charge of the beleaguered White House staff.
Putting aside his own White House ambitions, he agreed to take the job.

CONSUMER PRICES UP SHARP 0.7%
LEAD: The Consumer Price Index, the most widely followed inflation gauge, jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in January, the biggest increase in four and a half years, the Labor Department reported today.


Bush Says Iran Deals 'Failed the American People'
LEAD: Vice President Bush today accepted the conclusion of a special Presidential commission that the Reagan Adminstration's negotiations with Iran disintegrated into a trade of arms for hostages.
He said the conduct of that policy had ''failed the American people.''


Battle Reported in Sahara
LEAD: Polisario guerrillas marked the 11th anniversary of their self-styled republic today and said 213 Moroccans had been killed in a battle in the Western Sahara on Wednesday.
A Polisario communique also said 83 Moroccans were taken prisoner, the Algerian press agency reported.
Both the Moroccan Government and the Polisario, an Algerian-backed independence movement, claimed victory in the five-hour battle.


New Iranian Offensive Expected on Iraqi Port City
LEAD: Experts on the Iran-Iraq war said today that, while the Iranians had ended their offensive south of the Iraqi port city of Basra, the lull was probably temporary.


THE CACHET OF CASHMERE
LEAD: Valerie Louthan, whose specialty is knitted cashmere sweaters from Scotland, has expanded her collection to include coat-jackets, dresses, a sleek jump suit and culottes.


Actor's Son Gets Probation
LEAD: Griffin O'Neal, son of the actor Ryan O'Neal, was fined $200 today and placed on 18 months' probation for a boating accident that killed the son of the film director Francis Ford Coppola.
Griffin O'Neal was convicted Dec. 19 on charges of negligent operation of a boat in the death last Memorial Day of Gian-Carlo Coppola, 23 years old.


In Their Own Words: How the Iran-Contra Affair Took Shape
LEAD: Appendix B of the Tower Commission report, ''The Iran/Contra Affair: A Narrative,'' provides an extensive collection of documents and testimony by the participants in the arms initiative.
Here are excerpts from documents cited in the appendix, including transcripts of committee interviews and messages transmitted through the White House computer system.


AN IDIOSYNCRATIC EXPERT REDRAWS REMBRANDT
LEAD: Of the 30 eminent art historians and art conservationists invited to the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston in mid-February to discuss some of the issues that have turned Rembrandt into a battleground, the most unconventional may have been Gary Schwartz.
He is a Rembrandt scholar without a Ph.D. and without a university or museum affiliation.


NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1987
LEAD: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS 6-10  The President ousted Donald Regan from his post as the White House chief of staff and replaced him with former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., in a dramatic move to revive his troubled Presidency.
Page 1  Man in the News: Howard H. Baker had always said that it's hard to say ''no'' to the President.


2 'Spinal Series' Benefits At Town Hall and Tully
LEAD: Sixteen soloists and companies from New York's dance and music communities are to perform in ''The Spinal Series'' at 8 P.M. on Wednesday at Town Hall and March 12 at Alice Tully Hall.
The performances, produced by Manhattan Performing Ensemble in cooperation with the American Paralysis Association, will raise money for the association's Project Target, a research program, as well as the New York Regional Spinal Cord Injury System and Shake-a-Leg, a therapeutic summer rehabilitation program.


SAME UNIVERSITIES SHARING U.S. FUND
LEAD: Sixteen of the 20 universities that received the most Federal research money in 1967 were also at the top of the list for 1984, the auditing arm of Congress has reported.


Citadel of Fury: Anger Strikes Out At the Car Pound
LEAD: ''I'm furious!'' the woman screamed at the first person she saw. ''Get in line,'' the attendant responded courteously, and she did.

LEAD: One of the biggest natural gas discoveries in recent years has been made in southern Louisiana near the Gulf of Mexico, according to the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

CITY REJECTS SURVEY USED TO DETERMINE RENTS
LEAD: New York City has thrown out a central part of the system it used for 17 years to determine rents in stabilized apartments, sending officials scrambling for alternatives just four months before new rent levels must be set for about 690,000 apartments.


Worker Dies in Fire at Rail Station in Ossining
LEAD: Firefighters battling a blaze in the Metro-North Railroad station yesterday morning.
Samuel J. Biordi, a plumber, was killed after he became trapped in the station attic where he was working on frozen pipes with three other men.
The fire destroyed the ticket office and burned through the roof of the 80-year-old station.


McREYNOLDS KEEPS A VERY LOW PROFILE
LEAD: Kevin McReynolds, the new kid on the block, made his debut today in the uniform of the Mets.
And he was a private island of reserve and restraint in the clamor of the first full workout, which filled the Mets' camp with an overflow crowd that even broke down a fence in its frenzy to get close to the champions.


Iranian Speaker Says U.S. Panel Confirmed His Account of Events
LEAD: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament said today that he was pleased that the Tower Commission had confirmed his revelations on the arms-to-Iran deal, but he said the commission's report had not explained the Reagan Administration's mistakes.

Citicorp Card in Japan
LEAD: Citicorp Card Services Inc., a subsidiary of Citicorp, will enter Japan's credit card market in March, Citicorp officials said today.
Its Gold Citicard will be issued in cooperation with the Union Credit Card Company of Japan and Mastercharge International.
The move is part of an effort by Citicorp to expand its retail banking business in Japan.


15 Hurt in Carnival Parade
LEAD: Fifteen people, most of them children, were injured today when a horse, apparently frightened by a siren on an antique fire engine, bolted into a crowd at a special Mardi Gras parade for handicapped children, the authorities said.
The parade, at Percy Julien School on the west bank of Jefferson Parish, was an annual event for students at the school.


Prices Paid to Farmers Unchanged in February
LEAD: The prices that farmers received for raw products in February were unchanged, on the average, from a revised January index, the Agriculture Department said today.


Mervyn's Expands
LEAD: Mervyn's Department Stores, a division of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, will buy The Denver Dry Goods Stores in Pueblo, Fort Collins and Colorado Springs under an agreement announced today.
Terms of the sale were not disclosed.
The May Company, which acquired The Denver last fall in a $2.5 billion deal, announced last month that it was closing The Denver stores this spring.

A QUIET DAY AT HOME
LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, former national security adviser to President Reagan, with his wife, Jonda, at their Bethesda, Md., home.
He was released Tuesday from the hospital, where he recovered from a Valium overdose. (NYT/Paul Hosefros)


Council Panel Backs Move for More Taxis
LEAD: A City Council committee approved yesterday a measure that could place as many as 1,800 new medallion cabs on New York City's streets and that clears the way for a fare increase.


Florida Coast Is Fouled By an 30-Mile Oil Slick
LEAD: An oil slick up to 30 miles long from a freighter that ruptured her fuel tanks on a jetty began washing ashore today on Florida's northeastern shore, Coast Guard officials said.


AIDS TEST USED ON THOUSANDS, SOVIET SAYS
LEAD: The Soviet Union has developed and is mass-producing a test for AIDS virus infection that has already been used on tens of thousands of people, according to the Soviet weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta.


Can Albany Cut Down on Pork?
LEAD: Each spring, as New York's legislative leaders wind up budget negotiations, they divvy up tens of millions for projects justified by only sketchy proposals.
These are the ''member items,'' pet projects for individual legislators designed to curry support in home districts.
Governor Cuomo wants to uproot this tradition; it's a valiant undertaking.


SIDNEY BLAXILL
LEAD: Sidney Blaxill, a retired partner and managing director of Morgan Stanley &amp; Company Inc., died of cancer Tuesday at Williamson County Hospital, Franklin, Tenn., after a long illness.
He was 58 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

PROSECUTIONS URGED IN MANILA
LEAD: A Government inquiry commission today recommended the prosecution of police officers photographed firing their guns during a clash with demonstrators last month in which 15 people were killed and 100 wounded.


North Rebuked on Talks
LEAD: When Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North and his colleagues, George Cave and Richard V. Secord, met in Frankfurt with Iranians between Oct. 5 and 7, 1986, to pursue a second channel of contacts, the Tower Commission reported, ''Lieutenant Colonel North misrepresented his access to the President and attributed to the President things the President never said.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Kevin Houston of Army, the nation's leading scorer with an average of 31.8 points a game, has been named the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference's player of the year by league's coaches, who also honored Ted Fiore of St.
Peter's as the outstanding coach. . . .
Greg Page, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, will fight Frank Bruno of Britain at Wembley Stadium in London March 24 in a bout that the British fighter thinks will ''make or break'' his chance to meet Mike Tyson, the World Boxing Council champion, in September.


VATICAN DENOUNCES ATTEMPT BY ITALY TO ARREST BANK CHIEF
LEAD: The Vatican, throwing its full weight behind Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, issued a sharply worded statement today expressing ''profound astonishment'' at efforts by the Italian authorities to arrest the American head of the Vatican bank and two of his closest associates.


The Great Conciliator: Howard Henry Baker Jr.
LEAD: Howard H. Baker had always said that when the President asks you to do something, it's hard to say no.


FROM FASHION TO FURNITURE, BOVINES BOOM
LEAD: Sometime between 10,000 and 15,000 B.C. a Stone Age artist painted a red cow on the wall of a cave in Lascaux, France.
To archeologists and anthropologists, this cow represents one of man's earliest known paintings.
To ''boviniacs,'' so called because of their excessive enthusiasm for cows, it represents the birth of their esthetic.


ON PENTAGON SPENDING
LEAD: The Senate Armed Services Committee has concluded that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's proposed Pentagon budget is on target when it comes to the amount of money requested but flawed when it comes to how Mr.
Weinberger wants to spend some of the money.


PACTS REACHED WITH 3 UNIONS FROM L.I.R.R.
LEAD: The Long Island Rail Road yesterday reached tentative agreements with its last three labor unions, forestalling the possibility of another strike and ending more than two and a half years of bargaining.


LOUISIANA ECONOMY MAY FORETELL POLITICAL CHANGE
LEAD: Along the rural roads outside this city the trees are starting to sprout with the signs of a new election year, Louisiana's version of the World Series.

PAKISTAN ACCUSES AFGHANS OF JEOPARDIZING TALKS
LEAD: The Foreign Minister of Pakistan, Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, said today that Afghanistan was deliberately trying to jeopardize the two nations' peace talks here by staging new bombing raids on Pakistani villages near the Afghan border.

LEAD: Chrysler Corp., Detroit, said it was adding 1986 and 1987 Fifth Avenue cars to its current incentive program, and is offering either interest rates as low as 3.7 percent or $1,000 rebates.
Chrysler also announced other changes in the incentive program, including an increase in some rebates up to $1,500.
