Miller Halts Beer Test
LEAD: The Miller Brewing Company, which had been test-marketing its Dakota wheat-brewed beer in Cincinnati and four other cities, said it had halted distribution of the product and would make changes.
Company officials, who declined to comment on the results of the tests, said Miller wanted time to evaluate the beer's market performance.

Abolitionists Saw Blood On the Constitution
LEAD: To the Editor:


Ecuador Sees Gains
LEAD: Despite a slide in oil prices and strained relations with private foreign banks, Ecuador is expecting 2.5 percent growth in its gross domestic product in 1987, up from 1.7 percent last year, a central bank communique said today.


Israel Denies Offer of Contra Advisers
LEAD: Israel today described as ''totally groundless'' an assertion in a White House memorandum made public by the Tower Commission that Israel once offered military instructors to assist the Nicaraguan rebels.


FOREIGNERS BUTTRESS THE RALLY
LEAD: Heavy foreign buying of American stocks, which set records last year and has contributed to the recent surge in prices on Wall Street, is expected to continue for months to come.
Investment analysts believe that foreigners remain bullish, especially in Asia, despite the fears of many American investors that stocks are due for a tumble.


HOWARD BAKER WILL HEAD STAFF WITH MANDATE TO REORGANIZE; Congress Pleased
LEAD: President Reagan moved dramatically today to revive his troubled Presidency by replacing Donald T. Regan with former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. as the White House chief of staff.


OPERA: NEW PRINCIPALS IN 'WALKURE'
LEAD: The new production of ''Die Walkure'' that opened the Metropolitan Opera's ''Ring'' project last September returned for a reprise on Thursday evening.
The first of this season's three final performances of Wagner's music drama introduced a trio of principals who were not in the opening-night cast but have stepped into their roles since the premiere.


WASHINGTON PLAN FOR HIRING VOIDED
LEAD: A Federal appeals court panel today struck down an affirmative action plan aimed at increasing the number of black firefighters in the District of Columbia.


EMBATTLED BBC GETS A NEW DIRECTOR
LEAD: Michael Checkland, a 50-year-old Oxford-educated accountant, was selected Thursday night to become the new director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation.


A WORLD RECORD WITH FEW TO SEE
LEAD: Heike Drechsler, with shoes taped to prevent slipping, in the long jump.
She set a mark of 24 feet 1/4 inch.
Michael Conley won the triple jump with 58 feet 3 1/4 inches at the national indoor championships.
Only about 200 daytime spectators were in Madison Square Garden at the time.

LEAD: Lieut.
Col.
Oliver L. North said today that when Americans read the Tower Commission's criticism of his role in the Iran-contra affair, he hopes they will keep in mind the Bible verse that states ''Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness' sake: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.''


Pawnbroker Turns In Stolen $60,000 Violin
LEAD: An 18th-century violin worth more than $60,000, taken from a Manhattan musician in a holdup last week, was recovered yesterday after a Bronx pawnbroker called the police and turned it in.
The violin had been pawned for $50.
The pawnbroker, who asked the police not to release his name, ''knew it was a nice instrument when he first saw it,'' said Sgt.


TV: DON AMECHE IN 'PALS' ON CBS
LEAD: When three old pros like George C. Scott, Don Ameche and Sylvia Sidney take the wheel of a vehicle custom-built for them, the viewers who go along for the ride are entitled to expect a journey that will have its rewards.
There are a few, but mighty few, rewards in ''Pals,'' the vehicle that hits the road at 9 P.M.

BRITISH ALLIANCE TRIUMPHS ON BY-ELECTION
LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives and the opposition Labor Party both came away losers in a parliamentary by-election that was watched as a harbinger of voter behavior for the next national election.


Officer Defends Bumpurs Shooting
LEAD: The New York City police officer who was acquitted in the shooting death of Eleanor Bumpurs during an eviction from her apartment in the Bronx said yesterday that he would do nothing different if the situation arose again.


NOW, MOVE QUICKLY FOR '87
LEAD: With the Tax Reform Act of 1986 now the law of the land, taxpayers have greater incentive than ever to adjust their financial affairs even as they work on their 1986 returns.
Day by day, people who fail to take steps to adapt their finances may be getting hurt by the new law's restrictions or missing out on some of the law's opportunities.


Cardinal Suit Dropped
LEAD: William V. Bidwell, owner of the St.
Louis Cardinals of the National Football League, has dropped a lawsuit challenging the league rules that govern the relocation of teams.
On Feb. 11, 1986, the Cardinals filed a lawsuit in United States District Court in New York, charging that a set of rules drawn up in 1984 by Commissioner Pete Rozelle unreasonably restrained trade in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act, damaged the Cardinals' finances and led to irreparable injury to the team's efforts to find a new home.


Yeshiva Trading Cards: Rabbis but No Red Sox
LEAD: The boys from the yeshiva come to Shmiel Shnitzer's store after a long day of delving into the sacred writings with the sort of keenness American boys devote to memorizing batting averages.

Bond and Note Prices Gain
LEAD: Interest rates slipped as prices edged up in the credit market yesterday, despite the fact that consumer prices and the trade deficit for January showed stronger-than-expected increases.


REFUGEE WAVE CREATES A CRISIS IN BORDER CITY
LEAD: At 4 A.M. today, as her Greyhound bus drove up Interstate 87 past snow-covered apple orchards and fields to arrive at the Canadian border, Rosa Funes was as far away as she had ever been from the home she had left in Sonsonate, El Salvador.

Choice of Baker Welcomed in Congress
LEAD: Republican and Democratic leaders today praised the appointment of the former Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., as President Reagan's new chief of staff.


The Michel Plan for Central America
LEAD: Even mainstream conservatives in Congress who have loyally supported Reagan aid to the contras have been stirred by the new Central American peace plan put forth by Costa Rica.
Speaking for them is Robert Michel, the House minority leader, who urges a two-point program on Mr.
Reagan: First, announce a seven-month ''peace-plan moratorium'' before requesting an additional $100 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels.


DR. WILLIAM WITHERS
LEAD: Dr.
William Withers, professor emeritus of economics at Queens College and chairman of the New York Teachers Pension Association, died Wednesday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J.
He was 81 years old and lived in Red Bank.


California Club Loses Appeal On Order That It HireWomen
LEAD: The State Supreme Court has rejected a challenge by the all-male Bohemian Club to a ruling that it must hire women at its summer retreat north of San Francisco, where nudity is common.


CLINICS IN NEW YORK WILL HAVE TO OFFER AIDS TEST
LEAD: Several hundred clinics in New York State specializing in prenatal care, family planning and the treatment of sexually transmitted diseases and drug abuse will be required to offer their patients free, voluntary testing for infection with the AIDS virus, a top state health official said yesterday.


ALASKAN LAND PROPOSAL STIRS HIGH-STAKES GAME
LEAD: While others argue publicly whether oil-drilling rigs should invade the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, the calving ground of the continent's largest caribou herd, a related game with billion-dollar stakes has been going on in the back room.

LEAD: Bobby Short, Judith Jamison and Harold Nicholas are among the performers scheduled to appear Tuesday night at 8 at a benefit at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.
The proceeds will be used for building a memorial to Duke Ellington at the northeast entrance to Central Park.
The money for construction will come from the Duke Ellington Memorial

KIRKLAND ON THE MEND
LEAD: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., had a malignant tumor removed from a kidney at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore this week and is expected to spend the month of March recuperating.
Doctors told the labor leader they believed they were successful in removing all the cancer; Dr.
Patrick Walsh of the hospital reported that the surgery ''went exceedingly well.


U.N. Leader Appeals for Aid For Mozambique War Victims
LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar issued an emergency appeal today for more than $33 million to help Mozambicans impoverished by that country's civil war.

Booker T. Washington Had a Point
LEAD: Can a black person who quotes Booker T. Washington with approval hope to be taken seriously?
Glenn Loury, who teaches political economy at Harvard, offers such approval in an essay in The Public Interest, and so marks himself again as an independent thinker about the condition of blacks in America.


Wiggins Joins C.B.A.
LEAD: Mitchell Wiggins, who with a Houston Rocket teammate, Lewis Lloyd, was banned from the National Basketball Association on Jan. 13 for at least two years because they tested positive for drugs and had not requested rehabilitation, will be permitted to play this season in the Continental Basketball Assocation.


Costa Rican Leader Denies Report of U.S. Pressure
LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica said tonight that the Tower Commission report ''must be mistaken'' in saying that his country had been pressured by the United States to keep secret the existence of an airstrip used by Nicaraguan rebels.


EISENHOWER APPROVED SMALL ATOMIC EXPERIMENTS AMID TEST MORATORIUM
LEAD: The United States conducted secret nuclear experiments approved by the Eisenhower Administration while the United States and the Soviet Union had a moratorium on testing, according to a newly published report.


CHARGES IN SALMONELLA CASES
LEAD: State health officials brought charges yesterday against a Windsor nursing home in which five elderly patients died during a salmonella outbreak last year, a move that could cost the center its license.


Dollar Is Mostly Higher; Gold Prices Are Mixed
LEAD: The dollar inched higher yesterday against most key currencies in a narrow trading range.
Dealers shrugged off negative reports on the nation's trade deficit and inflation but continued to worry about possible central bank intervention.
